column2: At Army, football is taken seriously, but military service always comes first for the Black Knights.

''Clybourne Park,'' Bruce Norris's Pulitzer Prize-winning play about race relations and neighborhood gentrification, is looking for its own real estate on Broadway. A spokeswoman for Center Theater Group in Los Angeles said the company, along with Lincoln Center Theater and the producers Scott Rudin and Stuart Thompson, plans to bring its coming production of ''Clybourne Park'' to Broadway in the spring, pending the availability of a theater. The Los Angeles production, directed by Pam MacKinnon, is set to run from Jan. 11 to Feb. 26, 2012, at the the Mark Taper Forum. News of a possible Broadway transfer was first reported on Playbill.com.

GLADSTONE--Phyllis Kurzman, 80, passed away on Tuesday, September 6th at her home in Bay Harbor Islands, Florida. Daughter of the late Harold and Eleanor Kurzman of New York. Beloved sister of Peter, Harold, and Paul Kurzman. She was much loved and will be greatly missed by her four children Daniel, Brett, Russell, and Nina, and her four grandchildren Matthew, Sara, Salomon, and Jessica. Burial will be Saturday, September 10th at 11:00am at the Woodlawn Cemetery in Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Ruth K. Broad K-8 PTA, Phyllis Gladstone Library Fund, 1155 93rd Street, Bay Harbor Island, FL 33154.
FRANKSTON--Sherman, 66, died August 31, 2011 in Tucson, AZ. Loving husband of Julie and proud father of Adam, Douglas and Jeffrey.

In this week's Your Money column, I took the best shot I could in 1,400 words or so at helping widows avoid the financial pitfalls that so many of them fall into. They need not rush into making financial decisions, they should think hard about housing, they should not be a ''purse'' for anyone and they should be wary of blindly following financial orders left by their dead husbands. But surely there is more to add here. If you and your spouse are still alive, one of the best things you can do is make sure that you both know exactly what you own and what you owe and how to find all the relevant account information. I heard horror stories this week of accountants and financial planners digging in attic boxes for information and begging financial services companies to reset account passwords that a widow did not know.

A critic's notebook article last Saturday about commemorations of the Sept. 11 attacks referred imprecisely to the organization that conducted a poll asking, among other things, if people thought wrongdoing by the United States might have motivated the attacks. The poll was conducted by the Pew Research Center -- not the Pew Charitable Trusts, which sponsors the center.

LINFIELD--Jordan L.,87. Born in 1923 in Brooklyn; died September 8, 2011, in Manhattan of complications from a fall. Jordan was a lifelong New Yorker and he served the city in many ways, including as director of Neighborhood Action Program in the John Lindsay administration. He was a proud veteran of World War II and an equally proud graduate of Townsend Harris, City College, and Columbia University, where he wrote his master's thesis on the Socialist Workers Party. He was a man of prolific talents: union organizer, editor, publisher, author of many books, Hebrew scholar and math professor. He loved the Spanish Loyalists who fought Franco, and he was confident of the survival of the Jewish people. Most of all he loved his family: his wife of 63 years, Trudy; his daughters, Deborah, who predeceased him, and Susie; his granddaughter Sarah; and his sons-in-law Jay Bernstein and Eugene Scheiman. Jordan was an extraordinary man: kind, gentle, generous, and a true intellectual; we will remember him, love him, and miss him forever. Service Monday, September 12, 11:15 at "The Riverside", 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave.

8 P.M. (HBO) 127 HOURS (2010) In April 2003, Aron Ralston, a 27-year-old hiker, fell in a narrow slot in Blue John Canyon, in Utah, and was trapped, his right arm pinned beneath a boulder. For five days he struggled to free himself, narrating his plight into a small video camera and reflecting on the mistakes that landed him in this mess -- not least, neglecting to tell anyone where he was going. Faced with the increasing prospect of death, Mr. Ralston decided to amputate his immobilized arm using the blade of a cheap multipurpose tool. James Franco, above, earned an Academy Award nomination for his turn as Mr. Ralston in this film by Danny Boyle, which A. O. Scott, writing in The New York Times, called ''nearly flawless.'' There are scenes, he added, ''that are hard to bear -- the cracking of a bone, the severing of a nerve, the desperate consumption of a water bag filled with urine -- but what these moments communicate is more than worth a jolt of discomfort or a spasm of revulsion. To say that this movie gets under your skin is only barely a figure of speech. It pins you down, shakes you up and leaves you glad to be alive.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY In ''9/11 Then and Now,'' Kim Lawton revisits several people profiled by the program 10 years ago, including a Muslim lawyer who was at the World Trade Center the morning of the attacks; a Lutheran pastor who had arrived in Shanksville, Pa., just days before the crash of Flight 93; a rabbi who is a New York Fire Department chaplain; and Greek Orthodox parishioners trying to rebuild the only house of worship destroyed on Sept. 11, 2001.

New York State's minor parties scored a major victory Thursday when the state's Board of Elections agreed to alter a vote-counting anomaly that the parties argued was a threat to their very survival. In a rare alliance motivated by self-preservation, the Conservative Party, the Working Families Party and the Taxpayers Party sued the board because of a problem involving new electronic voting machines. Computer software allows voters to fill in ovals on electronically scanned paper ballots for the same candidate on more than one party line, although the vote is counted only for the major party that is listed first on the ballot.

TAFFNER--Donald L. An iconic independent distributor and producer of television programming and live theater attractions, passed peacefully on Tuesday, September 6, 2011 after a brief stay in Lenox Hill Hospital, Manhattan. Among his many achievements, he and his wife-business partner, Eleanor Bolta, were responsible for bringing such television shows to the American public as, "Three's Company", "Too Close For Comfort" and "The Benny Hill Show." She passed away a year ago. The quintessential American success story, Taffner grew up above his family's candy store in Brooklyn where his education in business began. Preparing the day's newspapers with his father, running telephone messages to persons throughout the neighborhood and just being "in the store" taught Don about getting along with and being able to talk to people...it gave him a unique set of social skills and a pronounced business attitude which held fast throughout his life. A proud graduate of St. John's College (now known as University), Don took a job in the mailroom of the William Morris Agency in 1952 and by the time he left the well-known agency in 1959, he had been an agent there for four years. In 1959 he built his expertise in television distribution by helping to begin the Television Distribution Program Department at Paramount. The Taffners were married in 1961 and in 1963 they launched D.L. Taffner Ltd, their own business. The company started out as a worldwide distributor of TV programs and later, as DLT Entertainment Ltd., expanded to TV and stage production. In 1986, Don Taffner's considerable significant contributions to the development of the industry were recognized by the International Council of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, which presented him with an Emmy for its prestigious Founders Award "for setting new levels of creativity in the worldwide exchange of television programs". As a result of his work in television, specifically British television, Don Taffner was awarded an OBE in 2002. As an offshoot of his television business, Don became involved with the prestigious Theatre of Comedy in the UK and the company continues to own and manage the Shaftesbury Theatre on the West End. Champions of St. John's University, in 2005, Donald and Eleanor Taffner were given Johnny's Angels Awards by St. John's Bread and Life, an organization that is devoted to getting food to those who need it in Brooklyn and in Queens. In 2007, the Taffners were presented with the Spirit of Service Award for their continuing contribution to the school. Having developed a great passion for Charles Rennie Mackintosh and the Glasgow School, Don and Eleanor Taffner were presented with a Wallace award at the 'Icons of Scotland Dinner' hosted by Scotland Magazine in 2005, and were the first individuals with no hereditary connection to Scotland to ever receive the award. Donald is survived by his daughter, Karen Butler and her husband Ronald Butler, his son, Donald L. Taffner Jr. and Rhonda Cantor and three grandchildren, John, Henry and Tom Butler. A funeral service will be held on Saturday, September 10, 2011 at 10:30am at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street followed by a luncheon at Villa Mosconi, 69 MacDougal Street. A Memorial Mass will be held on Saturday, September 17, 2011 at 10:30am on the St. Johns University Queens Campus conducted by Father Donald J Harrington at St. Thomas More Church. The Mass will be followed by a tribute at the Taffner Field House and luncheon. In lieu of flowers the family wishes that any and all contributions be made to St. John's Bread for Life www.breadandlife.org

MAHLER--Victor, Architect, died peacefully after a long illness on September 7, 2011, at the age of 79. Victor is survived by his beloved wife of 25 years, Mimi, his brother, Herbert, and his wife Nancy and four nephews. He achieved great success with his international work, specializing in the skin and exterior cladding of high-rise buildings. He was a fellow of the AIA. A Memorial Service will be held on Tuesday, September 13, 2011 at the church of St. Paul, 315 West 22nd Street, NYC at 2:30pm In lieu of flowers, donations maybe made in Victor's memory to NYU Medical Center Speech Department, 530 First Ave., New York, NY 10016.

Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi is joining American Crossroads, the influential Republican Super PAC, to help the group raise money during the 2012 election, the group announced on Thursday. Mr. Barbour, who briefly considered his own run for the presidency earlier this year, is a former chairman of the Republican National Committee and the Republican Governors Association. Well-connected in party circles and known as a formidable fund-raiser, his addition to the American Crossroads team suggests that the group is preparing to play a leading role in the 2012 elections, with the capacity to raise and spend more money than the G.O.P.'s official national party committees combined. They are, after all, subject to contribution limits, while Crossroads is not.

If it's Friday, it must be Wednesday, or something like that. Because of the two days lost to rain earlier in the week at the United States Open, the tickets being honored for Friday's men's quarterfinals were for Session No. 20 -- that is to say, Wednesday evening.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Tuesday with the On Football column, about the outlook for the Indianapolis Colts while quarterback Peyton Manning is out with an injury, misidentified the receiver wearing No. 85 and shown standing near Manning during a pre-season game again Cincinnati. He is Pierre Garcon, not Reggie Wayne.

Cliff Lee, the left-handed Philadelphia Phillies starter, is on quite a tear. In August he was 5-0 with a 0.45 earned run average in 39 2/3 innings. And it was not even his best month this season: in June he was also 5-0, with three shutouts and a 0.21 E.R.A. in 42 innings. On Aug. 31 he pitched eight and two-thirds scoreless innings against Cincinnati, but was pulled for closer Ryan Madson after he allowed a two-out double to Joey Votto, walked Jay Bruce and hit Miguel Cairo to load the bases. In his first September start, on Monday, he was able to get the game's final out, completing a five-hit shutout of Atlanta, his sixth shutout of the season. He matched Randy Johnson's six in 1998 as the most since 1989.

An obituary on Tuesday about the tenor Salvatore Licitra contained outdated information about a forthcoming production at the Metropolitan Opera. While Mr. Licitra had been scheduled to appear there in Verdi's ''Ernani'' in February, he was replaced in July by Marcello Giordani and Roberto De Biaso, who will alternate in the title role.

WEISBERG--Robert, beloved husband, father, and grandfather, died suddenly on September 1, 2011. The cause of death is still unknown. Bob was a long-time scientist at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, MD, where he was the head of the section on microbial genetics, National Institute of Child Health and Development Program in Genomics of Development. He retired in 2008 after nearly 40 years of service to the NIH but continued his work as a scientist emeritus. He was author on numerous papers, as well as a teacher and mentor to many students. He was a vibrant and productive member of the NIH community. Bob was born on May 24th, 1937, in Bayonne, NJ, to Clarice and Jack. He was class valedictorian at Bayonne High School in 1954 and went on to get an A.B. at Harvard in 1958. A summer course with Nobel laureate Jim Watson inspired Bob to pursue a career in microbial genetics. In 1963, Bob received a Ph.D. in virology at the California Institute of Technology, where he was advised by another Nobel laureate, Renato Dulbecco. His postdoctoral training took him to Europe first to the Medical Research Council Microbial Genetics Research Unit in London and then to 'Institut de Biologie Physico-chimique in Paris. He established his own lab at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee before moving to the NIH in 1969. As molecular biology was first emerging as a field of its own, viruses such as bacteriophage lambda that infect the bacteria E. coli became the favorite research tools, enabling biologists to conduct experiments to understand basic processes even before the modern tools of genome sequencing and recombinant DNA were available. Bob was a master practitioner in the study of lambda, and his research led to several breakthroughs in molecular biology. He published elegant work dissecting the genetics and molecular basis of key biological processes in bacteriophage lambda. The lessons learned have proven to be central to our understanding of how similar processes proceed in humans how cancer viruses incorporate themselves into our genomes, how viruses such as HIV are packaged, and how viruses and cells express genes at some times but not at others. After retirement, Bob moved to the National Cancer Institute's Laboratory of Molecular Biology, where he was a valued source of ideas, advice, and enthusiasm. Bob loved fine food and fine wine, travel, and fishing at his summer home on Fire Island, NY. But most of all, he loved the company of family and close friends. He was also an avid mushroom hunter and a collector of all things pig-related. He was happily married for 52 years to his dear wife Judy. He is survived by his wife Judy, of Garrett Park, MD; by his daughter Eve, of Silver Spring, MD; his son Josh, of Houston, TX; and his grandkids Philip, Sofia, and Angelina. He is also survived by his sister Beth, of Seattle, WA. Bob lived a remarkably happy life and touched all of our lives. We miss him deeply. Bob's family will be welcoming friends, family, and acquaintances to the Weisberg home on September 11, 2011. The family asks that donations be made in Bob's name to Bob's favorite local NPR station, WAMU (202-885-1252).

TELLIER--Janet Sullivan. Janet Sullivan Tellier, 72, of Vero Beach, Florida, died on September 5, 2011 surrounded by her husband and her daughters. She was born in Staten Island, NY to Patrick and Agatha Sullivan on August 27, 1939, and was raised in Scarsdale, New York with her sister, Ann Sullivan Kilfoil of Ft. Wayne, Indiana. The spirit in which Janet lived her life and the courage she showed while living with pancreatic cancer will continue as an inspiration to her family and her so many dear friends. In 1961, she married Francis Joseph Tellier of Rye, New York. One of Janet's happiest memories is when she and her beloved husband, Frank, celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary on August 5th, 2011. They settled in Mamaroneck, New York where they raised their three daughters, Susan Tellier Perticone of Darien, CT, Nancy Tellier Vandervelde of Wellesley, MA and Sheila Tellier Nottebohm of Darien, CT. Janet adored her ten grandchildren Lacey, Lexie, Hollis, and Isabelle Perticone; Murphy, Jack, and Sophie Vandervelde; Johann, Annabel, and Fritz Nottebohm. Janet was a graduate of the Ursuline School in New Rochelle, New York and Manhattanville College in Purchase, New York. She was a member of Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck, NY and The Manursing Island Club in Rye, NY. In 1980, she fulfilled her dream of owning her own business when Janet opened The Chocolate Lady, a gourmet chocolate store, in Greenwich, CT. In 2006, Janet moved to Vero Beach, Florida. Janet was an active golfer who enjoyed playing at the Johns Island Club and Quail Valley Golf Club. She was a parishioner of Holy Cross Church, and a volunteer at the Hospice House in Vero Beach. Her favorite past times were painting, playing bridge, gardening, sailing, and traveling. Above all, she enjoyed spending time with her family and many friends. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, friends may consider a memorial donation in Janet's memory to the VNA Foundation and Hospice, 1110 35th Lane, Vero Beach, FL 32960. A memorial mass will be held at Saint Mary Parish Greenwich, Connecticut on September 16, 2011 at 10:00. A reception will follow at the Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck, New York. An online guestbook is available at: strunkfuneralhome.com
International REBELS INCREASE ATTACKS

An article last Saturday about a special election for the State Assembly seat in the 54th District, in Brooklyn, referred imprecisely to Representative Edolphus Towns's connection to the position of local district leader. While Representative Towns ran for the position in May and lost to Erik Martin Dilan, a city councilman, he did not lose ''his'' leader position because he was not the incumbent. (His son, Darryl C. Towns, resigned from the position, prompting the election.)

Mel Gibson, the actor and director whose comments about Jews have drawn charges of anti-Semitism, is working on a movie about the life of Judah Maccabee, the Israelite warrior whose victory over the Greek and Syrian forces is celebrated during Hanukkah, according to The Los Angeles Times and Deadline Hollywood. The news on Friday morning that Mr. Gibson had closed a producing deal with Warner Brothers and had enlisted Joe Eszterhas to write a script immediately drew fire from Jewish leaders.

Like many homeowners, we pretty much ignored the option of earthquake coverage when we bought an insurance policy for our home. After all, we reasoned, it's not as if we live in California. But last month's earthquake based in Mineral, Va., which registered 5.8 on the Richter scale and was felt along the East Coast from Georgia to Canada, made us wonder if it's worth paying for coverage.

With all of its star power, Super Duper Saturday would be a fitting name for matches scheduled at the United States Open. NOVAK DJOKOVIC VS. ROGER FEDERER What would the Open be without a late-tournament tussle between these two champions? Djokovic and Federer have met here each year since 2007, with last year's match ending in an epic five-set win for Djokovic. Given Djokovic's near invincibility on the tour this year, it would be tempting to call this one for him. But after a very up-and-down 2011, Federer has raised his game through five matches here. Save for one set against Marin Cilic in the third round, Federer, a five-time Open champion, has been something close to dominant. His utter dismantling of Jo-Wilfried Tsonga in the quarterfinals has made many a believer. Expect Federer to win in four competitive sets.

SZETO--Keung, a fine-artist best known for his highly-detailed Photorealist paintings has died in Manhattan on Monday, September 5, 2011 of coronary heart disease. He was 62. Szeto was represented by the OK Harris Gallery in New York, and is survived by his mother, May Yee; his daughter, Susie; his brother, Man; and two grandchildren. Services will be held on Saturday, September 10, 2011 at 10AM at the Ng Fook Funeral Home - 36 Mulberry St, New York, NY 10013. (212)-374-1003.

Lady Gaga will be the featured guest performing at Times Square during the annual New Year's Eve celebration on ABC hosted by Dick Clark and Ryan Seacrest, The Associated Press said. The show is in its 40th year and Mr. Clark has been hosting it much longer than Lady Gaga, the pop diva given to euro-dance grooves and wacky costumes, has been alive. (She was born in 1986.) Fergie, of the Black Eyed Peas, will host the Los Angeles portion of the show, which will go for three hours in prime time, break for the local news, then return for two and a half hours. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article last Saturday about the recent World Police and Fire Games in New York City misidentified the team that won the gold in baseball. It was the New York Fire Department, not the New York Police Department. (The firefighters team beat the police team 7-2.)

Karen Pascoe left for Kennedy International Airport two weeks ago ready to make a fresh start. After 22 years in New York City, she was moving to San Jose, Calif., to take a job at a software design company. Naturally, her two cats, Jack and Barry, would be going with her. But it didn't turn out that way.

ADELMAN--Seymour D.,an attorney, CPA, and WWII Purple Heart Veteran, died on September 8th, of natural causes at home in Lawrence, NY. Mr. Adelman, who also resided in Boca Raton, FL, would be 90 on November 11th. His wife, Renee, passed in 2000 and he is survived by his brother, Dan Alden, his daughters, Marcia and Debra, and his grandchildren, Ariel and Ross. Services will be held Sunday, September 11th, at 10am at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel in Hewlett, NY.

ERLANGER--Dr. Bernard F.,88, distinguished Professor of Microbiology and Immunology at Columbia University, passed away on September 8, 2011, surrounded by his family. Born in the Bronx, NY, to Frieda and Leo Erlanger, he graduated from Stuyvesant High School and with highest honors from City University of NY. He served in the army during WWII and was chosen tech Adviser on the Manhattan Project at Los Alamos 1944-46. He then earned his masters degree at NYU and later his Ph.D at Columbia University, where he worked until his death. Services will be held at 10:30am on Sunday, September 11, 2011 at Andrett and Gramercy Funeral Home at 2nd Avenue and 21st Street, New York City, NY.

BODTKE--Shirley, 89, actor, on September 8th in Manhattan. Wife of the late Dick Bodtke, mother of Tina Carlson (Ray) of Port Washington, NY. Granny of Julie, Zannie, and Laura, sister of Lorraine Burton, and beloved aunt. A staunch New Yorker, Shirley's passion was the arts, especially the theater. "Gone to a world of light!" Memorial celebration to be announced (516-883-0565). Donations in her name may be made to HB Studio, 120 Bank Street, New York, NY 10014.

Two picture captions on Page 17 this weekend, with an article about objects people saved, are reversed. The caption that includes the quotation ''My office was on the 79th floor'' should accompany the ID card of Joseph Mendola on the far right of the page; the caption with the quotation ''I was certain these attacks would define me forever'' goes with the ID card of Deborah Feldman at the far left.

It's one of those things that makes you wonder why it wasn't available before. Fifth Third Bank has just introduced Duo, a piece of plastic that works as both a debit card and a credit card. Fifth Third, based in Cincinnati, says that while various institutions have been testing the cards, it is the first to formally offer it to consumers. Research with its own customers suggested that there was a significant demand for the two-in-one cards, said Stephanie Honan, a spokeswoman for Fifth Third. Many customers use both type of cards -- debit for smaller purchases, say, and credit for larger purchases they want to pay off over time. So, she said, customers like the idea of being able to choose credit or debit while carrying just one card.

A 27-year-old man living in Brooklyn was arraigned in federal court on Friday on charges that he provided material support to terrorists and had been planning to join a radical Islamic group in Pakistan. The man, Agron Hasbajrami, an Albanian citizen who had been living legally in Brooklyn since 2008, had sent more than $1,000 to a contact in Pakistan over the past year for the purpose of financing terrorist activities abroad, authorities said in a federal detention order unsealed Friday.

KRAMER--Irving M.,93. Former judge of the City of New York and Veteran of World War II. Beloved and devoted husband of Elayne for 58 years, loving father of Howard, and Paula and Jeff Weiss, adored "Gramps" to Melissa and Eli who gave him so much joy, and loving brother to Shirley Goldstein. A man of wisdom and integrity, he will be missed beyond measure. Funeral Sunday, September 11, 12:30pm, Gutterman's Funeral Home (in Parkside Building), 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, NY, 11234.

A Twitter account belonging to NBC News was hacked on Friday evening by an entity that claimed, falsely, that an airplane had crashed at the site of ground zero in New York. The account was swiftly taken offline and the news division apologized. The incident was deemed serious enough that the news anchor Brian Williams read the apology out loud on the ''NBC Nightly News.''

It's no surprise that the Democratic National Committee meeting in Chicago on Friday will include briefings on jobs and health care, issues critical to President Obama's re-election. But ''Jewish messaging'' will be the third topic presented to top party donors and fund-raisers, according to a schedule obtained by The New York Times. The session, led Debbie Wasserman Schultz, the committee's chairwoman, and Ira Forman, the Obama campaign's director of Jewish outreach, underscores a real but unexpected challenge for Mr. Obama. While Jewish voters generally still give the president high marks, some Jewish donors -- a major fund-raising constituency for Mr. Obama and other Democrats -- are resisting the campaign's appeals over unhappiness with the administration's approach to Israel.

Tyler, the Creator, and his group of irreverent young rappers known as Odd Future, have landed a television show on Adult Swim, the nighttime incarnation of the Cartoon Network, which has become a showcase for underground pop-music genres in recent years. Odd Future, a Los Angeles rap group known for its provocative lyrics and shocking video imagery, will star in a 15-minute live action show featuring sketches, man-on-the-street interviews, pranks and, of course, hip-hop music with the group's distinctive skate-punk edge, the network announced Thursday. The show will make its debut in 2012, though no specific date was given.

At around two in the morning on Sept. 7, 1861, Confederate soldiers burst into the home of Julia Marcum, intent on killing her father. They "broke the door open with bayonets on their guns and said there was 36 men around who had come to kill" him, she later wrote. The 16-year-old girl lived with her parents and five siblings on a farm in Scott County, Tenn., northwest of Knoxville near the Kentucky border. Like most of their neighbors, the Marcums were strong Unionists. Early in the war Julia's father, Hiram, made his farm available as a way station for the thousands of Southern men traveling north to join Lincoln's army, guiding many of them to the border himself.

The extinction-defying shrub is informally called Franciscan manzanita, for its home near San Francisco Bay, but maybe someone should rename it the Lazarus manzanita. It was given up for extinct some 60 years ago, then rediscovered in a traffic island in 2009 by a botanist driving home from a climate-change conference.

"Chic with a beautiful, sensual quality showcasing an elongation of the neck and the profile of the face," said Johnnie Sapong backstage at Duro Olowu of the style he created to channel the photographer Jacques Henri Lartigue's women, who were among the inspirations for both the beauty look and the clothes in the collection. Sapong molded an undone chignon using TIGI Catwalk Session Series Work It hair spray, the loose ends of the upswept hairdo dusted with Transforming Dry Shampoo. "Like a piece of raveled rope," is how he described the bun. As for makeup, Luc Bochard kept it modern and feminine, as well, with M.A.C. Metal X Crème Shadow in Gold Carbon over the eye and Russian Red and Film Noir on the lips. Among the hair and makeup team was Olowu's wife, Thelma Golden, watching the crew prep for the presentation. "Beautifully combined, broad influences," is how she described the cumulative effect of her husband's sensibilities. Spoken like a true art aficionada.

MONDAY'S PUZZLE - In another lifetime, I earned my living as a canine behaviorist. This means that I spent a lot of time explaining to people who hired me that their dogs would be much more well-behaved once the dog clearly understood what the people wanted from the dog. For example, if you train your dog to eliminate outside on the command "Hurry up!", you should not be surprised if, the moment you yell "Hurry up!" to your spouse when you're late to a social engagement, the dog eliminates as directed, most likely on your Persian rug. It's all about communication, people.

It's not every morning that starts with someone referencing Catherine Deneuve and drugstores in the same sentence. It happened backstage at Victoria Beckham where Guido Palau explained that he was using "quite a lot of product" and Goody hair barrettes to channel Deneuve-like elegance with a masculine bent. This meant Redken Thickening Lotion spread throughout the hair for texture, with Hardwear at the center to make a wet-looking panel at the crown, which was pulled back with a classic silver clip (here's where we get drugstore). Then loads of Hairspray 23 on the loose hair, "for texture, not hold," Palau said. "Wet and dry, shine and matte," is how he described the contrasts within the style. As the girls walked out, Palau added a little Glass Panel to heighten this effect.

Designers casting about for a credibly American fashion identity could do worse than to mine the sports arena. An influential cohort did just that, drawing inspiration from the locker room, the racetrack, sand and surf.

"Boardwalk Empire," the Prohibition-era drama set in Atlantic City, picked up seven awards at the creative arts Emmys on Saturday, making it the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences' most-honored television program a week ahead of the prime-time awards. "Boardwalk Empire," shown by HBO, won for art direction, editing, sound editing and visual effects, among other categories. HBO also received awards for the mini-series "Mildred Pierce," a Lady Gaga tour special and a children's program called "A Child's Garden of Poetry." The annual creative arts ceremony also recognized Justin Timberlake twice - once for guest-hosting "Saturday Night Live" and once for co-writing the lyrics to his "SNL" monologue song. Other stars who were recognized on Saturday include Gwyneth Paltrow, for her guest-star turn on "Glee"; Jay Leno, for his car Web site JayLenosGarage.com; and Jeff Probst, for his hosting of "Survivor." The ceremony will be shown on the ReelzChannel on Saturday, a day before the prime-time awards are shown live on Fox.

Siki Im's first runway show here in New York City, titled "The Topography of Globalization," was the perfect combination of concept and clothing. Bespectacled models walked the runway in stark multiculti clothing that was a combination of American sportswear staples like denim jeans and tailored sport jackets and Middle East style scarfs and wrapped coats. Smart military style cargo pockets and oversize flaps provided the fine finishing touches in this highly styled yet utterly wearable collection.

North American moviegoers, jumping at the chance to see Gwyneth Paltrow and a host of other stars die of a horrible disease, drove "Contagion" to No. 1 at the weekend box office with an estimated $23 million in ticket sales. That Warner Brothers film, directed by Steven Soderbergh and made in conjunction with Participant Media, cost about $60 million to produce; an all-star cast (Kate Winslet, Matt Damon, Laurence Fishburne and Jude Law in addition to Ms. Paltrow) and strong reviews contributed to audience interest. "The Help" (DreamWorks Studios) was second, taking in about $8.7 million for a five-week total of $137 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. "Warrior," a mixed martial arts drama from Lionsgate, was a disappointing third with about $5.6 million in ticket sales. "The Debt" (Focus Features) took in roughly $5 million for fourth place, lifting its two-week total to $22 million. "Colombiana" (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was fifth with about $4 million in ticket sales and a new three-week total of $29.8 million. On the gloomy side, "Bucky Larson: Born to be a Star," a Sony comedy produced by Adam Sandler's company, took in just $1.5 million and placed far outside the top 10.

Caroline Garcia versus Grace Min, Court 7, noon - Garcia, the No. 1 seed, has powered her way to a final of a junior slam after having reached the semifinals in the other three this year. The 17-year-old from France, who has lost only one set in her five victories this week, is a big favorite over the unseeded Grace Min of the United States. But an upset is certainly possible if Min can sustain the level of play she displayed in her semifinal victory over Nicole Gibbs, who was also a semifinalist for the N.C.A.A. singles title.

Film buffs may recognize Madrid's Cine Doré from the silent film sequence in Pedro Almódovar's film "Talk to Her." But the Art Nouveau movie theater (Calle Santa Isabel, 3; 34-91-369-1125), which is also the public face of Filmoteca Española, a Spanish film preservation association, is very much alive. This month, the theater, which dates to 1923, is screening films from two prominent Spanish directors, Luis García Berlanga and Carlos Saura.

Samantha Stosur is an exciting player who breaks the mold of the typical baseliner. She's got a big serve, and one of the best forehands going. Where many of her peers will be content to stand back and wait for errors, Stosur prefers to take the offensive - even sneaking into net occasionally.

A look at some of the long form Indian journalism India Ink has been reading this week:The much-discussed profile of Arvind Kejriwal, the man who is in many ways the brains behind the Anna Hazare anti-corruption movement, gives some fascinating details of the careful planning and execution of Mr. Hazare's high-profile fasts. One nugget: when Mr. Hazare and Mr. Kejriwal were planning the first fast in April, "they deliberately selected a date that would fall between the end of the Cricket World Cup and the start of the Indian Premier League." "This is our life!!" e-mails Maayan Zilberman when asked if she and her design partner, Nikki Dekker, of the Lake and Stars ever wear swimsuits as bodysuits. ""We were both wearing bikini tops as bras, with the straps poking out at the tops of our tanks when we met," says Dekker days later, in their TriBeCa studio. True to form, the Lake and Stars label is all about intimates that can be purposefully layered to wear with outerwear. "Our lingerie lives in the world of fashion," says Zilberman about their four-year-old line. In anticipation of their presentation today, which includes swimwear for the first time, the Lake and Stars gives T a lesson in wearing bathing suits as bodysuits.

When the Kruse Auction empire began to implode two years ago, it looked like the end of the perfect collectors' holiday in Auburn, Ind. The annual Labor Day weekend auction was supplemented by the Auburn Cord Duesenberg Festival, peripheral auction events and enough fried carnival food to blacklist northeastern Indiana as a potential site for cardiologist conventions. But a year ago, Auctions America by RM rescued the beloved sale and invested nearly $2 million in upgrades to the auction park. It all seemed barely ready for the sale in 2010, but this year, the spirit of the auction from its glory years in the late 1970s through the 1980s -- when it had little competition in the collector car auction world -- was back.

CARROLL--Sidney Burke, 87, passed away June 9 surrounded by her four sons. Born August 15, 1923 in Rutland, VT, she was the daughter of the late J. Frank and Mary Barnett Burke. Sidney and her three younger siblings spent their youth in Slingerlands, NY. She graduated cum laude from The Albany Academy for Girls in 1941 and graduated as a Wellesley College Scholar in 1945 with a B.A. in Political Science. From 1946-48 she served as special assistant to Senator Henry Cabot Lodge, in charge of speechwriting and press relations. Sidney and Thomas Sylvester Carroll were wed in 1947 and together raised five sons in New Canaan, CT. Sidney was known for her organic gardens, ardent support of Montessori education, and love of Vermont. Among other civic activities, she was a director of the League of Voters in New Canaan and Children's Services of Stamford, CT. In 1969, Sidney earned her Juris Doctorate from NYU School of Law and served as a staff attorney for the Juvenile Relations Division of The Legal Aid Society in New York from 1971-1981. Inspired by conversations with children from The Whitby School carpool, Sidney authored the children's book You Be The Judge. The book challenges the reader for decisions in legal cases and their precedents, and was intended to give children a better understanding of the law and its role in society. Residing in Manhattan for the past three decades, Sidney was a longstanding volunteer at the Guggenheim Museum, The Asia Society, and the English Speaking Union. Sidney's family is graced with her many original watercolor paintings and collections of "Easy Thoughts." She leaves behind her three siblings, James Burke, Daniel Burke, and Phyllis Burke Davis and their families; four of her sons, Jeffrey Burke Carroll, James Francis Carroll, Matthew Carroll, and Charles Laurence Carroll, her daughters in law, nine grandchildren, one great-grandchild, and her cherished caregivers. Her fifth son, Thomas Jeremiah Carroll, predeceased her; their remains rest together in Eden, VT. A celebration of Sidney's life will take place at The Whitby School, Greenwich, CT at 3pm on September 17th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Whitby School Annual Fund, 969 Lake Avenue, Greenwich, CT 06831.

STEHLI--Peter H.,78, of Oyster Bay, NY. Died peacefully September 2, after a long battle with pulmonary fibrosis. He leaves his friend Ethel Woolverton, sister Maggie Kelly, six children, nine grandchildren, many friends and family. A memorial service will be held at 2pm, Saturday September 17, at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions maybe made to The Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory or St. John's Church.

In an article on Metropolitan's cover last week, ''After Layoff, Hope, Fear and Insomnia,'' Jennifer Gonnerman chronicled the months of efforts by a forklift driver, Frederick Deare, to find work after the Old London snack company closed its factory in the Bronx last summer and moved its operations to North Carolina. Mr. Deare, 54, finally landed a job, making less than he had collected in unemployment benefits. Following are some of the more than 180 reader comments posted over the Labor Day weekend on NYTimes.com. I admire Mr. Deare very much. His spirit, his refusal to despair, gives us all hope.

TEN YEARS AGO, 69 CREDIT AGRICOLE GROUP Employees lost their lives in the attack on the World Trade Center. Jean-Marie Sander, Chairman of Credit Agricole S.A. and Jean-Paul Chifflet Chief Executive Officer of Credit Agricole S.A. and all 160,000 Credit Agricole Group employees are thinking of them & their families today. We shall not forget them.

Two skyscrapers are rising at the World Trade Center site to replace the twin towers, and two more are on the drawing boards. But the 16 acres in Lower Manhattan are also home to a memorial to the victims of the 2001 and 1993 attacks and to a major transportation hub. Fitting these elements together has been a difficult task for architects, engineers and construction workers. Over the decade, artistic differences, political in-fighting and the desire to rein in soaring costs have brought delays and redesigns. The work is far from finished, but a centerpiece of the site, the two memorial fountains, will be open for the 10th anniversary observance. The fountains, among the largest artificial waterfalls in the world, sit where the twin towers stood. They are surrounded by a plaza that, when completed, will be an engineered forest, with hundreds of trees growing amid the glass, steel and concrete.

A news analysis on Sept. 4 about the consequences of the Libya intervention for NATO incorrectly listed Sweden as a member. Sweden has provided support for the NATO effort to remove Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, but is not a member of the alliance.

HOCHHAUSER--Joyce. Our shining star. Be at peace knowing we will always have the joy of our years together. Our love will never fade. David, Christine, Marshall and Sophie Scott, Sally, Mae and Emily Beth, Alex and Max

JANE LYNCH Sue Sylvester on''Glee'' Jane Lynch may have mastered miscreant roles on ''Party Down'' and in ''The 40-Year-Old Virgin,'' but her flair for villainy shines most brightly in contrast with the perky pop hysteria of ''Glee.'' Lynch's sadistic cheerleading coach is not only the best character on the show, she's also the spoonful of rancor that makes the sugary earnestness go down. By keeping her churlishness at a slow boil -- half-whispered threats and singsong insults -- Lynch brings much-needed restraint to a show that features more weeping teenagers than a Justin Bieber concert. Who better to helpfully inform these tireless teenage crooners: ''So you like showtunes.Itdoesn'tmeanyou'regay.Itjustmeansyou'reawful.''HEATHER HAVRILESKY

BELL--Anne Ludington of Queenstown, MD, died suddenly at her home on August 27, 2011. Born on September 26, 1925, in Philadelphia, PA she was the daughter of the late Charles Townsend and Constance Cameron Ludington. She graduated from the Shipley School and from Bryn Mawr College. In April 1948, she married Samuel Bell, Jr. of Chestnut Hill, PA, and raised their four children in Miami, FL. She volunteered as a nurse's aid at Mercy Hospital, organized a Parent-Teachers Association at Everglades School for Girls, and served as a trustee of Ransom Everglades School. An avid sailor, she spent many years with her husband cruising on their yacht Blue Angel in North America and Europe. Upon retirement, they settled in Queenstown, MD where she served as a volunteer and trustee at the Academy Art Museum in Easton, MD. Mr. Bell died in 2009. Mrs. Bell is survived by three sons, Samuel Bell III, Charles L. Bell and Nicholas S. Bell; a daughter, Tiffany Bell and her husband, Richard Gluckman; a sister Constance Drayton; a brother Townsend Ludington; and, two granddaughters Nell Gluckman and Marina Gluckman. She was predeceased by a sister, Ethel Anderson.

PETER DINKLAGE Tyrion Lannister on''Game of Thrones'' Late in the first season of ''Game of Thrones,'' Tyrion Lannister gives a speech to troops fighting in his father's war against the north. It's an unpromising moment. Tyrion is friendless, despised by his family, and his prospects for success seem dim. Yet the speech is eloquent and rousing -- the warriors chant in his honor: ''Half-man! Half-man!'' The self-conscious, prideful smile that Dinklage gives in response hints at what makes his performance one of the richest on television. Tyrion could be merely a villain; certainly, that's how most of the characters in ''Game of Thrones'' view him. Instead, he's something more complex: a man out of time, toosmartforthisbrutalkingdom,aRenaissancemindinamedievalworld.DAN KOIS

When Jason Lee decides to take it off, he takes it all off. The 41-year-old actor, who played an affable, overweight and almost comically hirsute slacker on ''My Name Is Earl'' from 2005 until 2009, recently shed 40 pounds and a whole lot of unnecessary facial hair. ''I got chunky during 'Earl,' and I had the big mustache for four years,'' Lee says. ''It was time to clean up my act.'' He slimmed down thanks to a five-week cleanse under the direction of Dr. Bo Wagner, a leading Los Angeles diet guru. ''He taught me proper food combining, and how to eat for my blood type,'' the actor says. ''I cut out sugar, starch and booze, and I'm now as trim as I used to be in my early 20s, when I was skating. It's really gnarly.'' (Lee became a professional skateboarder at 18 and still heads up Stereo Skateboards, the skate company he co-founded 19 years ago.)
The Check In/Check Out column on Aug. 28, about Soho House in Berlin, misspelled the name of the district filled with cafes and bars that is it near. It is Prenzelauer Berg, not Prenzlauerberg.

GITTLEMAN--Adele, of Delray Beach and New York City died peacefully at age 82 on September 6th. Devoted and beloved mother, grandmother, cousin and friend. As a science teacher, she inspired many youngsters to pursue science, especially girls. She capped her career as director of Manhattan East JHS. Her loss will be felt by many. New York City memorial tribute at 5:30pm, October 5th, Mini Theatre, Julia Richman Educational Complex, 317 East 67th St., Manhattan. Contributions can be made in Adele's honor to ASPCA.

I have been witness to the rebuilding of the World Trade Center from the beginning. I have seen the creation of slurry walls, the blasting of bedrock, steel beams floating through the air. I have felt floors vibrate as concrete was pushed into new walls. The builders inspire me. The architects, developers, engineers, steamfitters, plumbers, electricians, steelworkers, rebar crews, concrete workers, welders and laborers have transformed a pile of despair into a teeming complex and a new and wonderful skyline. -- FRED CONRAD

MOSKOWITZ--Helen Silfen, September 9, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Jerome Moskowitz, mother of Lenny (Vickie), Kenny (Dianne), and Franny. Grandmother of Adam (Caitlin), Jesse (Sarah), Seth (Allison), Alyssa, Corey, Abby, Jaime, and Casey. Great-grandmother of Norah. Sister of Marcia Weisser, Arthur Silfen and the late Edwin Silfen. Donations can be made to the Sunrise Fund, Stony Brook University Medical Center, in loving memory of Liz Kelly (www.hsc.stony brook.edu/sunrisefund/). Funeral service will be on Sunday, September 11th at 11am at the New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. The family will sit Shiva following the service on Sunday, and Sunday, Monday, and Tuesday evenings from 6:30pm-9:30pm at the home of Lenny and Vickie.

CONVENIENCE is crucial when it comes to refueling during New York Fashion Week, and more often than not, models and editors make some very bad choices. Elettra Wiedemann, a model and a food activist, hopes to change that by opening Goodness, a pop-up restaurant installed at Ed's Chowder House across the street from Lincoln Center. From Sunday through Sept. 14, Goodness will serve locally sourced food from some of the city's best toques, including Nick Wilbur from the Fat Radish and Christopher Rendell of ''Iron Chef.'' Ms. Wiedemann has teamed with the Michelin star chef Ed Brown to design a soothing atmosphere in which to enjoy duck confit salad and pan-seared bream mash with a truffle vinaigrette. LILY HARRISON

Bill Kunkel, who helped invent video game journalism and create the first video game magazine in the United States, died on Sunday at his home in White Lake, Mich. He was 61. The cause was apparently a heart attack, his wife, Laurie Kunkel, said.

MULLIGAN--Tim, Died peacefully at home, age 73, surrounded by the art he loved and the lifetime partner he adored, on September 7, 2011, after a brave and uncomplaining battle with cancer. Brilliantly educated at Philips Andover, Yale, and The University of Paris, he spent the first 22 years of his career from 1963 as an editor at the magazines "This Week," "Good Housekeeping," and "Family Weekly." In 1985 he began 10 years of memorable service as head of public affairs for the New York State Council on the Arts, supporting Kitty Carlisle Hart's vision and reflecting her ebullience in venues throughout the state. Since 1995 he has been the respected director of external affairs for the Bard Graduate Center: Decorative Arts, Design History, Material Culture, working to expand international coverage and initiating the Center's global travel program and its annual Iris Awards for outstanding contributions to decorative arts under founder Susan Weber. As a public affairs consultant, he advised The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Mariners' Museum, and a host of corporate clients, while his amusing and insightful freelance pieces appeared in such national magazines as "Omni," "Conde Nast Traveler," and "Travel & Leisure." One of the most original, cultured, and highly praised travel writers of the 1980s and 90s, his books included "The Traveler's Guide to the Hudson River Valley," in its fifth edition and still considered the best in its field, along with: "The Traveler's Guide to Western New England and the Connecticut River Valley," and "Virginia: A History and Guide." He also co-edited the 2006 collection, "The Battle of Hampton Roads: New Perspectives on the USS Monitor and CSS Virginia." But even these accomplishments hardly begin to convey his infectious wit, his incomparable elegance, his peerless taste, and his innate modesty. He was a scholar, a gentleman, an arts champion, and a loving and endlessly delightful friend. He is survived by his partner of 46 years, and spouse of three heroic weeks, John O'Keefe.

ALEC BALDWIN Jack Donaghyon''30 Rock'' If humor can be derived from thwarting expectations, then the casting of the famously liberal Alec Baldwin as a Reagan-worshiping executive was a brilliant, if predictable, masterstroke. Still, stunt-casting gets you only so far. What makes Jack's lapidary refinement and his encyclopedic savoir-faire so funny (and, let's face it, he makes Don Draper look like a used-car salesman) is that it blooms in such coarse soil -- a corporate culture more suited to crusty vulgarians like Jack's mentor hero, Don Geiss. But in Baldwin's hands, Donaghy has become the chimerical dream of every ''Art of War''-reading, Rudyard Kipling-reciting executivewhoeverfanciedhimselfalover,afighterandadapperphilosopher-prince.CARINA CHOCANO
Theater Charles Isherwood

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Retrial for Clemens, and More Scolding for the Prosecutors,'' Sept. 3: Retrying Roger Clemens serves no purpose at a time of flooding, drought, hurricanes and economic hardship. A sloppy federal prosecutor already squandered resources.

ARCHIE PANJABI Kalinda Sharmaon''The Good Wife'' Just like Bogie -- and just like Bacall: that's the secret of Kalinda Sharma. She's a mash-up of film noir archetypes (and gender roles), both gumshoe and femme fatale, tough broad and heartbroken sap. The knee-high leather boots get the attention, but it's the luminous brown eyes, always alert, that tell the story. Panjabi takes a genre cliche -- the combination of hard shell and tender interior -- and redeems it by maintaining a constant but perfectly poised intensity, one whose tight control only emphasizes its operatic force. She provides a crucial emotional counterweight to Julianna Margulies's equally powerful performance asAliciaFlorrick,thegoodandmadwife.KalindasmolderssothatAliciacanburn.MIKE HALE

KRATOVIL--Emil Arthur, Jr.,"Tovi," on August 1, 2011, in Charlottesville, VA. Devoted member of St. Anthony Hall; Served honorably in Vietnam as an USMC First Lieutenant; Admiralty attorney, New York City. Survived by his devoted companion, Jane Barnes; former wife, Elizabeth Stetson; Sons: E. Arthur III and deWolf H; Brothers: Edward D; Stephen C. and David W. and their five children. Gifts: Disabled Veterans National Foundation: dvnf.org or St. Anthony Educational Foundation: stanthonyhall.org.

SIPHRON--Joseph R.,of New York, NY and Quogue, NY, died Sunday, September 4th. He was 78 years old. Beloved husband of 54 years to Mary John Siphron and loving father to John Siphron, Joe is survived by daughter-in-law Laura and granddaughter Elizabeth, sister Jeanne Siphron, brother David Siphron, sister-in-law Katherine Post, niece Whitney Strickler and nephew David Strickler. Born in Cincinnati, OH, Joe graduated from Yale in 1955. At Yale, he was a member of Scroll and Key, and his passion for singing led him to become both the president of the Glee Club as well as a Whiffenpoof. He went on to attend both Oxford and Yale Law School. Joe retired as a partner of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley and McCloy after 34 years with the firm. An avid amateur ornithologist, Joe traveled the world looking for exotic birds. He combined this enthusiasm with tireless fundraising for various nature organizations, and served on the boards of both the National Audubon Society and the Cornell Bird Lab. Joe was a member of the Union Club, the Quogue Beach Club, the Quogue Field Club and served on the vestry at St. James Church and on the executive committee at the Church of the Atonement in Quogue, NY. Loved and adored by his family, Joe will be remembered for his determination in all things, his deep sense of loyalty and commitment to family and friends, his quick wit, keen mind, and his enduring faith in God. A memorial service will be held at St. James Church on Madison Ave. and 71st St. in New York on Tuesday, October 25th at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to either the Wildlife Conservation Society or the Church of the Atonement.
FRANKSTON--Sherman, 66, died August 31, 2011 in Tucson, AZ. Loving husband of Julie and proud father of Adam, Douglas and Jeffrey.

KELLY MACDONALD Margaret Schroederon''BoardwalkEmpire'' ''Boardwalk Empire,'' HBO's painterly take on Prohibition-era Atlantic City, is so exceptionally cast and deftly acted that it is nearly impossible to choose from among the acreage of talent. We are compelled, though, to render the loudest hymns in praise of Kelly Macdonald. She brings us the immigrant widow Margaret Schroeder, a woman whose needs she generously honors by refusing to adopt an aura of neediness. She's so adept at conveying the character's vulnerability and defiance, pride and heartbreak, integrity and pragmatism, that watching her tends to make us question whether we're in the world of fiction or reality. GINIA BELLAFANTE

Deceptively diminutive, Archy Marshall fidgets onstage. He is 17, angsty and awkward. But he is no teeny-bopper. A pleasant dissonance arises when he opens his mouth, and from his slight body emerges a deep, rich sound. His barked out lyrics are first person and loop through cryptic, emotionally raw experiences. A dubstep influence is there, but mostly in his modern sensibility as his music is guitar-anchored. For the last year or two, Marshall has played around Britain under the name Zoo Kid, heading to gigs after school, on weekends and over holidays. This past July he played under his new moniker, King Krule, at a festival in Hyeres, France. With his second release due out in October, his seriousness is a welcome counterweight to the YouTube-driven fame of his contemporaries like Justin Bieber and Cody Simpson. ''Teenager'' need not be pejorative when it comes to lyricism. After all, Arthur Rimbaud was one. See the video for ''Out Getting Ribs,'' here:

LINFIELD--Jordan L.,87. Born in 1923 in Brooklyn; died September 8, 2011, in Manhattan of complications from a fall. Jordan was a lifelong New Yorker and he served the city in many ways, including as director of Neighborhood Action Program in the John Lindsay administration. He was a proud veteran of World War II and an equally proud graduate of Townsend Harris, City College, and Columbia University, where he wrote his master's thesis on the Socialist Workers Party. He was a man of prolific talents: union organizer, editor, publisher, author of many books, Hebrew scholar and math professor. He loved the Spanish Loyalists who fought Franco, and he was confident of the survival of the Jewish people. Most of all he loved his family: his wife of 63 years, Trudy; his daughters, Deborah, who predeceased him, and Susie; his granddaughter Sarah; his sons-in-law Jay Bernstein and Eugene Scheiman; and his siblings Hadassah and David. Jordan was an extraordinary man: kind, gentle, generous, and a true intellectual; we will remember him, love him, and miss him forever. Service Monday, September 12, 11:15 at "The Riverside", 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave.

TOMMER WEINGARTEN (RIGHT), 22: It's a custom that before you announce your engagement, you first go to the rebbe and you ask for his blessing. You ask him to deliver your prayers on high, that they should be heard by God and answered speedily. So we went to the ohel. It's the grave of our rebbe, the Lubavitcher rebbe. And my arm was in a sling, because I fell off my longboard and broke my collarbone. I'm into skateboarding. My friends set me up with Rochel. It's called a shidduch. I'm excited to get married more than ever. I'll be honest, I didn't see myself getting married this young, but when you find the right one, if you wait too long, she might run away. I don't want to be that guy who looks back at his life and says, ''You know, there was that one girl. . . .''
Boerum Hill Loft $1,425,000
TRAVERS--Wally P. May 22, 1957 -September 11, 2001 I love, adore and miss you. Your niece, Patti

When Gaby Wood went to Scotland to interview David Lasnet, an osteopath and father of four, she was struck by his deep sense of gratitude and contentment. ''We're so lucky, aren't we?'' he asked her, after a day spent surfing the waves off Coldingham Sands. His words resonated with me as we finished this issue of T. I am very grateful to work with a team that brings such expertise and daring to the business of making magazines. There is, for example, our creative director, David Sebbah, who spent the summer traveling the globe in pursuit of cool portraits. He created -- with Sebastian Kim, Sara Moonves and Jacob Brown -- a ''studio'' in a tent at the Bonnaroo festival in remote Tennessee. He packed a bag with coats and headed, with the indefatigable Max Vadukul, to Manchester, Beverly Hills and Arles to spend mere minutes with the magical talents of Man United, past and present. It was his friendship with his fellow Frenchman Lasnet and Lasnet's wife, Stella Tennant, that allowed us a peek into their family life. For this issue he has been everything from a fashion assistant to a set builder; his humility and humor are astonishing. Bruce Pask, our men's fashion director, returns each season from the catwalks with a stunningly precise map of the trends and twists. He then scours New York for guys to test his expert theories on. It's a huge undertaking. This time around he roped in the cast of Lincoln Center's ''War Horse,'' among others, to wear the runway. And Jacob Brown, our features/entertainment director, is responsible for putting the people we love on the pages of T. From Richard Ashcroft to really big bands, from Cristiano Ronaldo to King Krule, we could not do it without Brown. (He picked Bonnaroo for its tripped-out Americana spirit: kids with flowers and glow ropes in their hair, and little to no commercial hoopla.)
DARVIN--Renee. Happy Anniversary & Birthday. Missing You. Love Always, Jerry
To the Sports Editor: Re ''The Open's Missing Piece,'' Sept 8: A single covered tennis court at Flushing Meadows makes no sense.

Sebastian Kim Sebastian Kim, a longtime assistant to Richard Avedon and Steven Meisel, began his own photo career shooting his skateboarding friends in Southern California. Now his fashion editorials and portraits of actors, models and musicians appear frequently in T, Interview and Vogue. For ''Really Big Bands'' (Page 106), Kim ventured to Tennessee for the 10th Bonnaroo music festival. ''We lived like rock stars,'' says the photographer of his three-night stay on an overcrowded tour bus. ''We ended up shooting even more bands than we planned.'' The downside? ''Having to use port-a-potties and community showers.''

ATWOOD--William G.,M.D., of New York and Roxbury, CT died August 6, 2011. He had suffered from Alzheimer's disease for many years. Born December 14, 1932 in Kansas City, MO, he was the son of Dr. William Goodson Atwood, Sr. and Jenette Morris Atwood. Dr. Atwood was raised in Carrollton, MO, and he received his A. B. degree, cum laude, from Harvard College in 1954 and his medical degree from the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University in 1958. Dr. Atwood maintained a private practice in dermatology in New York, and he was on the staffs of Columbia Presbyterian and Lenox Hill Hospitals until his retirement in late 1999. Besides medicine he had a wide range of interests in music, literature, Asian art and religions, world travel, squash, gardening and his beloved beagles. He was recognized as one of the world's authorities on Frederic Chopin, and he wrote three books covering the composer's compositions and life. Two works were published by Columbia University Press and the third by Yale University Press. Dr. Atwood was predeceased by his parents; his brother, Dr. Morris Atwood; and a nephew, Ronald Atwood. He is survived by his partner of thirty eight years, David Balthrop; two nieces from his brother's marriage, Rachel Huber of Milford, MI and Maria Holloway of Baltimore, MD; and six great nieces and nephews. He had been a member of the University Club and the Harvard Club in New York. Funeral services will be held Friday, September 16, 2011, at 11am at Kirkland Chapel, Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 7 W. 55th Street, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Alzheimer's Association, alz.org, would be sincerely appreciated.

BAZARINI--Ronald J. For 30 years Baz was a beloved and inspiring teacher of many boys at both St. Bernard's School and the Buckley School. A memorial program celebrating Baz's life with his family, students and friends will be held at St. Bernard's School, 4 East 98th St. on Sunday, September 18 at 6pm. Please bring memories.

An obituary last Sunday about the advertising executive Leo-Arthur Kelmenson, using information from the family, referred incorrectly to his military service. While he was a Marine Corps paratrooper during World War II, he was not a member of the First Parachute Division. (There was no such division.)

Like Coco Chanel, Pierre-Henri Mattout was born in Saumur, the medieval French town in the Loire Valley famous among wine snobs for its superb cabernet franc appellation, Saumur-Champigny. The town also happens to be an equestrian center of France, home to the Cadre Noir, one of the world's most prestigious riding schools. ''It's very uptight, very bourgeois and very elegant,'' says Mattout, who, as a p'tit garcon, dreamed not of mounting a Lusitano but of being the academy's head tailor. Accordingly, Mattout's latest men's collection - all jodhpur-style chinos, leather elbow patches and whipcord wool blazers in dragoon red - is a paean to his horse-loving hometown. But rather than reboot some bygone vision of aristo chic, Mattout drew on his design experience at Dior Homme, Dunhill and Victorinox. The result is a modern sportswear collection of uncommon elegance, detail-obsessed yet refreshingly remote from the work-wear-inspired stuff that's glutting American runways. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
Film Andy Webster

BESCHEL--William H.,born in Astoria Queens raised in Whitestone NY passed away peacefully on August 10, 2011 after a long fiercely fought battle with cancer. He was 62 years old. He was a devoted father to his loving son Jared Beschel and his wife Alexandra Beschel. Proud grandfather of Jared, Michael and Tyler Beschel. Dear brother of Barry and Joann Beschel. Billy was a NYC Detective forced to retire when he was shot several times in the line of duty in 1971. Once retired he owned and operated a variety of used car dealerships in the NYC Metro area. Billy had a passion for sailing, skiing, swimming and spending Christmas with his family. Billy will be deeply missed and we will never forget him.

It took me a long time to realize that the things my parents did were not exactly normal. I was about 7 years old, and it was the tail end of the 1950s, when it started to dawn on me that they were . . . well, let's just say they were different. For instance: my friends and I got shots when we went to the doctor and we hated them. But my parents stabbed themselves with needles almost every day, and seemed to enjoy it. Weird. Most of my friends' parents sounded like the adults in school or on TV when they talked. People understood them. My parents, on the other hand, had their own language, laced with a flowery slang that I picked up the same way the Puerto Rican kids could speak English at school and Spanish at home with their abuelas.
Walk softly and wear a big trend.

WITH the Taj Mahal Palace Hotel (below) and the Gateway of India as landmarks, the Colaba district, on the Mumbai waterfront, has always been the heartbeat of the city and a major tourist destination. But it's also a great area for shopping, home to a slew of spots that are mainstays for the city's glamour set. International boutiques like Louis Vuitton have prominent placement, but it's the local purveyors that are the real stars. Following the 2008 terrorist attacks on the Taj hotel, Colaba lost some of its luster, but now that the historic property has reopened, the surrounding neighborhood is once again a premier destination in town. SHIVANI VORA

The Practical Traveler column last Sunday, about programs that provide V.I.P. treatment for airline coach passengers, misstated the surname of the managing director of premium services at American Airlines. She is Nancy Knipp, not Kipp.

Mr. Adelman, who also resided in Boca Raton, FL, would be 90 on November 11th. His wife, Renee, passed in 2000 and he is survived by his brother, Dan Alden, his daughters, Marcia and Debra, and his grandchildren, Ariel and Ross. Services will be held Sunday, September 11th, at 10am at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel in Hewlett, NY.

MILLIKEN--Gloria. The affordable housing community in New York City mourns the passing of one of its own. Gloria was a leader in the community development world and used her formidable life force to build organizations that made life better for thousands of New Yorkers-those who were homeless or lived in deplorable conditions or needed a hand up to get on their feet. Her activism began in 1964 when she started the Hundred Worst Buildings program in East Harlem. Over the next 40 years she helped to found many successful nonprofit groups, virtually all of which are still in operation today. They include: Adopt-a-Building; Housing Conservation Coordinators, formed to keep low-income families from being displaced during gentrification in Hell's Kitchen; the Winter Heat Fund, which lends money to low-income tenants to buy oil; the Association of Neighborhood Housing Developers, a citywide group comprising 40 neighborhood-based housing organizations; and Eviction Intervention Services, which teaches residents how to advocate on their own behalf to prevent homelessness. Add to that her involvement with senior citizen organizations, hands on training programs and umbrella coalitions, and Gloria was involved in more than 100 organizations in New York City. Her graciousness and generosity were legendary. She put both to use in the cause of community development and in the alleviation of individual misery. She loved the City and matched its energy with her own vitality. New York is a better place for her tireless efforts. We will miss her laughter and her energy and her leadership. Our thoughts and sympathy go out to her sons, Ashly and Arthur, and to their families. The Association of Neighborhood Housing Developers Los Sures Eviction Intervention Services Pratt Institute for Community Development Banana Kelly Forsyth Street Advisors Urban Homesteading Assistance Board Law Office of Lawrence H. WEXLER--Melissa Ann. 5/9/58-9/12/81. Missy, your life was too short. We miss you so much. Love, Mommy Arline Joachim, Eddie, Sheri & Larry.

Hitters like to hit fastballs, and the straighter the pitch, the better. So early in the count, hitters will often forgo swinging at a curveball even if it is a very hittable strike. Pitchers may do well to take advantage of this by throwing more of what players call a get-me-over curveball: not the pitcher's best curveball, but one designed simply to be over the plate and called a strike.

COUDERT--Alexis Tracy, died at age 72 in Miami on August 4, 2011. His parents were Allison Marie Moore, daughter of Louis Moore former president of Tiffany & Co., and Alexis Carrel Coudert, of the Coudert Brothers Law Firm. He grew up in Oyster Bay and New York City. He attended The Buckley School, St. Mark's School, St. George's School in Newport, RI and graduated from Harvard in 1960. As an undergraduate, he ran the radio stations at Harvard and Rochester. He excelled in racquet sports. Truely an American patriot, he enlisted in the U.S. Army, serving in Vietnam and Cambodia. He received the Certificate of Achievement from Ft. Jay and was honorably discharged as a 1st Lt. in 1967. Tracy's career spanned 22 years with the C.I.A., including posts in Vietnam, Cambodia, Western Europe, and Washington, D.C. He spent his last 10 years there with the Middle East Division, where he worked on Iranian, North African and Palestinian Affairs. After retirement, he enjoyed gardening, cooking, political blogging, and caring for his beloved German Sheperds, Warro and Janker. His lifelong loves were classical music and mathematics. He was an accomplished linguist fluent in six languages. He was a concert level pianist and harpsichordist. He is survived by his beloved wife, Carol Jane White Coudert; her daughter, Emma Ivy White of Boston; his sister, UCLA Professor Allison "Eo" Coudert; and his niece, Polly Moore Gottesman. Memorial services will be held on September 17 on Long Island and September 18 in New York. For details, please e-mail: carolcoudert@gmail.com Charitable donations in Tracy's name may be sent to Heifer International's Cambodia Fund, 1 World Avenue, Little Rock, AR 72202. Every friend who has gone before -- with knowledge, kindness, the passion for learning - reminds us of the loss of a fine library. This is the loss of a major collection - one entertaining work after another we shall miss.

''Neither of my parents ever threw anything away,'' says John Carter Cash, the only son of Johnny Cash and June Carter. So, by his parents' death in 2003, the family vault brimmed with photos and scattered ephemera. John Carter spent years cataloging everything, and the result is ''House of Cash'' (Insight Editions, $40), a deeply personal, often surprising scrapbook of his home life. (Now 41, he appears as a boy in many of the photos from the book.) In addition to the pictures, many taken by the Man in Black himself, the book includes Johnny Cash's handwritten poems; one, from 1982, is hopelessly titled ''Don't Make a Movie About Me.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Richard James: The London tailor, known for kitting out rock stars, royals, actors and moguls in killer bespoke suits, is loosening his tie a bit this season. ''Tailoring will never go away,'' he says. ''In fact, it's booming. But you also need something to walk the dog in.'' 1. James reinterprets camouflage every season. ''Most prints are feminine, but camouflage is purely masculine,'' he says. The designer would use this woven tie to spice up a navy suit and white or pale blue shirt. It's about $120.

SCHWARTZ--Michel Shevach. Born November 16, 1926 in Catskill, NY, died September 8, 2011 in Flushing, NY. Survived by wife, Josepha Siev Schwartz, daughter, Lynda Leslie, sons Lenny and Marty, sister Miriam Silverman, son-in-law Dr. Glenn Leslie, daughter-in-law Jodi Stern, and grandchildren Alec, Ray, Juliana, Jake and Morgan. Michel spent a lifetime painting and designing Jewish works of art for countless organizations, charities, foundations, friends and family. His works may be seen in Israel in the President's residence, the Knesset, Jerusalem City Hall, the Jewish Children's Museum in Brooklyn, numerous synagogues and the private collections of many dignitaries and celebrities. Michel's lifelong friendship with the Lubavitcher Rebbe Menachem Schneerson, shlita, lead to him being referred to as the Rebbe's personal artist. Michel also spent many years in the commercial world, creating and inventing products, promotions and campaigns.

I was walking recently with a friend near Stuyvesant Town, on the East Side of Manhattan, when we spied a low-lying plant, about knee-high, growing just outside an apartment building. The leaves gave off the unmistakable scent of gasoline that is characteristic of epazote. I immediately considered the culinary possibilities: guacamole, quesadillas or black-bean dip? Epazote (Dysphania ambrosioides or Chenopodium ambrosioides), a k a pasote or pasotes, Mexican tea and wormseed, is native to Mexico and Central and South America. An annual that can grow to three or four feet, with toothed, lance-shaped leaves, epazote favors full sunlight and is an intrepid weed. I've seen it flourishing throughout the city from the summer through mid-autumn, growing in cracks of the pavement, around trees on the sidewalk and in front yards in Brooklyn.

The National Museum of Scotland recently reopened in Edinburgh after a £46.4 million (about $75 million) refurbishment, with 16 new galleries. This multidisciplinary museum, with four million objects in its collection, was founded in 1866 with the goal of showing all the world under one roof. The museum's largest installation, the four-story Window on the World, can be found in the spacious Grand Gallery. There visitors will find things like the jaws of a sperm whale inscribed with the world's largest scrimshaw carving and the Pembridge helm, one of only four surviving 13th-century knight's helmets.

DONALD GLOVER Troy Barneson''Community'' Early in NBC's ''Community,'' one student in the study group at Greendale Community College was an arrogant jock so desperate to hold onto past glories that he still wore his high-school letter jacket. And Donald Glover probably could have developed a very funny character based solely on that sketch. Fortunately for viewers, he instead transformed Troy Barnes into a sweet nerd-nai f (and in a pair of notable episodes, a paintball kamikaze) who legitimately finds his horizons expanded by his community-college classes. Who could have guessed that the jock in those opening episodes would become someone famous for comically crying? TARA ARIANO
