The name is synonymous with glamorous, exotic-skinned heels (thanks to one too many ''Sex and the City'' puns), but Jimmy Choo's debut collection for men is thoroughly, surprisingly, masculine. The line ranges from Alfie-worthy Chelsea boots and crocodile monk-strap shoes to modern street-wear classics like the leopard-print high-top featured here on Tamara Mellon, Choo's founder. ''Men started going in and buying the big sizes of the women's sneakers,'' Mellon says. ''It was like an aha moment - it made sense.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

TAFFNER--Donald L. An iconic independent distributor and producer of television programming and live theater attractions, passed peacefully on Tuesday, September 6, 2011 after a brief stay in Lenox Hill Hospital, Manhattan. Among his many achievements, he and his wife-business partner, Eleanor Bolta, were responsible for bringing such television shows to the American public as, "Three's Company", "Too Close For Comfort" and "The Benny Hill Show." She passed away a year ago. The quintessential American success story, Taffner grew up above his family's candy store in Brooklyn where his education in business began. Preparing the day's newspapers with his father, running telephone messages to persons throughout the neighborhood and just being "in the store" taught Don about getting along with and being able to talk to people...it gave him a unique set of social skills and a pronounced business attitude which held fast throughout his life. A proud graduate of St. John's College (now known as University), Don took a job in the mailroom of the William Morris Agency in 1952 and by the time he left the well-known agency in 1959, he had been an agent there for four years. In 1959 he built his expertise in television distribution by helping to begin the Television Distribution Program Department at Paramount. The Taffners were married in 1961 and in 1963 they launched D.L. Taffner Ltd, their own business. The company started out as a worldwide distributor of TV programs and later, as DLT Entertainment Ltd., expanded to TV and stage production. In 1986, Don Taffner's considerable significant contributions to the development of the industry were recognized by the International Council of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, which presented him with an Emmy for its prestigious Founders Award "for setting new levels of creativity in the worldwide exchange of television programs". As a result of his work in television, specifically British television, Don Taffner was awarded an OBE in 2002. As an offshoot of his television business, Don became involved with the prestigious Theatre of Comedy in the UK and the company continues to own and manage the Shaftesbury Theatre on the West End. Champions of St. John's University, in 2005, Donald and Eleanor Taffner were given Johnny's Angels Awards by St. John's Bread and Life, an organization that is devoted to getting food to those who need it in Brooklyn and in Queens. In 2007, the Taffners were presented with the Spirit of Service Award for their continuing contribution to the school. Having developed a great passion for Charles Rennie Mackintosh and the Glasgow School, Don and Eleanor Taffner were presented with a Wallace award at the 'Icons of Scotland Dinner' hosted by Scotland Magazine in 2005, and were the first individuals with no hereditary connection to Scotland to ever receive the award. Donald is survived by his daughter, Karen Butler and her husband Ronald Butler, his son, Donald L. Taffner Jr. and Rhonda Cantor and three grandchildren, John, Henry and Tom Butler. A funeral service will be held on Saturday, September 10, 2011 at 10:30am at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street followed by a luncheon at Villa Mosconi, 69 MacDougal Street. A Memorial Mass will be held on Saturday, September 17, 2011 at 10:30am on the St. Johns University Queens Campus conducted by Father Donald J Harrington at St. Thomas More Church. The Mass will be followed by a tribute at the Taffner Field House and luncheon. In lieu of flowers the family wishes that any and all contributions be made to St. John's Bread for Life www.breadandlife.org

BRAZIL'S most famous exports usually end up prancing down a Victoria's Secret runway, but with the publication of ''Brazilian Style'' ($65 at assouline.com), the country's more obscure offerings -- pink dolphins, anyone? -- join Carmen Miranda and caipirinhas in a colorful look at Brazil. Armand Limnander, the author, said the book grew out of a 10-year love affair with the country. ''It's a very personal take on the people, places and things that resonate with me,'' he said (like the idyllic island of Fernando de Noronha, shown here.) He added that Brazil, which will host the World Cup and Summer Olympic Games this decade, '' is already an economic superpower, so the next logical step is for it to begin exporting its culture, which is rich, varied and, above all, fun.'' SANDRA BALLENTINE

When I was a kid in this neighborhood, it was a regular thing to walk to the promenade to see the harbor and skyline. I'd go with my grandmother, and she'd point out the statue, the ferry, Ellis, Governor's. Later we stared from that perch as they assembled these Erector-set-looking things, these twinned towers. Even then I was a New York purist, I preferred old things, and I resented the dull Saltine boxes for dwarfing the Empire State. But they were mine anyway, I couldn't help it. Big Apple, Abe Beame, Bicentennial, World Trade Center, my cheesy '70s New York. A decade later, when I first married, I dragged a California bride to my city, and we elevated to the roof of one of the buildings to exhilarate in the chill, dizzying wind of outer space. Yesterday, the Erector set reappeared, just for a moment. Yesterday, the same west-to-east wind that once nearly whisked newlyweds from the rooftop blew pulverized tower across the river and into my mouth. I've eaten my towers.
Dance Jack Anderson

SPIRO--Stanley. Stanley Spiro, of Hewlett, New York passed away on September 8, 2011 at the age of 70 after battling esophageal cancer. Born to Samuel and Lucille Spiro in Queens on December 10, 1940, Stanley graduated Far Rockaway High School and earned his degree in communications from the University of Wisconsin. He served as a radioman in the Naval Reserves during Vietnam. Stanley had an extraordinary career in the television broadcast industry as a freelance producer/director. Stanley won six Emmy Awards, a Director's Guild of America Special Commendation Medal and contributed to programs honored with Alfred I. Dupont and George Foster Peabody awards. Throughout the industry Stanley was known for his high standards, nerves of steel, methodical brilliance, and being an overall great guy. His list of credits is enormous and most everyone has seen Stanley's work. Titles over the past 40+ years include The Soupy Sales Show, The Electric Company, 20/20, nine Olympic Broadcasts, three Super Bowl Pre/Post/ Halftime Shows, Primetime Live, and most recently World Focus. For leisure, Stanley loved electronics and sailing. He bareboat chartered sailboats with his family in the Caribbean and crewed aboard sailboats on ocean crossings. He earned his Merchant Marine Captain's license and taught sailing in Oyster Bay. Wherever he went in life, Stanley made people laugh. Stanley was a loving husband, devoted father, and adoring grandfather. Stanley was predeceased by his wife Myrna and is survived by their children Stacy and David and four grandchildren, and is also survived by his wife Lillian, three stepchildren and seven step-grandchildren, and his brother Elliot. Services will be held today at 12:30pm at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels in Hewlett, NY.

Emilia Clarke is the nice English girl who plays Daenerys Targaryen in HBO's hugely successful pork-sword-and-sorcery drama series, ''Game of Thrones.'' In the show, which is adapted from George R. R. Martin's equally huge series of cod-medieval fantasy books, ''A Song of Ice and Fire,'' Daenerys is one of the two remaining children of the ousted Targaryen dynasty, forcibly married, aged 15, to Khal Drogo, another huge thing (played by the 6-foot-4 Hawaiian-born actor Jason Momoa), a warlord of the horse-mad Dothraki people who live beyond the Narrow Sea. When I say the Dothraki are horse-mad, I don't mean to suggest that they collect rosettes for their show ponies and enjoy nothing more than a spot of dressage, oh no. Daenerys's wedding involves a public orgy of explicit equine-style coupling, while to win a place in the dusky Dothraki's heart the platinum blonde must, gulp, eat a horse's heart, raw. Raped on her wedding night by Drogo - who resembles a mutant Klingon - Daenerys proves to be a tough-minded and shrewd operator, who quickly picks up the language of her adoptive people and learns how to please her testosterone-fueled consort from a helpful courtesan.

BRYAN CRANSTON Walter Whiteon ''Breaking Bad'' ''I'm begging you -- I just need $5,000,'' Bryan Cranston is saying. ''You think I would be calling you if I wasn't desperate?'' A scene from ''Breaking Bad,'' in which he plays a teacher turned meth dealer? No -- it's from the sitcom ''Malcolm in the Middle,'' in which he played a buffoonish dad. And this explains, in part, how Cranston went from three-time Emmy nominee (for ''Malcolm'') to three-time Emmy winner (for ''Breaking Bad''). It's virtually impossible for an actor to shed a role that he's identified with by millions; just ask Steve Urkel -- I mean, Jaleel White. To do so by taking on a role that is the polar opposite of the one burned into the public mind: that's a challenge many actors relish, but only one is pulling it off quite this well. NEIL GENZLINGER

If You Were to Make a Cityout of all the new or redeveloped buildings in Lower Manhattan since 2001, it would look like the city below: an upscale haven remarkably transformed after the Sept. 11 attack. Subsidized by tax breaks for developers and tolls from bridge and tunnel commuters, downtown has become the city's fastest-growing area, and one of the wealthiest. By FORD FESSENDEN This metropolis includes some buildings rendered realistically and other, generic buildings that are scaled to represent the amount of space in each category. Almost $24 billion was spent to rebuild the trade center area. A look at where the money went, Page 4.

Scholars call them vernacular artists -- ordinary people who create art not for its own sake, but because making things that can be seen and touched is their way to say what they feel. Their creations form an alternate record of the Sept. 11 attacks, outside news media or government accounts. Scores of Americans hired tattoo artists as translators and had their bodies inscribed with the names of the lost, and with towers that never stop burning. Painted or constructed tributes, some ephemeral, flowered on walls and in fields. And around the world, tradition bearers who may have had limited access to television reports were moved to depict the events. ''Cultures that have suffered, not just terrorist attacks, but have suffered other kinds of tragedies, looked to America and Americans and New Yorkers with sympathy and empathy,'' said Felicia Katz-Harris, curator of Asian and Middle Eastern folk art at the Museum of International Folk Art. These works, she said, were ''a way for them to reach out.'' -- SYDNEY EMBER

Harris Tweed, the flecked hand-woven wool from Scotland, is celebrating the centennial of its trademark stamp: a Maltese cross atop an orb. An ancestor to the counterfeit wars raging today, the stamp was implemented in 1911 to distinguish the genuine cloth from machine-milled knockoffs. This fall, designers are offering special-edition pieces in tweed as a tribute to those original weavers, our fashion brave hearts. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

BACK in 1993, long before Craig McDean started shooting waifish models for the likes of Vogue and Another Magazine, the fashion photographer (and martial arts enthusiast) spent a year in Japan, where he documented sumo wrestlers with an almost ritualistic devotion. The more time he spent with them, the closer he was able to get until, he recalled, ''Eventually, they scarcely noticed I was there.'' In ''Sumo,'' an intimate hand-bound volume from Mörel books, and in an accompanying show at the Half Gallery on the Lower East Side, Mr. McDean captures moments of unexpected fluidity and grace as mountains of Bacon-esque flesh come together as if in a dance. Half Gallery, 208 Forsyth Street, Sept. 12 to 18. ALIX BROWNE

The Frugal Traveler column on Aug. 28, about spending a $100 weekend in Madrid (and going slightly over budget), referred incorrectly to the origins of the Teotihuacan ruins in Mexico in describing an exhibition of treasures from the site at the art gallery Caixa Madrid. While the abandoned city of Teotihuacan was rediscovered by the Aztecs, the ethnicity of the builders of the ancient site remains unknown. It is not an Aztec city.

MILLIKEN--Gloria, with grace, elegance and a spine of steel activist and philanthropist Gloria Milliken made a permanent difference in New York City. Gloria had the vision that became The New York Women's Foundation. She understood what was needed-strong women, from all areas of the city, working together across lines of race and class, focusing on the root causes of poverty, committed to advocacy, determined to improve the lives of women and their families in New York City. It was Gloria Milliken's courage, determination and leadership that were responsible for creating what many thought unnecessary and most thought impossible, a powerful foundation of women working together to help women. It is unlikely that anyone other than Gloria Milliken could have done it. And she did it very well. The New York Women's Foundation honors the life of our co-founder and builds on her strength and vision
91 VICTIMS--Too Many to Name: To all those who perished on 9/11/01 may they rest in peace.

Emerging from the shadow of that other stylish, innovative Asian city (ahem, Tokyo), Korea's capital has become an epicenter for trends - particularly for men. The evidence is in popular street style blogs like Your Boyhood, Street Peeper and even The Sartorialist (which has featured the model Bae Jung Nam, who, a la Kate Moss, has turned into a style sensation and is the basis of ''Bae Jung Nam-style''). Korean men, in fact, have started to outshine the women in terms of experimentation and overall expression, wearing everything from Opening Ceremony's kookiness to the elegant homegrown designer Wooyoungmi. As for shopping, multibrand boutiques rather than staid department stores have been able to stock exactly what the guys are looking for: high-end lines like Givenchy and Maison Martin Margiela (at Boontheshop Men, 79-13 Cheongdam-dong, Gangnam-gu; 011-82-2-3445-2841; boontheshop.com; and Tom Greyhound Downstairs, 650-14 B1F Sinsa-dong, Gangnam-gu; 011-82-2-3442- 3696; tomgreyhounddownstairs.com) as well as younger labels like Patrik Ervell, Fitbow Kollektiv and Our Legacy (MSK Shop, above, 569-31, 6/F Woo Jung Building, Sinsa-dong, Gangnam-gu; 011-82-70-8233-3107; mskshop.net).

We asked the Paris-based designer Rick Owens, a native Californian, to make the T for our fall men's issue because he's our favorite independent American abroad. And indeed, he went straight to his home state for inspiration, recalling ''rapturous moments at stadium concerts in Fresno and at basement discos in Bakersfield'' to create the fog-filled installation that was then captured in this photograph by Fernando Stangelo. We knew that Owens would give us something arresting, original and distinctly American. His reference to the band Kiss and tips on what a man can do to make his masculinity ''pop,'' below, are just brilliant bonuses. Where did you get the idea for this T? Fog has become one of my favorite motifs because of its cheap, ambiguous mysticism. It's shamelessly corny but undeniably pretty. Don't we all dream of being a sweat-soaked Gene Simmons from Kiss, circa 1977, drooling blood in a swirling fog during a gloriously heroic guitar solo under a spotlight in a cape? Or is that just me?

MAYBE a year ago -- or was it longer? -- Prabal Gurung answered Demi Moore's Twitter post with his own. Until then, Mr. Gurung, an up-and-coming designer who had started his company two years ago, had been on the Twitter fence. He didn't know what it was, and, as he said, ''it seemed too much about yourself.'' But after replying to Ms. Moore, he quickly gained 500 followers. He has more than 32,600 followers, and as he calculated the payoff from the social media network, says, ''It's a business.'' It has helped him build his brand. I had come down to Mr. Gurung's small studio on West 38th Street to preview his spring collection, something I love doing but seem to have less and less time for, perhaps because I'm tweeting. I'm awfully busy, but so was Mother Hubbard.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Where Manners Go Missing,'' Sept. 6: Perhaps some of the bad behavior at events like the United States Open has been learned from the constant, often irrelevant, chatter -- some might say blather -- of the television commentators who seem to think we are more interested in their opinions and anecdotes than we are in simply watching and listening to the game and, like the players, hearing that clarifying and satisfying smack of ball against gut. Peter Miller

MILLIKEN--Gloria W.,Housing Advocate, Philanthropist, a New Yorker for 50 years, worked tirelessly to prevent homelessness and injustice. With her late husband, Seth M. Milliken, she co-founded, Housing Conservation Coordinators in 1969 to serve the Clinton neighborhood. Gloria established Eviction Intervention Services in 1984 to serve Manhattan's Eastside. In 1986, she founded the New York Women's Foundation to support programs for women and girls. Born in 1922, in Trinidad, W.I., Gloria W. Milliken died of natural causes in Seattle on September 4. She is survived by her sons, Arthur Knapp, in Redmond, WA., and Ashly Knapp in Seattle, WA., their wives, four grandchildren, and many nieces and nephews. Donations may be made to New York Women's Foundation, Eviction Intervention Services, or Housing Conservation Coordinators. Memorial services are not yet scheduled and will be held in Seattle and New York City.

Catching a wave with a royal clan of surfer outlaws. Christian Fletcher packs boxes in the warehouse of Astrodeck, the surf accessories company his parents own in San Clemente, Calif. He wears baggy jeans and Nike skate shoes. His tattooed arms poke out of a dingy white T-shirt. The back of his head is tattooed with a large skull. His son, Greyson Thunder Fletcher, helps.
FRIEDMAN--Paul J. September 11, 2001 on Flight 11. Loved yesterday, today, tomorrow, always. Mom and Family

Al Qaeda spent roughly half a million dollars to destroy the World Trade Center and cripple the Pentagon. What has been the cost to the United States? In a survey of estimates by The New York Times, the answer is $3.3 trillion, or about $6.6 million for every dollar Al Qaeda spent planning and executing the attacks. While not all of the costs have been borne by the government -- and some are still to come -- this total equals one-fifth of the current national debt. Costs are broken down here under three main categories: direct damage, shown in blue; the two wars that followed (assuming both can be linked to the attacks), in yellow; and other types of response, in gray. Experts differ on some of these numbers, as well as what should be included in a tally. Here, no attempt has been made to account for some of the imponderables: For example, are oil prices higher because of the Iraq war? But it is clear that it was the nation's response, rather than the damage from the attacks, that accounts for the bulk of the cost. Based on E.P.A. guidelines used to evaluate new regulations. Current guidelines suggest the value of life is around $8 million, but estimates vary widely

KAUFMAN--Hyman E.,89, of Kings Point, NY and Palm Beach, FL, passed away on September 7, 2011. He was predeceased by his beloved wife, Ruth, with whom he shared 62 years of marriage. He is survived by two sons, Dr. Allen M. Kaufman (wife Elizabeth), Kenneth C. Kaufman (wife Dana), grandson David and sister Frances Edelson. He served in World War II as a sergeant in the U.S. Army Air Corps. Post war, he founded and headed the highly successful Newport Tire & Rubber Company for nearly sixty years. Hyman remained extremely active in the company, working with his son Kenneth, until his illness in 2009. His philanthropy included the UJA Federation. A private service was held on Friday, September 9, 2011, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

In his revelatory memoir, ''Drama'' (HarperCollins, $27), John Lithgow, the consummate character actor, talks about infidelity, Oedipal striving and the awfulness of acceptance speeches. There are many admissions in the book, most notably that in the 1970s you had eight affairs with different theater co-stars (including the ''incandescent'' Bergman muse Liv Ullmann) while married to your first wife. You likened yourself then to a ''rampaging elephant.'' How hard was it for you to reveal the affairs? Of course they were difficult to write about, and I was very ambivalent about whether to press ahead. But I made a decision: Either I'm going to write an honest book or a dishonest book. And I thought it was sort of dishonest to leave those moments out. I have good friends who read the book and said, ''My God, 90 percent of this I didn't know about.''

An article on Aug. 21 about a visit to Russia by Kim Jong-il, the North Korea leader, misstated the history of the Kremlin's diplomatic recognition of South Korea and reduction of economic and military subsidies to North Korea. Official diplomatic ties with South Korea were established on Sept. 30, 1990, by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union -- not by Boris N. Yeltsin, who succeeded Mr. Gorbachev as president of Russia after the 1991 collapse of the Soviet Union.

Scott Sternberg: Ask him about his childhood troll collection, his penchant for old Time Life tomes or his worship of baked goods -- but please don't ask the Band of Outsiders designer to expound on his personal style. ''That's such a magazine question,'' he says with a groan. Like the cool subversions of men's and women's preppy classics his fast-growing label is known for (the first BOO store opens in Tokyo this winter), Sternberg's L.A. home is a playful amalgam of vintage references and bright color combinations with a winsome splash of naïveté.

Tim Coppens's first complete men's collection is a wonder not just of technical proficiency - Coppens was formerly the design director of Ralph Lauren's futuristic sportswear line, RLX - but also of economy. Coppens, a Belgian-born Royal Academy of Fine Arts grad, has no office, no employees and he's financing his 45-piece collection by himself. The design references are varied. They include a spit and polish riff on the leather jackets and baggy sweats of the Paris banlieues and also a curious repurposing of a Persian Farahan rug, which Coppens chopped up to form the back of a leather-sleeved varsity jacket. Characteristically, that jacket is assembled with almost clinical precision, but the carpet segment is left frayed on the bottom - an inspired touch. ''I don't want to be brand-marked as a technical designer,'' Coppens says. ''I want to make beautiful collections with classic fabrics. But the technical aspect gives me a good starting point.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
BENDIXEN--Birgitte, MD. Esteemed and compassionate Neurologist, courageous and noble human being. I have lost a friend. Charlotte Malasky, MD

KRAMER--Irving M.,93. Former judge of the City of New York and Veteran of World War II. Beloved and devoted husband of Elayne for 58 years, loving father of Howard, and Paula and Jeff Weiss, adored "Gramps" to Melissa and Eli who gave him so much joy, and loving brother to Shirley Goldstein. A man of wisdom and integrity, he will be missed beyond measure. Funeral Sunday, September 11, 12:30pm, Gutterman's Funeral Home (in Parkside Building), 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, NY, 11234.

The MyCar is a Smart-sized, two-seat electric vehicle with an international pedigree to match its manufacturer's outsize ambitions. Designed by Giorgetto Giugiaro, one of the auto industry's most famous stylists, the MyCar was originally intended for a manufacturer based in Hong Kong. But the diminutive E.V. is now scheduled to be produced by GreenTech Automotive, based in Mississippi, and shipped to Denmark for European distribution later this year. The MyCar project grew yet another wrinkle this month. Terry McAuliffe, GreenTech's chairman and the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said the car's hybrid and electric drivetrains would be built not at the brand's Chinese joint-venture plant - currently under construction in Inner Mongolia - but in Mississippi, a distinct reversal of the usual flow of manufactured goods.

With a Kermit-green ethos and paperwork-free, right-around-the-corner rentals, car-sharing schemes like Zipcar have built a loyal following among auto-less urbanites and college students, customers that Zipcar refers to as Zipsters. Now one of the biggest names in car rentals is rolling out some new competition. Hertz's first attempt at car-sharing, Connect by Hertz, has been replaced by a new service called Hertz on Demand. The new brand introduces several appealing features aimed at both Zipsters and traditional rental car customers. First: no enrollment or membership fees. With Hertz, if you don't use a car, you don't pay - perfect for those new to car-sharing, and car owners who want the convenience of car-share type rentals away from home. Hertz on Demand also offers one-way rentals, including from New York to area airports, and from New York to Washington and Philadelphia.

Fifteen years ago, ''Primary Colors'' meant politics, in the form of the novel written anonymously by Joe Klein. But with the United States primary season on the horizon, the phrase has taken on another meaning: bright pants in sizzling shades that are on offer for more than vacation wear.
The Trend Wide-brimmed hats are more mysterious than ministerial this season, thanks to Lanvin and Dior Homme.

Almost 10 years ago, on New Year's Day 2002, Sir Alex Ferguson believed he had finally retired from the greatest job in English soccer: manager of the most legendary sporting club of all, Manchester United. Ferguson, who had already achieved everything he could in the game he lived for, had celebrated his 60th birthday the day before. Now he was at home, taking a nap after a long lunch, when his wife, Cathy, kicked his foot to wake him up. When he opened his eyes, Cathy was standing in front of him backed by his three adult sons. ''We've decided you're not retiring,'' she said. And that was that. This incident is remarkable for a couple of reasons. For one, it disproved the most indelible rule of sport - that there is no such thing as a second act, still less an encore. You have to know when to quit. In the decade since he withdrew his notice of retirement, Ferguson has renewed and enhanced his club's status as the most valuable sporting brand in the world, and eclipsed all younger pretenders. More important, the incident is perhaps the only recorded occasion in which Ferguson, the embodiment of both an irresistible force and an immovable object, has allowed himself to be told what to do. Cathy, his childhood sweetheart and wife of 45 years, had her reasons: ''When he's under your feet, it's a nuisance,'' she has said. ''If he's here too long, he gets in my road.''

MARGO MARTINDALE Mags Bennetton ''Justified'' More than any of the other characters on ''Justified,'' Mags Bennett embodies the title of the show. In the purest sense of the word, she is justified -- justified in poisoning, maiming and manipulating kinfolk and friends, often with her trademark and toxic homemade applejack. How are her actions any different (you can almost hear her think) from those of the mining companies -- the ones that have poisoned, maimed and manipulated everyone she dearly loves? Didn't she learn from the masters? Any great actress could make this character frightening. But Margo Martindale is beyond great in the role: she is rare. She forces you to understand Mags--andthen,withoutrealizingyou'redoingit,torootforher.PATTON OSWALT
Manly bags for the weekend warrior.

Steelers at Ravens Sunday, 1 p.m. Line: Ravens by 2 One of the N.F.L.'s fiercest rivalries has become ''The Newlywed Game.'' Both Ben Roethlisberger and Joe Flacco got married in the summer in what, with a little creative planning, could have been an awesome dual ceremony: Roger Goodell presiding, DeMaurice Smith playing the organ, Ray Rice as ring bearer. Matrimony may have a mellowing effect on the two signal callers, particularly Roethlisberger; the already-mellow Flacco's gift registry was at Crate & Barrel, so while he still lacks a Super Bowl ring, he has all the napkin rings he could possibly need.

Uninspired by offers to clone their hit Chicago restaurant Alinea in locations near and far-flung, the celebrated chef Grant Achatz and his partner, Nick Kokonas, decided to open a restaurant where the entire concept changes every three months. ''We thought it would be really exciting to pinpoint a very thematic menu every time,'' Achatz says. For its fi rst three months, Next, which opened in April, had as its theme Paris in 1906. Now, its Tour of Thailand off ers a ''highly manipulated'' pad thai and panang curry. Adjacent to Next is Aviary, their equally imaginative bar, where an Old-Fashioned is served in the form of a spherical ice cube, then broken open with a slingshot. ABBY AGUIRRE

Some things are obvious: the Capitol Hill police armed with assault rifles, standing on the Capitol steps; concrete barricades blocking the once-grand entrances to other federal buildings; the surface-to-air missile battery protecting the White House; the National Archives security guards, almost as old as the Declaration of Independence enshrined inside, slowly waving a magnetic wand over all who enter. But most of the post-9/11 security measures have simply been embedded in the landscape and culture of the nation's capital. From the reflecting pool at the foot of the Capitol to the reflecting pool in front of the Lincoln Memorial, government cameras take pictures of citizens, who smile for Big Brother and snap their own pictures of the government cameras. In the $561 million underground Capitol visitors center, completed in 2008, people clutching gallery passes from a senator's or representative's office are funneled through magnetometers, to witness a secure Congress in its sealed chambers.

An article last Sunday about Fiasco Theater, a troupe known for its productions of Shakespeare's ''Cymbeline,'' misattributed a quotation about ''Two Gentlemen of Verona.'' It was Noah Brody, a member of the troupe, who said it ''was maybe not Shakespeare's greatest,'' not Ben Steinfeld, another Fiasco actor. The article also misstates how many roles Mr. Brody plays in ''Cymbeline.'' He principally plays Imogen's husband, but he also portrays other characters. The article also misstates in which play Jessie Austrian, another Fiasco member, made her Broadway debut. It was ''Lend Me a Tenor,'' not ''The Importance of Being Earnest.''

FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel talks to female travelers about the conventional wisdom that it's harder for single women to travel than single men, and finds that sometimes women have advantages that men don't.

While most New Yorkers spend their time avoiding pigeons, Andrew Garn spends his getting as close as possible. Mr. Garn, a freelance photographer, began taking pictures of the birds in the fall of 2007, an obsession that led to a mixed-media exhibition at A. M. Richard Fine Art Gallery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in 2008, complete with a coop of live pigeons on a simulated rooftop. Growing up in Manhattan, Mr. Garn said, he was ''strongly ambivalent'' about pigeons. ''I always thought they were kind of gross and they poop everywhere,'' he said. But once he began handling them and observing them at close range, the subtle beauty of intricate feather patterns, color variations and prehistoric feet struck him.

Two guys meet in a bar. It's an awful place. The music is terrible, and they are the only people in it with any sense of style. One is 6-foot-2, dark and dazzling. The other is just as tall and good-looking, but with yellow hair and a droll expression. They blow out of the bar and discover they both live not only on the same street but also in the same building. ''Somehow we were meant to meet,'' said Ingar Dragset, the darker half of the Scandinavian art duo Elmgreen and Dragset. Since that chance encounter in Copenhagen in 1994, when he and Michael Elmgreen became intimates, they have forged a collaborative career that has survived the breakup of their personal relationship and brought them increasing notoriety on an international stage.
The Getting Started column on Aug. 14, about tips on hiring a moving company, misspelled the surname of the owner of Steinway Moving and Storage. He is James Benatti, not Benati.

Outside, the desert sky had been darkened by a sandstorm. In the tent, an Army officer pulled up a chair. It was early in the invasion of Iraq, late March 2003. With the war postponed on account of weather, there was time to talk. As I remember, the officer was a lieutenant, wary of reporters, but squirming with curiosity. ''Sir,'' he said. ''I wonder if I could ask you something about New York.''

You have probably heard it said that there is no such thing as a bad question. That's not true; of course there is such a thing as a bad question. But the upside of that is that there is such a thing as a good question.People sometimes ask me, ''How do I know if my question is a good question?''''Good question,'' I reply, setting them on a spiral of positive feedback. A good question is, by definition, a question. You cannot just take a statement and raise the pitch at the end. Sometimes people will say ''Might it not be said that statement-statement-statement?'' or ''How would you respond were someone to say statement-statement- statement?'' You can't just take a statement and dress is up in a question's clothes, like the Little Rascals dressing up as a grown-up to get into a movie.

Fashion's Night Out marked its third year on Thursday with an extensive turnout. Fifth Avenue suggested Times Square on New Year's Eve. Some celebrity guests of stores were chased by hundreds of fashionistas, bringing traffic to a standstill. Angela Missoni (1) popped up at Target, Sixth Avenue and 42nd. Many stores had live models in the windows, including Bendel (4), Tiffany (5), Bergdorf's (6) and, at Barneys, Carine Roitfeld and her signature eyes (10). A fan (2) hoped to present a trophy to Anna Wintour, the founder of this spotlight on fashion. Terry Lundgren, Macy's president, and his wife, Tina, toured the scene by car (3), while the store celebrated Lagerfeld. Vuitton's window (9) had 1,000 identical dolls. Lord & Taylor attracted throngs, including Brendan Hoffman, the store's president, and Ivanka Trump (7), the designer of a handbag and shoe line. On the first floor, even the young men were getting facials. At Saks (8), the elevators were packed.

An entangled motorcycle chain may seem more highway hazard than design inspiration, but not for Jane Carr, the English designer who turned the twisted metal into a vivid neckerchief for her new men's accessories line. Carr based the collection, Rebel Rebel, on James Dean and his boy toys, with brake-pedal grids, road signs and even an image of the icon himself printed on scarves and pocket squares. Gentlemen, start your engines. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Telluride, Colo., July 10, 2011 The brave girl in the photograph is my 20-year old daughter, Anna. My younger daughter, Lolly, who is 15, also went for a ride, and of course, I had to follow. The swing is along a hike to the summit of Ajax Peak, at about 11,500 feet. We dangled from an aerial tram cable that was erected around 1910 and connects two old gold mines on opposing mountainsides. You don't contemplate, you just go.CINDY STEUART, Bethesda, Md.

FOR the Bulgarian-born shoe designer Gio Metodiev of Gio Diev, seven-inch heels are not the only prerequisite for seductive footwear. ''It's really not only about height anymore,'' said Mr. Metodiev, who shares a factory in northern Italy with Manolo Blahnik. ''You can make a statement without having to be sky high'' (the color blocked sandals pictured here, notwithstanding). Gio Diev's latest 30-piece offering will be unveiled this month in Paris at the accessory trade show Première Classe. The designer's meticulous construction (his mother road tests each new style) and intuitive sense of what strong women want have already made fans of the actresses Emily Rossum and Rose Byrne. His dream feet, though? ''Gwyneth Paltrow's.'' SARAH SCIRE

COLE--Jean Pardee, age 90, died in Chesterfield, MO on August 29, 2011. Born in Floral Park, NY, she graduated from Cornell University in 1942 and worked at Good Housekeeping before becoming a full-time homemaker. She resided in Wimbledon, England, Bordeaux, France, Port Washington, NY, and New Canaan, CT before moving to Chesterfield in 2003. She was predeceased by her husband of 56 years, James A. Cole Jr., and her brother, Graham Frederick Pardee, and is survived by her four children: Peter (Belinda), David (Sharon), Geoffrey (Linda), and Amy (Mark Buehler), five grandchildren (Kristin, Vincent, Robert, Amanda, and Jennifer), and sister-in-law Betty O'Rourke. Private interment in Cheshire, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to either the American Lung Association or St. Jude Children's Research Hospital.

Survivors are daughters Linda Schwartz, Beverly Hills, CA, Barbara Cohen Ault, Narberth, PA, granddaughter, Kim Schwartz, Santa Barbara, CA and sister, Daphne Pugh, Jonesboro, GA.

Pool, Jr. and Diana P. Delano. Devoted grandmother of Elliott L. Pool, Victoria M. Pool, Laura F. Delano, Catherine L. Delano and Chase L. Delano. Services and interment private. French gastronomy is considered so vital to world culture that even Unesco - the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization - included it on its Intangible Cultural Heritage list last year. Now France aims to celebrate it in the new Fete de la Gastronomie . Proposed as an annual one-day nationwide feast, the inaugural gorge will take place on Sept. 23 and feature food-focused events, from a culinary team treasure hunt in Paris to public picnics in Burgundy to a multicourse outdoor banquet prepared by 10 local chefs in Avignon.
A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the new Morgan 3-Wheeler misstated the given name of the company's chairman. He is Charles Morgan, not Peter.

Lizzie Owens knows how to dress performers. From psychedelic woodsmen to hip-hop street kids, Owens, a Utah native, has costumed an array of bands, like MGMT, the Cool Kids and Brandon Flowers from the Killers. Her third and most fully conceived collection for Highland, which she started with partners and childhood friends Cramer Tolboe (above left) and Mike Franks (right), features rugged, wearable clothes for the everyday man. Highland showcases mixed prints, unconventional details (like detachable pockets) and classic outerwear in surprising materials (like a teddy-bear car coat) that combine the theatricality of her past with what appears to be a practical future. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article last Sunday about teachers' visits to the homes of students who attend the Urban Assembly School for Applied Math and Science misidentified the street in the Bronx on which the school is located. It is Bathgate Avenue, not Bainbridge Avenue.

Here's a sampling of readers' comments on the dance critic Alastair Macaulay's column about the depictions of ballet by Edgar Degas. ''Mr. Macaulay can't fairly be described as an ordinary Joe, but he's not from the New York art world either. It's usually art world experts who write about painting and sculpture -- and sometimes they do a good job. But I found it very refreshing to listen to Mr. Macaulay as he brought his extraordinary eye to Degas's work.''

My partner and I are public school teachers, which limits our travel time to Thanksgiving and Christmas weeks, the third weeks in February and April and the summer. I have been told that Provence in summer is too crowded and too hot. Does it make sense to go in February or April? I am an artist and would want to see the art museums. Leslie Sills, Boston

THE unofficial mascot for Alexa Chung's second collection for Madewell has to be the black and gold palm-tree print that shows up on pajama-inspired pieces and looks like a polka dot from a distance. Ms. Chung, who wears the print in the line's new ad, drew the palm by hand. ''I sketch so much in meetings,'' she said. ''The Madewell team insisted.'' Madewell loves Ms. Chung's scribbles so much that they published Magaxine, a small 'zine, full of them. ''You know me,'' she said. ''I'm obsessed with polka dots and Peter Pan collars, British things like that, so they're all in there, too.'' JANE HERMAN

FROST--William Lee. William Lee Frost (84 years old), Chairman of the Lucius N. Littauer Foundation, passed away on September 7th, 2011. Born in Larchmont, New York to Charles and Eva Frost, he graduated Bayside High School and served in the Navy during World War II before attending Harvard College (1947), Yale Law School (1951), and the Harvard Graduate School of Public Administration (1958). He entered the State Department in 1952 and served as a Foreign Service Officer in Belgrade, Salzburg, and Bad Godesberg. Returning to New York City in 1959 due to the illness of his first wife, Judith, daughter of Charlotte and Lawrence E. Spivak, he re-entered legal practice specializing in management and investments until later becoming President of the Lucius N. Littauer Foundation. Always interested in health, he served as a member of the Public Health Council of New York State's Department of Health under Governor Carey, and as Chairman (1985-87), Treasurer, and Director of the New York Heart Association. He was also a Trustee of the Brearley School, the Collegiate School, Marlboro College, and Radcliffe College. As a student at Harvard, he was the founding President of Hillel and later, as a graduate, became a member of the Visiting Committee, Honorary Curator, and President of Judaica at Harvard University Library. He also served as a member of the Visiting Committee to the Harvard Divinity School. He was Chair of the New York State Archives Partnership Trust (1994-97) and on the Board of the Croton Aqueduct. He was also the President and a Director of the Jewish Telegraphic Agency, and a Trustee of the P.E.F. Israel Endowment Funds, Inc. His hobbies including rambling, whether around Manhattan, the Rockies, or Scotland, and often singing as he strolled along to whomever crossed his path. Predeceased by his first wife, Judith, he is survived by their daughters Rebecca (Mohammed) and Hannah, as well as by his wife Susan and their children Abigail (John) and Robert (Navah) and five grandchildren, Benjamin, Aviva, Cipa, Zamira and Ivry. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to one of the institutions mentioned above.

Norton, $25), the young classical composer Joshua Cody outstrips the weepy conventions of a cancer memoir by mixing aggressive, intelligent prose with shocking confessions, like the time he had cocaine-fueled sex with a stranger after chemotherapy. War correspondents cover the dubious comestibles that sustain them in ''Eating Mud Crabs in Kandahar'' (University of California, $28), and it's not the stuff of an A. J. Liebling story.

KIRWIN--Glenn Davis 11/1960-9/11/2001 On a bright warm sunny morning 10 years ago today, our father, husband, son, brother, & uncle, went to work and never returned. SVP Cantor Fitzgerald, Glenn was high above NYC in the north tower of the WTC. All he did wrong that day was to report to work; instead he became a victim of terrorism. He never had the opportunity to say goodbye. As the days, weeks, months and years have passed we have all learned to deal with our loss and grief and move slowly forward with our lives. Every 9/11 we gather to honor him and remember how caring an individual he was and how important a presence in our life he is. We miss him terribly and continue to mourn his loss everyday. We will never forget.

Stella Tennant - mother, model and David Lasnet's wife - had come to pick us up from the train station, so the first time I saw David I was standing on the steps of their grand 18th-century house in the Scottish Borders, and he was waving from a tractor. Was he moving logs? Mowing the lawn? No, he was efficiently transporting everything we'd need for a picnic across the lovely grounds. I had come with my children, because naturally, never having met any of us, Lasnet had invited them to stay, too. The Lasnet family already comprises four children, so - he seemed to suggest - what difference would two more make? When we arrived, there was also a family of five staying (old friends of theirs from Chile), so that was nine kids under the age of 13, and this appeared to bother the Lasnet-Tennants not at all. A small campfire had been set up by a pond, and next to it they'd erected a calico tent carpeted with random tartan blankets. Inside, the Lasnet children - Marcel, 13, Cecily, 11, Jasmine, 9, and Iris, 6 - were rolling around laughing, while the adults cooked risotto patties wrapped in bacon.

Last week I attended a wonderful presentation given by Keith Devlin, a Stanford University mathematician and NPR's "Math Guy," on "Fibonacci & the Golden Ratio: Exposed Common Myths and Fascinating Truths" as part of the public lecture series "Math Encounters" organized by the Museum of Mathematics. The golden ratio or phi (1.61803...) is a fascinating number that we have explored before in the puzzles, Moonlighting Triangles and The Golden Ratio Treasure. The ratio, which is approached to greater and greater precision by two adjacent numbers of the related Fibonacci sequence (1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13...), has become part of popular culture, attaining almost mystical status. Images and video clips like the one above abound on the Internet, connecting the golden ratio and the Fibonacci sequence with art, architecture, cosmology, biology, aesthetics, poetry, music and many other fields. But how much of all this is true and how much is myth? Professor Devlin, who recently published a scholarly book titled The Man of Numbers: Fibonacci's Arithmetic Revolution, examined the evidence with a scientific eye and separated the wheat from the chaff. I present some of his findings below - in the form of questions to you, of course.

TORONTO - "Don't be fooled by the smoke," James Benning told a sold-out audience at the Toronto International Film Festival screening of his latest film "Twenty Cigarettes." A collection of living portraits, in which 20 smokers, all friends of his, face the camera for the time it takes to consume a cigarette, it is both an homage to Andy Warhol's fabled screen tests and a quintessential film for Mr. Benning, 68, a giant of American experimental cinema whose conceptually minimalist works tend to open up vast spaces for reflection.

"I'm not reinventing the wheel," was how Eugene Souleiman introduced the sleek, simple ponytail at Tommy Hilfiger, before adding, "But for Tommy, I am. Because Tommy does that healthy, American girl with bouncy hair, and I'm doing something very clean, very sharp, and very chic." This shift from previous seasons (it was Souleiman who was behind those healthy, bouncy heads of hair at the fall 2011 show) was implemented through flat ironing strands with the help of Wella's Shine Finish, which he called "liquid gold," then tucking hair back behind the ears before pulling it into a low ponytail tied with a thin black elastic. To achieve a graphic but not hard, product-y look, Souleiman squirted a bit of Wella Professionals Stay Essential Finishing Spray on a brush blush before running it over the surface of the hair to smooth down flyaways. As it turns out, it takes almost as much work to not reinvent the wheel as it does to invent it; as he noted, "It's so easy to do something really wacky - I could do that with my eyes shut. But to think of something that has a subtlety and beauty to it, it's so much harder."

TORONTO - Not even the director Guy Maddin is certain how to classify a Guy Maddin movie. The Winnipeg-born filmmaker is known for his experimental, black-and-white, sometimes silent, often strange films that tackle issues in a surreal way. He delivers another puzzler with "Keyhole," a film starring Jason Patric that could be described as a gangster ghost drama, although it is loosely based on Homer's "Odyssey." Mr. Maddin offers an explanation of the film and gives some insight into his creative process.

Arun Chaudhary, the first official White House videographer, has written a book about the experience, to be published by Times Books, a division of Henry Holt and Company. Mr. Chaudhary, who was hired in 2007 to work on the Obama campaign, followed Mr. Obama to the White House and recently left the staff. His book will tell the story of what it means "to follow the president and be available 24/7 to record history; to be a video Boswell, as it were; how to use art, media and politics as a prism to capture history and record the quotidian moments even of the president," a statement from the publisher said. It was the architect Richard Neutra's rigorous West Coast houses that inspired the beauty look at Derek Lam - that and the color yellow. Both may be odd inspirations for hair and makeup, but that's what makes them so welcome. Better yellow and geometry than another repeat reference, though the look wasn't totally different from last time around. "This collection's an evolution from last season, not a complete change," Orlando Pita said. "The hair has that feeling too." This meant a low side-parted ponytail instead of hair pulled back at the crown without a visible barrette. "Clean, simple lines," is how Pita described the look he created using Phyto Volume Active Mousse, blow drying with a T3 featherweight Luxe, then sealing the ends with Phyto 7 and a T3 Single Pass iron. The hair was then scraped back into a ponytail with a part over the right eye. Pita used Phyto Finishing Spray and a little Shine Defining Wax to "make it perfectly done." Nails were painted Estée Lauder's Nude Attitude, but it was the eyes that went a little wild. Tom Pecheux (Estée Lauder's creative makeup director) explained the Neutra connection by making references to large windows that "let the outdoor weather into the house," which became a ray of yellow from Estée Lauder Rain Boots shadow on the lid highlighted with Cyber Copper brown shimmer all the way to the brow bone. Citron Kiss lip gloss was the final step. Canary colored in the vial, it's the perfect way to warm up another lip color or let the light in for spring.

When a beloved pet is found to have cancer, many owners aren't sure whether they should pursue aggressive treatments. John Rennie, the former editor of Scientific American, faced this decision when brain and lung tumors were diagnosed in his dog. He chose to give his dog chemotherapy treatment, an issue he wrote about recently in the online magazine Txchnologist. One of the surprises he encountered: Chemotherapy, while it creates many challenges for dogs, is often less grueling than it is for humans.

Ronald Carletta has spent nearly 20 years at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. In September 2001, he was a supervisory auditor at the agency's New York office in the World Trade Center. Ten years after terrorist attacks destroyed that office, Mr. Carletta has become a branch chief for the Division of Clearing and Intermediary Oversight. He remains in the New York office, which has relocated a few blocks from its former home.

Anthony Bourdain, the celebrity chef, author and reality TV star, will acquire books for Ecco, an imprint of HarperCollins, the publisher said on Monday. Mr. Bourdain has been given a line of books that is expected to release three to five titles each year, which Ecco said in a statement would "reflect his remarkably eclectic tastes." Daniel Halpern, the president and publisher of Ecco, said that Mr. Bourdain has been an informal adviser to him for about 10 years, a period during which Mr. Bourdain's own books were published by Ecco. "His intuition has been unerring - suggesting such authors as Ferran Adria and Fergus Henderson," Mr. Halpern said in an e-mail. "Now he's becoming one of us, sort of."

Hey, I'm directin' here! I'm directin' here! He's an excellent driver, a two-time Academy Award winner for "Kramer Vs. Kramer" and "Rain Man," a magnet for New York taxis (at least in the guise of Ratso Rizzo from "Midnight Cowboy") and now, finally, Dustin Hoffman has become a film director. On Monday, production began on "Quartet," Mr. Hoffman's feature-directing debut, its press representatives announced. The film, which is expected to shoot for nine weeks in Buckinghamshire, England, stars Tom Courtenay (whose previous films include "Doctor Zhivago" in 1965), Billy Connolly ("Mrs. Brown") and Pauline Collins ("Shirley Valentine") as residents of a home for retired opera singers. Their annual plans for a fund-raising concert, held on Verdi's birthday, are disrupted by the arrival of a down-on-her-luck grande dame (played by Maggie Smith, the "Downton Abbey," "Gosford Park" and "Harry Potter" star). The screenplay for "Quartet" is by Ronald Harwood, the Academy Award-winning screenwriter of "The Pianist" and "The Diving Bell and the Butterfly," and adapted from his play of the same title. Mr. Hoffman is also a producer on the film, which is financed by BBC Films, DCM Productions and Decca. An American distributor and release date for "Quartet" were not immediately announced.

3:38 p.m. | Updated Most attention on sea ice comes in early September, when the sheath of drifting, cracking floes cloaking the Arctic Ocean, warmed by nonstop sunlight and moved by summer winds, reaches its annual minimum. For a reminder of just how dynamic the ice is, click on the video above, which I shot near the North Pole in March, 2003, while standing with Tim Stanton, an expert on ice and oceans at the Naval Postgraduate School, next to a developing ridge where two floes were colliding. (We were drifting around 400 yards an hour at the time; all the sound is the crunching and huffing of the ice.)

That Indians have migrated far and wide for economic opportunities is well known. Yet, stories about specific communities of Indians making a home in a distant part of the world seem to have an enduring appeal.Last week, for instance, Twitter and Facebook accounts among readers in India and across the diaspora were abuzz after The New York Times published this story about a community of Sikhs who have migrated to northern Italy to work in its dairies.The story was only the latest in a series of such stories about the various ethnic Indian communities found in virtually all big, and many small, countries. The Times wrote about the Sikhs of Canada in this 2000 article. And let's not stop at Sikhs. Tunku Varadarajan, the American journalist who himself was born in India, wrote about the Gujaratis who dominate the motel business in much of the United States in this long 1999 article in The New York Times Sunday Magazine.

"Am I done?" Joan Smalls asked Orlando Pita backstage at Diane von Furstenberg as he fixed her teased out beehive. "Done," he said as she coyly examined his curly hair. "Done done?" Smalls asked knowing there may be yet another round of Orlando Pita hair spray to keep the look in place. Surprisingly, it wasn't the '60s that inspired the up-do that Pita referred to as "Kim Novak-y," rather Von Furstenberg's starting point for the collection: "New Beginnings." For makeup, this meant James Kaliardos used M.A.C. products for a face inspired by the land where it all began: Africa. The idea was to highlight the planes and tones of the face using an earthy (literally) palette of eight Crème Color Base shades, including Ochre, Pale Peach and Dark Brown. The inner and outer corner of the eye was highlighted with a khaki variation, while the middle of the lid was done in white or yellow. There was no lip, just as nails were kept clean, coated with only Sally Hansen's Hard as Nails. Kaliardos described the ingenuity of the woman who inspired him, "No matter her economic situation, she finds a way to look beautiful- regal even.''

Sometimes all a New Yorker wants is a little peace and quiet. And on the extended weekends of Sept. 15-18 and Sept. 22-25, it will be available, in a very carefully fashioned version, at various locations around Lower Manhattan, as part of "To a Great City," the second installment of "Stillspotting Nyc," a two-year multidisciplinary program by the Guggenheim Museum. Organized by David van der Leer, the museum's associate curator in architecture and urban studies, and Sarah Malaika, a project associate, "To a Great City" is a collaboration between the Estonian composer Arvo Part and the Norwegian architecture firm Snohetta. It creates urban soundscapes in five downtown locations that, according to the museum's press release, "quietly celebrate the city, 10 years after the Sept. 11 attacks." The locations include a green labyrinth created by the Battery Conservancy, an underground chamber at the Governors Island National Monument, and spaces in landmark skyscrapers that are normally inaccessible to the public. For a $10 admission fee, visitors will be given a map, directions and a one-day pass to each of the "stillspots" for a self-guided tour, which takes about three hours; reservations are recommended. In conjunction with the project, visitors can identify and map their own favorite quiet spots as part of "Create Your Own Stillspot" at stillspotting.guggenheim.org.

Here are a few extras from my interview with the billionaire owner of the Washington Redskins, Daniel Snyder. We spoke on the afternoon of Aug. 22, just after he came off the field from watching his team practice at their Ashburn, Va., headquarters. Snyder was very eager to talk about the initiative he'd embarked upon to install solar panels atop FedEx field. He sent assistants scurrying about to bring in renderings of what the field will look like after NRG, the energy company, installs them. (NRG gets some very prominent signage at FedEx  for its efforts.) He seemed less eager to discuss the general antipathy that has greeted his ownership from the media, fans and even a beloved Redskins Hall of Fame Running back. Throughout the interview, he kept glancing uncomfortably at Tony Wyllie, the Redskins' head of communications, who was sitting in. I honestly couldn't tell whether he was shocked that I was pursuing that particular line of questioning, or if he was so insulated that he didn't understand the depth and breadth of the criticism of the decisions he's made as owner.

BUCKLEY--Richard D. Dear Rick, Happy Birthday to my beloved brother. Spencer and I miss you terribly. We are waiting for you to come around the corner so we can see your big smile, hear your voice, hug and kiss you, and feel your eternal optimism. Today your life is celebrated. Thank you for being you and for having such a positive impact on our lives. We love you, Dana and Spenee

WASHINGTON - After helping President Lyndon B. Johnson pass his Great Society programs in the 1960s, Larry O'Brien gave his memoir a humble, and prescient, title: ''No Final Victories.'' Mr. O'Brien's observation has come sharply into focus, in Washington and on the presidential campaign trail. The accelerating debates over taxes, spending and economic policy amount to the most fundamental challenge yet to the achievements of Johnson and President Franklin D. Roosevelt a generation earlier.

Pop quiz. How long do you think a fresh new link lasts online before people stop clicking on it? The answer: on average, just shy of 3 hours. If you ask the same question about a news-related link, the answer is a measly 5 minutes. According to new research by Bit.ly, the URL shortening service, most links shared online don't live very long and quickly get lost amid the noise of our digitally distracted universe. The research found that links across all genres, from comedy to news, follow the same pattern, receiving an initial burst of attention, which quickly peaks, and then the link essentially dies.

Jean Salvemini wrapped her arms around a pair of headless mannequins -- one in a wedding dress, the other in a suit and tie -- and made a fashion statement: ''You know, we really don't have a glamorous address,'' she said, ''but we do glamorous work.'' Mrs. Salvemini, along with her sister, Mary Ipekcian, owns Sorelle Tailoring, a sort of mom-and-pop store to the fashion industry that is as well-known to Ralph Lauren as it is to Nola Solomon, a 24-year-old freelance writer in Manhattan who arrived Wednesday with a skirt to be shortened ($25) and five pairs of jeans to be hemmed ($13 to $15 each depending on the amount of handiwork involved).

PBS's Friday newsmagazine ''Need to Know'' is turning to a rotating group of well-known guest hosts for the next several months, as it seeks a new permanent anchor in the wake of Alison Stewart's departure on Friday. First up is Scott Simon, the host of NPR's ''Weekend Edition Saturday,'' who will fill in this week. Others to follow are Maria Hinojosa, the former ''Now on PBS'' correspondent who reports occasionally for ''Need to Know,'' and Ray Suarez, a senior correspondent for ''The PBS NewsHour.''

An article last Monday about religious pages on Facebook misstated the age of Rabbi Laura Baum of Congregation Beth Adam in Cincinnati, which started using social media three years ago. She is 32, not 31.

In the early days of the Cuban missile crisis, before the world knew that the cold war seemed to be sliding toward nuclear conflict, President John F. Kennedy telephoned his wife, Jacqueline, at their weekend house in Virginia. From his voice, she would say later, she could tell that something was wrong. Why don't you come back to Washington? he asked, without explanation. ''From then on, it seemed there was no waking or sleeping,'' Mrs. Kennedy recalls in an oral history scheduled to be released Wednesday, 47 years after the interviews were conducted. When she learned that the Soviets were installing missiles in Cuba aimed at American cities, she begged her husband not to send her away. ''If anything happens, we're all going to stay right here with you,'' she says she told him in October 1962. ''I just want to be with you, and I want to die with you, and the children do, too -- than live without you.''

North American moviegoers, jumping at the chance to see Gwyneth Paltrow and a host of other stars die of a horrible disease, drove ''Contagion'' to No. 1 at the weekend box office with an estimated $23 million in ticket sales. That Warner Brothers film, directed by Steven Soderbergh and made in conjunction with Participant Media, cost about $60 million to produce; an all-star cast (Kate Winslet, Matt Damon, Laurence Fishburne and Jude Law in addition to Ms. Paltrow) and strong reviews contributed to audience interest. ''The Help'' (DreamWorks Studios) was second, taking in about $8.7 million for a five-week total of $137 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. ''Warrior,'' a mixed martial arts drama from Lionsgate, was a disappointing third with about $5.6 million in ticket sales. ''The Debt'' (Focus Features) took in roughly $5 million for fourth place, lifting its two-week total to $22 million. ''Colombiana'' (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was fifth with about $4 million in ticket sales and a new three-week total of $29.8 million. On the gloomy side, ''Bucky Larson: Born to be a Star,'' a Sony comedy produced by Adam Sandler's company, took in just $1.5 million and placed far outside the top 10. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Theater owners are furious with movie studios for speeding up the release of movies on DVD and video-on-demand services. Except when they're not upset about it at all. That would seem to be the case with a new 3-D version of ''The Lion King.'' On Friday, Walt Disney Studios will release it in theaters. A lightning-fast 18 days later, new ''Lion King'' DVD and Blu-ray sets, two including 3-D versions, will arrive in stores. And theater owners, who normally get an exclusive period of about 120 days to show a film and have been forcefully protecting that privilege, are totally fine with that plan.

KEY PERFORMANCE After missing the Jets' final three preseason games because of a knee injury, Sione Pouha trotted out for the coin toss as a defensive captain. Pouha, a nose tackle, put pressure on the Cowboys' inexperienced offensive line. And he recovered a crucial fumble, falling on Tony Romo's dropped ball by the goal line in the fourth quarter. Mike DeVito, caused the fumble, but Pouha wrested it away, stalling a potential scoring drive. NOTABLE NUMBER So much for ground-and-pound. The Jets ran the ball eight times in the first half, three times in the third quarter and 16 times over all, for 45 yards, as they instead entrusted Mark Sanchez and his right arm with moving the ball downfield. Only one of the Jets' first downs came on the ground. It was a poor omen for Shonn Greene, anointed the team's primary ball-carrier and lavished with praise by Rex Ryan and his staff.

He stood by his family, friends, and colleagues through good times and bad. He made a difference in all our lives and made our world a better place. We will all miss him terribly. He was the loving father of Stephanie Robertson Saunders and her husband Donald. A cherished grandfather of Cynthia Jackson Saunders. He predeceased by his daughter Heather Merriweather Robertson. In addition he was also loved by Christopher Boyd Lemmon, Stephanie's half brother. Funeral service Friday, September 16th at 5:30pm at St. Lukes Episcopal Church in East Hampton, NY. Burial with full Military Honors at Cedar Lawn Cemetery in East Hampton. Additional services will be held in New York City and Los Angeles date to be announced. BALSAM--Sylvia, born March 15, 1916, passed away September 9, 2011. Beloved wife and lifelong friend of the late Leon Balsam. Devoted and caring mother to Michael and Barbara Balsam and Anne and Brian Terry. Adoring grammy to Lisa, Jennifer, Rebecca and Daniel and their spouses. Delighted great-grandmother of Anna and Lucy Hirsch and Sarah and Noah Solinga. A talented artist and teacher of sculpture, she will be missed and remembered with love. Donations in her memory to Temple Israel Center, White Plains would be appreciated.

SLOSS--Rosalyn (Saperstein), 91, dearly loved wife, mother and grandmother, died of a stroke on September 10, 2011. Ros was predeceased by her husband Richard with whom she traveled the world watching birds, and her beloved son David. She leaves behind her cherished daughters Virginia and Katherine, daughter-in-law Elyse Goldweber, grandchildren Sophie and Sammy Chamino, Katharine Sloss-Hartman and Gabrielle Sloss, and her brother and sister-in-law Richard and Joan Steele and sister and brother-in-law James and Elinor Schatz. Ros graduated from Russell Sage College in 1941 and received her MLS in Library Science from C.W. Post. She was a reference librarian at the Hewlett-Woodmere Public Library for 25 years, and served on the Board of The Five Town Senior Center. Ros was remarkable. A life-long Democrat possessed with an active social conscience, she was an early proponent of civil and woman's rights. She was a great clipper and sender of articles from the New York Times which she hoped would motivate her children and grandchildren. Ros loved New York City, books, theater, film, museums and traveling. She cherished friends and family who returned those feelings in kind. Donations may be made to The Five Towns Senior Center and Planned Parenthood of New York City. A private memorial service will be planned.

PATTIN--Helen Barbara (Horowitz), M.D. Beloved wife of Herbert, died peacefully after a long illness. Devoted mother of Andrew (Melissa) and Lisa (Alan). Sister of Michael (Sylvia) and Joan (Walter), cherished aunt. She was an inspiring mentor, loved by her patients and respected by her colleagues. Former staff member of Montefiore Hospital and Beth Israel North. Lived her life to the fullest with great strength, dignity and passion for the practice of medicine, the arts and antiques. She will deeply missed by her family, patients and friends. Contact family for Shiva.

KATZEN--Howard Buzz Katzen, 79, of Westport, CT and Scottsdale, AZ passed away on September 9th, surrounded by his adoring family. He had a zest for life, was a true gentleman, and loved everything he did. Loving husband to Arlene Rieger for 54 charmed years; exceptional father to Jane Katzen DeNunzio and Sue Katzen, and father-in-law to Robert DeNunzio. Born in Brooklyn to the late Julius and Margaret Katzen; brother of the late Joan Buchman. A graduate of James Madison High school in Brooklyn, NY; attended Syracuse University, was a brother in the TEP fraternity and graduated from NYU. Buzz served the US Army in the CIC; Stuttgart, Germany. Howard enjoyed a distinguished career with Xerox Corp. where he rose to Global Marketing Director from sales over his 32 years there. He retired to Scottsdale, AZ and enjoyed a second career as jazz promoter and prominent figure in the Arizona Musicfest. Loving uncle of Robbie and Brooks Sumberg, Charles and Andrea Jayson; Matthew and Melitte Buchman and Victoria Lorini and grand uncle of Jenna and Jake Sumberg and Matthew and Zachary Jayson. Buzz was extraordinary in his grace; his absence will be felt by so many. We will love, remember and miss him forever. Services Wednesday, September 14, 2pm at The Collins Funeral Home, 92 East Ave., Norwalk, CT. The family will receive at home from 7-9pm Wednesday and Thursday. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Arizona Musicfest Jazz Education Program, Arizona Musicfest, P.O. Box 5254, Carefree, AZ 85377 or Arizonamusicfest.org.

FROST--William. The Society for the Protection of Nature in Israel (SPNI) and the American SPNI mourn the passing of a true friend, William Lee Frost, who as Chairman of the Lucius N. Littauer Foundation, provided loyal and generous support for SPNI's environmental work. Our condolences to his family.

LINFIELD--Jordan L.,87. Born in 1923 in Brooklyn; died September 8, 2011, in Manhattan of complications from a fall. Jordan was a lifelong New Yorker and he served the city in many ways, including as director of Neighborhood Action Program in the John Lindsay administration. He was a proud veteran of World War II and an equally proud graduate of Townsend Harris, City College, and Columbia University, where he wrote his master's thesis on the Socialist Workers Party. He was a man of prolific talents: union organizer, editor, publisher, author of many books, Hebrew scholar and math professor. He loved the Spanish Loyalists who fought Franco, and he was confident of the survival of the Jewish people. Most of all he loved his family: his wife of 63 years, Trudy; his daughters, Deborah, who predeceased him, and Susie; his granddaughter Sarah; his sons-in-law Jay Bernstein and Eugene Scheiman; and his siblings Hadassah and David. Jordan was an extraordinary man: kind, gentle, generous, and a true intellectual; we will remember him, love him, and miss him forever. Service Monday, September 12, 11:15 at "The Riverside", 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave.

Dr. Bruce Dan, who as a leading federal researcher helped establish a link between the life-threatening disease toxic shock syndrome and the use of tampons, prompting a major shift in the way tampons are produced, died Tuesday in Baltimore. He was 64. The cause was complications of a bone marrow transplant he received last year after learning he had leukemia, said his wife, Lisa Stark, a correspondent for ABC News.

SIPHRON--Joseph R.,of New York, NY and Quogue, NY, died Sunday, September 4th. He was 78 years old. Beloved husband of 54 years to Mary John Siphron and loving father to John Siphron, Joe is survived by daughter-in-law Laura and granddaughter Elizabeth, sister Jeanne Siphron, brother David Siphron, sister-in-law Katherine Post, niece Whitney Strickler and nephew David Strickler. Born in Cincinnati, OH, Joe graduated from Yale in 1955. At Yale, he was a member of Scroll and Key, and his passion for singing led him to become both the president of the Glee Club as well as a Whiffenpoof. He went on to attend both Oxford and Yale Law School. Joe retired as a partner of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley and McCloy after 34 years with the firm. An avid amateur ornithologist, Joe traveled the world looking for exotic birds. He combined this enthusiasm with tireless fundraising for various nature organizations, and served on the boards of both the National Audubon Society and the Cornell Bird Lab. Joe was a member of the Union Club, the Quogue Beach Club, the Quogue Field Club and served on the vestry at St. James Church and on the executive committee at the Church of the Atonement in Quogue, NY. Loved and adored by his family, Joe will be remembered for his determination in all things, his deep sense of loyalty and commitment to family and friends, his quick wit, keen mind, and his enduring faith in God. A memorial service will be held at St. James Church on Madison Ave. and 71st St. in New York on Tuesday, October 25th at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to either the Wildlife Conservation Society or the Church of the Atonement.

''Boardwalk Empire,'' the Prohibition-era drama set in Atlantic City, picked up seven awards at the creative arts Emmys on Saturday, making it the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences' most-honored television program a week ahead of the prime-time awards. ''Boardwalk Empire,'' shown by HBO, won for art direction, editing, sound editing and visual effects, among other categories. HBO also received awards for the mini-series ''Mildred Pierce,'' a Lady Gaga tour special and a children's program called ''A Child's Garden of Poetry.'' The annual creative arts ceremony also recognized Justin Timberlake twice - once for guest-hosting ''Saturday Night Live'' and once for co-writing the lyrics to his ''SNL'' monologue song. Other stars who were recognized on Saturday include Gwyneth Paltrow, for her guest-star turn on ''Glee''; Jay Leno, for his car Web site JayLenosGarage.com; and Jeff Probst, for his hosting of ''Survivor.'' The ceremony will be shown on the ReelzChannel on Saturday, a day before the prime-time awards are shown live on Fox. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Donations to the American Parkinson Disease Association (www.apdaparksinson.org).

An obituary on Friday about Michael Hart, who founded Project Gutenberg, the world's oldest and largest collection of e-books, misstated Mr. Hart's source for the term replicator, which he adopted to describe how e-books would allow for the infinite reproduction of books. It comes from the television show ''Star Trek,'' not the film ''Star Wars.''

There are online dating services, and then there are location-based social services like Foursquare. A new application called Blendr combines the two, letting users cut to the chase and find someone to meet nearby, right now. After firing up the application, which is free and available for Apple iOS devices and on Facebook, users create a simple profile featuring a photo and a short description of themselves. They select several options from a long list of interests -- everything from liking tennis to being a fan of Gossip Girl. The app then shows people nearby who have also used the app recently and share similar interests.
