KEY PERFORMANCE Jake Ballard came out of Ohio State with a reputation as a blocking tight end, but he said repeatedly during training camp that he was capable of catching passes, too. Ballard proved it Sunday, catching two passes for 59 yards, including a 41-yard completion over the middle in which he ran a perfect route and pulled in the ball with a defender on his back. Replacing Kevin Boss will be difficult, but Ballard could give the Giants' offense another important element. NOTABLE NUMBER Santana Moss and Chris Cooley are bigger names, but the Redskins backup tight end Fred Davis caught five passes for 105 yards, a career high. Davis caught two passes on Washington's final scoring drive, one for 7 yards (not including a 15-yard penalty on Antrel Rolle for a late hit) and a 22-yard reception down to the Giants' 9. Three plays later, Jabar Gaffney caught a 4-yard touchdown pass.

RAY RICE rushed for 107 yards in the Ravens' 35-7 win over the Steelers. Pittsburgh's defense has allowed only two 100-yard rushing efforts in its last 51 games; Rice has both of them. MIKE TOLBERT scored all three of San Diego's touchdowns -- receptions of 1 and 19 yards and a 7-yard run -- in its 24-17 victory over Minnesota.

Federal officials have ordered a museum in Tallahassee, Florida, not to return a painting on loan from Italy because it may have been stolen by the Nazis during World War II, the head of the museum said. The authorities are working with the Italian Ministry of Culture to determine the rightful owners of the work: a 473-year-old oil painting by the Italian Renaissance artist Girolamo Romano entitled ''Christ Carrying the Cross Dragged by a Rogue.''

Could blaxploitation meet Broadway? It's an obvious question that comes up with news that Bill T. Jones, the director and choreographer, will spend three weeks next month developing ''Super Fly: The Musical'' in New York. Young African-American singers will no doubt be lining up early at Pearl Studios on Monday morning for auditions. The show, which is still in its early stages according to a spokesman, is a theatrical adaptation of the classic 1972 blaxploitation film directed by Gordon Parks, Jr.

An article on Thursday about American military casualties in the Iraq war misidentified, at one point, the month this year when 14 American troops were killed in hostilities. As correctly noted later in the article, it was June, not July.

ATWOOD--William G.,M.D., of New York and Roxbury, CT died August 6, 2011. He had suffered from Alzheimer's disease for many years. Born December 14, 1932 in Kansas City, MO, he was the son of Dr. William Goodson Atwood, Sr. and Jenette Morris Atwood. Dr. Atwood was raised in Carrollton, MO, and he received his A. B. degree, cum laude, from Harvard College in 1954 and his medical degree from the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University in 1958. Dr. Atwood maintained a private practice in dermatology in New York, and he was on the staffs of Columbia Presbyterian and Lenox Hill Hospitals until his retirement in late 1999. Besides medicine he had a wide range of interests in music, literature, Asian art and religions, world travel, squash, gardening and his beloved beagles. He was recognized as one of the world's authorities on Frederic Chopin, and he wrote three books covering the composer's compositions and life. Two works were published by Columbia University Press and the third by Yale University Press. Dr. Atwood was predeceased by his parents; his brother, Dr. Morris Atwood; and a nephew, Ronald Atwood. He is survived by his partner of thirty eight years, David Balthrop; two nieces from his brother's marriage, Rachel Huber of Milford, MI and Maria Holloway of Baltimore, MD; and six great nieces and nephews. He had been a member of the University Club and the Harvard Club in New York. Funeral services will be held Friday, September 16, 2011, at 11am at Kirkland Chapel, Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 7 W. 55th Street, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Alzheimer's Association, alz.org, would be sincerely appreciated.

Cliff Robertson, the ruggedly handsome actor who won an Oscar for ''Charly'' but found himself frozen out of jobs for almost four years after he exposed a prominent Hollywood studio boss as a forger and embezzler, died Saturday on Long Island. He was 88 and lived in Water Mill, N.Y. A son-in-law, Donald Saunders, said Mr. Robertson died at Stony Brook University Medical Center a day after his birthday.

Workers suffering from information overload, and companies drowning in the Internet-era exaflood of data? These are good problems indeed, if you are in the data storage business. In a shaky economy, companies are spending cautiously on most things, but computer storage in data centers is an exception. The most recent evidence came earlier this month, when IDC reported that sales of disk storage systems in the second quarter grew more than 10 percent, to $7.5 billion.

ZALAR--Gregory L.,M.D., 1945-2011. The Department of Dermatology of Columbia University Medical Center mourns the loss of Gregory L. Zalar, M.D., who passed away on August 30 in Logatec, Slovenia at the age of 66. Dr. Zalar was a distinguished faculty member and clinical professor of dermatology at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. In 2005, Dr. Zalar and his wife Patricia retired and moved to his ancestral family home in Logatec, Slovenia. In addition to his wife, Dr. Zalar is survived by a son, Andrej Zalar. Dr. Zalar epitomized the role of physician-educator and was a superb teacher. He made enduring contributions to our teaching programs. He was a mentor to numerous students, residents and faculty members and was beloved by his patients.

Google, continuing to seek a path into the large market in local Web advertising, announced on Thursday that it would acquire Zagat, which publishes customer-generated restaurant review guides. Google will be able to compete directly with online restaurant guides like UrbanSpoon, as well as sites like Yelp and AT&T's YellowPages.com, which offer reviews of businesses and services including restaurants. At present, Zagat offers a subscription-based Web site in addition to its city-based printed guides. In July, it ranked far below the top sites, with 238,000 users. SHELLY FREIERMAN

On a stretch of road by the crest of a hill in Logan, Utah, on Monday, a motorcycle and a BMW collided, throwing the cyclist under the car and causing the bike to burst into flames, which quickly spread to the sedan. Rather than fleeing those two flaming vehicles, a dozen bystanders rushed toward the blaze, lifted the car and pulled the injured man out by his ankle.

Lt. Col. Charles de Choiseul was not a happy man. It was September 1861, and de Choiseul, a well-educated French Creole, had been ordered to take temporary command of Maj. Chatham Roberdeau Wheat's First Special Battalion of Louisiana Infantry while Wheat recovered from a serious wound suffered at the First Battle of Bull Run. It was no routine assignment: a Virginia officer had been given the position previously, but he was unable to control the rowdy men and quit after only a few days. Now it was de Choiseul's turn to try to rein in what was known as the Tiger Battalion. He wrote a friend, "I am a victim of circumstances, not of my own will. ... Whether the Tigers will devour me, or whether I will succeed in taming them, remains to be seen."
Edward Wong travels on a trial run of the first-ever tourist cruise to the secretive authoritarian nation of North Korea.

Maybe it's back-to-school fever, but everyone I know seems besieged by pessimism. I'm distressed by water shortages, the state of the labor movement and the Somalian famine, which may needlessly kill 700,000 people this year. In a bellwether for other large financial firms, JPMorgan Chase warned that third-quarter trading revenue was likely to fall about 8 percent from a year ago, The New York Times reports. On Friday, I wrote about an organization called Little Kids Rock, which has helped to revitalize and broaden music education in more than a thousand schools by encouraging children to learn to play popular music, form bands and compose their own songs. The column sparked a little bit of a culture war: some readers were aggrieved by the idea that children should learn popular music in schools, others suggested that classical composers would love rock 'n roll. Some feared that teaching pop would "dumb down" music education, others felt it was vital to make music education more relevant to children. I'd like to clarify some misconceptions and explain why I think the program is a valuable addition, rather than a threat to the classical tradition.

Some designers this week released their inner gypsies, unveiling collections that brimmed with violently colorful, multicultural references. Some shows carried a whiff of Haiti or Hawaii, while others mined the landscapes and cultures of India and North Africa. Embracing a vagabond spirit,Thakoon Panichgul married the exoticism of Bollywood with broad hints of the American West; Donna Karan combined Haitian-inspired geometry with a dusky African palette, Duro Olowu offered an homage to his Jamaican-born mum, and Joseph Altuzarra showed a smattering of hothouse florals redolent of the South Pacific. It's a global marketplace, they say, in more ways than one.

Backstage at Rodarte, James Kaliardos was touching up Kate Mulleavy's makeup while one of his assistants prepped the model Samantha Gradoville (wearing her own webby, iridescent knit) nearby. Odile Gilbert was on the other side of the space getting girls ready for what she calls the "Sweet 16," an off-center part with a natural wave and one side twisted up and tucked in with a comb. "Soft, innocent - not pretentious," she said of the style created with Kérastase Volume Active Mousse and Double Force hairspray. "It looks easy, but it's not easy." Deborah Lippman painted toes Fashion, her opaque beige, and fingers a custom variation of Lady Sings the Blues. The Mulleavy sisters asked her to up the amount of large graphite glitter in the polish rather than the standard mix of paillettes. Like Lippman, Kaliardos channeled Van Gogh's "Starry Night" with dark navy, shimmering eyes. Using Nars products, he drew all over lids with the shadow pencil in Dark Night and then added Night Flight and Tropic, a turquoise glitter. "Looks a bit like Edvard Munch's 'The Scream,'" Kaliardos said laughing as he moved on from Van Gogh. Penny Lane cream blush was used high on the cheeks and to cover the lips, which were then coated with Pearl Beach eyeshadow and Na Na gloss. "Dreamy and aggressive at the same time," he said. "A cool, ethereal girl."

You know you're a beauty industry rock star when a designer makes references to your past work in his preshow brief. "Nineties Guido," was what Marc Jacobs wanted for Marc by Marc Jacobs according to Guido Palau backstage before the show. "They got out all my old pictures," he said of the stack of images unearthed by Jacobs's team. In the end, Palau came up with a half pulled-through ponytail created by first blow-drying the hair with Redken Satinwear, then pulling it back with an elastic. The next step was attaching the tail to the back of the head with a silver Goody clip and coating the hair with Shine Enrich and Forceful 23 Spray. "A little bit spiky - aerodynamic," is how Palau described the finished look. Nails were painted Zoya's Olivia with a custom matte top coat to make a nude velvet effect. For makeup, Dick Page conceived what he referred to as the appropriately collegiate "Pretty 101, just a healthy face." This was done using Shiseido gold blush dusted just above the cheek bones with a rosy tone below. Eyelids were spread with Shiseido Maquillage Lip Gloss and brows were colored with Shimmering Cream eyeshadow in one of four shades: Sable, Gold Meadow, Caviar or Leather, a reddish brown for those with auburn hair. Roseate was dabbed onto the bare mouth with the finger. Said Page, "Nothing too complicated, no tricks."

At some point in the New York hotel boom of the last few years, roofs became the new lobbies. (Who wants to step over people sitting around on poufs just to get to the check-in desk?) And if the roof had a pool, even better. The latest refinement of the trend is La Piscine, the pool bar and restaurant on top of the new Hôtel Americano. Reached directly from the street by an external glass elevator (part of the building's striking design by Enrique Norten), the 10-stories-up space looks north and east over the glamorously gritty cityscape of industrial Chelsea and west toward a slice of the Hudson. In warm weather, the grill sends out Greek-style octopus, lamb chops and baba ghanouj, the bar slings mojitos and mezcalitos, and the stereo plays a set list devised by Bebel Gilberto. In winter, a big glass garage door will swing down to seal off the glass-roofed dining area, sheepskin will cover the butterfly chairs, and the menu will shift to fondue and hot sake. Even the pool will be winterized. Open only to guests during the day, the four-foot-deep oasis will become a hot tub, complete with ultrathick robes and slippers. Explaining the après-ski vibe, one of the hotel's owners, Carlos Couturier, says, "It's the first time we're doing a wintertime hotel. All the rest are in Mexico." The Americano, part of the Mexico City-based Habita group, expects to welcome a largely Latin American clientele (most of the staff are from South America) - who, it could be assumed, do a lot of outdoor living (but may not yet know from snow). "We want to embrace the crowd," Couturier says, "make them feel at home in New York."

In the 1991 thriller "Point Break," a squad of surfers-cum-bank robbers commit their crimes while wearing masks of Presidents Lyndon B. Johnson, Richard Nixon, Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan, so we'll assume that in a newly announced remake of this film, they'll disguise themselves as Bill Clinton, George W. Bush, Barack Obama and Hu Jintao of China. That's just a guess, but we can tell you for certain that the original "Point Break" was directed by Kathryn Bigelow, the future Academy Award-winning director of "The Hurt Locker," and starred Keanu Reeves as a young F.B.I. agent on the trail of the "Ex-Presidents" gang, whose philosophical leader is played by Patrick Swayze. The new version was announced late Monday by Alcon Entertainment, a production and finance company based at Warner Brothers, which has been on a rebooting binge; last month the company announced that it was producing a new "Blade Runner" film that could serve as a sequel or prequel to Ridley Scott's original movie.

Mark Thoma objects to Tyler Cowen's attempt to pigeonhole some of us as "Old New Keynesians", and makes the case for flexibility in use of models. Indeed. But there's something more systematic to the macro story - something that very much informs my work. Namely, "old Keynesian" and "new Keynesian" models represent two intelligent but imperfect responses to the problem of thinking about an economy in which people must make future-oriented decisions. Neither is fully convincing, but there are no better alternatives at this point. So what I do, and I hope others do as well, is to think about policy issues both ways, and try to "bracket" things in a way that leads to reasonably secure conclusions.

Otto Pérez Molina finished first in the country’s presidential election on Sunday, but short of the 50 percent plus one vote required for outright victory.
Aleksandr Galimov, who somehow staggered from the wreckage under his own power after his team’s plane crashed last week, had burns covering 90 percent of his body.
An explosion shook a French nuclear waste site in southern France, killing one person and injuring four, officials and news reports said.
Kenyan police officials say more than 100 may have died after a leaking pipeline exploded in a crowded slum.
The days of 142-0 thrashings in the Rugby World Cup seem to be over, as lesser teams like Namibia, the United States, Romania and Japan have given bigger teams a scare in early games.
American markets turned slightly higher by the end of the day after global indexes were battered.

YAHR--Beatrice, of Pompano Beach, FL, passed away Sunday, September 11, 2011. Loving mother of Dr. William Z. Yahr and M. Peter (Roberta) Yahr, cherished grandmother of Elizabeth (Robert), Harriette, Marc, Lisa, Erica and Alexander, dear great-grandmother of Ashley, Bryce, Ryan and Brooke. Contributions to your favorite charity. Graveside Services, 2pm, Wednesday, September 14th at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Levitt-Weinstein (305) 932-2700.

SCHAFFER--Eugene (Gene). Eugene (Gene) Schaffer, who lived in Stamford, CT for 46 years, died peacefully at his home. He was 88 years old. Gene grew up through high school in Allentown, PA where he played basketball and swam on the state championship swim team at Allentown High School. He specialized in long distance free style. He put in one semester at the University of Notre Dame before entering the Army in February 1943. He served as a Paratrooper with the 11th Airborne Division in the Pacific Area. He recently, out of nostalgia visited Fort Benning, Georgia where he took his training in parachuting. He was a life long learner and at the advanced age of 68 received a Master of Arts in Theology degree at Notre Dame He also attended classes at Harvard Medical School, the University of Southern California, Fairfield University, Muhlenberg University, and Sacred Heart University. Following graduation from Notre Dame in 1949, Gene worked for nearly fifty years in the newspaper business, 30 of them with The New York Times. He was Promotion Manager of the New York Times Western Edition, a key staff member of Promotion in New York. He also worked for the Houston Chronicle, the Los Angeles Times, the Los Angeles Mirror, and the Riverside California Press Enterprise. He was a Vice President of the American Newspaper Promotion Association. He was a heart and soul University of Notre Dame Football fan; it was do or die every Saturday of the season. Gene felt his proudest accomplishment was his family. He was happily married 58 years to Sarah Anne Kathleen Smith of Texas. Kathleen also was a life long learner a graduate from St. Mary's College of Notre Dame, Indiana, received a Master Degree in Nutrition at New York University and a Dietetic Internship at Yale New Haven Medical Center. Together they brought into the world five children Scott, Jack, Kevin, Peter and Mary. From there came much adored grandchildren Justin, Jordan, and Julianna Schaffer; Kathryn-Rose, Kevin and Christian Schaffer; and Samantha and Devon Morgan. Peter is married to Marci-Ann Rustic, Kevin is married to Karen Goukler, Jack is married to Nancy Smith and Mary is married to Charles Morgan. Gene is predeased by his father Clarence Eugene Schaffer and mother Gertrude McGinley Schaffer, his brother John Albert Schaffer. Gene engaged in many volunteer activities. In Gene's belief system it wasn't enough to just grow up through childhood and high school but to reach out to help others. He volunteered at St. Joseph's Hospital, the Hospice organization, Connecticut Department of the Blind, the Autism Foundation, the Boys and Girls Club of New York City for run away children. Gene was a lover of all animals and particularly fond of dogs. He loved deeply his own dogs - Tony, Pookie, Pookie two and Ethel. He loved adventure and travel. He swam with the dolphins in Bermuda, hung out with the big turtles in Barbados, and in a major venture studied Taiko (Japanese) drumming on Sato Island in Northern Japan. He had a fondness for the people and culture of Japan despite the fact that we engaged in a war with them. Gene's family will receive friends on Wednesday, September 14th, 2011 from 5pm to 9 pm at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, CT. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Church of St. Cecilia 1184 Newfield Ave., Stamford on Thursday, September 15th at 10:00am. Interment will follow at St. John's Cemetery in Darien. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to World Wildlife Fund at www.worldwildlife.org. To leave an online condolence please visit: leopgallagherstamford.com

FROST--William L. The Board of Directors of Overseas Shipholding Group, Inc. ("OSG") expresses deep sorrow on the passing of William L. Frost, who was a valued director of OSG for 15 years. OSG benefited from Bill's many contributions during his tenure as a director. His wit, humor and singing ability enlivened many Board meetings.

On the same day it was announced that Amy Winehouse's last recording - a duet with Tony Bennett -- would be released on Wednesday, her father said she had been experiencing seizures related to alcohol withdrawal in the weeks before her death. Ms. Winehouse recorded a version of ''Body and Soul'' with Mr. Bennett on March 23, four months before she was found dead in her London apartment. An inquest has yet to determine the cause of death, but her family has said that she did not have illicit drugs in her system. She had battled drug and alcohol addiction for much of her short and tumultuous career.

Patricia, the child of Ralph Carleton and Caro (Cleveland) Powell, was born September 13, 1933 in Spartanburg, SC, and attended The Shipley School in Bryn Mawr, PA and Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, NY. She is survived by two of her brothers as well as many nephews, nieces, grandnephews and grandnieces. There will be a funeral in Spartanburg, SC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Amagansett Free Library: ww.amaglibrary.org

Count one more person coming through the revolving door separating official Washington from the influence industry. Jim Manley, the recently departed spokesman for Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the Democratic majority leader, returns to Washington on Thursday to join the lobbying and communications firm Quinn Gillespie & Associates. He'll work as a senior director for the firm's communications and government affairs operations. John Feehery, the firm's director of government affairs and an aide to J. Dennis Hastert, the Illinois Republican, when he was speaker of the House, called the hire a ''coup.''

An article on Saturday about the private memorials planned in Shanksville, Pa., for families of those killed on United Airlines Flight 93 misstated, in one instance, the surname of the father of a passenger killed on the flight. He is Jerry Bingham, not Brighton.

Hey, I'm directin' here! I'm directin' here! He's an excellent driver, a two-time Academy Award winner for ''Kramer Vs. Kramer'' and ''Rain Man,'' a magnet for New York taxis (at least in the guise of Ratso Rizzo from ''Midnight Cowboy'') and now, finally, Dustin Hoffman has become a film director. On Monday, production began on ''Quartet,'' Mr. Hoffman's feature-directing debut, its press representatives announced. The film, which is expected to shoot for nine weeks in Buckinghamshire, England, stars Tom Courtenay (whose previous films include ''Doctor Zhivago'' in 1965), Billy Connolly (''Mrs. Brown'') and Pauline Collins (''Shirley Valentine'') as residents of a home for retired opera singers. Their annual plans for a fund-raising concert, held on Verdi's birthday, are disrupted by the arrival of a down-on-her-luck grande dame (played by Maggie Smith, the ''Downton Abbey,'' ''Gosford Park'' and ''Harry Potter'' star). The screenplay for ''Quartet'' is by Ronald Harwood, the Academy Award-winning screenwriter of ''The Pianist'' and ''The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,'' and adapted from his play of the same title. Mr. Hoffman is also a producer on the film, which is financed by BBC Films, DCM Productions and Decca. An American distributor and release date for ''Quartet'' were not immediately announced. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

PALMIERI--Robert A. November 11, 1956 - September 12, 2011. Devoted husband of Rina for 32 years. Treasured father of Jacqueline, Stefanie and Joseph. Adored son-in-law of Lisa and Antonio. Brother-in-law and best friend to Mario. He lead a successful career in business technology for over 30 years. Beginning with work at The New York Stock Exchange, he went on to earn his master's degree in management from Polytechnic Institute of New York University and served as Global Program Manager at Hewlett Packard. Robert valued nothing more than spending time with his family. He is celebrated for his warmth, one-of a-kind-laugh, generosity, sense of humor, dedication to the New York Yankees, as well as his love of traveling, music, fishing and a nice home-cooked Italian meal. He is loved endlessly and will be missed everyday.

As Gov. Rick Perry of Texas was assailed by some rivals for the Republican presidential nomination at Monday night's debate for his exaggerated claim that Social Security is a ''Ponzi scheme,'' he also seemed to be debating himself at times. Mr. Perry used the debate to talk about the need to shore up Social Security, which politicians of all stripes agree is needed if the program is to continue paying out full benefits a quarter century from now. In making his case, Mr. Perry adopted a very different tone from what he did in his book ''Fed Up'' just a year ago, when he described Social Security as a failure that ''we have been forced to accept for more than 70 years now.''

Anthony Bourdain, the celebrity chef, author and reality TV star, will acquire books for Ecco, an imprint of HarperCollins, the publisher said on Monday. Mr. Bourdain has been given a line of books that is expected to release three to five titles each year, which Ecco said in a statement would ''reflect his remarkably eclectic tastes.'' Daniel Halpern, the president and publisher of Ecco, said that Mr. Bourdain has been an informal adviser to him for about 10 years, a period during which Mr. Bourdain's own books were published by Ecco. ''His intuition has been unerring - suggesting such authors as Ferran Adria and Fergus Henderson,'' Mr. Halpern said in an e-mail. ''Now he's becoming one of us, sort of.'' The deal is similar to Chelsea Handler's imprint at Grand Central Publishing, which was announced last year. While most publishing imprints are sparingly bestowed on influential editors who have worked in the industry for decades, handing an imprint to a celebrity author is something different: an opportunity for publishers to express their loyalty to their own authors, receive their editorial input and benefit, they hope, from the publicity and attention the celebrity authors can bring to the books they are acquiring.

BERKSHIRE HIRE Berkshire Hathaway said on Monday that Ted Weschler would be its second investment manager. He joins Todd Combs, who was hired last October. The hiring is part of an effort by Berkshire to prepare for life after Warren E. Buffett, left. Mr. Buffett, who is 81, has said that his roles of chairman, chief executive and chief investment officer will be split among at least three people upon his death or departure from the company. Mr. Weschler is the founder and managing partner of Peninsula Capital Advisers.

An obituary on Sept. 3 about John Cullen, a Coast Guardsman who uncovered a Nazi sabotage plot, referred incorrectly to the day he encountered four German spies on Long Island. As the obituary correctly noted, the encounter was on June 13, 1942, but that was a Saturday, not a Friday.

Over the weekend, Christine Lagarde, the president of the International Monetary Fund, was desperately trying to back-pedal. A report had surfaced citing an internal I.M.F. document estimating that Europe's banks were woefully short of capital - by a whopping $273.2 billion. ''Misreporting,'' Ms. Lagarde insisted, before awkwardly describing the number as ''tentative.'' Then she went even further, saying that the number ''is not a stress test that the I.M.F. conducts nor is it the global capital need for European banking institutions.'' She added, ''We are currently in discussions with our European partners to assess the global methodology until we reach a tentative draft. It will be published before the end of September.''

PEMBROKE PINES, Fla. -- Like so much else in Florida these days, the ambitious and touching Sept. 11 memorial in this small town was jolted hard by the recession. The memorial began small, with a request in 2004 for a chunk of steel from the remnants of the twin towers and the idea of a modest, but fitting tribute. It grew large, with 11 tons of marble for one sculpture and sheets and sheets of steel for four others. Then it turned even larger, with requests for a $1 million, air-conditioned glass building to house the expansive artworks.
Symphony Space 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street

A dad with lower testosterone is maybe a little more sensitive to cues from his child, and maybe he's a little less sensitive to cues from a woman he meets at a restaurant. PETER GRAY, an anthropologist at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, on a study finding that fatherhood decreases testosterone levels. [A3]

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, buoyed by his handling of Tropical Storm Irene, is once again viewed favorably by a majority of New York City voters, according to a poll released Monday morning by Quinnipiac University. By 54 percent to 35 percent, voters said they approved of Mr. Bloomberg's performance as mayor - a near reversal of Quinnipiac's findings in March, when a majority of voters said they disapproved of the mayor's performance. Mr. Bloomberg's handling of Tropical Storm Irene won particularly high marks; voters approved of the city's storm preparations by 86 percent to 10 percent, and of the decision to evacuate flood-prone areas by 90 percent to 8 percent.

An article on Monday about an oral history of Jacqueline Kennedy that is being published this week paraphrased incorrectly, in some copies, from her recollections 47 years ago about her exhaustion on the night of President Kennedy's inauguration in 1961. She noted that she was recovering from a Caesarian section, not that she was nine months pregnant. The article also misspelled the brand name of a drug the White House doctor gave Mrs. Kennedy that night. It was Dexedrine, not Dexadrine.

TURNER--A. Richard. The Institute of Fine Arts of New York University notes with deep sadness the death of our valued colleague, A. Richard Turner, Director Emeritus of the Institute of Fine Arts, from 1979-1982, Professor of Fine Arts and Chairman of the Department of Art History, College of Arts and Science. An art historian of the Italian Renaissance, he enriched the intellectual life of the University community in innumerable ways, sharing generously of his knowledge, insights, and teaching gifts. We extend our condolences on this great loss to his wife Jane, to his family, and to his many colleagues and friends. Judy Steinhardt, Chairman, Patricia Rubin, Director, Institute of Fine Arts, New York University

The On Education column on Sept. 5, about the union for New York City Catholic school teachers, misstated the terms of pensions for public school teachers in the city. After 30 years on the job, a city public school teacher can expect to collect a pension of up to $60,000, which can continue to climb with more service. Teachers do not qualify for a $60,000 pension after 22 years (the point at which the maximum teacher salary, $100,000, is reached).

A picture caption on Saturday with the On Religion column, about the partnership between Dave Hall, an Arab-American man, and Sam Botwin, a Jewish boy studying for his bar mitzvah, misstated the focus of Sam's weekly lesson with Mr. Hall. Sam was working on his bar mitzvah speech, not rehearsing Torah passages.

THE FACTS Anyone who has ever been out in the rain too long or soaked for hours in a tub knows the prunelike effect it can have on your hands and feet. Conventional wisdom suggests it is nothing more than the skin absorbing water.

What a difference nine days can make. On Sept. 3, the Boston Red Sox led the Tampa Bay Rays by nine games in the American League wild-card race, a cushion that seemed all but unassailable with 24 games left. According to the Web site Coolstandings.com, which simulates the rest of the season using probabilities based on each team's runs scored and allowed per game, Boston had a 99.6 percent chance of making the playoffs. The Rays' odds stood at a lowly 0.5 percent.

Texas officials flew to Oklahoma on Sunday to try to dissuade the Sooners from their stated intent to explore joining the Pacific-12 Conference, two Big 12 university officials who had been briefed on the meeting said. Texas officials reported little progress. Texas A&M's imminent move to the Southeastern Conference from the Big 12 has long been considered the first domino in conference realignment. The threat of Baylor and other Big 12 universities suing the SEC has stalled that move. But the SEC commissioner, Mike Slive, released a statement that made Texas A&M's move sound inevitable, saying the conference had begun exploring a 13-team schedule model. More coverage at nytimes.com/sports.

An article on Saturday about Andy Roddick's loss to Rafael Nadal in the United States Open quarterfinals misstated the number of times Nadal has been a runner-up in a Grand Slam tournament since he last played Roddick at the Open, in 2004. He has been runner-up three times, not four. (He has also won 10 Grand Slam singles titles during that time.)

Will President Obama finally make it Down Under? Mr. Obama plans to visit Australia on Nov. 16 and 17 to help commemorate the 60th anniversary of the alliance between the United States and Australia, the White House said on Monday. Mr. Obama's trip to Australia will immediately follow the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting, which the president is hosting in Hawaii. Mr. Obama is also expected to travel to Bali, the Indonesian island, as part of that trip for a meeting with regional leaders, although those plans have not been announced yet.

As Bank of America executives prepared last week to announce the first phase of their turnaround plan, a group of consultants hurried to complete their recommendations for the overhaul, called Project New BAC. The 44 senior bank managers and roughly two dozen consultants assigned to the initiative worked through lunch, barely pausing to enjoy the pepperoni, sausage and vegetarian pies that had been ordered from a pizzeria.

WILLIAMS--Claude Kress. Claude (C.K.), died peacefully at home at age 88 on September 7, 2011, in Montecito, California. Born in New York City on April 9, 1923, he was a graduate of St. Bernard's School, St. Paul's School and Princeton '45. C.K. served for three years in the U.S. Army during WWII and later as a 2nd Lt. during the Korean War. In 1948 he moved to Houston Texas and founded the Williams Brothers Construction Co. When he retired in l985, it was the seventh largest highway construction company in the country. In addition to running a successful business, C.K. enjoyed a flourishing career as an artist with many sell-out one-man shows and a large group of collectors. His paintings reflect his exuberance for life as well as a skilled technique developed over many years of experimentation. C.K. is survived by his wife of 22 years, Mary Elting Church Williams, a son, Claude Kress Williams, Jr., a daughter Cynthia Williams Collins, a son-in-law, Atwood Collins III, two grandchildren, Atwood Porter Collins and Dwight Mallory Collins and three great-grandchildren. The burial service in New Paltz, New York, will be private.

The Rome Opera has leveled unusually harsh criticism for the outwardly genteel world of opera houses at the conductor Fabio Luisi, who canceled performances there and elsewhere to fill in for James Levine at the Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Luisi has long been on standby for the ailing Mr. Levine and was elevated from principal guest conductor to principal conductor, the Met said last week in announcing his last-minute substitute role. Mr. Luisi's withdrawal has put the Rome Opera in ''difficulty,'' as well as the opera in Genoa, the Muskverein in Vienna and the San Francisco Symphony, the house added pointedly. Mr. Luisi also canceled there in order to conduct at the Met in October and November.

It was a gig that a thousand out-of-work actors would die for: a cameo on Sunday night's season finale of ''Curb Your Enthusiasm,'' Larry David's homage to his own bottomless neurosis on HBO. But Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had a better invitation. At the last minute, the president of the United States invited him to play golf on Aug 27, 2010, the same day Mr. Bloomberg was scheduled to tape a scene for ''Curb.''

KATZEN--Howard Buzz Katzen, 79, of Westport, CT and Scottsdale, AZ passed away on September 9th, surrounded by his adoring family. He had a zest for life, was a true gentleman, and loved everything he did. Loving husband to Arlene Rieger for 54 charmed years; exceptional father to Jane Katzen DeNunzio and Sue Katzen, and father-in-law to Robert DeNunzio. Born in Brooklyn to the late Julius and Margaret Katzen; brother of the late Joan Buchman. A graduate of James Madison High school in Brooklyn, NY; attended Syracuse University, was a brother in the TEP fraternity and graduated from NYU. Buzz served the US Army in the CIC; Stuttgart, Germany. Howard enjoyed a distinguished career with Xerox Corp. where he rose to Global Marketing Director from sales over his 32 years there. He retired to Scottsdale, AZ and enjoyed a second career as jazz promoter and prominent figure in the Arizona Musicfest. Loving uncle of Robbie and Brooks Sumberg, Charles and Andrea Jayson; Matthew and Melitte Buchman and Victoria Lorini and grand uncle of Jenna and Jake Sumberg and Matthew and Zachary Jayson. Buzz was extraordinary in his grace; his absence will be felt by so many. We will love, remember and miss him forever. Services Wednesday, September 14, 2pm at The Collins Funeral Home, 92 East Ave., Norwalk, CT. The family will receive at home from 7-9pm Wednesday and Thursday. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Arizona Musicfest Jazz Education Program, Arizona Musicfest, P.O. Box 5254, Carefree, AZ 85377 or Arizonamusicfest.org.

9 P.M. (ABC) JACQUELINE KENNEDY: IN HER OWN WORDS Diane Sawyer reports on the release of eight hours of recordings made of Mrs. Kennedy by the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. in 1964, shortly after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. The conversations, which were sealed until now, include Mrs. Kennedy's impressions of life with her husband (above, the couple in 1961) and events that shaped his administration, including their early years on the campaign trail, the Cuban missile crisis, the attempted invasion at the Bay of Pigs and the president's last days. The interviews reflect her evolving sense of self and her role as first lady, as she talks about her family, world leaders and life in the White House. Ms. Sawyer also speaks with Caroline Kennedy about her parents. The report coincides with the publication on Wednesday of the book ''Jacqueline Kennedy: Historic Conversations on Life with John F. Kennedy.'' 5:45 P.M. (MoreMax) (500) DAYS OF SUMMER (2009) Tom Hansen (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) is an ''unapologetic believer in true love, soul mates and other touchstones of greeting-card mythology (and romantic comedy ideology),'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Summer Finn (Zooey Deschanel), he said, is ''skeptical of such notions and refuses to promise commitment or even consistency, but she does seem to want more and more of Tom's company, and this leads him to believe that her carefully maintained barriers to intimacy are beginning to fall.'' That pretty much sums up this Marc Webb movie.

A theater review on Monday about ''The Select (The Sun Also Rises),'' at the New York Theater Workshop, referred incorrectly to ''The Sun Also Rises,'' the Ernest Hemingway novel on which the play is based. It was his second novel, not his first. (''The Torrents of Spring'' was his first.) The review also referred incorrectly to ''Under the Volcano'' by Malcolm Lowry, another novel in which alcohol plays a prominent role. Lowry was British; the book is not an American masterpiece.

Every day across the western half of North Dakota 100 million cubic feet of natural gas — enough energy to heat nearly half a million homes for a year — is deliberately burned by oil companies rushing to extract oil from the Bakken shale field and take advantage of the high price of crude.

Every day across the western half of North Dakota 100 million cubic feet of natural gas is deliberately burned by oil companies rushing to extract oil from the Bakken shale field and take advantage of the high price of crude. The gas bubbles up alongside the oil, and with less economic incentive to capture it, the drillers treat the gas as waste and simply burn it.

The police charged (Indian Express) two high school students with criminal conspiracy in connection with the bombing of the Delhi High Court last week, the first criminal charges to be filed in the blast, which killed 12 people and injured dozens more. The police say the young men had sent an e-mail claiming that the militant group Harkat-ul-Jihad Islami was responsible for the attack.

My Thursday column tells the story of Jane Ngoiri, a woman in Nairobi who has managed to transform her life - and her children's - with some outside help. Originally, I thought I would write this column about microfinance, but as I followed Jane it became increasingly obvious that while her access to credit helped her start a business, the biggest help was the psychological push to save and start thinking about the future.
SEATTLE - Mariano Rivera has done many things in baseball, from recording 600 saves to starting games and even batting. But he has never played center field.

THURSDAY'S PUZZLE - Today marks a two-day streak, if you can have one of those, of Seattle constructors. Yesterday, we had Jeff Chen's animated SPY VS. SPY puzzle. Today, Samuel A. Donaldson is back and he is building HOUSEs all over our puzzle.

A YouTube channel called the Syrian Interpreter has posted a subtitled recording of the Syrian television station Addounia TV claiming in a Sept. 9 broadcast that the news station Al Jazeera has built enormous "cinematic replicas" of Syrian cities and squares in the Gulf state of Qatar in order to fabricate the uprising in Syria.

Anna Sui rarely fails to put a smile on your face with her whimsical prints and girly dresses, and her show Wednesday night was no exception. Her soundtrack transformed the big tent at Lincoln Center into a scene from Club Sept in Paris in the 1970s, and the models lined up at the back of the runway as if they were waiting to get in. One by one, they took the catwalk wearing chiffon trousers and tops in dark vintage prints, many of them with matching turbans, or long lace gowns with floppy hats. Her prints were especially witty, one with stripes that, if you looked closely, were made of toothbrushes.

Entrepreneurial zeal is the inevitable theme at technology conferences like TechCrunch Disrupt, which ends its three-day run in San Francisco on Wednesday. Start-up founders and those who wanted to be overdosed on self-promotion, salesmanship and name-dropping while Silicon Valley celebrities pontificated on stage.

Julie Newmar has appeared on many TV shows that entranced young baby boomers - "Star Trek," "The Twilight Zone," "Get Smart" and "Batman," in which she was Catwoman. One of her earliest roles was playing an android on the 1964 science-fiction sit-com "My Living Doll." Miss Newmar discusses her new book "The Conscious Catwoman Explains Life on Earth" and reflects on her career and her continued fame on the Internet.

Katinka Domotorffy, the head of Goldman Sachs's quantitative investment strategies group, will retire from the firm at the end of the year, according to a letter the bank's asset management division sent to investors on Wednesday.

This week, Facebook is rolling out two new features designed to make it easier to share posts with small groups of people who belong to the same family, city, workplace or school as you, and to separate your best friends from your so-so friends.

J. Crew staged its highly anticipated, first-ever New York Fashion Week presentation at the tents in Lincoln Center this season. The men's collection, designed by Frank Muytjens, included some greatest hits of American sportswear (the perfect slender suits and sports jackets, sailor-striped knits and tailored trousers) alongside clever pieces in bright colors, plaids and polka dots, always impeccably styled. The cuffed khakis lined with St. James stripes were absolutely charming, but my favorite look was on the more minimal side. A stone-colored jean jacket, buttoned all the way up and worn with matching jean-style trousers, topped by a navy nylon lightweight parka, was the winner for me. The jacket is from a new capsule collection called Wallace & Barnes that will consist of reinterpretations of favorite vintage pieces that somehow never made it into the main line. Coming soon to a J. Crew near you.

In a season marked by all manner of flounces and frills, the peplum was a standout. Embraced in the 1940s and '50s by Jacques Fath and Christian Dior, the look, defined by a starchy little overskirt that flares from the waist, reappears every decade or so. It was picked up last season by Marc Jacobs of Louis Vuitton and Christophe Decarnin at Balmain, and revisted once more this week on the runways of Jason Wu, Vera Wang, Badgley Mischka and Rodarte, to name but a handful, lending their collections a shot of vintage Hollywood allure.

Neil L. Rudenstine, the former president of Harvard University, was elected chairman of the board of the New York Public Library on Wednesday. Mr. Rudenstine, 76, is replacing Catherine Marron who has led the board since 2004. He will assume the post immediately.

The fall TV season is finally upon us, as a handful of premiere episodes faced off against the remaining summer mainstays on Tuesday. An identical twin premise on the CW's "Ringer" meant a double dose of Sarah Michelle Gellar, but the return of that former vampire slayer to television was mostly met with a ratings shrug. The show averaged 2.7 million total viewers and matched the rating in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic of last season's "Hellcats" opener on the CW, which was ultimately canceled. NBC was the No. 1 broadcast network in the 18-to-49 category for the night, helped by the return of "Parenthood" (6.7 million total viewers) and the final performance episode of "America's Got Talent" (13.2 million).

TORONTO - In "Drive," directed by Nicolas Winding Refn, Ryan Gosling plays a man who works as a stunt driver for movies by day and an occasional getaway car driver by night. The film, screening here ahead of its Sept. 16 release in the United States, plays both as a psychological drama and a genre-focused crime movie. Here, Mr. Refn discusses a chase scene that happens early in the film and is primarily shot within the car's interior.

The cover story of this week's education issue, "The Character Test," by Paul Tough, discusses an unusual curriculum taught at two very different schools in New York. Educators at KIPP Infinity, a charter school in Harlem, and Riverdale, a prestigious private school in the Bronx, are using special lesson plans to improve the character of their students. To illustrate the piece, we wanted to show the two school environments as well as express the idea of teaching traits like optimism, grit and curiosity.

A popular hair-straightening product called Brazilian Blowout, which has received scrutiny in recent months after tests found it contains significant amounts of the harmful chemical formaldehyde, has come under new government pressure. The United States Food and Drug Administration has stepped into the fray by warning the company that its product contains a "poisonous or deleterious substance" and that it was falsely labeled as formaldehyde-free.

Bob Turner, who won a special election on Tuesday to replace Anthony D. Weiner in the Ninth Congressional district, emerged onto his porch in Rockaway Point, Queens, at 9:45 Wednesday morning in shorts and T-shirt and with bare feet, still somewhat groggy from his late-night victory party and surprised to find a reporter and photographer waiting in his yard.

"Michael loves a bronze girl or boy," said Dick Page backstage at Michael Kors. "This is a sort of rough glamor." Page used Shiseido Creme Shadow in Caviar, Leather and Sable to create strong eyebrows with Meadow gold spread on the lid and Caramel Perfect Rouge on the lips. Luminize Satin Face Color in BE 206 was mixed with Bronzer 1 and 2 all over the face to make sure the models "didn't look like they had to get up at 6 a.m. to do a show." No one did. "It's pretty," Hanne Gaby said of her tousled hair braided with black leather. "I don't think I'd be able to do it, though." Luckily, Orlando Pita was there to help create the look that came about based on one of Kors's fantasy stories. ("He embellished it more than I do," said Pita of the designer's storytelling prowess.) The tales goes: These girls are on a trip in Africa with only shoelaces to tie back their hair. "They groom themselves," said Pita. "The front is all they can see." This explains why the hair around the face was more tidy, parted in the middle, while the back was wild and messy. Orlando's own Dry Shampoo was used with Bumble and Bumble Surf Spray to coat the hair before braiding. The tail was then teased up between the lacing and Pita's Elevate Texture Spray added. The model Magdalena Frackowiak offered a way to translate the look to her own routine: "braid it loosely and then pull bits out."

TORONTO - The English actor Matthew Goode has appeared in a wide range of movies during his relatively brief film career, including a Woody Allen movie ("Match Point"), one inspired by a comic book ("Watchmen") and  a Hollywood romantic comedy ("Leap Year"). We've just published a lively small-business conversation with Zane Tankel, who bought into the established Applebee's business model but who has also challenged that model in many ways, including what his employees wear, how they are hired and rewarded, where he builds his restaurants, and what food those restaurants serve. Based on revenue numbers confirmed by Applebee's, the results have been impressive. "Maybe this kind of thing isn't for the average franchisee," Mr. Tankel told Eilene Zimmerman, "but we pushed the envelope right from the start, took those protocols to the next level, and I think that's entrepreneurship."

"Design is not about objects anymore; it's more pervasive," says Vasif Kortun, a director of Istanbul's new arts center Salt (Istiklal Caddesi 136; saltonline.org). "Turkey is picking it up belatedly." And quickly. Since the opening of Adnan Kazmaoglu's austerely geometric Yesil Vadi Mosque in Istanbul last year, a design and architecture movement is sweeping through the city. Salt's Beyoglu building, a columned space by the local architect Han Tumertekin on the boulevard Istiklal, features the work of a different Turkish designer in each room - there's a cinema by Hakan Demirel, a bookstore by Omer Unal and a cafe by Ali Selcuk and the chef Murat Bozok. Regular symposiums cover everything from urban planning to electronic music, and later this fall a second outpost will open nearby in Galata.

Finally, something for the J. K. Rowling fan who has everything, including some extra space in his or her shoe closet. Arriving on the heels, so to speak, of Tuesday's announcement that a one-sentence letter from J. D. Salinger to his maid was being offered for $50,000, a company in Omaha is putting up for auction a pair of boots that Ms. Rowling wore while she wrote the first book in her best-selling "Harry Potter" series. The boots, which are being sold by Blue Earth Benefit Auctions in an online auction that starts Friday at proxibid.com, were given to a fifth-grade class at Harrison Elementary School in Omaha in 1999. At that time, the class was conducting a project called "Operation Shoe Tree," in which celebrities or other people the pupils admired were asked to write about their lives from the perspective of their footwear.

"Bertrand Goldberg: Architecture of Invention," at the Art Institute of Chicago from Sept. 17 through Jan. 15, 2012, is the first comprehensive retrospective of the architect's work, and in addition to drawings, models and photographs, also includes examples of Goldberg's seldom-seen graphic and furniture designs. Famous for his design of Marina City, the striking twin circular apartment towers that were completed in 1967 in downtown Chicago, Goldberg (1913-1997) - who took courses at the Bauhaus and briefly apprenticed to Mies van der Rohe in Berlin in the early 1930s - was also known for his innovative designs for low-cost housing, hospitals and prefabricated structures for everything from dwellings to mobile medical facilities during World War II. And his village-like spatial configurations for both education and medical facilities were well ahead of their time. The exhibition was curated by Zoe Ryan, the chair of the museum's architecture and design department, and Alison Fisher, an assistant curator of architecture in the department, with Elizabeth Smith, the executive director of curatorial affairs at the Art Gallery of Ontario. The installation was designed by John Ronan Architects - who recently completed the elegant new headquarters of the Poetry Foundation in Chicago - with a graphic design by Studio Blue. Accompanying the Goldberg show is a photography exhibition called "Inside Marina City: A Project by Iker Gil and Andreas E.G. Larsson," which offers visitors a rare glimpse inside the iconic towers, with more than 30 images that explore the relationship between Goldberg's modular framework for the buildings and the way that residents live in the spaces he designed.

On Sept. 14, 1959, the Luna 2 space probe crashed onto the surface of the moon. Though Luna 2 was shattered on impact, the mission was a major success, as it represented an important first in the history of space exploration.

Ms. India, a regular feature by Nilanjana S. Roy, offers snapshots of the changing lives of women in the country, from the perspective of the "Bharatiya Naari", or ideal Indian woman, whether she lives in urban, small-town or village India.Everyone in Karaikal knows the Women's Press, whose colorful pink sign advertises the press and its stationery shop just outside the Old Bus Stand, on a dusty street perfumed by the scent of jasmine sold everywhere. The Karaikal Women Society Co-operative Printing Society Ltd., to give the press its full name, was started in 1979 in this thriving port town in the Union Territory of Puducherry, making it the oldest - and perhaps the only - printing press in India run by women.Tamil Selvi, the manager, was part of the original team that founded the press. The founder, she says, was Bharati Natarajan, who pawned her jewelry to fund the press. Women's co-operatives flourish in many of the states of South India, but they are more typically involved in food processing or the textile and handicrafts business.

The outcome of any individual election to the United States House, even in a highly partisan era where Congressional elections have a relatively strong correlation with presidential voting and national trends, is going to be determined based on a combination of local and national factors. One congressional district's outcome may diverge significantly from another's - even if they seem similar on the surface -- based on the quality of the candidates, the demographics of the region and issues highly pertinent to the district but not to the nation at large. Any one race may or may not be representative.

Brooklyn's latest historic district - a cluster of 21 skyscrapers and office buildings surrounding Borough Hall downtown - was created on Tuesday over the objections of some of its landowners and inhabitants. The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission approved the Borough Hall Skyscraper Historic District despite opposition from business groups that said the designation would burden owners with new costs and regulations, and from the co-op board of one of the district's few residential buildings, 75 Livingston Street.

FINCH--Edward Ridley, Esq. The Board of Trustees of The New York Institute for Special Education (founded in 1831 as The New York Institute for the Education of the Blind) records with deep regret the death of its beloved and distinguished member. Mr. Finch was a dedicated friend of the Institute and he ably assisted in guiding its growth as a Trustee and member of numerous committees for over 63 years including several years as President of the Board. His guidance and friendship will be sorely missed. Our sympathy is extended to his family. The Board of Trustees and Employees of The New York Institute for Special Education

BOSTON - Elizabeth Warren, the Harvard law professor who has battled the financial industry as a consumer advocate, will announce her candidacy Wednesday for what will probably be a high-profile race against Senator Scott P. Brown. A senior adviser to Ms. Warren said she would spend the day greeting voters in Boston, Springfield, Worcester and other heavily Democratic cities around Massachusetts. Ms. Warren, 62, started an exploratory committee last month and for weeks has been meeting quietly with Democratic activists while mulling whether to join an already crowded field of Democrats hoping to unseat Mr. Brown.

UPDATE 6:50 p.m.: The Senate on Tuesday cleared the way for consideration of a large aid package for communities and people affected by this summer's hurricanes and tornadoes by tucking $6.9 billion in new disaster aid into a Republican-sponsored bill to renew sanctions against the Burmese government. The question of how to increase federal disaster aid, and by how much, has raised some controversy on Capitol Hill in recent days because many Republicans would like to see any increase in aid offset by federal spending cuts. The House plans to include new disaster aid in a short-term spending plan that is expected to hit that chamber's floor next week, with far lower levels expected and a possible offset though cuts to an auto loan program.

Hugh Jackman is 2-for-2 at turning a profit on Broadway, with his 2003 musical ''The Boy from Oz'' and his 2009 play with Daniel Craig, ''A Steady Rain'' - a golden track record in a business where only 25 to 30 percent of shows even recoup their investment each year. Now Mr. Jackman has a chance at a hat trick: He will return to Broadway this fall with an 18-piece orchestra for his one-man show, ''Hugh Jackman, Back on Broadway,'' featuring a selection of his favorite musical numbers, the producers announced on Tuesday. A version of the show earned gushing reviews when it played in Toronto and San Francisco earlier this year.

An Op-Ed article on Tuesday about the implications of surveillance technologies for privacy incorrectly described a new feature on Facebook. The feature uses face-recognition technology that scans photos and automatically suggests identifying tags that match images of a user's friends with their names. It does not match every face with a name.

An article on Aug. 31 about the variety of regional brigades who held a patchwork of territories in Tripoli, the Libyan capital, a week after it was overrun by rebels gave an incorrect alias for one rising commander. The fighter, Abdel Hakim Belhaj, a former Islamist militant who was named commander of a newly formed Tripoli Military Council, was also known as Abu Abdullah al-Sadiq -- not Abdel Hakim al-Hasadi. (Mr. Hasadi is another Islamist fighter among the rebels who leads a military council in the eastern city of Darna.)

FARNSWORTH--Patricia N. (nee Nordstrom) of Englewood, NJ, on September 12, 2011 at her residence. Loving mother of Jeanne Farnsworth, Karen Einsidler and her husband Jon and Pamela Wilkinson and her husband, Mark J. Dear Buddy and Gammy to Alexander Farnsworth, Nina Aris, Edward Allan (Teddy) and Scott Eric Einsidler and Kimberly Elle Wilkinson. Predeceased by her husband Edward Allan Farnsworth (2005), a Professor at Columbia School of Law and her beloved son Edward Allan Farnsworth Jr. (1993), a Princeton graduate and Naval Lieutenant, Senior Grade. Her devoted dogs, Princess and Ruffles will miss her "muchly." Patricia was born in Sioux City, IA and lived most of her life in Englewood, NJ. She graduated Summa Cum Laude in 1951 with a BA from Morningside College and then went on to graduate school at Columbia University where she received her MS in 1952 and her PhD in Physiology in 1960. She started her teaching career at Fairleigh Dickenson University in 1964 as an Assistant Professor. In 1967, Patricia left to teach at Barnard College until 1972 when she became a member of the Department of Physiology at UMDNJ-New Jersey Medical School where she was made a full professor in 1979 and remained for the balance of her career until retiring in 2003. In addition to teaching, Patricia was a research scientist originally concentrating on Sickle-cell Anemia and later eye research focusing on the lens. In 1983 she received the Alcon Research Institute Annual Award (International prize for excellence in eye research). Patricia was a research mentor for 40 plus medical students who have successfully completed Ophthalmology residencies, several who live locally. She was well published as a research scientist and received numerous grants during her career as well as being an invited speaker to seminars in Turkey, France, Germany, England, Japan, Senegal and major Universities in the United States and Canada. Funeral services Thursday 4-6pm at Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Dr., Tenafly, NJ. Please send tributes and stories to www.pnfarnsworth.com. Visit: www.barrettfuneralhome.net

Jane Austen is going to be reworked - again. Adding to the spinoffs, fan fiction and creative interpretations of Ms. Austen's beloved novels (such as the 2009 book ''Pride and Prejudice and Zombies'') will be a new offering by Joanna Trollope, which its publisher, HarperCollins, called a contemporary version of ''Sense and Sensibility.''

8 P.M. (Sundance) LEAVING (2010) A gunshot is heard in the opening scene of this turbulent French drama from Catherine Corsini, which finds Suzanne (Kristin Scott Thomas, right), a British expatriate and physiotherapist, living in apparent comfort in the South of France with her husband, Samuel (Yvan Attal), a doctor, and her teenage children (Alexandre Vidal and Daisy Broom). That is, until she meets Ivan (Sergi López), a Spanish day laborer hired to help renovate a stone shed where her new office will be. Soon enough, Suzanne is abandoning almost everything for love, with Samuel threatening to take away the rest if she doesn't stop this foolishness. ''Here, a contemporary French white woman who yearns for liberté, égalité and fraternité is as much a prisoner of her circumstances as women were once upon a time and still are in some cultures,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, ''though truly it's all the clichés in this film that make her a captive.'' 8 P.M. (NBC) AMERICA'S GOT TALENT The host Nick Cannon reveals the winner of the $1 million prize and a Las Vegas show.

BERGER--Martin S, of New York City, Quogue, NY and Palm Beach, FL, passed away suddenly on September 12, 2011. Loving husband of Karen, cherished father of Brad, Greg (Janelle) and Leslie (Jeff) and stepfather of Staci (John) and Sueann (Peter), sister of Ina Feidelman (and the late Arnold) and Jack Berger (Carole) and adored Pop-Pop to Nicole, Jason, Morgan, Matthew, Niki, Tara, Eric and Sam, and beloved uncle and friend. Martin was the Chairman of the Board, Principal and Founder of the Robert Martin Company LLC, a Westchester County based diversified real estate company. He was also the Chairman of the Board, Owner and CEO of the City and Suburban Federal Savings Bank for over 40 years, as well as the President of the Construction Industry Foundation, and President of the Builders Institute of Westchester and Putnam Counties and a former Commissioner of the Westchester County Parkway Commission. Martin served on the Board of Mack-Cali Realty, the Municipal Assistance Corporation of New York, and Director of the Governor's Island Preservation Corporation. He also served on the Board of the White Plains Hospital Medical Center, UJA Federation of Westchester, and was a Founder of the Young Men's Division of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Martin was a member of Palm Beach Country Club and Hampton Hills Golf Club. Born June 19, 1930 in the Bronx, Martin graduated from DeWitt Clinton High School. He graduated from New York University in 1951 and proudly served his Country in the Korean War. In 1987, he was awarded an Honorary Doctorate in Commercial Science from Pace University. Martin was an extraordinary man whose towering presence will be sorely missed by so many. One of his greatest achievements was being named as one of the top ten most influential people in the history of Westchester County. He was a leader, visionary, friend and mentor to so many and his proudest accomplishments were his beautiful wife, devoted children and adoring grandchildren. Funeral services to be held Thursday, September 15 at 10am at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Avenue, New York City.

The actor Bobby Cannavale, a Tony Award nominee last spring for the biting play ''The ------------------------ With the Hat,'' will make his musical theater debut this winter in the Broadway-bound revival of ''Funny Girl'' as the con man Nick Arnstein, starring opposite Lauren Ambrose as the comedian Fanny Brice, the production announced on Tuesday. The musical, which ran on Broadway from 1964 to 1967 and originally starred Barbra Streisand, revolves around Brice awaiting the return of her husband Arnstein from prison, recalling their life together as she rose to show business stardom. Sydney Chaplin played Arnstein in the first Broadway production, and Omar Sharif played him in the 1968 film that also starred Ms. Streisand.

Before the season, the N.F.L. statistical community pulled out its calculators and protractors -- do they still use protractors? -- to determine how damaging the absence of Peyton Manning might be. It's no longer a math exercise, with Manning most likely out for the season. (Even if he's ready to return late in the season, the Colts may be out of the playoff hunt by then, so why risk re-injury by rushing him back? If the Colts really nosedive, they also may have a shot at drafting Andrew Luck as Manning's eventual replacement, another reason not to hurry Manning back.)

In the 1991 thriller ''Point Break,'' a squad of surfers-cum-bank robbers commit their crimes while wearing masks of Presidents Lyndon B. Johnson, Richard Nixon, Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan, so we'll assume that in a newly announced remake of this film, they'll disguise themselves as Bill Clinton, George W. Bush, Barack Obama and Hu Jintao of China. That's just a guess, but we can tell you for certain that the original ''Point Break'' was directed by Kathryn Bigelow, the future Academy Award-winning director of ''The Hurt Locker,'' and starred Keanu Reeves as a young F.B.I. agent on the trail of the ''Ex-Presidents'' gang, whose philosophical leader is played by Patrick Swayze. The new version was announced late Monday by Alcon Entertainment, a production and finance company based at Warner Brothers, which has been on a rebooting binge; last month the company announced that it was producing a new ''Blade Runner'' film that could serve as a sequel or prequel to Ridley Scott's original movie. Alcon said in a news release that ''Point Break'' 2.0 ''is set in the world of international extreme sports, and like the original involves an undercover F.B.I. agent infiltrating a criminal ring, but plot points beyond that have not been revealed by the filmmakers.'' The screenplay will be by Kurt Wimmer, whose credits include a coming remake of the science-fiction action movie ''Total Recall'' that stars Colin Farrell. No director has been chose and no laconic, muscle-bound young star has been announced to play the lead, but we'll surmise that Taylor Lautner's phone is ringing off the hook.

Operating a bit like a stealth business news network, The Wall Street Journal on Tuesday announced a major expansion of its video unit, which is now producing three and a half hours of live programming each weekday and will soon produce even more. In a bid for more viewers and advertisers, The Journal released a new video app, called WSJ Live, for iPads and for a wide array of Internet-connected television sets and set-top boxes. Previously the newspaper's live newscasts were mainly confined to The Journal's Web site, WSJ.com.

WASHINGTON -- The United States faced increasing pressure on Tuesday as the Palestinian quest for statehood gained support from Turkey and other countries, even as the Obama administration sought an 11th-hour compromise that would avoid a confrontation at the United Nations next week. With only days to go before world leaders gather in New York, the maneuvering became an exercise in brinkmanship as the administration wrestles with roiling tensions in the region, including a sharp deterioration of relations between three of its closest allies in the region: Egypt, Israel and Turkey.

This is a tale of two deals. Three years ago today, Bank of America leapt into the maelstrom and bought Merrill Lynch for about $50 billion. Early the next morning, Lehman Brothers announced its bankruptcy filing. Lehman soon sold its investment banking and capital markets operations to Barclays for $250 million.

LARTIGAU--Maurice, died peacefully at his home on September 10, 2011 after a long illness. Born in St.-Jean-de-Lier, France on August 9, 1927, he lived in New York City, Long Beach and St.-Jean-de-Lier. He received his baccalaureate from Cendrillon, a catholic boarding school in Dax, France. After attending two years of University in Paris and Military duty, he arrived in New York in 1951. He continued his studies at Columbia University and worked at Austin Nichols where he met his lifelong business associate Ab Simon. They would work together for the next 30 years at Seagram's Chateau and Estates Wines, which became one of the leading importers of Classified Estates Wines from France. In 1987 he was awarded the prestigious "Order of Merit Agricole" by the French Government for his promotion of French wines in the US. In addition to his wife Helenmarie, he is survived by his children Mark (Miranda), Maurice (Linda), and Marianne (John) Plahs and grandchildren Dominique, Danielle, and Nicole. Memorial visitation will take place at Macken Mortuary 52 Clinton Ave., Rockville Centre, NY, Thursday, September 15, 4-8pm. Inurnment to follow in France. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Make-A-Wish Foundation 1111 Marcus Ave., Suite LI22, Lake Success, NY 11042 (Please place M. Lartigau/Long Beach Polar Bears in the memo line). www.mackenmortuary.com

When Sebastian Janikowski tied the N.F.L. record by making a 63-yard field goal to end the first half in Denver on Monday night, few on the Oakland side of the field were surprised. Janikowski routinely kicks 65-yarders in practice, and made one from 70 in pregame warm-ups Monday. But the best part of the kick might have come before Janikowski trotted out to take it. With 17 seconds left, the Raiders declined the chance to get him a little closer and instead ran Michael Bush right for no gain. What appeared to be a wasted play was in fact a favor; the left-footed Janikowski prefers to kick from the right hash mark.

Facing a strike that has lasted a month, the owner of the Boathouse Restaurant in Central Park has made several major concessions in the hope of ending the walkout, among them agreeing to recognize and negotiate with a union, representatives of the two sides said. The restaurant's owner, Dean Poll, has also agreed to rehire more than a dozen fired workers. But even so, union officials said they were not ready to end the strike. Peter Ward, president of the New York Hotel Trades Council, said on Tuesday that his union would not end the walkout until the two sides hammered out a full union contract.

SHAINE--Sylvia, died August 15, 2011 peacefully at her home in Los Angeles at age 95. Survived by Fred, her loving husband of 67 years, her son Rick and daughter-in-law Karen, granddaughter Isabel, sister Lee Becker, brother Cy Pollack, sister-in-law Elizabeth, and numerous other dear relatives. She was a pioneer for women in the fashion and retailing industry. Starting in the buyer training program at Macy's in 1932, she rose to become a buyer at Bamburgers and Montgomery Ward, a Merchandise Manager at Bloomingdales and AMC, a VP and Merchandise Director at Frederick Atkins, VP and Merchandise Manager of All Apparel at Bradlees, and Senior VP General Merchandise Manager of Venture Stores. She attained these positions at a time when it was unusual for women to have jobs of such responsibility. Her vision was to bring fashion style to the general public. After retiring, she worked at the non-denominational soup kitchen at St. James Church in Manhattan. Her warmth, caring, humor and leadership will be deeply missed by many.

We've heard that contributors to The New Yorker get paid handsomely for their work, but J. D. Salinger might outpace them all if a Las Vegas-based company realizes its asking price for a brief letter by that reclusive writer it is selling on eBay for $50,000. The sale, which was reported by Reuters, was listed on Tuesday by History For Sale, a memorabilia company, and offers an ''exceedingly rare handwritten letter'' by Salinger, the author of ''The Catcher in the Rye'' and ''Franny and Zooey,'' on his monogrammed letterhead and dated March 12, 1989. In handwriting that even the most perceptive Glass family member might have difficulty deciphering, Salinger wrote: ''Dear Mary -- Please make sure all the errands are done before you go on vacation, as I do not want to be bothered with insignificant things. Thank you, J. D. Salinger.'' It may not be the most enduring sentence composed by the author, who died in 2010, but it works out to about $2,083.33 a word (if you disregard the salutation and signature), a rate that even Malcolm Gladwell would have to envy.

He had a zest for life, was a true gentleman, and loved everything he did. He retired to Scottsdale, AZ and enjoyed a second career as jazz promoter and prominent figure in the Arizona Musicfest. Loving uncle of Robbie and Brooks Sumberg, Charles and Andrea Jayson; Matthew and Melitte Buchman and Victoria Lorini and grand uncle of Jenna and Jake Sumberg and Matthew and Zachary Jayson. Buzz was extraordinary in his grace; his absence will be felt by so many. We will love, remember and miss him forever. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Arizona Musicfest Jazz Education Program, Arizona Musicfest, P.O. Box 5254, Carefree, AZ 85377 or Arizonamusicfest.org.

This time last year, I wrote that an opening day loss wasn't necessarily a harbinger of things to come. But Week 1 isn't meaningless, and no team knows that better than the Chiefs. Last season, Kansas City pulled off the biggest upset in Week 1 and rode a hot start directly into a division championship. This past weekend, no team exceeded expectations like the Buffalo Bills. The Bills were initially listed as 6.5-point underdogs to the Chiefs, although speculation about Matt Cassel's injury drove the point spread down to 3.5 points by kickoff. But by either measure, a 34-point victory was nothing short of shocking. The Bills covered the point spread by either 40.5 or 37.5 points, depending on your perspective. The largest opening day ''cover'' in modern history came in 1997, when the Jets shocked the Seattle Seahawks, 41-3. The Jets were coming off a 1-15 season and were 6.5-point underdogs in Bill Parcells' first game with the team. The season ultimately ended with a 9-7 mark.

WASHINGTON -- Another 2.6 million people slipped into poverty in the United States last year, the Census Bureau reported Tuesday, and the number of Americans living below the official poverty line, 46.2 million people, was the highest number in the 52 years the bureau has been publishing figures on it. And in new signs of distress among the middle class, median household incomes fell last year to levels last seen in 1997.

President Obama is awarding Marine Cpl. Dakota Meyer the U.S. Medal of Honor for his valor during a 2009 battle in Afghanistan's Kunar Province. Corporal Meyer, 23, is credited with saving the lives of 36 Marines and soldiers - 13 Americans and 23 Afghans, when he charged repeatedly into a Taliban-held area after learning that four American military personnel -- three fellow Marines and a Navy corpsman -- were missing. Corporal Meyer came under heavy fire, but located and retrieved his fallen comrades from the battlefield with the help of a Afghan troops. He is only the third living veteran to receive the award for service in Afghanistan or Iraq and the first living Marine to receive the award since 1973.

The number of New Yorkers who smoke has declined 35 percent since 2002, bringing the adult smoking rate to what city officials said was an all-time low of 14 percent, the lowest level since they started tracking the habit, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced Thursday.

On what's supposed to be the last day of summer weather, a cool breeze was appropriately the inspiration for Odile Gilbert's hair backstage at Phillip Lim. After coating strands with Kérastase Fibre Architecte, a yet to be released product that's both a texturizer and a treatment conditioner, she parted straightened hair on the side and separated it into two low ponytails. These were then knotted at the neck and four little strands were pinned to the head as if blown back by a gust of wind. Perhaps in an allusion to the raincoats in the collection, nails were painted a custom blend of CND Raspberry Parfait, Guava and Speedy top coat. Francelle Daly for Nars created what she described as "dewy, fresh, skin" with Radiant Tinted Moisturizer intended to contrast "a edgy, heavy metallic eye." Night Life shadow was applied in the crease to make a demi lune; underneath it, a hollow of bare skin. The silver Paris Duo was used along the eyebrow and Rue Bonaparte neutral liner in the duct. Not one but six coats of mascara were applied to lashes. "Romantic and rebel," is how Daly explained this juxtaposition. Lips were covered in concealer and topped with Gaiete blush to create color in a fresh way. You know, these things change with the wind.
