Her last name means partner or husband, and her parents have married and divorced each other more than once. So it's no surprise that the Los Angeles artist Bettina Hubby is fascinated with the institution of matrimony. "Marriage is a big topic for me," she said. "I was married and so were my parents, several times, and I wondered why marriage hasn't changed or evolved the way other things have changed." In 2009 she initiated Get Hubbied, a multitiered art project to investigate the idea of marriage, which she describes as both fragile and resilient. Hubby and the artist and musician Tif Sigfrids, who have been working together for the last four years, conducted intensive research into all aspects of marriage and the rituals surrounding the wedding ceremony.

The barrier for entry into the jock memoir genre is, unsurprisingly, pretty low. For every "Open" - Andre Agassi's much-acclaimed, lovely autobiography - there are a dozen or so books like "Outrageous!," the decidedly less literary reminiscences of Charles Barkley, in which the author famously claimed he was misquoted. Sure, ghostwriters have something to do with this, but at least "Outrageous!" was about Charles Barkley - a controversial N.B.A. Hall of Famer who played with and against some of the league's all-time greats. What has always confounded me is the sheer number of ordinary, even journeyman athletes who cash in by documenting their rise to midlevel greatness between hard covers. But since so many of them do it, here are my favorites. (Intentionally missing is Jim Bouton's totally awesome, gossip-laden "Ball Four." Though Bouton was the definition of a mediocre player, he remains the Homer of the genre he created. Simply put, it's not fair to compare him to anyone.)

Two years after his attempt to travel to the Zurich Film Festival resulted in his arrest in connection with a decades-old sex crime Roman Polanski will return to that festival to receive the lifetime achievement award he was to have received in 2009, Reuters reported. Mr. Polanski, the director of films including "Rosemary's Baby," "Chinatown" and "The Pianist" was arrested at the request of the United States when he arrived in 2009 at the Zurich airport en route to the festival. Prosecutors in Los Angeles and Washington were seeking to extradite the filmmaker, who fled the United States in 1978 to avoid facing punishment after he pleaded guilty one year earlier to having sex with a 13-year-old girl. Mr. Polanski spent several months under house arrest in Gstaad before Swiss prosecutors said they would not extradite him.

Anchored by cones, spheres and stars, the wear-around-the-clock collection is an obvious departure from the designer's zanier, gem-heavy (and maybe less versatile) oeuvre. "Geometry is the starting point," says Azagury-Partridge, who was inspired by grade-school building blocks. "The first art lesson you ever learn is how to draw a sphere, a cone and a cube." And the stars? "They're just what you see every time you look up in the sky. They're eternally attractive."

A controversial version of ''Porgy and Bess,'' the famous 1935 opera, will move to Broadway as planned this winter now that the estates of the opera's creators have signed off on the adaptation, its producers announced on Wednesday. The show, titled ''The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess'' and now running at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., won praise from Boston critics, but New York reviewers were more mixed. The attention came after comments by members of the creative team about improving the opera had provoked the ire of the original's fans, most notably the composer Stephen Sondheim. But the producers on Tuesday released a batch of fulsome letters from representatives for the estates of George and Ira Gershwin and DuBose and Dorothy Heyward, ending speculation that the show might be derailed before New York.

Marc Jacobs, citing production delays caused by Hurricane Irene, decided a couple of weeks ago to move his main collection show from its usual perch on Monday night to Thursday, at the end of Fashion Week. He instead showed his diffusion line, Marc by Marc Jacobs, in the usual Monday time slot. And that turned out to be a good move, for more reasons than the extra design time he was able to buy. Too often, Marc by Marc gets swept under the rug, lost in a sea of shows. But giving it prime time placement enabled more people to see it (except for those who did not get the word that the show would start precisely on time). And this happened to be a really good season, with clothes that reflected better workmanship and clearer designs than I've seen in the past. Often, the denim-and-chinos heavy secondary lines from designers, Mr. Jacobs included, can look a little mass.

RIORDAN--Frances A.,82, passed away on September 11, 2011 in Cortlandt Manor, NY. She was born on April 7, 1929 in Jefferson, KY to James P. and Frances Whelan. Frances is survived by six children: Catherine (Kurt), Timothy (Suely), Mary Fern Edwards (John), Maureen Malone-Reed (Michael), David (Joan), and Marjorie Kemper (Michael), three siblings: Marjorie Hanawalt, James Whelan and Thomas Whelan, ten grandchildren and numerous nieces and nephews. She is predeceased by her husband Gerard T. Riordan, infant son James, parents, sister Beverly Marchetti, and brother Charles M. Whelan SJ. She was a lifelong member of Our Lady of Mercy Church in Forest Hills, NY and also active in the parish of Our Lady Queen of Martyrs. She attended Marymount College and worked for Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP in New York City. Frances was an accomplished watercolor painter, loved a good story, and was a generous host. We will miss her. Visitation will be on September 14th from 3pm until 7pm at the Edward F. Carter Funeral Home, Montrose, NY, with a Mass of Christian Burial on September 15th at 10am at the Church of the Holy Spirit, Cortlandt Manor, NY. Burial will follow at Mount St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations in Frances's memory may be made to the charity of one's choice. For further information please visit: www.efcarter.com.

We will be talking to Emmy nominees leading up to the awards show on Sunday. ArtsBeat talked to ''Raising Hope's'' Martha Plimpton, a nominee for best supporting actress in a comedy; Michelle Forbes, nominated for best supporting actress in a drama for her role in ''The Killing''; and Beth McCarthy-Miller, nominated for best directing of a comedy for ''30 Rock.'' It took five seasons of time-slot swaps, near-cancellations, lamentations from its devoted fans and an innovative network-sharing arrangement, but ''Friday Night Lights'' finally received an Emmy nomination for best drama in its last year.

Groupon is planning to put its initial public offering back on track even as markets remain rocky. After postponing presentations to potential investors early this month, the online coupon giant is now aiming to go public in late October or early November, according to people briefed on the matter. That would mean that Groupon could embark on its investor roadshow by the middle of next month, these people said.

HOSTILE TAKEOVER The reinsurer Validus Holdings said on Wednesday that it would seek to replace the board of Transatlantic Holdings. Transatlantic's shareholders are scheduled to vote next week on a proposed all-stock merger with Allied World Assurance. ''Validus believes the Transatlantic board has repeatedly failed to take the necessary steps to secure greater value for Transatlantic stockholders,'' Edward J. Noonan, above, chief executive of Validus, said in a statement. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

OPENINGS TORY BURCH wants shoppers to feel at home at her new shop, which just opened at 797 Madison Avenue; (212) 510-8371; toryburch.com. The five-story 19th-century town house, with a cozy fireplace and family photos, carries the label's entire collection, including clothing, handbags and accessories. To celebrate the opening, she created the 797 bag collection, with styles like a structured messenger bag, $525, and an envelope clutch, $425. ... Also opening a new store is MULBERRY, bringing British flair to SoHo at 134 Spring Street; (212) 835-4700; mulberry.com. The store, fitted out with some 8,000 books, carries the handbag line as well as exclusive pieces like the New York Clipper bag, in red, white or blue with a peace, love and apple luggage tag, $950. And for 10 shoppers really willing to demonstrate their love for N.Y.C., there is the Alexa bag, $6,250, made of ostrich skin and covered in dozens of gold apple-shaped trinkets. ... Another European new to the SoHo nabe is the French label SURFACE TO AIR, at 27 Mercer Street; (212) 256-0340; surfacetoairstudio.com. Admirers of the avant-garde brand can now buy the men's and women's collections here, including a fleece wool coat, $945, and a waxed cotton parka, $600.

The security guard at the New York Public Library took one look at Anna Dello Russo in her platform heels and pink Versace minidress and said: ''You're going to the fashion show, right? Third floor.'' How did he know Ms. Dello Russo wasn't there browsing for a nice biography of Winston Churchill?

As soon as Tayshana Murphy, 18, was shot early Sunday in the Grant Houses, a public housing project in Morningside Heights, Manhattan, her friends and neighbors declared that they knew, immediately, who had killed her. ''Manhattanville killed her, it's a fact,'' said Calvin Spencer, 30, who lives in the same building as Ms. Murphy did: 3170 Broadway at West 125th Street, where Morningside Heights meets West Harlem.

LYNCHBURG, Va. -- As a child, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas was dead set on being a veterinarian. ''That was my heart's content. It's what I always wanted to do,'' he said. Then came a day of reckoning, during the second semester of his sophomore year at Texas A&M University, when he went to see the dean of the veterinary school. His advice: switch to an easier major.

TAFFNER--Donald. The St. John's University family mourns the passing and celebrates the life of Donald Taffner, 53C, 89HON, illustrious and accomplished alumnus, extraordinarily generous benefactor, and loyal, cherished friend. For more than half a century, he blessed us with his love, dedication, and support and shared with us his remarkable creativity and business acumen. An inveterate sports fan, he inspired our student athletes, in particular, to pursue and achieve excellence in every facet of their lives. His legacy to them and to the entire University includes the Taffner Field House, a gift from him and his beloved wife, the late Eleanor Taffner, trustee emerita. St. John's has been immeasurably strengthened by his service, humbly given and most gratefully received. We shall remember him with admiration and affection always. Our thoughts and prayers go to his children and grandchildren in this time of sorrow. Peter P. D'Angelo, Chair, Board of Trustees Donald J. Harrington, C.M., President

The MakerBot 3-D printer offers the possibility of manufacturing products in the home almost as easily as printing a document with an inkjet printer. The company's Thing-O-Matic machine moves in three dimensions to spray layers of colored plastic to form objects, some quite intricate. Do-it-yourselfers are already selling 3-D printed products like lacewing earrings or custom dollhouse furniture at art fairs and museum shops and on Web sites that feature homemade crafts.

An article on Wednesday about the rise in the poverty rate misstated the year in which the median income, which fell last year, was at a similar level. It was 1996, not 1997.

Just as Palinologists and politicos are awaiting Sarah Palin's imminent (or so she says) decision on whether she will run for president, a new biography of her makes lurid accusations that have filtered out to media outlets now that the book has begun circulating. The book, ''The Rogue: Searching for the Real Sarah Palin,'' is by her former next-door neighbor - or rather, by Joe McGinniss, the best-selling but controversial author who moved into the house next door to the Palins in 2010 to research the book. (That prompted the Palins to erect a fence and claim via Twitter that he was trying to peek into their young daughter's bedroom. Mr. McGinniss responded that there was no bedroom view, and that Ms. Palin could have come over with a plate of cookies and had a civil discussion about the matter instead.)

An article last Thursday about restaurants and clubs expected to be popular with the fashion industry during New York Fashion Week misstated the name of a restaurant. It is Pulqueria, not La Pulqueria.

An article on Saturday about heightened anti-terrorism security measures being put in place in New York and Washington misspelled the given name and omitted the middle initial of the Senate's sergeant at arms, who told lawmakers and staff that there was no reason to change their daily routines. He is Terrance W. Gainer, not Terrence.

BERGER--Martin S, of New York City, Quogue, NY and Palm Beach, FL, passed away suddenly on September 12, 2011. Loving husband of Karen, cherished father of Brad, Greg (Janelle) and Leslie (Jeff) and stepfather of Staci (John) and Sueann (Peter), sister of Ina Feidelman (and the late Arnold) and Jack Berger (Carole) and adored Pop-Pop to Nicole, Jason, Morgan, Matthew, Niki, Tara, Eric and Sam, and beloved uncle and friend. Martin was the Chairman of the Board, Principal and Founder of the Robert Martin Company LLC, a Westchester County based diversified real estate company. He was also the Chairman of the Board, Owner and CEO of the City and Suburban Federal Savings Bank for over 40 years, as well as the President of the Construction Industry Foundation, and President of the Builders Institute of Westchester and Putnam Counties and a former Commissioner of the Westchester County Parkway Commission. Martin served on the Board of Mack-Cali Realty, the Municipal Assistance Corporation of New York, and Director of the Governor's Island Preservation Corporation. He also served on the Board of the White Plains Hospital Medical Center, UJA Federation of Westchester, and was a Founder of the Young Men's Division of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Martin was a member of Palm Beach Country Club and Hampton Hills Golf Club. Born June 19, 1930 in the Bronx, Martin graduated from DeWitt Clinton High School. He graduated from New York University in 1951 and proudly served his Country in the Korean War. In 1987, he was awarded an Honorary Doctorate in Commercial Science from Pace University. Martin was an extraordinary man whose towering presence will be sorely missed by so many. One of his greatest achievements was being named as one of the top ten most influential people in the history of Westchester County. He was a leader, visionary, friend and mentor to so many and his proudest accomplishments were his beautiful wife, devoted children and adoring grandchildren. Funeral services to be held Thursday, September 15 at 10am at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Avenue, New York City.

LORBER--Celia Benrubi. We are deeply saddened by the loss of the Lorber Family Matriarch. She was an exceptional lady who will be missed by all who knew her. Our heartfelt thoughts are with Howard, one of my dearest friends and mentor, for more then twenty-five years and his family. The Eide Family

EAYRSLEE, a new collection of utilitarian bags from Mimi Eayrs and Joanne Lee, is a happy result of their shared experiences in the job market. Bouncing around design and art-direction jobs, including a stint with the Brooklyn handbag label Hayden Harnett, they longed for a bag that could hold a computer and design materials yet not look woefully out of place heading straight to dinner. The Nicholson bag in navy canvas with leather trim, $425 (or in black or antique tan leather, $695), is a unisex on-the-go piece with adjustable straps so you can wear it as a backpack. The line includes an everyday satchel with brushed brass hardware, $475, and a mini cross-body bag, $275, that can double as a belt. Eayrslee bags at Gargyle, 16A Orchard Street;(917) 470-9367;gargyle.com.

Making the switch from a presentation, with models standing on platforms, to a formal runway show this season allowed Georgina Chapman and Keren Craig of Marchesa to do a lot of things differently. They could hire supermodels like Karen Elson and Karolina Kurkova. They could seat their guests, including Tinsley Mortimer and Courtney Love. They could show in a beautiful space, the Palm Court of the Plaza Hotel. And they could prove that they can design clothes that move, that sing and that have a reason to exist beyond knocking you over the head with their technical audacity. Ms. Elson opened the show in a tiered dress made of cascading silver fringe that was breathtaking. And the illusions created by the dresses that followed were fascinating to see in motion. Several of the dresses were made entirely of sheer tulle, on which sequins were embroidered to create coral-like patterns on the models' bodies. Others were inverted, with the sequins just visible beneath layers of draped organza or chiffon.

BERGER--Martin S. In a business partnership of over half of a century, sharing the glows of successes and trembling together through cycles of near disaster, bonds become those of friendship and grow to the strength of family. For the fortunate, like Marty and myself, those ties become ever stronger with the passage of time, and envelop children and grandchildren in the glow. Ours was that way and Marilyn, who looked to Marty as the brother she never had, and our Eileen, Stacy and Sam, Scott and Whitney all shared his paternal care and warmth, which was boundless. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his Karen, Ina, Jack, Brad, Leslie, Greg, and their families, as they struggle to accept the unexpected and sudden death of a wonderful husband, brother, father, and grandfather. We will all weep together. Marilyn S. and Robert F. Weinberg

If, as poetess Ella Wheeler Wilcox is right, ''a weed is but an unloved flower,'' then there are no weeds in the work of Tony Sweet. Mr. Sweet is a macro photographer whose close-up pictures practically caress the petals of the flowers that are his primary subject. While macro photography was once the realm of shooters who sprung for specialized close-up lenses, even basic point-and-shoot cameras come with a macro setting. Switch it on and you can get face to face with grasshoppers and make flowers look the size of cathedrals.

COHN--Michael, passed away in New York on Tuesday, September, 13. Born in Germany 1924, he came to the United States as a child, returned as a member of the U.S. occupation forces after WWII and became a lifelong student of the Jewish Diaspora. He produced books and exhibits at the Yeshiva Museum. He is survived by wife Susan, sister-in-law Bernice, and nephews David and Claude. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to GT Foundation, 706 Spring St., NW, Atlanta, 30308. Services Friday, 11:15am, Riverside Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave, Manhattan.

The New Music column on Sept. 6 misstated part of a lyric in the song ''Wedding Crasher'' on Terius Nash's new album, ''1977.'' It is ''I hate to have to crash your wedding,'' not ''I hate to have to cry at your wedding.''

Sales of Lil Wayne's new album dropped 77 percent in its second week out but it still easily holds No. 1 on the Billboard chart in a week that also saw the return of the Beatles to the Top 10. Lil Wayne's record, ''Tha Carter IV'' (Cash Money/Universal Republic), opened on last week's chart with a remarkable 964,000 sales, the second-biggest opening of the year and even more than many in the industry predicted for it. In its second week of release, the album moved 219,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

Most toddlers, being the intelligent creatures they are, like to mimic adults. Give them a toy cellphone to play with, and they demand yours instead. But who wants to put their mobile device in the hands of a 2-year-old? To help parents and other wary adults, Fisher-Price created the Laugh and Learn Apptivity Case, designed to hold an iPhone or iTouch securely and protect it from sticky fingers and drooling mouths.

Neil L. Rudenstine, the former president of Harvard University, was elected chairman of the board of the New York Public Library on Wednesday. Mr. Rudenstine, 76, is replacing Catherine Marron who has led the board since 2004. He will assume the post immediately. ''The New York Public Library is one of New York's great institution's, and one of the world's greatest libraries,'' Mr. Rudenstine, said in a statement. He has been a library trustee since 2001 and is also chairman of the board of ARTstor, a nonprofit digital library.

In these days of always-on devices, there's nothing worse than a dead gadget. New bags by PowerBag promise portable charging for multiple devices on the go. The bags, which will start at $140, come with built-in batteries to charge multiple USB devices. Called ''ful,'' the charging system is light enough not to weigh you down and powerful enough to charge almost any device including iPhones, tablets, ereaders, and Bluetooth devices - essentially anything powered with a USB cable.

The Advertising column on Wednesday, about new marketing campaigns by some luxury hotel chains, quoted incorrectly from comments by David Williams, the chief marketing officer of Orient-Express, about the chain's revenue trend for this year. He said revenue was up 14 to 15 percent from last year, not 40 to 50 percent.

An article in some editions on Nov. 25 about a dispute involving turkeys sold at farmers' markets in New York by Tamarack Hollow Farm contained several errors. The financier who invested in the farm, Michael Liebis, was born in Israel, not Brooklyn. And while Mr. Liebis and Mike Betit, the owner of the farm, in Burlington, Vt., did indeed travel between New York and Vermont on business, they said they did not do so five times a week, though they continue to disagree about how many trips they did make. They met as early as 2006, not in 2009. And at the time the two formed a partnership, Mr. Betit was selling at three greenmarkets, not one. These errors were raised with The Times in April. This correction was first delayed because e-mails went astray and later because of research. Because of an editing error, two picture captions on Wednesday with an article about a conflict over an affordable housing project in Woodstock, N.Y., were reversed in some copies. Iris York, an opponent of the project, was shown at the right, standing on the perimeter of the complex site. And Susan Goldman, a supporter, was at the left, in a cafe.

For nearly 40 years, several much-larger-than-life neighborhood advocates have been battling the establishment from a wall overlooking a West 46th Street playground. Turning against the ravages of drug abuse and the juggernaut of slum clearance, they carry blueprints, flowers and a manifesto - ''We the people demand control of our communities'' - into a rainbow-anointed future. The mural where they have done battle - ''Against Domestic Colonialism,'' by Arnold Belkin (1930-1992) - hasn't fared so well.

AT Lincoln Center last Friday morning, at the somewhat challenging hour of 9:30, the fashion and reality-TV worlds converged into one during the taping of the finale of this season's edition of ''Project Runway.'' The packed house lacked the usual star wattage of New York Fashion Week (the celebrity contingent included Jennifer Love Hewitt, Andie MacDowell, Thomas Jane, the guest judge L'Wren Scott and two of the ''Mob Wives''), but the crowd seemed content to be in the presence of the real stars of the event: the judges. Before the show, more than a few fans crowded around the seats where Michael Kors, Heidi Klum and Nina Garcia would soon sit and pass judgment, some taking iPhone photos of the empty seats with the judges' names listed on placards.
A selection of recent comments from readers of the Home section, drawn from nytimes.com. Intimidating Price Tags

If the photos you post to your Flickr account still have room for improvement, you can perform basic image-editing chores like cropping and adjusting exposure right on the site. To edit a photo already uploaded to Flickr, click its thumbnail on your photostream page. When the picture appears on its own page, click the Actions menu in the upper left corner and choose ''Edit photo in Picnik.'' If you have not used Picnik before, you will need to accept a user agreement and wait for the software to load. Once you are in Picnik mode, you can use the on-screen tools to adjust photos, apply special effects, add caption text and more. While Picnik does offer a premium service that costs money, many of the standard features are free to Flickr users.

Supreme Court Justice Stephen G. Breyer and the architect Zaha Hadid will join the jury that selects the Pritzker Prize, architecture's highest award, Thomas J. Pritzker, chairman of the Hyatt Foundation, the prize's sponsor, announced on Wednesday. Justice Breyer has long been interested in art and architecture and wrote the foreword to the 2006 book, ''Celebrating the Courthouse: A Guide for Architects, Their Clients, and the Public.'' Ms. Hadid, who received the Pritzker Prize in 2004, has projects in numerous countries including the United States, China, Germany, Spain and Italy.

9 P.M. (CW) THE SECRET CIRCLE After her mother dies in a fire, Cassie Blake (Britt Robertson, above with Louis Hunter), a seemingly normal teenager, is sent to live with her grandmother (Ashley Crow) in beautiful Chance Harbor, Wash., where everyone seems to know more about Cassie than she knows about herself. Including her hidden abilities. Thomas Dekker plays the warlock who helps her harness her magic. Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times, ''Pretty young characters in a picturesque location (British Columbia standing in for Washington State), coming of age to a pop soundtrack; dead or vanished parents; latent paranormal abilities; local hangout; small-town secrets -- it's the entire supernatural teenage soap opera template, but the execution is rushed and chintzy, without the languorous gloss that makes 'The Vampire Diaries' worthwhile.'' That show's Season 3 premiere leads in at 8. 1:40 P.M. (Sundance) THE MATADOR (2008) As a boy in Granada, Spain, David Fandila (right) would fight imaginary bulls with his mother's dish towels. He grew up to confront real bulls, some weighing 1,300 pounds or more, to his mother's dismay. This documentary from Stephen Higgins and Nina Gilden Seavey chronicles Mr. Fandila's quest to reach 100 fights in a single season, a goal only 12 matadors had achieved. ''Barbaric, elegant, primitive, erotic, revolting, thrilling: the movie, like bullfighting itself, is all of these,'' Jeannette Catsoulis wrote in The Times. ''Blessed with a charismatic leading man, an arcane setting (bullfighting has roots in Roman sacrificial religion) and a narrative steeped in blood and hand-to-hoof combat -- not to mention a triumphant six-bull climax -- the film is a Hemingway fantasy.''

6:46 p.m. | Updated The Avis Budget Group, which made an offer last year for the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, is walking away from its bid, potentially paving the way for Hertz Global Holdings to make the acquisition instead.

Calle 13, the urban duo from Puerto Rico, dominated the list of nominations for the Latin Grammys on Wednesday, named in 10 categories including album of the year and song of the year. - The other nominees for best album were a mix of new acts and stalwarts in the Latin scene. A recently formed pop trio - Alex, Jorge y Lena - was nominated for its sugary and romantic debut album of the same name (on Warner Music Latina), while Shakira, the pop superstar, was given a nod for ''Sale El Sol'' (Sony Music Latin/Epic). The other nominees were Enrique Iglesias for his album ''Euphoria'' (Universal Music Latino/ Universal Republic Records) and Franco De Vita, the veteran Venezuelan songwriter, for ''En Primera Fila.'' (Sony Music Latin).

The White House wants to make sure voters know that administration officials are doing everything they can to cut waste in these hard economic times. Towards that end, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday convened the first Cabinet meeting dedicated solely to looking at how to reduce waste at federal agencies. Mr. Biden announced a new waste-cutting initiative that he said would save $2 billion, and tasked the assembled Cabinet secretaries to mount reviews focusing on unnecessary and inefficient federal spending in their agencies.

An article on Aug. 30 about the energy challenges facing Germany as it moves toward shutting down all of its nuclear plants described the nation's peak electricity demand incorrectly. It averages 80 gigawatts, an instantaneous measure of power -- not 80 gigawatts per day.

There have long been whispers on Wall Street that hedge funds have hijacked the bankruptcy process, using their influence as debt holders to obtain and trade on insider information about when and how a company will restructure. A federal court ruling highlighted such concerns late Tuesday when a judge raised the possibility that four large hedge funds might have used confidential information to trade in the debt of Washington Mutual.

WHEN Henrik Vibskov, the cheeky Danish designer, decided to add fragrances to his inventive repertory, he took an uncharacteristically minimal, and global, approach with the three unisex scents. Type B, named for Berlin, is woody and warm, to suggest the German capital in winter; Type C, for Copenhagen, is evocative of the salty air of the harbor city; and Type D, for Damascus, is a spicy blend to conjure the marketplaces of the Middle East. Each is packaged in an adorable knit bottle sock that you'll wish came in hat sizes.
A listing of military deaths on Tuesday misidentified the branch of the military in which Petty Officer Brian K. Lundy served. It was the Navy, not the Marines.

BERGER--Martin S. Dad, we are grateful to have had you as our mentor, inspiration and loving father. Your life, which embodied passion, integrity and enthusiasm, set an impeccable standard for us and others to aspire to. While we mourn your passing we rejoice and celebrate the wonderful life you have lived and the legacy you have left behind. Our love for you and our memories of you are eternal. Rest in peace Daddy. Brad, Leslie and Greg

THE designer Yael Aflalo has moved the Reformation, her Lower East Side shop beloved for effortlessly hip basics made from vintage silk and lace, to an enormous (by Ludlow Street standards) space across the street. The revamped store, which will house the Reformation line of one-of-a-kind pieces repurposed from vintage materials, is divided into three rooms: an Alice in Wonderland-inspired boudoir with armoires filled with lingerie from Cosabella and Elle Macpherson; a loftlike space with silk keyhole gowns ($345), sleeveless camel coats ($165) and unisex cashmere sweaters ($75); and a dreamlike second floor with lots more clothes, jewelry by Pamela Love and Bing Bang and a floral installation courtesy of the Brooklyn florists Sprout. And it will continue its inspired collaborations: Come fall, look for cloaks from Lindsey Thornburg, vintage rock 'n' roll leather pieces from Veda and hats from Victor Osborne. The Reformation, 156 Ludlow Street; (646) 448-4925.

NEW YORKERS may not be paragons of patience. (Ask anyone who has ever had a taxi hijacked out from under him.) But what many lack in civility they make up in audacity. As Fashion Week draws to a close, some of that vaunted chutzpah was revealed on the runways in a parade of spring fashions that were among the most brazenly colorful and exuberant in years. At Lincoln Center, in Chelsea and all around town, designers signaled their optimism in a joyfully gaudy palette of cobalt blue, caution yellow, violet and searing chartreuse. Some, like Peter Som, Jason Wu and Nicole Miller, offered cheery mash-ups of pink and teal, purple and scarlet and assorted tints of rain-forest green. Their collections teemed with cabbage roses, outsize peonies and, in the case of Rodarte, van Gogh-inspired sunflowers meant to put a smile on the dourest of Fashion Week veterans.

A music review on Saturday about a performance by the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble, made up of members of the Orchestra of St. Luke's, referred imprecisely to the orchestra's new home. While it is in the same building as the Baryshnikov Arts Center and the orchestra co-owns the building with the arts center, the orchestra's home is the DiMenna Center for Classical Music, not the arts center.

SATURDAY'S PUZZLE - It is said, within some circles of crossword puzzle construction, that Saturdays are when the heavy lifters like to show off their stacks. Long, crunchy entries abound, foreign and complex words get shined up for their turn in the spotlight. Solvers are asked to ignore the sweat stains left after trying to formulate coherent Down entries all the way across rows of stacked 15s. I won't even get into the cluing; you know what I'm talking about. Saturday is not for the faint of heart.

Frederick Douglass spent much of his life speaking about the hardships of slavery - but even he, at times, realized that words were not enough. Instead, he turned to music: "The mere hearing of [slave] songs," he said, revealed the "physical cruelties of the slave system; for the heart has no language like song." Today, spirituals like "Go Down, Moses" and "God's Going to Trouble the Water" continue to convey American slaves' anguish, frustration and hope.

TORONTO - It is increasingly de rigeur for film festivals to encompass much more than film. Many major festivals now supplement screenings with installations and performances, and entire sections are devoted to exploring the intersection of cinema and the other arts. The Rotterdam Film Festival pioneered this kind of cross-disciplinary programming in the '90s. Berlin has an annual Forum Expanded mini-festival, which spills logically into the museums and galleries of an art-centric city. Sundance has a New Frontier sidebar. And since 2007 the Toronto International Film Festival has made room for film-based art installations in the Future Projections program.

I met Cliff Levy for the first time when he was in New York to collect his Pulitzer Prize last spring. He came up to my office and pitched a story about how he put his three Brooklyn-bred kids in a Russian school, even though they didn't speak the language, when he was sent to Moscow as a correspondent for The Times. I could hardly say yes fast enough to his story, which I knew would fascinate the many people on this earth obsessed with how best to educate their children. But I also privately wondered if maybe Cliff wasn't a little insane. I have twin daughters who just started kindergarten this week, and though their school could not be a warmer, more welcoming place - they even speak English there! - I still worry about their adjustment to an unfamiliar environment.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation took an important step this week toward getting big financial institutions, foreign and domestic, to submit resolution plans -- also known as living wills or funeral plans -- as required by the Dodd-Frank Act. And thus the living wills are key.

"The New Teen Titans" omnibus, Vol. 1, sits atop the hardcover list this week. It reprints the first 16 issues of the 1980s series that brought together a few sidekick heroes (Robin, Kid Flash and Wonder Girl) and teamed them with some new ones (Cyborg, Raven and Starfire). These Titans, written by Marv Wolfman and illustrated by George Pérez, become one of DC's most popular books. The stories reprinted in this omnibus edition chronicle the formation of the team, faceoffs with the assassin Deathstroke and the Fearsome Five, a misguided confrontation with the Justice League and a battle royal against Trigon, a demon who is also Raven's father. About midway in there is a "day in the life" story that focused on the civilian lives of the heroes. That issue cemented this series as doing something different: the creative team was developing three-dimensional characters and exploring new directions.

It's fitting that an artist whose work hinged so scrupulously on process - elaborate, showy, delicate process - would be drawn to photography as a medium. Robert Rauschenberg's paintings often incorporated many elements: premade images, junk, animal matter, all smothered in paint. They weren't paintings so much as developments, events, narratives of the process that produced them. There were the "Combines," which involved scraps of found items, clippings, stuffed creatures and silk-screens. Some works smashed the wall separating painting and sculpture. He once erased a drawing by his friend Willem de Kooning. Another time, he covered a painting acquired by John Cage in all black. In 1961, his submission to a show of portraits dedicated to the gallery owner and curator Iris Clert consisted of a telegram, stating, "This is a portrait of Iris Clert if I say so." The power of the work is diminished without taking note of the process. And photography, trapping light on a sensitive surface and using chemical wizardry to turn it into a printed image, is nothing if not about process.

"Rock 'n' roll on the Riviera" is the beauty catchphrase backstage at L'Wren Scott. "A contessa from wherever," is how Serge Normant described the woman that inspired the undone French twists he created using his own line of products. He coated hair with Meta Lush Volumizer and Meta Revive Dry Shampoo before blow-drying and using a small barrel curling iron to create the base for finger waves. Then, the back was swept to the side and tucked into a twist secured with pins. "Sophistication becomes disheveled," Normant said, using his fingers to pull apart the up do. Nails went the way of the lady, as well. "She wanted something sexy, nothing dark or overpowering of the clothes," Yuna Park said of Blush, the custom mauve polish she created for Scott to replace last season's black varnish. "It's less Gothic, more feminine -- not so harsh." For makeup, Aaron De May translated Scott's directive with a dense shiny eye, bronzed skin and a subtle lip. "Normally, L'Wren always likes strong, smoky, colorful, this was also about decadence, the duchesses, princesses arriving on boat in the '40s and '50s," he said. De May used Lancôme Star Bronzer in Solaire to make each girl's skin color "two tones darker." He then applied Le Crayon Kohl in Black Coffee all around the eye and in the crease. This was blended with Mochaccino shadow on the top and Vintage Brown on the bottom. He painted the inner corners of the eye gold from the 5 Pan Palette in Gold Frenzy and spread Juicy Tubes Pure clear lip gloss on the lid. "It can look dull or muddy with all that brown," De May said. "This brings life to the face in need of a little bit of sparkle."

After closing its doors in 2005 for a rafters-to-orchestra-pit renovation, Moscow's Bolshoi Theater still kicked up controversy - embezzlement, corruption, sex scandal. Now, three years past due and way over budget, the hall, which dates to 1825, will reopen next month with a gala performance of the ballet and opera companies' greatest hits. In attendance will be President Dmitri Medvedev and other heads of state, who will finally see what $760 million restores. It took more than 3,500 workers to restore the Apollo and the Muses ceiling piece, replicate the missing Villeroy & Boch tiles and hang 617 pounds of crystal from the main chandelier. Much of the work was supervised by the president's office itself, which stepped in when construction faltered in 2009, after a contractor was paid three times for the same work. Now the acoustics are fixed, subterranean hydraulic stages are built, and, for the finishing touch, the Romanov coat of arms has been reinstated above the lintels, in place of the hammer and sickle.

Eagles (1-0) at Falcons (0-1)Sunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Eagles by 2 1/2In honor of Michael Vick's return to Atlanta, the Eagles have starting using their 1989 throwback offense. The scheme pays homage to Randall Cunningham's glory days. The Eagles do not really drive down the field; they just string together amazing highlights, interspersing the occasional punt or baffling mistake. A typical play begins with two defenders knifing untouched through Philadelphia's porous, inexperienced offensive line. Vick either gets flattened or performs some Matrix-style escape, scrambling for a big gain or tossing to a receiver who used the confusion to get wide open. Andy Reid calls for a timeout four or five times per half to impose order (teams only get three timeouts per half, but a 5-yard penalty is a small price to pay for the chance to install a precisely designed sequence of plays for Vick to scrap).

In 1972, Massimo Vignelli designed a diagrammatic map for the New York City subway. It was a radical departure. He replaced the serpentine maze of geographically accurate train routes with simple, bold bands of color that turned at 45- and 90-degree angles. Each route was color-coded, its stops indicated by black dots. Its abstract representation of the routes was elegant but flawed. To make the map function effectively, a few geographic liberties were taken, something that didn't sit well with New Yorkers.

On Sept. 16, 1974, President Gerald R. Ford issued a proclamation that offered amnesty to those who evaded the draft during the Vietnam War. As Western democracies contemplate the ravages of debt and recession, in India the global economic crisis has manifested itself this summer as a burning debate about corruption. Led by a 74-year old farmer from Maharashtra, Baburao "Anna" Hazare, the popular outcry against this scourge of the Indian polity has consumed the months of summer and monsoon from April to September. While the Indian media have read Anna's appearance in public life as a historic moment, in fact it is an old tension within India's founding principles that has once again come to the fore.

There's more bad news for households. Two years after his attempt to travel to the Zurich Film Festival resulted in his arrest in connection with a decades-old sex crime Roman Polanski will return to that festival to receive the lifetime achievement award he was to have received in 2009, Reuters reported. Mr. Polanski, the director of films including ''Rosemary's Baby,'' ''Chinatown'' and ''The Pianist'' was arrested at the request of the United States when he arrived in 2009 at the Zurich airport en route to the festival. Prosecutors in Los Angeles and Washington were seeking to extradite the filmmaker, who fled the United States in 1978 to avoid facing punishment after he pleaded guilty one year earlier to having sex with a 13-year-old girl. Mr. Polanski spent several months under house arrest in Gstaad before Swiss prosecutors said they would not extradite him. The organizers of the Zurich festival, who plan to present Mr. Polanski with his award on Sept. 27, said in a statement, ''We have always been tremendous admirers of his work and we are delighted that we will soon be able to express this to him in person.'' Mr. Polanski's new film, ''Carnage,'' an adaptation of the stage play ''God of Carnage,'' will be the opening night film at the New York Film Festival on Sept. 30, and the director is the subject of a retrospective now running at the Museum of Modern Art.

The $2 billion trading loss that has rocked the Swiss banking giant UBS has also cast a spotlight on a relatively unknown but increasingly profitable corner of Wall Street - Delta One desks. Both Kweku Adoboli, the UBS trader in London arrested on Thursday in connection with the loss, and Jerome Kerviel, the Societe Generale trader who was responsible for $6.8 billion in losses in 2008, worked on such desks.

Perhaps there is something worse than being talked about, and that is having words attributed to you that you never wrote. At least, that's the case being made by Merlin Holland, the grandson of Oscar Wilde, who says that a coming play promoted as a rediscovered Wilde text is not the handiwork of his illustrious grandfather, The Guardian reported. On Friday, the King's Head Theater in London plans to open its production of ''Constance,'' a play that its Web site describes as ''Oscar Wilde's final play.'' The theater says the play, about an industrialist, his loyal wife and her extended family, was written by Wilde after his release from prison in 1897 and given to the actress Cora Brown Potter, who in turn gave it to the French writer Guillot de Saix. With a collaborator, Henri de Briel, de Saix produced a French translation, which has been adapted by Charles Osborne for this production.

For decades, they have solved the riddle of what to give those who seem to have everything. Pieces of Steuben glass, those quintessential samples of American artisanship, have proved suitable for queens and presidents, brides and retiring executives. But in a few months, wedding guests and sheepish husbands will have to find a substitute for gifts from Steuben because the 108-year-old glassmaker is shutting down its factory in Corning, N.Y., and its flagship store on Madison Avenue in Manhattan. The cause of the company's demise was a waning appetite for fancy crystal that was exacerbated by the weak economy, company officials said.

CHARASH--Dr. Leon I.,passed away on September 14th, two days after his 84th birthday after a long illness. He is survived by Phyllis, his devoted wife of 58 years, his children, Barbi and Reuven Yellin, Bruce, William and Lori and Michael, his former daughters-in-law, Sarah and Nancy, his grandchildren, Judith and Kenneth David, Karyn Kovacs, Dayna Yellin, Philip, Brian, Leah and Rachel Charash and Arin Charash as well as brothers-in-law Herbert Newman and his wife, Beth, Martin Newman and sister-in-law Toni Sachs and her husband, Michael Norcia. Dr. Charash graduated from Cornell University, Phi Beta Kappa and from Cornell Medical School, Alpha Omega Alpha. After completing a residency program in pediatrics at the Massachusetts General Hospital, he served as a Captain in the United States Air Force from 1952 to 1954. After returning from service, he completed another year of training in pediatrics at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in New York. After this training, Cornell devised a fellowship for him in pediatric neurology. It was the first such fellowship in that specialty in New York State. After all his training, Dr. Charash opened up an office on Long Island limited to the practice of pediatric neurology. He served on the faculty of Cornell University Medical College as Associate ClinicalProfessor of Pediatrics and as a Consultant in Child Neurology at as many as 20 hospitals. He was the first physician to be sent to Brazil by the United States Government to start a Cerebral Palsy Center in Sao Paulo. He served as the National Chairman of the Medical Advisory Committee of the Muscular Dystrophy Association for decades, as well as being a member of their Board of Directors. He appeared on the Jerry Lewis Labor Day Telethon every year since its inception, until he retired four years ago, informing the public of the latest medical breakthroughs and treatment. He, also, chaired international meetings on neuromuscular disorders for the MDA. And, in addition to all the medical societies to which he belonged, Dr. Charash was a member of the Child Neurology Society and the American Academy of Cerebral Palsy and Developmental Medicine. He was much beloved by his patients, his office staff and all who knew him. He loved being a physician and has helped countless familes at their time of distress and need. He will be sorely missed by his very devoted and loving family, his nieces and nephews, cousins and his friends. The funeral will take place at Guttermans, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury at Noon on Sunday, September l8th. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions in his memory to the Gurwin Jewish Healthcare Foundation, UJA-Federation, The Muscular Dystrophy Association, North Shore Synagogue or the charity of one's choice.

Simmering tensions between the faculty and administration at the prestigious Bronx High School of Science have led to an exodus of teachers, with 8 of the school's 20 social studies teachers choosing not to return this year. Of those, one teacher retired several years before she planned to, one took a sabbatical, and six went to other schools, including places whose students are more likely to struggle academically, faculty members said. ''In my 25 years of teaching experience, I have never witnessed so many people transfer out of one department so quickly,'' said Louis DiIulio, a social studies teacher who remains at the school.

An article on Wednesday about Senate efforts to provide more money for disaster aid misstated the result of a procedural vote on Tuesday. The vote for cloture, on a bill for Burmese trade restrictions that included the disaster aid, was 61 to 38, with one abstention -- not 53 to 33, with 14 abstentions. (That was the result on Monday for an initial cloture vote on the bill.) The article also misstated the votes of two Republican senators. Senator Dan Coats of Indiana voted for cloture on Monday but changed his vote to no on Tuesday. And Senator Patrick J. Toomey of Pennsylvania voted in favor of cloture on Tuesday after voting against it on Monday.

The Madoff family is having its say. Little, Brown & Company said on Thursday that it was moving up the publication of ''Truth and Consequences,'' a book conceived by Catherine Hooper, the fiancee of Bernard L. Madoff's son, with Laurie Sandell, a journalist and author, to October from November.

The University of California, Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive on Wednesday presented the schematic design for the transformation of a former printing plant into its new home, designed by the New York firm Diller Scofidio + Renfro. Located at 2120 Oxford Street in Berkeley's arts district, the $100 million project is scheduled to be completed in late 2015; $65 million has been raised so far. The design combines the existing 1939 concrete Art Deco-style building, unoccupied since 2004, with a new metal-clad, skylighted structure that will include galleries, a 32-seat screening room, a store and a learning center.

A capsule summary on Wednesday for an article about plans by Wal-Mart to help women-owned businesses and women workers misstated the outcome of a class-action lawsuit that women workers filed against the company. The Supreme Court threw the case out this summer; the women did not lose the case.

After a summer of strong ticket sales the producers of the Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' are doubling down on the commercial longevity of the show, announcing Thursday that its star, Reeve Carney, will extend his contract through May 2012. Mr. Carney has played Peter Parker and Spider-Man at most performances since the musical began running last November, and he stayed with the show during its difficult winter months when a series of accidents and artistic changes plagued the show. Mr. Carney's contract had been set to expire in November, and the extension will probably keep him in the musical when Tony Award nominees are chosen. ''Spider-Man'' did not open in time to qualify for this year's awards.

BEIJING -- In the name of fighting pollution, China has sent the price of compact fluorescent light bulbs soaring in the United States. By closing or nationalizing dozens of the producers of rare earth metals -- which are used in energy-efficient bulbs and many other green-energy products -- China is temporarily shutting down most of the industry and crimping the global supply of the vital resources.

Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about ''Heart of a Soldier,'' an opera about the Sept. 11 attacks, misidentified the country where Rick Rescorla, a hero of Sept. 11, served. He led troops in Northern Rhodesia, which is now Zambia, not Zimbabwe.

An article on Monday about the excitement in the Russian republic of Dagestan generated by an elite Cameroonian soccer player hired by an obscure club there that is owned by Sulyman Kerimov, a Russian oligarch, misstated the salary of the player, Samuel Eto'o. He is being paid $30 million per season, not $30 million over three years. The article also erroneously included a wealthy American industrialist of Russian descent among a group of sporting oligarchs who have purchased or sought to purchase professional teams. The industrialist, Len Blavatnik, never expressed interest in purchasing the West Ham United team of Britain. So it is not the case that he ''tried and failed in an attempt to buy West Ham United,'' a rumor that had been generated by a speculative article in the now-defunct News of the World tabloid on July 11, 2010, which was refuted at the time by Mr. Blavatnik's representatives.

It is one of the district's few residential buildings, not the only one. The error was repeated in a picture caption.

OZMON--Nat P. Nat P. Ozmon, the senior member and founder of Anesi, Ozmon, Rodin, Novak & Kohen, Ltd died on September 14, 2011, in Chicago, IL at the age of 86 of natural causes. He was born in Davenport, Iowa, attended college at New York University and received his law degree from Northwestern University, ranking first in his class. He was elected to the Board of Law Review Editors and installed in the Order of Coif, a legal scholastic honor society. Mr. Ozmon's 40 years as a trial and appellate lawyer was dedicated to preserving and enhancing the rights of injured victims. He was certified by the American Board of Trial Advocates, a diplomat of the American Board of Professional Liability Attorneys, a fellow and a founder of the Roscoe Pound Foundation, the Trial Lawyers for Public Justice and the Institute for Injury Reduction. He was a recognized leader of the bar and has served on the managing boards of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America, the Chicago Bar Association, and the Society of Trial Lawyers. He was also a past president of the Illinois Trial Lawyers Association. He was an Adjunct Professor at Loyola University School of Law where he taught Trial Advocacy senior law students for ten years. The Harvard Law School Study listed him as one of "The Best Lawyers in America." He also received the Leonard Ring Lifetime Achievement Award for his commitment to victims rights and trial by jury. He is survived by his wife, June Maguire Ozmon; his children, Nat P. Ozmon, Jr.; Laird Ozmon; Lorna Ozmon; Kelle Ozmon; Rachel Maguire; and his six grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Salvation Army, https://donate.salvationarmyusa.org/page.aspx?pid=207#

She is survived by her husband of 57 years, John M. Franks, devoted mother of Colettte Coan of Rockville Centre, NY, Lauren Pollack of Bayport, NY. Baby sisters Agnes (Bobby) Nevin of Downingtown, PA, Audrey Hagemaier of Edgewater, FL. and beloved grandmother of Nicolette, Myles, Dylan and Skyler. Always caring and giving, her loss and her legacy are immeasurable.

Kweku Adoboli traveled from Ghana to Israel to a Quaker boarding school before attending a leading university in Nottingham, England. With his education pedigree, he landed a coveted job at UBS, the giant Swiss bank, right after graduation. But his ascent came to an end in the cool, predawn hours on Thursday when Mr. Adoboli, a 31-year-old trader, was arrested in London on suspicion of causing some $2 billion in losses. The bank said the loss could be enough to wipe out its entire quarterly profits. Investors recoiled, sending shivers through European banks that have already been buffeted by the Continent's debt woes. Mr. Adoboli had not been charged on Thursday.

The Scouting Report column on Thursday misstated the dates for H. Stern's Gold Rush event. It is next Wednesday through Saturday, Sept. 21 to 24 -- not today and tomorrow. The column also misstated the dates of the Zadig & Voltaire sample sale. It is next Wednesday through Sunday, Sept. 21 to 25; it is not in progress and it does not end this Sunday.

Holoszyc--Gertrude, died on September 14 in Riverdale. Born in Lubaczow, Poland on December 11, 1920, she survived the Holocaust with false identity papers. She emigrated to New York in 1947 and married Leon Holoszyc in 1949. In 1964, they established Bert-Hollis Business Machines, and after Leon's untimely death in 1972, she managed the business alone for ten years before her younger son, Michael, joined her. She continued working until 1995, when the onset of Alzheimer's Disease prevented her from continuing. She then struggled with the disease for over 15 years. She is survived by her two sons, Henry and Michael, and four grandchildren, Petrina, Gabriel, Raphael, and Felix.

AMER--Norman Stanley, Dr. 81, of Woodmere, NY, devoted husband to Jo, beloved father of Scott (Yvon) Amer, Jeffrey (Audrey) Amer, Wendy (Howard) Amer Hirsch, and Lori (Dan) Amer Winston, and proud grandfather of Loen, Addison, Callia, Jenny, Chelsey, Arinn, Moss, Robbie, Lisle, Spencer, Graham, and Jonah, died on September 13. Norman was a noted Cardio-Thoracic Surgeon who practiced at several Long Island hospitals.

PLOTKIN--Carol, on September 14, 2011. Beloved daughter of Frances and the late Gerald. Dear sister of Beth. Loving aunt of Eve, Jake and Gabe. Graveside service Sunday 11am at Cedar Park Cemetery. Donations in her memory may be made to The American Diabetes Association.

SUNDAY'S PUZZLE - DON'T QUOTE ME ON THIS, but I do believe this is one of my favorite Sunday puzzles in quite a while. I'm not much for negativity, but even with all of the DON'TS! it was a lot of fun hunting for the theme phrases. Naturalism is the philosophical theory that treats science as our most reliable source of knowledge and scientific method as the most effective route to knowledge. In a recent essay for The Stone, Timothy Williamson correctly reports that naturalism is popular in philosophy. In fact it is now a dominant approach in several areas of philosophy - ethics, epistemology, the philosophy of mind, philosophy of science and, most of in all, metaphysics, the study of the basic constituents of reality. Metaphysics is important: if it turns out that reality contains only the kinds of things that hard science recognizes, the implications will be grave for what we value in human experience.

There are cities you love for what they offer in terms of superficial diversion - the joy of hunting down a perfect piece of passementerie in Paris or of locating a wonderfully sinuous leather journal in Milan - and there are cities you love for their significant history and scope, despite their lack of good shopping. Athens is one of those cities, offering up the Parthenon and not much else, as is (so I'm told) St. Petersburg. Jerusalem is one of my favorite cities on the planet; its yellow stone and golden light draw me back time and again, but when I was there this past July as a judge for the Jerusalem Film Festival I was reminded of the serious absence of retail therapy.

8 P.M. (HBO) HEREAFTER (2010) Clint Eastwood imagines what happens after we're gone by braiding together three story lines, each involving a collision between the living and the dead. In San Francisco George Lonegan (Matt Damon, above), who receives messages from the deceased loved ones of anyone he touches, decides to live a life of obscurity instead of cashing in on his gift. In London Marcus, a solemn boy, feels the presence of his twin, Jason, whose violent death has left Marcus adrift. (The brothers are played by George and Frankie McLaren.) And in Paris Marie Lelay (Cécile de France), a television journalist who nearly died in the 2004 tsunami in South Asia, is convinced that she has seen a metaphysical reality the rest of the world is determined to ignore. ''Persuasion is not really the point, though if anyone could make me believe in ghosts, it would be Clint Eastwood,'' A. O. Scott said in The New York Times of this film, written by Peter Morgan (''Frost/Nixon,'' ''The Queen''). ''What does seem new -- newly strange, newly beautiful -- is what 'Hereafter' makes of the here and now,'' Mr. Scott added. ''It is a curious movie in both senses of the word: an unusual experience and an open-ended inquiry into something nobody can really claim to understand. It leaves you wondering, which may be the most fitting way of saying that it's wonderful.'' 9 P.M. (Animal Planet) TOO CUTE! PUPPIES The first three months of three puppy litters are chronicled from a dog's-eye perspective.

An article on Page 57 this weekend about the singer-songwriter Feist omits the first paragraph and part of the second in some editions. The passage should read: Leslie Feist, the songwriter who records as Feist, led a visitor up a winding trail to a hilltop with expansive views of treetops and a reservoir. Bounding ahead were her two mongrel dogs: the white Sasha, described by her owner as ''hyperemotional, sometimes gets depressed,'' and the black Bentley, who's ''just out for a good time.'' Feist added, ''They're both like me.'' Along the path Feist mentioned lyrics -- from her new album, ''Metals'' (Cherrytree/Interscope) -- inspired by the view. ''River dam, lake fills up the land,'' she recited. ''Climb up to the lookout.'' She laughed. ''I can't believe I'm doing the cheesy self-quoting thing.'' The complete article can be found at nytimes.com/music.

LEVINE--Harvey. The Board of Governors and the members of the Seawane Club, record with sorrow the loss of our member Harvey Levine. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife Gloria and family. Jack Irushalmi, President

The television and film actor Jerry O'Connell (''Sliders,'' ''Jerry Maguire'') will make his Broadway debut this fall as a self-satisfied young writer in Theresa Rebeck's new comedy, ''Seminar,'' which stars Alan Rickman as a no-holds-barred writing teacher. The producers also announced on Friday that Hettienne Park would play another budding author, one who brings a charged-up libido to class; Ms. Park played a supporting role in Tony Kushner's recent play at the Public Theater, ''The Intelligent Homosexual's Guide to Capitalism and Socialism With a Key to the Scriptures.'' Mr. Rickman, along with Lily Rabe and Hamish Linklater, had already been cast in the production, which Sam Gold (''Circle Mirror Transformation'') will direct. Preview performances are scheduled to begin Oct. 27 at the Golden Theater, with an opening night of Nov. 20.

ANNA SUI rarely fails to put a smile on your face with her whimsical prints and girly dresses, and her show this week was no exception. Her soundtrack transformed the big tent at Lincoln Center into a scene from Club Sept in Paris in the 1970s, and the models lined up at the back of the runway as if they were waiting to get in. One by one, they took the catwalk wearing chiffon trousers and tops in dark vintage prints, many of them with matching turbans, or long lace gowns with floppy hats. Her prints were especially witty, one with stripes that, if you looked closely, were made up of toothbrushes.
NO. 1 OKLAHOMA AT NO. 5 FLORIDA STATE 8 p.m., ABC

ROTHSCHILD--Ruth, (Perlman), beloved wife, mother, grandmother and sister passed away in Delray Beach, FL, on September 16, 2011. Born in Wilkes Barre, PA, she lived most of her life in New York and later in Florida. She will be missed by all who knew her. Ruth spent her life as a registered nurse caring for those in need, particularly geriatric and Alzheimer patients. She leaves behind a loving family that will miss her including her husband, of 53 years, Raymond, sons Howard and Tod, daughters-in-law Amy and Gittie and grandchildren Jennifer, Michael, Yehuda and Bayla. Services Sunday 12 noon at Gutterman's, 175 N. Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, NY.

A picture caption on Friday with an article about a hedge fund manager who is taking a major role in philanthropy reversed the identifications of the manager, Tom Steyer, and his brother Jim in some editions. Jim is at the left, in a blue shirt, and Tom is at the right. And Jim was also erroneously identified as Tom in some editions in a picture with the continuation of the article.

And so the day finally came when even Peter Rabbit, the vegetable-nibbling, clothes-losing, tea-sipping bunny created by Beatrix Potter more than 100 years ago was the subject of a planned sequel-slash-reboot. But at least in this case his latest adventure is being written by an author with the sense and sensibility to preserve the voice and spirit of Potter's original stories. Emma Thompson, the actress whose films include ''Howards End,'' ''Remains of the Day'' and the 1995 version of ''Sense and Sensibility'' that won her an Academy Award for best adapted screenplay, will write ''The Further Tale of Peter Rabbit,'' the Frederick Warne imprint of Penguin Young Readers Group said. This book, which is planned for publication next September, will be the first to feature Peter Rabbit since 1930 and the first authorized version to be written by any author other than Potter, who introduced the character in ''The Tale of Peter Rabbit'' in 1902.

CHARASH--Leon I. The Muscular Dystrophy Association expresses its deep sorrow at the passing of Dr. Leon Charash, a volunteer leader of the Association since the mid-1950s, serving as Chairman of its Medical Advisory Committee from 1971 to 2008, as a corporate member from 1985 to 2009, and as a member of our Board of Directors from 1994 to 2009. A strong advocate for children, Dr. Charash worked with MDA in the late 1950s to help children who use wheelchairs gain admission to New York City public schools. He had a particular interest in the psychosocial aspects of muscle disease, especially for children. Dr. Charash helped direct the growth of our clinic program to more than 200 hospital-affiliated clinics across the country, and was a key figure in the expansion of our worldwide research program, leading to significant advancements in the understanding of neuromuscular diseases and to present-day clinical trials of potential treatments. His strong and compassionate leadership will be missed by the entire MDA family. Board of Directors, Muscular Dystrophy Association R. Rodney Howell, M.D., Chairman Gerald C. Weinberg, President & CEO Olin F. Morris, Chairman, Executive Committee Lois R. West, Vice Chairman, Executive Committee Suzanne Lowden, Treasurer

OSTROW--Marvin, Beloved husband of Elayne (Sherry) for 68 years, and father of Peter and Stacy. Grandfather, great-grandfather, brother, brother-in law, friend, and citizen. Born in New York City in 1921; graduated from UNC Chapel Hill. Lt. in the US Navy Service in WWII on the USS Sigsbee; CEO Forest Paper Company. Avid sailor, life-long learner and laugher. He was loved by many and will be missed forever. Funeral service on Sunday, September 18 at 1pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. at 76th St.

With unemployment hovering around 9 percent, many Americans are relying on government unemployment benefits to make ends meet. Now, a new, private option is available that can help replace, at least temporarily, more of the income forfeited when you lose your job. IncomeAssure is a supplemental unemployment insurance policy that, when combined with public unemployment insurance, can help temporarily replace up to half of your lost wages. Leslie Nylund, chief executive of the Assura Group of NY Ltd., which introduced the offering this summer, says she believes her firm is the only company currently offering such coverage.

A few days into a much-publicized shakeup of its superhero titles, DC Comics has experienced a less pleasant tremor with the resignation of the writer of ''Static Shock,'' one of 52 comic books that the publisher restarted at issue No. 1 this month. John Rozum, the writer of ''Static Shock,'' wrote Thursday on his personal blog that his decision to leave the series ''was of my own choice'' and that he had not been fired by DC. He added: ''I've been very happy overall with my time at DC over the roughly 15 years that I've worked for them, and I plan to continue working with them into the future. The feeling is mutual.''

AILLONI-CHARAS--Dan, died peacefully in his home in Scottsdale, Arizona on August 27, 2011. He was born on May 22, 1930 in Ploesti, Romania and immigrated to Palestine in 1944. He fought with the Haganah and lived in Israel at the beginning of its statehood. In 1952, he received a Bachelor's degree in Political Science and, in 1953, a Master's degree in Political Science from the University of California, Berkeley. Subsequently, he returned to Israel and held an administrative position at the Israel Institute of Technology (Technion) and founded the Israel Association of Social Scientists. He married Miriam Taytelbaum in Israel in 1957 and they moved to the US the following year. In 1968, he received a Ph.D. in Management Sciences from the NYU Graduate School of Business. He founded the NY-based marketing services company Stratmar Systems in 1969 and acted as President and CEO until his retirement in 2001. He continued as Chairman of the Board and stayed involved in daily operations until his death. He participated in the leadership of the American Marketing Association and the Promotional Marketing Association. He also served on the board of the Coro National Alumni Association. and the Industry Advisory Board of the National Association of Chain Drug Stores. He was an adjunct professor of Marketing at NYU and Pace University and developed the first university course on Promotion. He authored Promotion: A Guide to Effective Promotion Planning, Strategies & Executions. He is survived by his wife, Miriam, his sons, Ethan, Orrin, and Adam, and his grandchildren, Ben, Hayley, Adin, Eli, Cole, and Natasha.

For decades they have been an elusive collector's item sought by puzzle fans and musical theater aficionados alike: The cryptic crosswords that the celebrated composer Stephen Sondheim created for New York magazine in the late 1960s and that were later compiled in a book that has long been out of print. But earlier this week some online chat sites devoted to puzzles began to buzz about a Web site that included scans of 19 crosswords that were apparently the Sondheim mother lode. ''These are the gold standard for sure!'' one commenter gushed on Facebook. But are they the genuine Sondheim?

Until this week, Kweku M. Adoboli was riding high, a young trader for a big bank, with a stylish apartment in a fashionable London neighborhood and a steady girlfriend. On Wednesday, the world of Mr. Adoboli - whose name in a language spoken in his native Ghana means ''born on a Wednesday'' - began to come tumbling down around him. After being questioned by compliance officers about some of his trades, he became evasive, later sending a ''confessional'' e-mail to bank officials, saying that he did not have the information they wanted.

In the third in a series of columns about financial pitfalls that dog certain groups, Ron Lieber used the troubles of professional athletes as examples of what not to do if you suddenly come into a lot of money. Here is a sampling of reaction to the column. COMMENTSMy income ballooned instantly upon a huge promotion last year, vaulting my salary from the top third to the top 10 percent. We handled (and still handle) this by immediately lopping off all of the extra income beyond what I had earned prior to the promotion, and have rolled this into savings/investments.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has snuffed out smoking more audaciously than any of his recent predecessors, as the latest figures attest: only 14 percent of New Yorkers now smoke, the city reported Thursday, discouraged in large part by the ever-cresting wave of Bloomberg-driven taxes and bans. But Mr. Bloomberg is hardly the first New York official to battle tobacco use. Efforts to restrict smoking can be traced back at least as far as an edict in 1639, which happened to coincide with the start of New Amsterdam's first tobacco plantation.

An article on Friday about the effect of China's control over rare earth metals on energy-efficient products like light bulbs misstated the price of 11-watt G.E. compact fluorescent bulbs listed on Wal-Mart's Web site. The price of $15.88 is for a three-pack, not a single bulb.

The Media Equation column on Monday, about the growing popularity of niche media sites on the Web, misstated the terms of The New York Times's arrangement with Nate Silver's political blog FiveThirtyEight. The blog is licensed by The Times; it was not acquired, and the blog reverts to Mr. Silver at the conclusion of the license.

LEVINE--Harvey L.,83, of Hewlett Bay Park, NY and Palm Beach, FL passed away on Friday, September 16, 2011 at home. He was the beloved husband of Gloria for 61 years, wonderful father of the late Dr. Steven Levine and Cheryl Gursky, Carolyn and Neil Coplan, MD, and Gail and Richard Rubel, and the cherished grandfather of Stephanie, Matthew, Kathryn, Alison, Jaclyn, Lauren and Sarah. Harvey was an alumnus of William & Mary and the NYU School of Law. He was a prominent member of the Real Estate community and a generous philanthropist. He was a long-term member of the Seawane and High Ridge Country Clubs, and an outstanding athlete. Harvey was deeply loved and appreciated, and will be greatly missed by his family. Services Sunday, 11:30, Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, Hewlett.

A bitter trial that rattled the normally quiet world of mutual funds came to an unusual end on Friday, as a jury awarded Jeffrey E. Gundlach, a star bond fund manager, millions of dollars in unpaid compensation even though it found him liable for breaching his fiduciary duty and stealing trade secrets at his former firm, Trust Company of the West. Jurors took two days to find Mr. Gundlach and three co-defendants liable for taking trade secrets from Trust Company of the West, known as TCW, after he was fired in December 2009. It also found all four liable for breaching their fiduciary duty to TCW and Mr. Gundlach liable for interfering with investor contracts.

An earthquake measuring 6.8 on the richter scale shook Sikkim, leaving eighteen people dead, of which 13 are Indian and five Nepali, and dozens injured (NDTV). Although the epicenter of the earthquake was 40-miles north-west of Gangtok, Sikkim, tremors were felt across North and East India. The three aftershocks "triggered massive landslides" causing National Highway 31, the only road link to Sikkim, to cave in in four places, disrupting rescue operations (Indian Express). Most telephone lines remain dead and the region faces extensive power cuts.

The slump in the United States and other advanced economies is the result of a failure of demand -- period, end of story. All attempts to claim that it is somehow structural, or maybe the result of reduced incentives to produce, have collapsed at first contact with the evidence.

Just a quick thought: in much discussion of economic policy these days, the presumption is that stimulus had its chance, it failed, and that's that. Never mind those of us who say that we actually didn't do nearly enough -- and were saying that from the beginning, not as an after-the-fact rationalization. It's one strike and you're out.

All of India has been up in arms about corruption. Hundreds of thousands of people, many of them middle class, flocked to mass demonstrations led by the social activist Anna Hazare this summer, enraged by the constant demands for bribes by petty bureaucrats. But in some places the stakes are much higher. This video report by Poh Si Teng and article by South Asia Correspondent Lydia Polgreen examine the interconnected deaths of three doctors in Uttar Pradesh, India's most populous state. The killings have laid bare a violent culture of graft that has hobbled the state's health system, they report from Lucknow. Read more »

SLOSS--Rosalyn (Saperstein), 91, dearly loved wife, mother and grandmother, died of a stroke on September 10, 2011. Ros was predeceased by her husband Richard with whom she traveled the world watching birds, and her beloved son David. She leaves behind her cherished daughters Virginia and Katherine, daughter-in-law Elyse Goldweber, grandchildren Sophie and Sammy Chamino, Katharine Sloss-Hartman and Gabrielle Sloss, and her brother and sister-in-law Richard and Joan Steele and sister and brother-in-law James and Elinor Schatz. Ros graduated from Russell Sage College in 1941 and received her MLS in Library Science from C.W. Post. She was a reference librarian at the Hewlett-Woodmere Public Library for 25 years, and served on the Board of The Five Town Senior Center. Ros was remarkable. A life-long Democrat possessed with an active social conscience, she was an early proponent of civil and woman's rights. She was a great clipper and sender of articles from the New York Times which she hoped would motivate her children and grandchildren. Ros loved New York City, books, theater, film, museums and traveling. She cherished friends and family who returned those feelings in kind. Donations may be made to The Five Towns Senior Center and Planned Parenthood of New York City. A private memorial service will be planned.

The end of summer is marked by public pool closings, neighbors firing up the leaf blower and the kids whining about the burdens of furthering their educations. But for car collectors, at least those in temperate climate zones, it is a chance to plan the season's last long drives and visit the final car shows of the season, among them the Fairfield County Concours d'Elegance, which takes place this weekend. Of the post-Pebble Beach concours, Fairfield stands out for its robust corporate sponsorship (Porsche is the official presenter), inventive classes and, based on its ZIP code, ready access to some very fine cars, many of which will be displayed at the Fairfield County Hunt Club in Westport, Conn. The grounds are walkable on Saturday, with the judged concours following on Sunday. (Admission to the concours is $10 on Saturday; Sunday admission is $30.) For the second consecutive year, Bonhams will also hold an auction of collector cars and memorabilia on Sunday.

A report in the Evening Hours column last Sunday about the opening of an exhibition at the International Center of Photography misstated the show's title. It is ''Harper's Bazaar: A Decade of Style'' -- not ''Harper's Bazaar: Greatest Hits,'' which is the title of a book published in conjunction with the exhibition. The column also misidentified Glenda Bailey. She is the author of that book, not the ''author'' of the exhibition. (The show's curator is Vince Aletti.)
Classical Allan Kozinn
