In a time bank, the unit of currency is not a dollar, but an hour. Members indicate what services they might be able to offer: financial planning, computer de-bugging, housecleaning, child care, clothing alterations, cooking. People teach Mandarin and yoga and sushi-making. Time banks -- more than 300 of them -- exist in 23 countries. The largest one in New York is the Visiting Nurse Service of New York Community Connections TimeBank. Exchanges are easiest when people live in the same neighborhood.

Muscovites have been taking to cycling, and one of their new traditions, the Moscow Architectural Velonight, which drew more than 5,000 participants in July, is coming to Manhattan on Oct. 1 as Velonight New York (velonightnyc.blogspot.com). Velonight's creator, Sergey Nikitin, is an associate professor of Russian art, architecture and ''sociourbanistics'' at the People's Friendship University of Russia in Moscow. ''Moscow and New York are incredibly alike these days,'' said Mr. Nikitin, who added that the midnight-to-dawn bike tour of Manhattan would focus on architecture and sites evocative of the city's postwar culture.

RONALDUS SHAMASK thinks he was the first designer to show at the New York Public Library, in the Celeste Bartos Forum. He cannot recall the year, but suffice to say the tents and all the hoopla had not yet arrived. ''I paid $1 for the library,'' Mr. Shamask, 66, said with a grin on Friday morning in his studio on West 38th Street. I first met Mr. Shamask in the late 1980s, when his spare and architectural designs had already been celebrated with industry awards. His modernist clothes, in contrast to the ladies-who-lunch fashion then causing a clamor, made him a maverick.

A true lady in life-she will be missed by all who knew her. Services to be held Monday at 11:45 at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

WILLIAMS--Claude Kress. Claude (C.K.), died peacefully at home at age 88 on September 7, 2011, in Montecito, California. Born in New York City on April 9, 1923, he was a graduate of St. Bernard's School, St. Paul's School and Princeton '45. C.K. served for three years in the U.S. Army during WWII and later as a 2nd Lt. during the Korean War. In 1948 he moved to Houston Texas and founded the Williams Brothers Construction Co. When he retired in l985, it was the seventh largest highway construction company in the country. In addition to running a successful business, C.K. enjoyed a flourishing career as an artist with many sell-out one-man shows and a large group of collectors. His paintings reflect his exuberance for life as well as a skilled technique developed over many years of experimentation. C.K. is survived by his wife of 22 years, Mary Elting Church Williams, a son, Claude Kress Williams, Jr., a daughter Cynthia Williams Collins, a son-in-law, Atwood Collins III, two grandchildren, Atwood Porter Collins and Dwight Mallory Collins and three great-grandchildren. The burial service in New Paltz, New York, will be private.

Naturalism is the philosophical theory that treats science as our most reliable source of knowledge, and scientific method as the most effective route to knowledge. It is now a dominant approach in several areas of philosophy: ethics, epistemology, philosophy of mind, philosophy of science and, most of all, metaphysics, the study of the basic constituents of reality. Metaphysics is important: if it turns out that reality contains only the kinds of things that hard science recognizes, the implications will be grave for what we value in human experience. Perhaps the most notable thing about naturalism is the way its philosophers have employed Darwin's theory of natural selection to tame purpose. In 1784 Kant wrote, ''There will never be a Newton for the blade of grass.'' What he meant was that physical science could never explain anything with a purpose, whether it be human thought or a flower's bending toward the sun. That would have made everything special about living things -- especially us -- safe from a purely scientific understanding. It would have kept questions about humanity the preserve of religion, mythmaking and the humanities.

An article last Sunday about a recording studio in Brooklyn that was opened by Converse, which invited musicians to use it for free, misstated the name of the marketing company that runs the studio. It is Cornerstone Promotion, not Cornerstone Promotions. The article also referred imprecisely to the relationship between Cornerstone and the lifestyle magazine Fader. While Cornerstone and Fader have the same top executives and operate from the same address, Fader Inc. is publisher of the magazine, not Cornerstone.

Saturday Morning at the Museum When I was growing up, Saturday mornings meant one thing only to me: a trip to the Boston Museum of Science. I loved science -- still do -- and there was nowhere else I'd rather be. The museum's instructors would give these fascinating two-hour lectures and demonstrate the laws of physics using hands-on experiments. They would also quiz us on the museum's exhibits, and all the kids would try to show off by having every answer. Those visits to the museum stretched my mind in ways that my schoolwork didn't. They taught me to listen, question, test and analyze. Figuring out how things work -- and how they can work better -- is what led me to become an engineer, a technology entrepreneur, a philanthropist and a mayor. I guess I can count my lucky stars that there were no Saturday morning cartoons when I was kid. Mayor, New York City

An article on Page 57 this weekend about the singer-songwriter Feist omits the first paragraph and part of the second in some editions. The passage should read: Leslie Feist, the songwriter who records as Feist, led a visitor up a winding trail to a hilltop with expansive views of treetops and a reservoir. Bounding ahead were her two mongrel dogs: the white Sasha, described by her owner as ''hyperemotional, sometimes gets depressed,'' and the black Bentley, who's ''just out for a good time.'' Feist added, ''They're both like me.'' Along the path Feist mentioned lyrics -- from her new album, ''Metals'' (Cherrytree/Interscope) -- inspired by the view. ''River dam, lake fills up the land,'' she recited. ''Climb up to the lookout.'' She laughed. ''I can't believe I'm doing the cheesy self-quoting thing.'' The complete article can be found at nytimes.com/music.

In the heat of a pennant race with Boston on Friday, the Tampa Bay Rays made a curious choice for their cleanup spot. Batting fourth was Casey Kotchman, the journeyman first baseman who was hitting .312 - between Boston's David Ortiz and Chicago's Paul Konerko that night on the list of A.L. batting leaders. Kotchman, 28, had the worst full season of his career for Seattle in 2010, hitting .217 with a .280 on-base percentage and a .336 slugging percentage. As early as spring training, he said, he had problems with depth perception.

An opinion essay on Sept. 4 about the mood in New York City before the Sept. 11 attacks incorrectly described the institution that was on the site of what is now the south wing of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in Manhattan. It was an orphanage, not a lunatic asylum. The essay also incorrectly described a sequence of events in 2001. The first day of classes at the Cathedral School of St. John the Divine, which the writer's daughter and stepson attended, was Sept. 5, not Sept. 11. A phone call from a school employee, mentioned in the article, occurred before the start of classes, not on the Thursday before the attacks.

She was happiest when pushing herself to her physical limits. She competed in countless marathons and triathlons, including the Iron Man, and never gave anything less than her best. HARTENBAUM--Gloria, age 89 of Weston, CT.,on September 13, 2011. Born Gizelle Herskovits in Bixad Romania/Hungary, the eldest living member of four sisters who survived The Holocaust. Gloria was the author of the book, "Gizelle, Save The Children," which were the last instructions her mother gave to her when separated in the concentration camps. The book recounted her family's journey before, during and after World War II. She was a frequent lecturer on The Holocaust to groups and students around the nation. Gloria was married to Bela Hartenbaum for over fifty years. She is survived by her devoted children, Marge Currie and husband Jon, Ron Hartenbaum and wife Alexandra, the late Laura Hartenbaum, seven grandchildren, Matthew, Scott, Nicole, Marisa, The late Michael, Steven and Jonathan, and their wives/husbands; Carrie, Eva and Seth. Gloria was blessed with five great grandchildren; Ava, Ethan, Ruby, Anais and Angeles. Gloria resided in New York, NY., Los Angeles, CA., and Weston, CT. Funeral services were held Friday, September 16, 2011.

A chronology of events last Sunday with an article about oral histories of the Sept. 11 attacks misstated President George W. Bush's whereabouts at 8:50 a.m. when he was told that a plane had hit the north tower of the World Trade Center. He was about to enter Booker Elementary School in Sarasota, Fla., to visit a second-grade class; he was not reading to the students at that time. (At 9:05 a.m., he was listening to the students read when he was told that the south tower had been hit by a plane.)

When the euro was born more than a decade ago, its creators argued that, as a common currency, it would bring strength and efficiency to Europe's economy. They surely didn't imagine that in the summer of 2011, it would do exactly the opposite. A debt crisis first hit Europe in 2009, but that was only the beginning. This summer, the crisis grew to threaten the euro itself -- requiring the European Central Bank and governments to take unusual actions, including complicated bailouts and strict austerity measures.

''Perhaps this collection is minimal, but only by comparison to my other collections,'' Solange Azagury-Partridge said of 24:7, her new group of cast-gold jewelry. Anchored by cones, spheres and stars, the collection is an obvious departure from the designer's zanier, gem-heavy (and maybe less versatile) oeuvre. ''Geometry is the starting point,'' said Ms. Azagury-Partridge, who was inspired by grade-school building blocks. ''The first art lesson you ever learn is how to draw a sphere, a cone and a cube. And the stars? They're just what you see every time you look up in the sky. They're eternally attractive.'' Available Tuesday, with prices starting at $1,200; solangeazagurypartridge.com. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

A review on Sept. 4 about ''The Emperor of Lies,'' a Holocaust novel by Steve Sem-Sandberg, referred incorrectly to the Lodz ghetto and to others geographically located in present-day Poland. While they were established by the German occupiers of the country, they were not ''Polish'' ghettos.

BERLIN -- The courtyard of the nightclub Picknick was packed with partygoers dancing, shouting over the music and snapping photographs of one another, by all appearances just another night in this dilettante party capital. But appearances, on this recent Saturday night, were very much deceiving. The images snapped with iPhones and Android smartphones were projected in a constantly changing slideshow on the side of the neighboring building by a new photo-sharing application called EyeEm. The plastic foam clouds dangling from the wires crisscrossing overhead were the logos for the popular audio-sharing service called SoundCloud, which has roughly seven million users.

An article last Sunday about relics of an Indian tribe found in Montana misstated the name of the university where the tribe's archaeologist works as a professor of anthropology. It is Little Big Horn College, not Bighorn Community College.

There's a taste of the art house of old in the release on Tuesday of two of the omnibus films so popular with audiences in the '60s -- ''Casanova '70'' and ''Boccaccio '70.'' And speaking of 70, you've never seen an elephant fly until you've watched ''Dumbo,'' whose Disney character is celebrating his 70th anniversary. Michelangelo Antonioni's early film ''The Story of a Love Affair'' bows that day, as do two of Claude Chabrol's movies, ''Les Cousins'' and ''Le Beau Serge.'' And Jamie Lee Curtis and Patrick Swayze star in Randal Kleiser's winning small-town drama, ''Grandview U.S.A.'' Three of the films of Theo van Gogh, the Dutch director who was assassinated in 2004, will be released on Sept. 27, including ''Interview'' (remade in this country with Steve Buscemi and Sienna Miller). Charlton Heston's chariot races for glory will arrive on the 52nd anniversary of ''Ben-Hur.'' ''Carlos,'' Olivier Assayas's epic and wildly entertaining bio of the terrorist mastermind, also arrives that day, along with ''The Ma & Pa Kettle Complete Comedy Collection'' from Universal. Come and git it.

The Ping column on Aug. 28, about Web sites that link users to people who will run errands or perform other tasks for them, referred incorrectly to a music podcast recorded by James Levine, whom the columnist hired to organize her closet. The podcast is recorded in rehearsal space at the Chelsea Arts Building in Manhattan, not in his apartment.

As the Jehovah's Witnesses prepare to move their headquarters out of Brooklyn, where their Watchtower sign has long been a fixture of the cityscape, they are selling two town houses, two brownstones and a carriage house on prime Brooklyn Heights blocks. The five properties, with combined asking prices of $18.8 million, are going on the market this weekend. They join three that went up for sale a few weeks ago, and are also among 35 borough properties that have housed staff members and hosted out-of-town guests for more than a century. The Watchtower Bible and Tract Society, the legal and publishing entity of the Jehovah's Witnesses, has bought a 250-acre forested plot in Warwick, N.Y., a small town on the New Jersey border, and is moving ahead with plans to build a self-contained campus there.

I have never seen Bertrand Blier's raucous, lyrical road comedy ''Going Places'' without noticing at least one audience member stalking out in disgust. In a way that's an honest reaction. Mr. Blier means to rough you up, just as his two loutish heroes rough up the people they encounter. It's not bullying, more like someone telling you not to worry if you get grease on your pressed shirt or dirt under your nails. Mr. Blier means to make us feel more alive, more in touch with simple, sensual, irresponsible pleasure. Gérard Depardieu's Jean-Claude and Patrick Dewaere's Pierrot are dirty enough for Henry Miller, but they also could be offspring of D. H. Lawrence's happy idiot. In their dumb, brutish way they revere the familiar mystery of sex and are in awe of nature.
'It's not the right moment to find excuses.'

''3 Women'' is less like other, earlier Robert Altman films than it is a precursor to the weird world of David Lynch, particularly ''Mulholland Drive.'' The picture starts us off swimming, almost literally, in a state of dislocation: the marvelously gangly Shelley Duvall is Millie, a low-level worker at a water-therapy center for the elderly in a California nowheresville. Sissy Spacek is Pinky, the weird new girl whom Millie must train; she's just shown up from Texas, seemingly with nothing but her portable sewing machine in tow.
Manhattan Battery Park City $330,000

IN 2003, when I was living in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, I suddenly developed a severe sensitivity to chemicals. It cut short my work as a documentary and editorial photographer. The urban life I had previously navigated with ease became a toxic war zone. I fled the city and lived in tents and trailers, and under the open sky, for two years, then built a house in the woods where I live, in Truxton, N.Y.

HOW do you achieve the perfect cherry-stained lip? On the perfect fall face? T asked the makeup artist Tina Turnbow, who replied: ''I start with a base of moisturizing lip balm by Clark's Botanicals in Madge Mauve. On top of the balm, I line and fill in with Laura Mercier's lip pencil in Luscious Very Cherry. Then I blot the excess with a tissue. I touch up the skin (but only where necessary) with a moisturizing concealer by Koh Gen Do, and then apply a bit of Lush Flush Lip and Cheek Stain by Sephora to the apple of the cheek. Finally, I coat the lashes with Lancôme Hypnose Doll Lashes, and set it all with a light misting of Tata Harper Hydrating Floral Essence.'' Easy, breezy. Thanks, Tina.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the effects of Israel's crises with Egypt, Turkey and the Palestinians misstated the nationalities of the dead in the May 30, 2010, confrontation between Israeli naval commandos and a Gaza-bound flotilla from Turkey that had been seeking to break Israel's blockade of Gaza. They included eight Turkish citizens and one American citizen of Turkish descent. They were not all Turkish citizens. (The Times also corrected this error in an article on July 7 about the mending of Israeli-Turkish relations. And the erroneous information, taken from statements by Turkish officials at the time of the incident, also appeared in articles on Jan. 25 and April 2, and in numerous articles during 2010.)

CHARASH--Dr. Leon I.,passed away on September 14th, two days after his 84th birthday after a long illness. He is survived by Phyllis, his devoted wife of 58 years, his children, Barbi and Reuven Yellin, Bruce, William and Lori and Michael, his former daughters-in-law, Sarah and Nancy, his grandchildren, Judith and Kenneth David, Karyn Kovacs, Dayna Yellin, Philip, Brian, Leah and Rachel Charash and Arin Charash as well as brothers-in-law Herbert Newman and his wife, Beth, Martin Newman and sister-in-law Toni Sachs and her husband, Michael Norcia. Dr. Charash graduated from Cornell University, Phi Beta Kappa and from Cornell Medical School, Alpha Omega Alpha. After completing a residency program in pediatrics at the Massachusetts General Hospital, he served as a Captain in the United States Air Force from 1952 to 1954. After returning from service, he completed another year of training in pediatrics at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in New York. After this training, Cornell devised a fellowship for him in pediatric neurology. It was the first such fellowship in that specialty in New York State. After all his training, Dr. Charash opened up an office on Long Island limited to the practice of pediatric neurology. He served on the faculty of Cornell University Medical College as Associate ClinicalProfessor of Pediatrics and as a Consultant in Child Neurology at as many as 20 hospitals. He was the first physician to be sent to Brazil by the United States Government to start a Cerebral Palsy Center in Sao Paulo. He served as the National Chairman of the Medical Advisory Committee of the Muscular Dystrophy Association for decades, as well as being a member of their Board of Directors. He appeared on the Jerry Lewis Labor Day Telethon every year since its inception, until he retired four years ago, informing the public of the latest medical breakthroughs and treatment. He, also, chaired international meetings on neuromuscular disorders for the MDA. And, in addition to all the medical societies to which he belonged, Dr. Charash was a member of the Child Neurology Society and the American Academy of Cerebral Palsy and Developmental Medicine. He was much beloved by his patients, his office staff and all who knew him. He loved being a physician and has helped countless familes at their time of distress and need. He will be sorely missed by his very devoted and loving family, his nieces and nephews, cousins and his friends. The funeral will take place at Guttermans, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury at Noon on Sunday, September l8th. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions in his memory to the Gurwin Jewish Healthcare Foundation, UJA-Federation, The Muscular Dystrophy Association, North Shore Synagogue or the charity of one's choice.

Buster Keaton has the most noble, solemn and honest face of all 20th-century film comedians, a face that says, ''Nothing bad should ever happen to me.'' But, of course, faces like that are magnets for all manner of trials and troubles, and in the silent movie ''Seven Chances'' Keaton, who also directs, plays a lowly businessman whose firm will fall to ruin unless he can raise a lot of cash quickly. Happily, he learns he stands to inherit $7 million -- but only if he can find a bride by 7 o'clock that evening. Keaton does have a true love, played by Ruth Dwyer, but a misunderstanding has separated them, leaving him to conduct a series of rushed bridal auditions. This trim little movie's glorious extended finale consists of Keaton's outrunning first a stampede of eager brides-to-be (their makeshift veils constitute a kind of tribal uniform), and then, as he skedaddles down a steep hill on the way to his one true love, a mini-avalanche of boulders. The sequence is a marvel of physical comedy, rendered in wide shot with very judicious cutting. We get to see it all, Keaton's arms and legs a windmilling whirlwind of motion as he flees the throng of bloodthirsty womenfolk. Nothing bad should ever happen to a guy with a face like Keaton's, but in ''Seven Chances'' he triumphs by running like the dickens. They had faces then, but they also had legs. (Kino, December, standard $29.95, Blu-ray $34.95) STEPHANIE ZACHAREK
GREENWICH VILLAGE CO-OP $569,000

CHARASH--Leon I. The Muscular Dystrophy Association expresses its deep sorrow at the passing of Dr. Leon Charash, a volunteer leader of the Association since the mid-1950s, serving as Chairman of its Medical Advisory Committee from 1971 to 2008, as a corporate member from 1985 to 2009, and as a member of our Board of Directors from 1994 to 2009. A strong advocate for children, Dr. Charash worked with MDA in the late 1950s to help children who use wheelchairs gain admission to New York City public schools. He had a particular interest in the psychosocial aspects of muscle disease, especially for children. Dr. Charash helped direct the growth of our clinic program to more than 200 hospital-affiliated clinics across the country, and was a key figure in the expansion of our worldwide research program, leading to significant advancements in the understanding of neuromuscular diseases and to present-day clinical trials of potential treatments. His strong and compassionate leadership will be missed by the entire MDA family. Board of Directors, Muscular Dystrophy Association R. Rodney Howell, M.D., Chairman Gerald C. Weinberg, President & CEO Olin F. Morris, Chairman, Executive Committee Lois R. West, Vice Chairman, Executive Committee Suzanne Lowden, Treasurer

For months the protesters had planned to descend on Wall Street on a Saturday and occupy parts of it as an expression of anger over a financial system that they say favors the rich and powerful at the expense of ordinary citizens. As it turned out, the demonstrators found much of their target off limits on Saturday as the city shut down sections of Wall Street near the New York Stock Exchange and Federal Hall well before their arrival.

CHARASH--Leon. The Board, Administration and Staff of the Gurwin Jewish Healthcare Foundation and the Gurwin Jewish Nursing & Rehabilitation Center extend heartfelt sympathy to Phyllis Charash, President of our Foundation, and founding board member and Vice President of our Center, on the loss of her beloved husband, Dr. Leon Charash. Leon, a nationally renowned scientist and caring physician, defined the word "gentleman" and was a devoted friend and advocate to Gurwin and to those we serve. We extend sincere condolences to Phyllis, Barbi, Bruce, Michael, William and the entire family. Lawrence Simon, Chairman Bert E. Brodsky, President Herbert H. Friedman, Exec.VP

ROSENAU--James N.,a renowned scholar in the field of International relations and a pioneer in the study of globalization, died on September 9, 2011 in Louisville, Colorado. He was 86 years old. Rosenau is predeceased by his first wife, Norah McCarthy. He is survived by his current wife of 17 years, Hongying Wang, and children, Margaret, Fan and Patrick, and granddaughter Nicole. Throughout his groundbreaking academic career, Rosenau wrote and edited over 40 books, and many more articles. In 2005 Foreign Policy named him among the 25 most influential academics in foreign affairs. In 1991 Rosenau also wrote and produced a play, Kwangju. Rosenau liked to say that for him home was any college campus. He began his teaching career in 1948. He taught at Rutgers University, Ohio State University, and the University of Southern California before being named University Professor of International Affairs at the George Washington University in 1992. He retired from teaching in 2009, having taught continuously for over 60 years. Rosenau was born in Philadelphia in 1924, the son of Walter and Fanny Rosenau. His family moved to New York City in 1929, and in 1933 he entered The Lincoln School of Teachers' College where he was known for his athletic prowess and the long term papers he wrote. During World War II, Rosenau served in the US Army, as a cryptographer. After the war, he enrolled at Bard College. While there, Rosenau was hired to compile and edit a volume of FDR's personal letters, during which time he lived at the Roosevelts' Val-Kill farm. Rosenau received his Masters from the School of Advanced International Studies and his Ph.D. from Princeton. Rosenau is predeceased by a sister, Helen, and a brother, William.

In a recent article, The New York Times Magazine implied that Pastor John Hagee has a favorite candidate in the 2012 presidential election. Like most Americans,Hagee has not yet decided whom he will support. Contrary to what is written, Hagee has never referred to Catholicism as a''godless theology of hate.'' When he used those words, Hagee was referring to general Christian anti-Semitism, not to any particular denomination.Further, the coverage asserts that Hagee has a poor relationship with the Catholic community.This is also untrue. Bill Donohue,the president of the Catholic League, very recently put out a press release entitled ''Pastor John Hagee Deserves Better Than False Accusations,'' in which he directly refutes such assertions.The article also grossly over simplifies a sermon Hagee gave concerning the Holocaust and the rise of modern Israel. While some took offense to the sermon, the coverage fails to mention that in Hagee's subsequent reconciliation with the Anti-Defamation League, it's national director, Abe Foxman,thanked Hagee, the founder of the largest pro-Israel group in America, for having ''devoted [his]life to combating anti-Semitism and supporting the State of Israel.'' ARI MORGENSTERN, Spokesman, Christians United for Israel E-MAIL letters to magazine@nytimes .com or post comments at nytimes.com /magazine. Letters should include the writer's name, address and daytime telephone number. We are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished submissions. Letters and comments are edited for length and clarity. The address of The New York Times Magazine is 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018.

FRIEDENBERG--Daniel Meyer, a financier, collector, historian and philanthropist died on August 28 in Portland, Oregon. He was 88 and had recently moved to Portland from Greenwich, Connecticut to be closer to family. Daniel Meyer Friedenberg was born on February 24, 1923, in Mt. Vernon, New York and grew up on Manhattan's upper east side, where his father, Samuel Friedenberg, a Jewish immigrant from Poland, ran a commercial building enterprise. Daniel received his B.S. from the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce at the University of Pennsylvania in 1943 and enlisted in the Army where he served from 1943-1944. After the war Daniel traveled the world, an experience that changed him forever and rooted him as a world citizen. Called home to take over the family business, Dan earned his living in real estate development and management in New York City, where he headed John-Platt Enterprises. Dan believed in lifetime accomplishments and admired scholarship, intellectual curiosity and writing. Jewish themes and history remained close to his heart. An expert in Judaica, Daniel served as part-time Curator of Coins and Medals at the Jewish Museum in New York City from 1962-1982. "The Jewish Museum family mourns the loss of our Esteemed Curator Emeritus, Dan Friedenberg. During his tenure, and throughout his life, Dan made major scholarly contributions to the fields of Jewish numismatics and medieval seals. He was an eclectic collector and a generous donor of important works to the museum," the museum wrote in the New York Times. Daniel published several poems, over one hundred magazine articles and seven books including, Great Jewish Portraits in Medal, Jewish Medals from the Renaissance to the Fall of Napoleon, Jewish Minters Masters & Medalists, Medieval Jewish Seals from Europe, for which he won the National Jewish book award, Life Liberty and the Pursuit of Land, about land development in Colonial America, Sold to the Highest Bidder, a chronicling of the role of money in presidential politics and Tiberius Julius Alexander, a historical novel which he published in his 87th year. He was formerly a contributing editor of Dissent and a correspondent and feature writer for the New York Herald Tribune. A life-long collector, Dan strongly believed in philanthropy and donated a number of collections to museums and colleges, including significant Judaica, Pre-Columbian art, first edition books and modern art. Beyond his many and great accomplishments, we believe the true legacy of Daniel M. Friedenberg was the love and generosity he shared for his family. He possessed a dignity and genuineness that was rare. We were blessed to have him as a father. Daniel is survived by Beba Joy, mother of Samuel Clark and Danielle Joy and also survived by June Daniels, mother of Jay and Russell, and four grandchildren; Andrew, Emily, Chloe and Johnny Sequoyah. Interment will be at Mt. Pleasant, Valhalla, NY following services.

As the world knows, Americans own too much stuff. Yet watching ''Pee-wee's Big Adventure'' makes you realize how many things you never knew you needed, some of them available directly from the back pages of comic books: 3-D glasses, the better to see through girls' dresses; a giant plastic thumb, which makes a handy hitchhiking aid; big rubber ears to make people think you're listening when you're really not. In the world of Pee-wee -- a k a the actor-comedian Paul Reubens -- these are life's essentials, and the director Tim Burton revels in their candy-corn colors, their shiny, gleaming textures, their outright silliness. The plot of ''Pee-wee's Big Adventure'' -- which revolves around the theft of Pee-wee's beloved bike -- is slender, but the delights that fan out around it are plentiful. Mr. Reubens's Pee-wee is a naïf and an imp, a Pan figure in too-short trousers who prances in delight at his own jokes and eschews the allure of women. (When his comely bicycle technician, played by the angel-faced Elizabeth Daily, suggests a date, he informs her solemnly that he's ''a loner, a rebel.'')

Nolan Ryan threw baseballs past hitters for 27 years with the Mets, the Angels, the Astros and the Rangers, and set major league records with 5,714 strikeouts and 7 no-hitters. Ryan, 64, who was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1999, is part owner, chief executive and president of the Texas Rangers. Q.

To the Editor: In ''On Campus, It's One Big Commercial'' (Sept. 11), we learn that students are working as brand representatives at their schools, promoting products and assisting on corporate-sponsored field trips for late-night shopping sprees.

An article on Aug. 28 about the original production of the Stephen Sondheim-James Goldman musical ''Follies'' misstated the initials of the person who once hosted a get-together where Mr. Sondheim played and sang the whole musical. And a correction in this space on Sept. 4 also referred incorrectly to the host. The host, D. D. Ryan -- not B. B. -- was a woman.

RIBICOFF--Casey (Lois). A memorial service celebrating Casey's life will be held at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th St. on Tuesday, September 20 at 11am. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Weill Cornell Medical College, in memory of Casey Ribicoff, for the Dr. J. Ruggiero Research Fund, 1300 York Avenue, Box 314, New York, NY 10065.

THE not uncommon view that Ryan Gosling is among the most disarming of young actors took on another meaning last month with the emergence of a viral video of a New York City street fight. In a scene that could be out of Laurel and Hardy, two men are going at it in an East Village crosswalk while bystanders, to no avail, try to pull them apart. A young man in a tank top and a baseball cap strolls into the melee. In the time it takes for the excited voices behind the cellphone camera to realize that this movie starlike good Samaritan is in fact ''the guy from the movie -- 'The Notebook' '' he has somehow orchestrated a cease-fire. ''That's what Ryan does,'' the filmmaker Derek Cianfrance, Mr. Gosling's director in ''Blue Valentine,'' said with a laugh. ''He walks around, and he brings magic. He makes everything better.''

Devoted brother of the late Bill, Oscar and Abe. Loving uncle of Robert, Joanie and Margie. An alumnus of the Wharton School and Harvard University whose career spanned over 60 years in business, finance and arbitration. Service Monday, September 19, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

LATHAM--J. Lindsay, died September 10, 2011 at Essex Meadows, in Essex, CT. He was 96 years old and a longtime resident of Montclair, Morristown and Madison, NJ. Lindsay graduated from Andover '34 and Yale '38. He spent a majority of his business career as the Vice President of Sales with The Medallic Art Company based in New York City and in Danbury, CT. Lindsay was pre-deceased by his first wife, Dorothy Greenwood Christy and his second wife, Susan Smith. He is survived by his three children: James Lindsay Latham Jr. and wife Carolyn, of Starlight Lake, PA; Christy Latham Fowler and husband Paul, of New Canaan, CT; and Dorothy Latham of Ft. Myers, FL. He is also survived by six grand children and ten great-grandchildren. Remembrances in Lindsay's honor may be sent to The First Congregational Church of Old Lyme, 2 Ferry Road, Old Lyme, CT 06371.

An article last Sunday about Les Arts Florissants' version of the 1676 opera ''Atys,'' which will be performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music starting Sunday, misspelled the surname of a lighting designer who has worked on the opera. His name is Patrick Méeüs, not Méüs.

LIBRETT--Betty B.,75, of Palm Beach Gardens, died on August 24 after a long and courageous fight with COPD. Survived by husband Arthur, four sons, and five grandchildren. Burial was at Mount Eden Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

TIGRE, about 45 minutes outside Buenos Aires, has long been home to artists who prefer the quietude of the Paraná Delta to the urban tumult of the big city. Now, thanks in large part to Soledad Benvenuto, an antiques collector who fell in love with the neighborhood and began buying up houses (she owns four new venues and has plans for more), aesthetically minded visitors to Tigre have a block that reflects their interests: Boulevard Saenz Peña (boulevardsaenzpena.com.ar). Here businesses, often in newly renovated spaces, offer art in all its expressions. You'll find ceramics, antiques, food, decoration, design and curiosities -- sometimes all under one roof. Stunning street art is on display, too, with facades whimsically adorned by professional painters. RACHEL FRIEDMAN
AVOID THIS WHEN...

An entry on the ''On the Market'' page last Sunday, about a co-op for sale at 800 Riverside Drive, at 158th Street in Upper Manhattan, misidentified its neighborhood. It is Audubon Park, not Terrace. (Audubon Terrace, a neighborhood landmark, is the Italian Renaissance-style museum complex a few blocks away, at 155th Street and Broadway.)

A caption with the Look photo feature on Sept. 4, about a catfish-catching tournament, misidentified one of the participants. The man shown holding a fish horizontally is Mike Moff at, 21, of Piedmont, Okla., not his teammate, Chad Meiwes.

A CAR is not just a road warrior. To many, it's a second home -- except, that is, when it's more like a handbag from Louis Vuitton. In that case, it's simply a gas. So are the photographs in Luis Gispert's ''Decepción,'' a show at the Mary Boone Gallery spotlighting a subculture devoted to making both cars and clothes into personal showrooms for designer-logo fabrics. It's not that members of this street-art underground are shilling for brands like Gucci, Fendi and Coach. The fabrics are counterfeit. But the designs are real bombs declaring a war on status. Mr. Gispert's photos, though life-size, are not strictly documentary. But by equating natural splendor with a more bombastic human kind, he mirrors a tension between beauty and taste that both art and fashion create. LINDA YABLONSKY

To the Editor: In ''How to Make Business Want to Invest Again'' (Economic View, Sept. 11), N. Gregory Mankiw suggested a cut in corporate taxation as a first step toward encouraging companies to investment in the economy. Other business columnists have made similar recommendations, all despite news reports that some major corporations have paid either minimal or no taxes for years.

NORTH--Suzy Hansen, daughter of Violet Colt Hansen and Philip H. Hansen died September 11, 2011. Suzy is survived by son, Christopher Colt North; grandchildren Matthew Colt North, Kathryn Clayton North, and Christopher Colt North II; and great-grandchild Ellasynne Ryder McCleskey. In her professional life Suzy was an editor of Harper's Bazaar and held positions in public relations at Allied Chemical and CBS in New York City. In Washington, DC she was with the Capital Association of Advertisers. She retired to Williamsburg, Virginia in 2003. Suzy's volunteer work included teaching teenaged girls in Harlem Gracious Living. In Washington she was a member of the American Newswomen's' Association, and The National Cathedral Literacy Program where she tutored first graders. She was also a volunteer at the Hospice House and Support Care of Williamsburg. Suzy traveled extensively and loved to dance, read, and converse. She especially enjoyed music, architecture, interior design, fashion and fine dining. Her friends will miss her wit, generosity, grace, class, and independence. Suzy's legacy will continue in her family and friends, especially the five ladies she lovingly referred to as her "Angels". In lieu of flowers, please donate to the American Cancer Society at www. cancer.org.

BOWDITCH--Barbara Nason Bobby, most recently of White Township, New Jersey, the founding head coach at Yale University in women's lacrosse and field hockey, died on September 10, 2011. She was born on February 11, 1924, in Philadelphia, PA, to the late Emma Anderson Temple Nason and Walton Hooker Nason. An exceptional athlete, Bobby played field hockey, basketball and lacrosse for the legendary Swarthmore High School coach, Virginia Ginger Allen. In 1941 Bobby chaptained Swarthmore's lacrosse team to a 7-6 victory over the All-Philadelphia Club team, ranked number one in the country. Bobby graduated from the University of Pennsylvania with a degree in Occupational therapy (1945) and BS in Education (1946). In 1947, she married her high school sweetheart, James P Bowditch. The Bowditch family moved to Wilton, CT in 1956, and where instrumental in starting the Wilton Presbyterian Church and the Wilton High School boys' lacrosse team. The mid-1970s found Bobby coaching at Yale and, later, she would coach field hockey and lacrosse at Wilton and Weston High Schools. In 1988, Bobby and Jim retired to Brunswick, ME, and the Bowdoin College athletic teams became a primary focus. Bobby is survived by her loving family, her husband, Jim, sons, Penn and Peter daughters in-law, Maria and Wendy, grandchildren Courtney, Emily, and J. P. and sister, Shirley N MacPherson. A celebratory service is planned for 2012. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be sent to Yale Lacrosse Association, Memorium for Barbara Bowditch, PO Box 208216, New Haven, CT 06520 or Polar Bear Athletic Fund, Memorium for Barbara Bowditch, Office of Development, Bowdoin College, 4100 College Station, Brunswick, ME 04011. Services are under the direction of Newbaker Funeral Home, 200 Rt. 94, Blairstown, NJ.

Because of an editing error, an article on Page 48 this weekend about the different educational experiences of a variety of writers misstates the surname of the second-grade teacher of one writer, David Leonhardt. She is Ms. Sandler, not Sander.

PADUANO--James A.,Lazard managing directors and employees mourn the passing of our dear friend and former colleague, Jim Paduano. During his 30 years at Lazard, Jim made both a professional and personal impact, and left us with many fond memories. He will be missed. Our thoughts are with his wife, Eileen, and his family.

With National Child Passenger Safety Week approaching, the nonprofit organization Safe Kids USA released on Thursday new research relating to the use of child safety seats. The study, the largest of its kind, used data collected in 79,000 child safety seat inspections completed by Safe Kids coalitions and specially trained technicians over the course of a year.

ISSEROW--Rachelle Rosenberg of Jerusalem, Israel, on August 25, of pancreatic cancer. Born to Esther and Rabbi Israel Rosenberg in Czechoslovakia on May 18, 1932, immigrated to the U.S. in 1939, Rachelle was a member of the first graduating class of the Ramaz School and graduated from Hunter College in 1953 and received a Master's Degree in Speech Therapy from Boston University. Upon marrying Dr. Saul Isserow in 1954, Rachelle moved to Brookline, MA, and then to Newton in 1981. She was an active and lively member of a many Jewish organizations in Boston, Shabbat hostess to innumerable students and friends and speech therapist for a generation of students in the Winchester public schools. Rachelle and Saul retired to Jerusalem in 1995, where they continued to have an open home, and where Rachelle furthered her lifelong love of the study of Jewish texts. Hostess with the mostest, early adopter of Julia Child, avid reader and moviegoer (her viewing of 17 movies in one week during the Jerusalem Film Festival is a record that may go unchallenged), dear friend to many of all ages, Rachelle is survived by her husband Saul, brother Dr. Herby Rosenberg, daughters Miriam (Yehuda Goldman), Faye Landes (David), adored grandchildren Ronee Goldman and Chana, Yitz, Matanya and Adir Landes, as well as numerous loving nieces and nephews. Contributions in Rachelle's memory may be made to support her passions: American Friends of Matan www.matan.org.il or the Hunter College Foundation, https://onlinedonation. hunter.cuny.edu.

An article last Sunday about the absence of a long-term national policy on manufacturing misstated the source of a $141 million grant to Dow Chemical for a roof shingle plant. It was the state of Michigan, not the federal government.

Some travelers would take the train rather than a plane if the price was right, but entering an itinerary at multiple travel sites is inconvenient. Two search engines, Hipmunk and TripAdvisor Flights, are fixing this problem by allowing users to do one-stop shopping for airplane and intercity rail tickets. Amtrak ticket information now appears alongside airfares and flight schedules in the search

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about plans by the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, to seek membership for a state of Palestine from the United Nations Security Council this week misstated a circumstance under which Israel says it would favor creating a Palestinian state. While Israel officially accepts the idea of such a state, it wants to leave nearly all of the settlers -- not borders -- where they are.

WINSLOW--John Grenville died peacefully at home in Newport, RI on September 15, 2011. He was 93 years old. He leaves behind his devoted wife, Helen Michalis Winslow, stepson W. Barton Baldwin, and step grandson Blair F. Baldwin Jr. He was predeceased by his stepson, Blair F. Baldwin, who passed away in 2005. Born in 1917, Mr. Winslow's childhood was spent in New York City and Tuxedo, NY. Mr. Winslow attended The Buckley School in New York City and St. George's School in Newport, RI. He worked at the National City Bank of New York (now Citibank) until 1940, when he enlisted in Squadron A of the New York National Guard. During World War II, he served in five campaigns across Europe, from Normandy to the Battle of the Bulge, in the 448th Anti Aircraft Artillery Battalion attached to the 35th Infantry Division. Mr. Winslow was awarded the Bronze Star for leadership and courage. Following the War, Mr. Winslow returned to Citibank, where he had a long and successful career. Mr. Winslow's greatest legacy is to the city of Newport, RI, where he was considered the foremost expert in the history of the town and the families who lived there. In the 1970s, Mr. Winslow played a key role in the revitalization of Newport as President of the Preservation Society of Newport. He also served as President of the Seaman's Church Institute of Newport and as President of the Spouting Rock Beach Association (Bailey's Beach) for 32 years. Mr. Winslow was recently awarded the Doris Duke Distinguished Steward Award by the Newport Restoration Foundation for his contributions to historic preservation in Newport. He was also an active member in the Newport Reading Room and the Newport Clambake Club. In New York, Mr. Winslow served as President of the Seaman's Church Institute of New York and was on the Boards of the New York Historical Society and the New York Genealogical Society Mr. Winslow was also a member of the Saint Nicholas Society, the Brook Club, and the Pilgrims. A memorial service will be held at Trinity Church in Newport, RI on a future date to be determined. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions to Trinity Church, 1 Queen Anne Square, Newport, RI 02840 and Newport Hospital, 11 Friendship St, Newport, RI 02840. He will be greatly missed by all and his legacy will live on for years to come.

The now-standard critical line on D. W. Griffith's silent landmark ''Birth of a Nation'' is that it's important but irredeemably racist. That's a coward's approach, a way of reducing the film to a technical achievement while avoiding the hard work of reacting to its emotional content. As an evaluation of the movie without which movies as we know them would not exist, it's sheer ingratitude. Griffith's tale of two families caught up in the Civil War is both a racist film and a great one. Griffith, on fire to prove this new medium the equal of his beloved Dickens, pushed it, with the help of his great cameraman, Billy Bitzer, to a narrative breadth and emotional depth no one had. And like all masterpieces ''The Birth of a Nation'' is impure and imperfect. The film's vision of Reconstruction is a farrago. Vile racist caricature exists alongside moments of aching tenderness. Mawkish odes to home and family alternate with sequences in which, as in Dickens, sentimentality achieves the transcendence and catharsis of tragedy.
Enthusiast: Rob Sheridan, television writer, Los Angeles Object of Enthusiasm: Hashtag games

Big Shoes to Fill in New England Chad Ochocinco's first game with the New England Patriots did not go well, with just one reception. Unfortunately for Tom Brady and the Patriots, Ochocinco may be miscast as a replacement for Randy Moss in terms of his ability to get into the end zone. While his other statistics are similar, Ochocinco is unlikely to make anyone forget Moss.

YAHR--Dr. William Zachary, 74, renowned cardiovascular surgeon, passed away Wednesday at his home in Miami, Florida, after valiantly fighting brain cancer. Dr. Yahr was born in Brooklyn, attended Dartmouth College and Harvard Medical School, and trained in New York at Columbia Presbyterian, Montefiore, and Maimonides. In the mid-1960s, as a member of Dr. Adrian Kantrowitz's team, he helped develop and treat the first patients with the intra-aeortic balloon pump, still a standard of care in heart surgery. Among his many other accomplishments, Dr. Yahr patented the ambidextrous clamp for surgery and was a pioneer in the research and use of lasers during surgery. He was Vice-Chairman of Thoracic Cardiovascular Surgery at Mt. Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach from 1970-1995, then moved to Tallahassee to practice at Capital Regional Medical Center. Above all, "Bill" was a generous and loving father and friend and will be sorely missed. Son of the late Beatrice and Harry Yahr, he is survived by children Elizabeth (Robert) Southard, Harriette, and Alexander; grandchildren Ashley and Ryan; brother Peter (Roberta). Contributions to William Zachary Yahr MD Endowment for Children's Heart Health. Checks to Community Foundation of Broward, memo Yahr Fund. 1401 East Broward Blvd., Suite 100, Ft. Lauderdale, FL 33301.

New York Fashion Week ended last Thursday after more than 250 designers presented looks for spring 2012, each hoping to be the one to redefine the language of fashion. Watching the shows, I kept thinking of Melissa Kuba Lederer, left and right, a woman I often see on her way to work. To me, her daily interpretation of men's wear triumphed over all the designer dreams, poetic as many were. Ms. Lederer's sleek style has the look of the future. And I thought of men I see en route to the office who, through small details, subtlely inserted their own personalities into the conventional suit, like James Aguiar, bottom row, left, and Andrew Mukamal, bottom row, right. Certainly, as Chanel knew when she slipped into the clothes of her lovers, man-tailoring can be terrific on women. And Ralph Lauren knows it, too. At his show, top row, he harked back to the Garçonne look of the 1920s to dress today's women for serious careers. Of course, there is room for the glorious kaleidoscopic diversity of designer visions shown last week on the runways. But then again, I can't tell you how many women pulled me aside during Fashion Week and said, ''Beautiful clothes, Bill, but nothing to wear.''

Eagles (1-0) at Falcons (0-1) Sunday, 8:20 p.m. Line: Eagles by 2 1/2 In honor of Michael Vick's return to Atlanta, the Eagles have starting using their 1989 throwback offense. The scheme pays homage to Randall Cunningham's glory days. The Eagles do not really drive down the field; they just string together amazing highlights, interspersing the occasional punt or baffling mistake. A typical play begins with two defenders knifing untouched through Philadelphia's porous, inexperienced offensive line. Vick either gets flattened or performs some Matrix-style escape, scrambling for a big gain or tossing to a receiver who used the confusion to get wide open. Andy Reid calls for a timeout four or five times per half to impose order (teams only get three timeouts per half, but a 5-yard penalty is a small price to pay for the chance to install a precisely designed sequence of plays for Vick to scrap). The Falcons have built a solid foundation on the lip of the crater Vick left when his career in Atlanta ended, but you could not tell by watching Sunday's messy loss to the Chicago Bears. In addition to giving up too many sacks and turnovers, the Falcons lost several key starters to injury, most notably defensive tackle Jonathan Babineaux (knee). The Falcons have the talent to compete with the Eagles and the Packers in the N.F.C., but they must get back to fundamentals. Nobody is going to beat the Eagles in a battle of sloppy playground brilliance. Pick: Eagles

In the run-up to 2008, there was no end of speculation about the so-called Bradley Effect or Wilder Effect - the theory that polls tend to overestimate the vote share of black candidates - and what it meant for Barack Obama. But the actual evidence for this effect is weak. Whatever effect may have existed when Tom Bradley and Douglas Wilder were running for office does not exist now.

Columbia University and Mahmoud Ahmadinejad might seem to be an odd couple, but for a while last week it looked as if they might be dating. A few years back, when an invitation (extended by a dean) to the Iranian leader generated outrage and bad publicity, Columbia's president, Lee Bollinger, responded by trashing Ahmadinejad before introducing him. On Sept. 13 Fox News reported that an undergraduate organization - the Columbia International Relations Council and Association (CIRCA) - had set up a dinner, scheduled for the 21st, at which Ahmadinejad would interact with a group of students and, perhaps, with Bollinger.

In "A Face in the Crowd," Andy Griffith plays Larry Rhodes, a drifter who is taken from an Arkansas jail and turned into a media sensation. He is first tapped to sing on the radio, but then lands his own television program as "Lonesome" Rhodes. His down-to-earth sensibilities make him a hit with audiences seeking someone with a voice similar to their own.

Amazon.com did not create the notion of buying things online, but it has done more than any other retailer to move the experience into the mainstream. It has exceeded its customers' expectations so often it must constantly struggle to top itself. "At first people were incredulous that the mouse on their computer was connected to their doorbell," the Amazon executive Russell Grandinetti said recently. "Now they say: 'It's been 12 hours. Where's my stuff?' "

Unity: Journalists of Color, an organization whose goal is to promote newsroom diversity, is forming a partnership with the National Lesbian and Gay Journalists Association, the two groups announced Monday. This will be the first time that the lesbian and gay association will be on the board of Unity, and it will participate in the Unity convention in Las Vegas in 2012.

Last week, in the wake of President Obama's jobs speech, I wrote that the president seemed poised to campaign for re-election on an essentially centrist policy agenda: A short-term payroll tax stimulus, a plan for tax reform that would close loopholes while lowering corporate rates, and a long-term plan for deficit reduction modeled on the grand bargain that the White House and John Boehner were supposedly close to striking during the debt ceiling negotiations. The president's goal in 2012, I suggested, would be to try to paint himself as the moderate bipartisan grownup, and dismiss the Republicans as extreme, intransigent, and hyper-ideological.

"Dear Diary," was the reference bandied about backstage at Christopher Kane. This girl was young and cool, and collected, well, stickers (flowers, holograms, etc.), to decorate her secret-filled notebooks. In beauty terms, this translated into youthful, easy rolled buns created by Anthony Turner with TIGI Catwalk Volume Mousse and dry shampoo. Makeup was "all about a gorgeous flushed cheek," said Lucia Pieroni of the three Chantecaille shades (Laughter, Emotion and Joy) she used to make the models appear as if they'd "just run up a mountain." For eyes and lips, it was taupe-shiny Valerian shadow from the beauty brand's new Classic Palette for lids and Lip Sheer in Comet on the mouth. "Rose-tinted, very girly," is how the model Romee Strijd described the look. "Nostalgic, fresh, suited to the season." Did she once keep a diary? "Yes, but I only wrote insignificant things down," she said, avoiding any further questions.

Burberry staged another of its big live-stream events Monday, under a clear plastic tent in bucolic Kensington Park. Pedestrians and joggers got to see the fashion people arrive, and, of course, celebrities like Rachel Zoe and Kanye West, who attended the Christopher Kane show earlier in the day. The scene at Burberry was one big camera-flashing moment before the designer Christopher Bailey sent out the clothes to music by Jeff Beck and George Harrison, among others. His idea this season was to give Burberry's trenches and bags an artisanal dimension, with crochet, beading and latticed leather on collars and sleeves. Shapes included full linen skirts with smallish knits and super-slim coats, as ruched and knotted skirts.

In this week's column, I wrote about an Italian technique for cooking pasta that calls for finishing it in a pan of simmering sauce. Ever since I learned how to make pasta this way, I haven't gone back to the usual drain-dump-and-toss-in-a-serving-bowl method.

Having only qualified for the Nascar Sprint Cup playoffs in the final race of the regular season, just nine days ago in Richmond, Va., Tony Stewart was not expected to threaten the 2011 season's frontrunners at Chicagoland Speedway on Monday afternoon. The $2.3 billion trading loss at UBS shows once again how a single employee who knows how to game internal accounting and reporting systems can wreak havoc at a financial firm. A trader at the Swiss bank, Kweku M. Adoboli, has been accused of making unauthorized trades and charged with fraud and false accounting. The charges outline a type of white-collar crime that does not involve theft so much as what looks like an effort to cover up bad decisions that ultimately spiraled out of control.

About 75 to 80 million Americans follow college football regularly. But how are the loyalties of these fans divided among the 120 current Football Bowl Subdivision programs? Over at The Quad -- The Times' college sports blog -- Nate divined an answer, and explored what the relative popularity of various teams means for college football's complicated conference realignment picture. Read more at The Quad.

Sometimes in the process of putting a magazine together, a late-breaking idea emerges that seems worth taking a flier on. In the case of our education issue, that idea - to ask all sorts of influential and creative and inspiring people about the formative educational moments of their lives - was very, very late-breaking, indeed. Too late, really, for us to have much faith that it was going to work out. People are busy, after all. They have metropolises to run and rock shows to rock in and explanations for the fabric of the universe to nail down. And yet . . . when they received a call or an e-mail from someone here (in most cases, that person was the great Tony Gervino), many of those we reached out to agreed to sit down more or less immediately and type something out. Fifteen of those submissions are in this week's issue. What follows below are several bonus tracks, arguments for the necessity of doing your homework (Glenn Beck) and reading Thucydides (David Brooks). Read, enjoy, and feel free to leave a comment describing the educational experience that made the difference for you.

The 63rd Primetime Emmy Awards -- television's celebration of, well, television -- performed to expectations on Sunday, up slightly when compared with last year in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic coveted by advertisers. But the show on Fox was down in total viewers, to 12.4 million from 13.5 million. Those are respectable numbers considering that last year's ceremony did not have to compete for viewers against the National Football League. This time, "Sunday Night Football" on NBC dominated the night in both ratings categories, according to preliminary overnight Nielsen estimates (the Atlanta Falcons defeated the Philadelphia Eagles, 35-31). Final audience figures were unavailable on Monday.

More than 500 New York City residents are injured badly enough to be treated in hospitals after being struck by bicyclists each year, according to an analysis by Hunter College professors. The number, while small compared with the number of pedestrians injured by cars, is a much higher figure than an earlier study by the same researchers found.

About two years ago I told a business owner a number of things she wasn't ready to hear about the sale of her business. She was disappointed with our meeting, called later to tell me she disagreed with what I had said, then listed her business for sale with one of my competitors. I didn't lose much sleep over it at the time. In fact, I happened to admire both her and her business, and I slept better knowing that I had told her what I thought.

The designer Blake Simpson started coming out from Los Angeles to Joshua Tree in the late 1990s, after buying a house in the desert that he's still tinkering with. At the time, he was making furniture for Marc Jacobs and for the renovation of the Sunset Tower Hotel. Then, in 2002, he spotted the 1950s motel that would become his new five-room hideaway, Mojave Sands (mojavesands.com; doubles from $200). "It was just sitting there, more or less abandoned," he says. "But I could see that it had really good bones." True to the D.I.Y. culture of the high desert, Simpson did a lot of the nine-year renovation himself, stripping and sanding the concrete floors and putting up honey-colored cedar planks for walls. He made the beds from black walnut and paired them with new and vintage modern furniture. And he used perforated metal tread plates to create a private patio for each room.

Though we'd like to believe that there was a magic time between the youthful distress of pimples and the more mature worry of wrinkles, when skin simply behaved, the evidence points increasingly to the contrary. "Just because you're 35 doesn't mean you're not going to have breakouts," says Antonia Burrell, a straight-talking facialist-turned skin-care guru, whose namesake, all-natural year-old line has a rabid following in her native Britain. The problem, according to Burrell, is our higher levels of exposure to a host of complexion-wrecking factors like stress, pollution and the chemicals and hormones in food. "I've been doing this for 18 years and the phenomenon of older women breaking out is not something I would see 10 years ago," Burrell says. "After having so many clients moan to me about their skin, I decided to do something about it - but I wanted products that were holistic and a pleasure to use, not harsh chemicals that would dry out your skin. And I wanted to make them anti-aging, too." At Shen Beauty in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, the only store in the United States that sells Burrell's products, her multitasking, plant-extract-packed Cream Supreme moisturizer and deep cleaning Natural Glow Cleansing Oil are perennial best sellers. The co-owner Jessica Richards first tried the line just before the store opened late last year. "My skin was completely broken out from the stress of launching a business, and this cleared it up in, like, three days," she says. "It's like a natural version of Proactiv. People cannot get enough of this line." Burrell's products are so popular at Shen that hers is among the 12 lines that will be available to order online when the boutique's retail Web site goes live later this week. Also in the works are plans to get Burrell to Shen sometime this fall so she can work her facial magic on the Brooklyn faithful. For those unwilling to wait, Burrell has a standing gig as a guest facialist at Harrods and also sees clients at the Urban Bliss spa in Notting Hill; appointments can be made through her Web site. But be aware - she's usually booked three months in advance.

If there is an advantage to being an underappreciated novelist, it might be that when you get around to writing a memoir, the anecdotes of your life have not already been trotted out ad infinitum by book reviewers the world over. Such is the case with Bruce Jay Friedman, whose memoir, "Lucky Bruce," will be published next month. On the strength of his early novels - "Stern" (1962), "A Mother's Kisses" (1964) and "About Harry Towns" (1974) - Friedman was a literary star, frequently mentioned alongside Bernard Malamud and Philip Roth. He hung out at Elaine's; edited for legendary Magazine Management pulp journals, where he hired Mario Puzo onto the staff of True Action; and, later, moonlighted as a screenwriter ("Stir Crazy," "Splash"), rubbing shoulders with Warren Beatty and Richard Pryor. Yet Friedman has always remained somewhat under the radar. In "Lucky Bruce," readers get fresh, amusing stories from Friedman's life in letters - the time he provoked Norman Mailer into a fistfight by mussing his hair at a party, say, or was hired to write a script and introduced to his new secretary, a between-marriages Natalie Wood. The Moment caught up with Friedman, now 81, at one of his favorite Chinese restaurants in Manhattan, Chin Chin, to talk about his latest book.

Turns out the style was to be 40s waves à la Veronica Lake, Ingrid Bergman or Rita Hayworth. This was achieved using Clairol ColorSeal Gloss to prep the hair and then Frédéric Fekkai mousse before blow-drying and creating a low side part. A large-barrel curling iron set the front wave, clamped very tight until the end ("really cooking the hair"), when it was brushed out. For makeup, Val Garland created what she called a "film noir Fellini-flick look": liquid liner on the top of the lid, a sooty matte on the bottom and M.A.C.'s Carbon shadow in between. M.A.C. The multistripe Hudson's Bay point blanket (also referred to as the Glacier National Park Blanket and the Chief Blanket) follows a very simple aesthetic pattern: green stripe, red stripe, yellow stripe and indigo stripe on a white background, mirrored on the top and bottom of each blanket. Lately, that recognizable motif has adorned a number of items from travel mugs to boots to Swiss Army knives to snow boards. The versatility of the pattern is a testament to the endurance of that basic color combination. While the palette is mainly prized today for its aesthetic value, back in the early 1800s, those colored stripes bore special significance for aboriginal people of North America, who were Hudson's Bay's original customers.

5:26 p.m. | Updated The conductor Myung-whun Chung, who has completed a trip to North Korea, said on Friday that he had pushed for orchestra joint performances involving musicians from the North as well as South Korea. ''The North side's position that I've been given from the beginning and confirmed when I was there was that they would like very much for this to happen,'' Mr. Chung said in a telephone interview, basing his conclusions on conversations with cultural officials. In the south, he said, the government was ''positively inclined, and wary.'' The idea would be to have members of the Seoul Philharmonic Orchestra and musicians from North Korean symphonies play a concert in Pyongyang at the end of the year and another concert in Seoul. Barring political upheaval, he rated the chances of the exchange ''very possible.'' He said he also discussed the possibility of establishing a regular joint North-South orchestra of young musicians.

The playwright Annie Baker and the director Sam Gold, who drew critical acclaim for their recent Off Broadway collaborations ''Circle Mirror Transformation'' and ''The Aliens,'' will reunite for Ms. Baker's adaptation of Chekhov's ''Uncle Vanya,'' which Soho Rep will mount in June, the theater company said on Tuesday. Further casting will be announced later.

NOTABLE NUMBER It was not by design, but Rex Ryan was delighted nevertheless that Mark Sanchez was the Jets' second-leading rusher Sunday. That Sanchez ran for 29 yards, a career high, signified moderate progress. When Jacksonville's zone coverage was inviting, Sanchez tried to exploit it. But when the Jaguars' defensive backs dropped deep, Sanchez, as he put it, ''just took off and ran.'' His longest rush, 15 yards, was not his most important. That scramble came when he converted a third-and-4 in the third quarter, dashing for a 7-yard gain that was amplified by a late-hit penalty. Five plays later, Sanchez used his arm -- a more familiar weapon -- to connect on his second touchdown pass. KEY PERFORMANCE A tight end made life miserable over the middle for the opposition, and for a change the Jets were the beneficiaries. Dustin Keller accounted for 101 of Mark Sanchez's 182 passing yards, and he bookended a third-quarter drive with critical catches. The first, a 37-yarder down the right sideline, moved the Jets off their own 8. On the second, Keller shook off linebacker Paul Posluszny for an 11-yard touchdown that extended the Jets' lead to 22-3. With Jacksonville's imposing tight end, Marcedes Lewis, sidelined because of an injured calf, Keller grabbed the spotlight.

CHARASH--Leon I. The Muscular Dystrophy Association expresses its deep sorrow at the passing of Dr. Leon Charash, a volunteer leader of the Association since the mid-1950s, serving as Chairman of its Medical Advisory Committee from 1971 to 2008, as a corporate member from 1985 to 2009, and as a member of our Board of Directors from 1994 to 2009. A strong advocate for children, Dr. Charash worked with MDA in the late 1950s to help children who use wheelchairs gain admission to New York City public schools. He had a particular interest in the psychosocial aspects of muscle disease, especially for children. Dr. Charash helped direct the growth of our clinic program to more than 200 hospital-affiliated clinics across the country, and was a key figure in the expansion of our worldwide research program, leading to significant advancements in the understanding of neuromuscular diseases and to present-day clinical trials of potential treatments. His strong and compassionate leadership will be missed by the entire MDA family. Board of Directors, Muscular Dystrophy Association R. Rodney Howell, M.D., Chairman Gerald C. Weinberg, President & CEO Olin F. Morris, Chairman, Executive Committee Lois R. West, Vice Chairman, Executive Committee Suzanne Lowden, Treasurer

WASHINGTON -- President Obama will unveil a deficit-reduction plan on Monday that uses entitlement cuts, tax increases and war savings to reduce government spending by more than $3 trillion over the next 10 years, administration officials said. The plan, which Mr. Obama will lay out Monday morning at the White House, is the administration's opening move in sweeping negotiations on deficit reduction to be taken up by a joint House-Senate committee over the next two months. If a deal is not struck by Dec. 23, cuts could take effect automatically across government agencies.

Maybe it's the battered economy that is driving the public's longing for a different era. Or maybe it's Hollywood's own obsession with the 1950s and '60s, as witnessed by the lineup of fall television offerings like ''Pan Am'' and ''The Playboy Club'' that are following on the success of ''Mad Men.'' Whatever the cause, fans of old-time television, film, radio and pop culture can't get enough of the period. So from Thursday through Saturday they will visit Hunt Valley, Md., for the Mid-Atlantic Nostalgia Convention to relive their memories of shows and movies like ''Peyton Place'' and ''The Miracle Worker.''

The top programs on broadcast TV last season were entertainment competitions and crime dramas. The top two comedies, both on CBS, were ''The Big Bang Theory,'' with a rating of 8.0, and ''Two and a Half Men,'' at 7.7. As the new season begins, ''Men'' and NBC's ''Office'' face the uncertainty that comes when new lead actors are introduced: Ashton Kutcher joins ''Men'' and James Spader, above, joins ''The Office.'' Republicans in Pennsylvania are considering a proposal that would award 18 of the state's 20 electoral votes to the winner of each of its congressional districts, leaving the remaining 2 to the winner of the state at large. Had the proposal been in place in 2008, when Pennsylvania had one more electoral vote prior to reapportionment, Barack Obama would have carried only 11 of the state's 21 electoral votes despite winning Pennsylvania by a 10-point margin.

As Washington looks to squeeze savings from once-sacrosanct entitlements like Social Security and Medicare, another big social welfare system is growing as rapidly, but with far less scrutiny: the health and pension benefits of military retirees. Military pensions and health care for active and retired troops now cost the government about $100 billion a year, representing an expanding portion of both the Pentagon budget -- about $700 billion a year, including war costs -- and the national debt, which together finance the programs.

Even as Civil War history has gone through several cycles of revision, one thing has remained fixed: the number of dead. Since about 1900, historians and the general public have assumed that 618,222 men died on both sides. That number is probably a significant undercount, however. New estimates, based on Census data, indicate that the death toll was approximately 750,000, and may have been as high as 850,000.

Friday's Fixes post about time banks resonated with readers.  Time banks are local organizations that allow people to use their skills to help others by exchanging hours instead of money. You earn time dollars by, say, taking a neighbor to the doctor, and spend those time dollars on the same number of hours' worth of other services, such as computer repair or singing lessons.  Strikingly, very few readers talked about what they could get from time banks; most  responded to the possibility of giving.  "The chance to help others and feel good about myself makes the bargain seem better than I thought possible," wrote Ajasys from Vancouver, Wash. (41)  - a typical comment.

A rich film tradition and low production costs have long brought stars to Budapest, among them Jeremy Irons, 63, pictured here on the shores of the Danube River. Irons made "Nijinski," his first movie in the capital, in 1980, and returned to make "M. Butterfly," "Being Julia" and Showtime's "The Borgias." When not on set, Irons explores the city's "wonderful crumbling faded beauty" on his motorcycle. "It's very hard to find the soul of a city," he says, but he suggests starting at the Dohany Street Synagogue (011-36-1-413-5500), the Hungarian State Opera (right; opera.hu) and the Western Railway Station (Terez korut at Nyugati ter), designed by the Eiffel Company of Paris. Irons also recommends Cafe Kor (011-36-1-311-0053; cafekor.com), Pomo D'Oro (011-36-1-302-6473; pomodorobudapest.com) and Nobu (noburestaurants.com/budapest), inside the Kempinski Hotel (011-36-1-429-3777; kempinski.com), where he usually stays.

A new report finds more evidence that climate change is gradually moving to the center of corporate strategy. Virtually every big company in the world now pays at least lip service to sustainability, and many of them are starting to take real action to reduce their environmental footprint. The new report from the Carbon Disclosure Project finds that for the first time, a majority of companies in the United States responding to the group's survey "now integrate climate change into core business strategy."

"What shape is a shoe box?" asked the hairstylist Duffy backstage at Peter Pilotto. "Oblong?" Duffy was trying to explain the rectangular woven patch he created at the top of the head to mimic the cross-hatch pattern on the collection's clothes. "Clean, sleek and structured," is how he described the textured "shoe box" secured into a tight, slicked-back ponytail, to contrast the "soft, feminine, fluid" hair left loose beneath it. Nails, like the hair, were intended to be polished, but discreetly so as not to compete with the bright colors of the clothes. This meant Essie's Jazz on fingers and toes. Makeup, on the other end, was all about shine. M.A.C. Lustre drops were mixed with Strobe Liquid Lotion and applied all over the body by Adrien Pinault and team. Taupe blush and Creme Colour Base in Dusk were used on the face with the latter brushed onto the lips and coated with clear gloss. There was no mascara and brows were simply brushed, perhaps so as not to distract from the handiwork of the "shoe box" shape in the hair.

Post-Fidel anticipation has tourists flocking to Cuba to bask in the sunset of the revolution: the patched-together Studebakers, the stuck-in-time streetscapes. But visitors often leave without a real sense of the island's rich, pre-Communist past, much less its inscrutable present - both the subjects of new photo books. Michael Dweck's "Habana Libre" (above left, Damiani, $65) is a sun-baked "Who's Who" of Cuba's cultural elite. Michael Connors's "Splendor of Cuba" (above right, Rizzoli, $85) catalogs the country's 450-year architectural history, casting a rosy eye on exquisitely preserved examples of Spanish-Creole colonial style.

It took five people to carry the finale dress for Mary Katrantzou backstage before the show, where it was to be sewn onto a model after she was finished with hair and makeup. When it arrived, the full beauty look remained undecided as Val Garland was still mixing M.A.C. pigments to sort out the perfect 10 holographic shades to be painted on lips. "If you look at the clothes, they are all really colorful and energetic," she said. "Sam [McKnight] did great, sexy hair. It felt right to do a statement, but not makeup makeup." This meant choosing to do simply a striking mouth to complement the collection. Garland's been known to go on instinct when it comes to Katrantzou. It was during her first season that Garland decided to change up the makeup hours before the presentation. Twelve girls were sent out with 12 different versions of eyeliner, a look that ended up creating quite a stir. For spring, the bold lip needed little else save for a sheer, sparkling nail (Nailgirls Pink 19) and simple ponytail. "Incredibly naïve, childlike - and clean" is how McKnight described the hair, which was pulled back with pieces pulled out as "a veil all around the hairline, so that it wafts when she moves." To start, he wanted models to have perfectly washed hair, which was achieved by shampooing and conditioning with Pantene Color Protection products in the bathroom sink. "The loo's three floors over," McKnight said. "They were not very happy about that."

3:56 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES -- The world of Pandora is coming to Walt Disney World. In a deal that underscores Disney's continued spending on new theme park attractions, the entertainment conglomerate has obtained exclusive global theme park rights to the hit movie "Avatar" from 20th Century Fox, the two companies said on Tuesday morning. The partnership will include much more than a ride. "Avatar," which sold $2.8 billion in tickets at the global box office, will form the foundation for a themed land at Animal Kingdom, the newest of the four major parks that make up Disney World in Orlando, Fla. Animal Kingdom is built around the theme of mankind's responsibility to nature, which is also the core message of "Avatar."
