Consider Burberry's history as a heritage brand and it follows that wind and weather were the inspiration for this season's beauty. The hairstylist Neil Moodie wanted to make each girl look as if she'd just been out in the crisp air for a walk. He created loose, tousled strands by prepping with Bumble & Bumble Styling Lotion and then using a large-barrel curling iron. This easy approach was in contrast to the polished 1960s girl of last season - especially when topped off with cheery pompom hats. As for makeup, Wendy Rowe used Burberry Beauty's new Fresh Glow foundation all over the skin with Russet Blush and Tulip Pink lip color. On the eyes were a trio of shadows: Almond, Taupe and Pale Barley, a gray-gold used at the inner corners.

San Franciscans sometimes get a bad rep. On behalf of all of the Bay Area (or so it seems), watch the Girls' frontman Christopher Owens play about town singing lyrics like, "They don't like my bony body, they don't like my dirty hair," in their new video for the track "Honey Bunny," off their recently released sophomore album, "Father, Son, Holy Ghost" (True Panther Sounds). Surprisingly, the title of this record, which was released last Tuesday to rave reviews, does not directly refer to Owens's childhood in the infamous Children of God cult, he said. Instead, the moody album -- filled with heavy metal riffs that channel Fleetwood Mac, and light '60s strumming that brings you back to the Beach Boys, supported by hallowing gospels -- reaches down deeper than that: to Owens's relationship with women, primarily his mother. This record is no doubt less lo-fi than their first, but the straightforward and honest sentiment Owens and the bassist and producer J.R. White bring feels evermore present. Currently on a United States tour, Girls talked to The Moment about their new song "Honey Bunny," which Owens initially wrote using his cellphone, and the video, imagined by White. Girls will play at New York's Bowery Ballroom on Thursday and Friday.

As the longtime editor of downtown magazines like V and Interview, the writer Christopher Bollen has lived for years at the center of New York life in all of its diverse iterations, from creative glitz through cutthroat entrepreneurialism to the desperation bred by failed dreams. In "Lightning People" (Soft Skull, $25), his first novel, Bollen turns his inside-as-inside-gets perspective and experience with young creative Manhattanites into fertile literary ground, cultivating a tale of the city as universal and globe-spanning as it is singular and all his own. Bollen will take part in a talk, and a reading, at the Union Square Barnes & Noble on Thursday. Following the release of his book last week - and the expected release party filled with art and fashion luminaries - The Moment sat down with Bollen to ask a few questions.

We had plenty of inquiries, but no sales in the last week of August and the first two weeks of September. Frankly, I'm a little bit nervous. Dry patches are not unheard of in this business, but three weeks is about as long as I have gone without a new order. Maybe it was just the end of summer, and decision makers weren't around to make decisions. We could well get a clump of new business soon -- we have lots of proposals sitting out there, the clients swear that the jobs are still alive, but still. Why don't they pull the trigger? Is it fear of a recession? Or could it be our pricing? At the beginning of August, after months of good sales, I made a very slight adjustment to our pricing, adding in an extra 2 percent for the salesmen. Did that slight hike make a difference?

Distraught parents searching for missing children, commodity traders, home buyers, rickshaw drivers - people from all walks of life - have come forward with tales of being forced to hand cash to government employees to secure a job, a birth certificate, a home or even their family's safety.

The effects of the 6.8-magnitude earthquake that struck Sikkim on Sunday evening continued to surface as the death toll in India, Nepal and Tibet reached 71, while many more are feared dead buried under the debris of buildings. (Hindustan Times)  At the epicenter of the quake, in north Sikkim, the count rose to 41 on Monday. Sikkim Chief Minister Pawan Kumar Chamling said that along with the national highway, state highway and other important linking roads, the electricity transmission lines and water supply have also been affected. Though nearly 6,000 army and paramilitary forces personnel were deployed, landslides and blocked roads hindered their ability to reach the most severely affected areas. (Times of India)Narendra Modi continues to dominate headlines as he ended his three-day fast with a speech urging India to "dream like Gujarat."(Indian Express) He also announced a one-day fast in every district of the state "to strengthen the spirit of unity and brotherhood." While his closing speech steered clear of the 2002 riots, he attempted to reach out to the Muslim population with claims to pluralism and Urdu advertisements drawing a parallel with Roza - the monthlong fast during Ramadan. (Hindustan Times) However, when a maulvi, or religious scholar, offered him a skullcap as a mark of respect Modi refused, accepting a shawl instead.

Stephen Colbert can't be influenced by the agendas of politicians and public officials, but if you're a popular rock group that doesn't easily embrace television cameras he will gladly roll over for you. On Monday Comedy Central announced that it would expand ''The Colbert Report'' to an hourlong broadcast for the first time in that show's history to present a special episode featuring Radiohead, the British rock quintet of ''OK Computer'' and ''Kid A'' fame, whose song ''How to Disappear Completely'' could sometimes be mistaken for their press strategy. (Perhaps in an effort to be more visible, the band will also appear on Saturday's season premiere of ''Saturday Night Live,'' and will perform at Roseland Ballroom in Manhattan on Sept. 28 and 29.) In a news release Comedy Central said that the one-hour ''Colbert Report'' special would be shown next Monday, Sept. 26, and would present the band in interviews and performances of their songs from their recent album, ''The King of Limbs'' (including an unreleased track called ''The Daily Mail''), along with that program's usual mix of topical comedy segments. Mr. Colbert, who isn't afraid to flaunt his rock-music bona fides, has used his show to feature artists like the Decemberists, LCD Soundsystem and Jack White, who appeared in multiple''Colbert Report''segments over the summer. Mr. Colbert said in a statement, ''I look forward to meeting the Radioheads and leveraging their anti-corporate indie cred to raise brand awareness for my sponsors.''

Before Philip Roth announced his tortured feelings about his own Jewishness to the world in ''Goodbye, Columbus'' (1959) and ''Portnoy's Complaint'' (1969), he described to Martin Greenberg, the editor of Commentary magazine, his difficulty in writing about the subject. ''If fiction isn't hard enough to write, personal dilemmas - my own Jewishness - don't help it any,'' he wrote in a January 1958 letter. That letter is part of a collection of documents and correspondence that Commentary has donated to the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas, Austin. The archive, which spans 1945 to 1995, includes letters by and to Bernard Malamud, Norman Mailer, Amos Oz, Elie Wiesel and Isaac Bashevis Singer, as well as the revisions of essays written for the magazine by George Orwell, Pearl S. Buck and Jean-Paul Sartre.

Although the UBS trading scandal happened at the London office of a Swiss financial company, big American banks will feel regulatory heat. When UBS revealed on Thursday that a rogue trader had lost a quantity of money so large that it potentially wiped out profits for the entire quarter, the case cast a glaring spotlight on banks' risk-taking activities and evoked painful memories of the financial crisis. Such blowups had helped bring the system to the brink, forcing governments to bail out banks and prompting a global economic slowdown.

Regulators are moving ahead with a plan to rein in conflicts of interest in the securitization market. The proposed rule, unveiled on Monday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, would prohibit banks and other financial firms from both sponsoring asset-backed securities and betting against the deals. The S.E.C. also would crack down on practices that a ''reasonable'' investor would consider a conflict of interest. The rule would have covered deals by both Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase, which created collateralized debt obligations with help from hedge funds that went on to bet against them. BEN PROTESS

BLOOM--Murray, 72, loving husband, wonderful friend, gentle and understanding father and grandfather, intuitive, innovative and inventive entrepreneur and avid jazz enthusiast, died peacefully Sunday, September 18, 2011. As the patriarch of cardiac electrophysiological instrumentation and himself a Horatio Alger type figure, Murray, under the banner of the company he founded, Bloom Associates Ltd., designed, manufactured and distributed cardiac stimulating, recording and monitoring devices used for the evaluation of arrhythmias of the heart. His designs helped usher in the modern era of cardiac electrophysiology. This niche business which distributed his products worldwide was sold to Fischer Imaging in 1992 and continues to this day as a part of the Fischer Medical Technologies product line. A jazz writer, arranger, player and producer, Murray's love of music took root at a very young age on the street corners of West Philadelphia and flourished throughout his life. His fondness for jazz added color, enjoyment and breath to his life, opening doors at Florida Atlantic University (the Jazz Department essentially adopted him) and within the Jazz community in Philadelphia which provided him a musical home. His arrangements has been played by many bands and immortalized on several albums. Born and raised in Philadelphia on July 24, 1939, Murray spent most of his later years in Villanova, PA annually migrating to Highland Beach, FL each winter. Besides his wife Susan, he is survived by his daughters Celia, Pamela and Amy and his grandchildren Alexandra, Daniel, Anya, Emily and Sophie. He is remembered fondly by the many friends, associates and clients he met along his journey and for the innovations and inventions by which so many lives were saved. Funeral Services will be held at 11:30am, Wednesday, September 21, 2011 at the Bringhurst Funeral Home, West Laurel Hill Cemetery, 225 Belmont Avenue, Bala Cynwyd, PA. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Bloom Fund for Cardiac Research and Education, University of Pennsylvania Development Office, 3535 Market Street, Suite 750, Philadelphia, PA 19104.

FRONT PAGE Because of an editing error, an article on Monday misstated the central fiscal goal of President Obama's newly proposed budget plan. The plan calls for reducing the budget deficit by $3 trillion over 10 years, half of it from tax increases and half from spending cuts. It would not cut spending by $3 trillion. The article also misstated the deadline by which a bipartisan Congressional committee must come up with its own cuts. It is Nov. 23, not Dec. 23.

The 63rd Primetime Emmy Awards -- television's celebration of, well, television -- performed to expectations on Sunday, up slightly when compared with last year in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic coveted by advertisers. But the show on Fox was down in total viewers, to 12.4 million from 13.5 million. Those are respectable numbers considering that last year's ceremony did not have to compete for viewers against the National Football League. This time, ''Sunday Night Football'' on NBC dominated the night in both ratings categories, according to preliminary overnight Nielsen estimates (the Atlanta Falcons defeated the Philadelphia Eagles, 35-31). Final audience figures were unavailable on Monday. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

MOLLOD-LUCKA--Sandi. It is with indescribable sadness, grief and pain that we are announcing the passing of Sandi Mollod Lucka of NYC. Sandi died on September 18 at 12:11pm, the day after her birthday, as a result of complications from cancer. Sandi had fought a courageous and heroic battle against cancer and refused to give up or give in right up to the last second. Sandi's life gives everyone who has ever met her a model for how to be a good and kind person in every way. She died way too young and will be missed by everyone who has ever had the privilege of knowing her. Services are on Wednesday, 12:45pm, September 21st at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC followed by interment at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont NY. We love you Sandi.

Federal prosecutors want to send the convicted hedge fund chief Raj Rajaratnam to prison for as long as 24 years, which would be the longest insider trading sentence in history. How a judge rules next week on Mr. Rajaratnam's punishment is being seen in legal circles as a litmus test of whether the crime of insider trading justifies such a long prison term.

In a considerable expansion of its Off Broadway profile Signature Theater Company announced on Monday that five respected playwrights - Annie Baker, Will Eno, Katori Hall, Kenneth Lonergan, and Regina Taylor - would be charter members of a program to develop and stage their new works. The program, called Residency Five, guarantees three full productions of new plays by each writer over the next five years. Each will also receive a $50,000 cash award, stipends to attend theater, and health insurance benefits. Additional playwrights will be added to the mix in the coming years as writers rotate out of the program.

More than 500 New York City residents are injured badly enough to be seen in hospitals after being struck by bicyclists each year, according to an analysis by Hunter College professors. The number, while small compared with the number of pedestrians injured by cars, is a much higher figure than an earlier study by the same researchers found. The professors surveyed hospital data gathered by the State Department of Health between 2007 and 2010 and found that roughly 1,000 pedestrians in New York State were seen at hospitals each year after being hit by cyclists, and that 55 percent of the accident victims were in New York City.

Neil Young, easily one of the most influential and enigmatic musicians of his generation, will write a memoir, his publisher said on Monday. Blue Rider Press, an imprint of Penguin Group USA, acquired the book after several years of discussions with Mr. Young, said David Rosenthal, the president and publisher. ''He's been very busy playing and touring and making records, and the guy has 100 things going on all the time,'' Mr. Rosenthal said. ''He felt that this was a really propitious moment to try and put some stuff down on paper.'' The book, tentatively titled ''Waging Heavy Peace,'' will be released in fall 2012. Mr. Young has already finished writing ''a good deal of material,'' Mr. Rosenthal said. ''The intention is to cover pretty much everything - growing up, music, life,'' he added. ''I am astounded at his memory for detail.''

ELLMAN--Leonard, 80, of Cedar Grove, NJ on September 18, 2011. Beloved husband of Phyllis. Loving father of Sharon and Stuart (Susan). Cherished grandfather of Bradley, Alison, Benjamin and Lily. A native New Yorker, Leonard was the owner of Encore Studio, where he was a supplier of theatrical sets and props to Broadway shows, film, television and photographers for over 40 years. In addition, he was a member of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, Moving Picture Technicians, Artists and Alliance Crafts of the United States (IATSE-Local 52), the National Association of Broadcast Engineers and Technicians, (NABET-Local 15), and the Association of Interior Decorators. A Master Mason, Leonard also was past President of the Theatrical Square Club. Service Wednesday, September 21, 9:30am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory may be made to: The Golda Och Academy, 1418 Pleasant Valley Way, West Orange, NJ 07052.

(Fox) NEW GIRL She's ''adorkable'': Zooey Deschanel, above, stars as Jess Day, a nerdy loser who, after discovering that her boyfriend is cheating on her, moves into a loft apartment with three male roommates: the bartender Nick (Jake Johnson), the womanizer Schmidt (Max Greenfield) and the personal trainer Coach (Damon Wayans Jr.). Their mission is to help Jess turn off the ''Dirty Dancing'' reruns, pack away the Kleenex box and re-enter the dating scene. Hannah Simone is Cece, Jess's childhood best friend. '' 'New Girl' is charming and quite funny,'' Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times, adding that ''it seems quite old-school: an appealing, clueless heroine who bewitches male protectors -- like Barbara Eden on 'I Dream of Jeannie' or Daryl Hannah in 'Splash.' The only difference is that in those older comedies the women have supernatural powers; Jess stands out because she seems so natural.'' 5:30 P.M. (AMC) NO COUNTRY FOR OLD MEN (2007) Before last year's remake of ''True Grit,'' there was this more modern western from Joel and Ethan Coen, adapted from the Cormac McCarthy novel. Tommy Lee Jones plays Ed Tom Bell, a world-weary sheriff along the Texas border in 1980; Josh Brolin is Llewelyn Moss, a welder who finds $2 million at the scene of a drug deal gone bad; and Javier Bardem, above, is Anton Chigurh, a psychopath charged with retrieving the cash. The film earned Oscars for best director, best picture and best adapted screenplay, as well as a best supporting actor award for Mr. Bardem.

WEBB--Anna. The Board of Directors, officers, and staff of American Friends of Tel Aviv University are deeply saddened by the passing of Anna Hitter Webb, our cherished friend and member of TAU's Board of Governors. Anna's generosity of spirit touched countless lives. Passionately dedicated to the State of Israel and the global Jewish community, she and her husband Max were committed to wide-ranging and inspirational philanthropy. Their impact pervades the TAU campus, in the award-winning Anna and Max Webb Family School of Languages Building and in creative programs to preserve Yiddish language and culture. We will miss her warmth, spirit, and lively intellect, and extend our sympathies to Max, Anna's children Steve and Sabrina, Max's daughters Rose and Chara, and all the family. Jon Gurkoff, Chairman Gail Reiss, President & CEO

By late summer, most of the corn in America is head high and bristling. The stalks stand shoulder to shoulder like an army without rank, their sharp-edged, swordlike leaves forming a nearly impenetrable wall. A modern cornfield would have rebuffed Cary Grant in "North by Northwest" because there are no rows to speak of, only a dense lattice of intersecting spears. This corn - grown by the tens of millions of acres - has been genetically engineered, altered by having stacks of apparently desirable traits wedged into its genetic code. Saving the kernels of engineered corn in the fall to plant in the spring is both illegal, because of company patents, and largely irrelevant, since the plants they yield, which contain a packet of foreign genes, won't necessarily resemble the parent crop. Nearly all the corn you see anywhere in our nation of corn is this year's model, new and, so they say, improved.

My parents left New York City in 1979 and moved north to a Mayberry manqué in Westchester called Irvington. That was just what bourgeois couples did when they were expecting. You can't really blame them. They had spent three years as interns and residents in hospitals in the South Bronx, taking care of patients with gunshot wounds and reviving heroin addicts. The apartment they'd lived in had been burglarized, and besides, they were children of the suburbs themselves.

Judicial opinions on the constitutionality of the new health care law are pouring out of the federal courts. With the general expectation that the Supreme Court will have to resolve what is now a clear conflict between two federal courts of appeals, the individual lower-court decisions have pretty much ceased to make news. By the time the Supreme Court rules, if and when it does, a decision earlier this month by the federal appeals court in Richmond, Va., throwing out Virginia's challenge to the statute without reaching the ultimate constitutional question, will be all but forgotten.

When John Peters, the guy who created the modern messenger bag, invites you up to his home in Saugerties, N.Y., to see his latest project, you go and look. But mostly you listen. Peters, whose tall and skinny frame can be attributed to the years he spent climbing in New York, New Hampshire and beyond, touches on about 20 things at the same time - from A.T.V.'s to Levon Helm's Midnight Rambles. But it's talk about his latest collection of bags, called Peters Mountain Works, that overshadows all. The line is the culmination of many things: the sewing skills that Peters's mother taught him growing up in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.; the collection of packs he later started in New York with a fellow climber he met at the Shawangunks; the now ubiquitous line of cordura messenger bags that Peters created (that line, with the red and white skyscraper logo), which would begin its takeover of Manhattan in the early 1980s - "a little hillbilly line from Upstate," he calls it, though it was anything but.

It was the summer of 1983. I was just out of high school, and I had by this point repudiated all my Ted Nugent, Led Zeppelin and Rush records. I was a "new waver" now - at least as much as you could be in suburban Pittsburgh. There were exactly two record stores that sold "good music." The best one, Jim's Records in Bloomfield, a working-class neighborhood in eastern Pittsburgh, was about a 45-minute drive for me. I had only $10, and I had narrowed my choices down to "Care," the debut LP of a British band called Shriekback, and "Murmur," R.E.M.'s debut LP. For no reason that I recall, I went with the Shriekback. It was a good record. The next week, I picked up "Murmur."

New research on the dynamics of Greenland's ice sheets complicates efforts to forecast sea level rise in this century, as the Green Blog reports. Expanding fields of crevasses appear to be limiting the flow of water to the base of the ice through tube-like moulins. That flow has been thought to ease the seaward movement of the ice over bedrock. In August officials of the City and County of Denver announced that they had chosen Sotheby's to sell four canvases by the Abstract Expressionist painter Clyfford Still to raise money for the endowment of the new Clyfford Still Museum, which is to open there on Nov. 18. The agreement called for Sotheby's to try to sell the four as a group to a museum by Monday; if it were unable to do so, the works - which together are estimated to be worth more than $50 million - would then go to auction separately. Christie's, the rival auction house that had competed for the sale, was so miffed by Denver's selection of Sotheby's that it hired lawyers and lobbyists in an unsuccessful effort to stop the arrangement.

It's tempting to dismiss the "Daphne Guinness" exhibition at the Museum at F.I.T., which features the extraordinary wardrobe of one of the fashion world's most visible eccentrics, as an attempt to cash in on the public's appetite for narcissistic excess. But the truth is that the pint-size brewery heiress's passion for design is not only inimitably extreme, it's completely sincere. Her funds might run as deep as her walk-in closets, but unlike countless other couture clotheshorses, Guinness doesn't fetishize fashion as a status symbol. Instead, over the years, she has developed a sartorial persona that's one part Victorian damsel, one part sci-fi geisha and 100 percent off-the-wall.

The Brazilian jeweler H. Stern named its latest capsule collection of sphere-inspired gold pieces Copernicus, after the 16th-century Polish astronomer whose heliocentric model of the universe put the sun at the center of the solar system. It was a revolutionary notion at the time - planets circling the sun! - and one that struck an artistic chord for H. Stern's president and creative director, Roberto Stern. "We've always been inspired by nature," he says. "This time I had orbits on my mind." The collection comprises 24 18-karat gold pieces, many of which bear a signature diamond bead, and is characterized by loopy, never-ending lines on earrings, necklaces and rings. One bracelet is made of hollow, faceted baubles to circle your pretty wrist until infinity.

There's a well-established line of work in economics on the political business cycle, starting with a paper by my original mentor Bill Nordhaus (pdf). The basic idea was that since voters tend to have short memories, it pays for a government to reflate the economy centering on the proposition that government have an incentive to reflate the economy in the period leading up to an election, even if this imposes costs that will have to be paid later. Concern about this issue is one reason for central bank independence.

The starting point for Jennifer Chun's spring collection was a grainy, paparazzi-style photo of the Yves Saint Laurent muses Betty Catroux and Loulou de la Falaise casually flanking Laurent on a London sidewalk. "It shows how real women wore his designs on the street," says Chun, who worked at Michael Kors, Derek Lam and Brian Reyes before starting her namesake line of practical and "utilitarian" clothes. Making her New York Fashion Week debut at the recent Gen Art show, a group runway that spotlights emerging designers, Chun presented spring looks that elegantly mix fashion's masculine and feminine. "I definitely wouldn't say they're androgynous. They aren't literal interpretations of men's pieces," she explains. "You don't want it to become too costumey. I'm more interested in functionality." In Chun's gender blender, a khaki boyfriend blazer is paired with a cropped top; a long, creamy silk dress bears a baseball raglan. Everything appears to be designed for women who don't spend all day planning outfits. "This is for a city girl," she says. "I never leave the house without a blazer, without a trench coat - so those will be my signatures."

The latest version of Apple's Safari browser for Windows and Mac OS X includes a Reading List feature that lets you quickly save Web pages for later perusal. To save a Web page on screen, go to Safari's Bookmarks menu and choose the "Add to Reading List" option. You can also press Control-Shift-D in Windows or Command-Shift-D on a Mac to save the current page to the Reading List. And you can Shift-click on a link within a Web page to save that article to the Reading List without opening it.

Top civilian and military leaders said ending the 18-year-old ban was in line with the nation’s values and would not diminish defense readiness.

A trade group that represents airlines raised its forecast for combined airline profit in 2011 to $6.9 billion, but said demand would slow by the end of the year.

An attentive listener would be hard pressed to deduce the stylistic preferences of Sequitur, which opened its season on Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, but maybe that’s as it should be.

The conceit behind “Conni’s Avant Garde Restaurant: The Mothership Landing” is that a band of fictional performers who specialize in cutting-edge art and pretentiousness are serving up dinner theater.
“The Oxford Companion to Beer,” edited by Garrett Oliver of the Brooklyn Brewery, represents how far beer has come in the United States since the days before the craft beer movement took off.
The base hourly wage of the new workers will rise 36 percent over the next four years, the union said.
After months of a friendlier tone toward President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, Iraqi has joined a chorus of other nations calling on him to step down.
The new iteration of St. Anselm in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is charming, with a pulsing bass line of ambition beneath its simple steakhouse melody.

David Hallberg, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, is becoming the first American star to enlist permanently with the fabled Bolshoi Ballet of Moscow.
Federal prosecutors who blocked three poker sites in April said Full Tilt Poker had been improperly paying out money from customer accounts to the company’s owners.
A Somali radio station run by the Shabab held an awards ceremony to honor children who were experts at Shabab trivia and at reciting the Koran.
The office of Prince Alwaleed released documents to rebut an accusation that the prince raped a Spanish woman on a luxury yacht.

A conflict-of-interest case involving David M. Becker, the former general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is being referred to the Department of Justice for a possible criminal investigation.
Gunmen in Baluchistan Province attacked a bus carrying Shiite pilgrims to Iran, killing at least 25 people and wounding 6 more.
At the trial of a second man accused in the three murders in Cheshire, Dr. William A. Petit Jr. told of being awakened at home after a quiet end to the weekend with his daughters and wife.
President Obama met Libya’s transitional leader for the first time and extolled what he called the Libyan people’s successful struggle to depose Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
A tale of a police chase, an abandoned pocketbook and an officer in trouble, as Hurricane Irene hits Pawtucket, R.I.
The Dodd-Frank Act, the sprawling law to address the causes of the financial crisis, is a job killer that should be repealed, Republican presidential candidates say.
Real estate developers and local officials are pressing the City Council to create a Chinatown Business Improvement District, but merchants are divided about whether it is worth the expense.
A suicide bomber’s attack on Burhanuddin Rabbani, a former president and the leader of Afghanistan’s High Peace Council, may prove devastating to talks with the Taliban.
The International Monetary Fund downgraded its outlook for the United States economy through 2012 because of weak growth and concern over Europe’s debt crisis.
Stocks gave up early gains as investors weighed the progress on Greek debt and possible new action by the Fed.
August housing starts fell 5 percent from July, the Commerce Department said, to a level that is less than half of what economists say is consistent with healthy housing markets.
Barring an unimaginable legal reversal, Troy Davis will be executed by lethal injection at a Georgia prison on Wednesday.
In “The Quest: Energy, Security, and the Remaking of the Modern World,” Daniel Yergin returns to the topic of how energy policy is driving global change.
“Revenge,” a new series on ABC, is one of the new fall shows focused on class warfare, and a significant number find ways to kick Wall Street greed and Bernard L. Madoff.

A bombing attack in central Ankara on Tuesday killed three people and wounded at least 34 in the first deadly bombing in Turkey’s capital in more than four years.
Violence in recent days, with more than 50 people killed, has constituted the worst outbreak in Sana since the beginning of the uprising in Yemen.
The essence of garlicky clams, garlic and tomatoes all in one bowl of pasta.
A recipe for linguine with littlenecks, roasted tomatoes and caramelized garlic.
Transforming the traditional Middle Eastern dish of ground lamb, cracked bulgur and onion into a very untraditional meatloaf.
A recipe for Baked Lebanese Kibbe.

10 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER: SPECIAL VICTIMS UNIT The series begins its 13th season with a thinly veiled account of the Dominique Strauss-Kahn case, as Detective Benson (Mariska Hargitay) is called to the scene when a hotel maid (Anika Noni Rose) accuses a powerful Italian diplomat (Franco Nero, above right, with Ron Rifkin) of rape. The bureau chief, Cutter (Linus Roache), and Assistant District Attorney Cabot (Stephanie March) eventually find their prosecution growing more complicated when the maid's credibility is questioned. Back at the precinct, Detective Amanda Rollins (Kelli Giddish) steps into the shoes of Detective Stabler (Christopher Meloni, who has left the series). 11:45 A.M. (MoreMax) CRAZY HEART (2009) Jeff Bridges, in his Oscar-winning role, stars as Bad Blake, an aging country singer with a wayward streak, and Maggie Gyllenhaal is Jean Craddock, the small-town reporter who inspires Bad in this tale of second chances, written and directed by Scott Cooper and based on the novel by Thomas Cobb. ''Some of Mr. Bridges's peers may have burned more intensely in their prime, but very few American actors over the past 35 years have flickered and smoldered with such craft and resilience,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''There can never be too many songs about drinking, loving and feeling bad, and there is always room for another version of that old song about the guy who messed it all up and kept on going,'' he added. ''Especially when that guy can play the tune as truly and as well as Mr. Bridges.''

A message of condolence may be sent to lfhome@sccoast.net. Lee Funeral Home & Crematory of Little River/North Myrtle Beach is serving the family.

As part of his campaign swing through New York this week, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is courting crucial constituencies, including Hispanic and Jewish voters. -But on Monday he dined with the one constituent that could prove more influential than any religious or ethnic bloc this election: Rupert Murdoch.

In his first policy address since becoming schools chancellor in April, Dennis M. Walcott announced on Tuesday that New York would open 50 new middle schools in the next two years, many in the city's poorest neighborhoods. The city will also apply for about $30 million in federal money to replace teachers and leadership, while keeping students in place, at five struggling schools for each of the next two years, the chancellor said.

DOUGLAS--Paul W. Paul W. Douglas, a former administrator of the Marshall Plan and minerals executive, died on September 18, 2011 in New York City. He was 85. Paul Wolff Douglas was born on September 12, 1926 in Springfield, MA. He was the youngest of four children born to Paul H. Douglas, a Democratic U.S. Senator from Illinois for 18 years, and Dorothy Wolff Douglas, a chairman of the economics department at Smith College. He graduated from Deerfield Academy in Massachusetts and completed two years in the V-12 naval officers training program at Williams College and Holy Cross, before resigning in 1944 to become an ordinary seaman. After the war, he completed a B.A. in economics from Princeton University where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa then attended Leeds University in England where he was a member of an international economic team studying the post-war prospects of the British coal industry. He subsequently joined the post-war European Aid Program commonly known as the Marshall Plan, a job he later described as the most interesting he ever had. He served as chief of the internal finance section for France and later joined the group of U.S., French, and German diplomats exploring the development of a proposed European army, meetings that laid the groundwork for NATO. After the Marshall Plan ended in 1952, he joined Freeport Sulphur Company in New York, rising through the ranks to become President and Chief Executive Officer of Freeport Minerals Company by 1975. Among other accomplishments during his tenure, he engineered the development of successful Indonesian copper and Australian nickel projects and shepherded Freeport's turn-around from a $400 million one-product company to a $1.6 billion diversified mineral resource company ranked as the premier company in its field. He later became Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of the Pittston Company, a coal and transportation service concern in Greenwich, CT. He served as a director on the boards of New York Life, Philip Morris, U.S. Trust, Phelps Dodge, and the Canadian mining conglomerate MacMillan-Bloedel Ltd. and was a trustee for the International Center for the Disabled and many other non-profit groups. In the 1960s, as Chairman of Local Planning Board #

YOUNG--Susan Beaty. With heavy hearts we must announce the sudden death of our sister, Susan, on August 30th. Whether related by blood, marriage, work, friendship or sports, those whose lives she touched will not soon forget her. We must try to muster the courage and enthusiasm with which she faced her own challenges, and remember and honor Susan in that way. Certainly not with tears, as she would want us to toast life and take care of the living. So we raise our glasses to you, Suze; Godspeed, until we all meet again. With love from, her brothers and sisters, Nancy, Sam, Rich, Franny, John, Anne, Martha, Yogi and Charlie; her children, Stephanie and Alex; her adored grandchildren, Orlando, Felix andMadeline; best friends, Marcy, Peggy and Jean, and too many other friends and relatives to include here.

IVERS--Richard H. II, died peacefully on September 12th. Beloved father to J. Alexander Ivers, loving husband to Barbara Dalton Russell, and brother to Helen Henkels, Scott and Kent Ivers, Rick had a distinguished career in the financial services arena. Founder of Callidus Capital Management, and a former Managing Director of Credit Suisse and Citibank, Rick touched the lives of many in his sphere of business, as well as his personal life, through his incredible generosity and kind heart. A proud Texan, Rick was a graduate of SMU, a member of Phi Beta Kappa, and a veteran of the US Army. A memorial service is planned for mid-October.

BLOOM--Murray, 72, loving husband, wonderful friend, gentle and understanding father and grandfather, intuitive, innovative and inventive entrepreneur and avid jazz enthusiast, died peacefully Sunday, September 18, 2011. As the patriarch of cardiac electrophysiological instrumentation and himself a Horatio Alger type figure, Murray, under the banner of the company he founded, Bloom Associates Ltd., designed, manufactured and distributed cardiac stimulating, recording and monitoring devices used for the evaluation of arrhythmias of the heart. His designs helped usher in the modern era of cardiac electrophysiology. This niche business which distributed his products worldwide was sold to Fischer Imaging in 1992 and continues to this day as a part of the Fischer Medical Technologies product line. A jazz writer, arranger, player and producer, Murray's love of music took root at a very young age on the street corners of West Philadelphia and flourished throughout his life. His fondness for jazz added color, enjoyment and breath to his life, opening doors at Florida Atlantic University (the Jazz Department essentially adopted him) and within the Jazz community in Philadelphia which provided him a musical home. His arrangements has been played by many bands and immortalized on several albums. Born and raised in Philadelphia on July 24, 1939, Murray spent most of his later years in Villanova, PA annually migrating to Highland Beach, FL each winter. Besides his wife Susan, he is survived by his daughters Celia, Pamela and Amy and his grandchildren Alexandra, Daniel, Anya, Emily and Sophie. He is remembered fondly by the many friends, associates and clients he met along his journey and for the innovations and inventions by which so many lives were saved. Funeral Services will be held at 11:30am, Wednesday, September 21, 2011 at the Bringhurst Funeral Home, West Laurel Hill Cemetery, 225 Belmont Avenue, Bala Cynwyd, PA. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Bloom Fund for Cardiac Research and Education, University of Pennsylvania Development Office, 3535 Market Street, Suite 750, Philadelphia, PA 19104.

MAY--William F. The Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation's board and staff mourn the loss of our beloved friend and leader William F. May. Mr. May became our President in 1984 and served as Chairman from 1987-2004, then becoming Chairman Emeritus. Under his leadership, the Foundation restored Lady Liberty, created the Ellis Island Museum, digitized the records of millions of immigrants arriving in NY Harbor, and reopened the Statue after 9/11. Mr. May was a strong, steady and inspiring figure admired and loved by board and staff. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife Kathleen and family. Lee Iacocca, Founding Chairman Paul Weaver, Chairman Stephen Briganti, President and CEO

Walter C. Righter, an Episcopal bishop who in 1996 was brought to trial and absolved of a charge of heresy for having ordained an actively gay man as a deacon, died on Sept. 11 at his home outside Pittsburgh. He was 87. The cause was chronic lung disease, his wife, Nancy, said.

A music review on Sept. 5 about the Rock the Bells hip-hop show on Governors Island, where 11 albums were performed in their entirety, included several errors. The rapper who made the album ''Heavy Mental'' is Killah Priest, not Killa Priest. The album by Raekwon re-enacted at the concert is ''Only Built 4 Cuban Linx,'' not, as the program rendered it, ''Only Built for Cuban Linx.'' The full title of another album re-enacted is ''Mos Def & Talib Kweli Are Black Star,'' not simply ''Black Star.'' One of the songs on Erykah Badu's album ''Baduizm'' is ''Otherside of the Game,'' not ''Other Side of the Game.'' The title of a song performed by Nas is ''Live at the Barbeque,'' not ''Live at the Barbecue.'' And Large Professor, a member of Main Source, was born in Harlem -- not Queens, which is where he was raised.

MONEY BACK Brevan Howard, the large European hedge fund firm, is returning $2 billion to investors. Assets in its main portfolio, the Brevan Howard Master Fund, have swelled to $26.9 billion amid strong returns, with a gain of 11.5 percent so far this year. The firm has an agreement with clients to not let assets rise above $25 billion, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.

Jill Zarin, Alex McCord, Kelly Bensimon, and Cindy Barshop are all off the show.

An article on Saturday about the verdict in a legal dispute between Jeffrey E. Gundlach, a bond fund manager, and his former employer, Trust Company of the West, misstated one of the jury's findings. The jury found Mr. Gundlach and three co-defendants liable for breaching their fiduciary duty to Trust Company, known as TCW, not their fiduciary duty to investors.

HUNTINGTON--Derek Updegraf, 64, longtime Manhattan resident and former President of ZZZ Carpentry Inc., died on September 19th at home in the West Village. Son of John Willard Huntington and Patricia Shaffer Huntington, Derek was born on 26 February 1947 and grew up in West Hartford, CT. He graduated from Phillips Academy Andover in 1965 and Yale College in 1969. At Yale he was a nationally ranked lacrosse player, and a member of Fence Club and Scroll & Key Senior Society. Music was always a vital part of Derek's life. Throughout the 1970's he was a professional singer, songwriter, music producer and sound engineer, living and performing in Los Angeles, Boston and across New England. In 1980, Derek moved to Manhattan and in 1982 he founded ZZZ Carpentry, a high-end residential construction firm, collaborating closely with a number of notable architects on both traditional and modern renovations. Derek was an avid fresh and salt water fly fisherman, an enthusiastic tennis player, and an all-around athlete. He was a summer resident of Saltaire on Fire Island. Derek had many friends whom he loved and who loved him. He is survived by his wife and partner of 21 years, Caroline Northcote Sidnam, son Samuel Dworkin Huntington, stepdaughter Emma X Sidnam Pucci, stepson Samuel Northcote Pucci, former wife Elizabeth Dworkin, sister Sara Huntington Ohly of New Haven, CT and brother John Willard Huntington of Chicago IL. The time and place of a memorial service have not yet been determined. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Natural Resources Defense Council or The Wildlife Conservation Society.

Treatments for prostate cancer take a significant toll on male potency, leaving a surprisingly high percentage of men unable to have a normal sex life, new research shows. The findings, based on a study of more than 1,000 men treated for prostate cancer at multiple medical centers, show that whether a man is able to achieve adequate erections after treatment for prostate cancer varies greatly depending on a number of individual variables, including his age, the extent of his cancer and the quality of his sex life before treatment.

JACOBS--Dr. Eugene Leslie, 78, died September 17th after a long illness. A native New Yorker, he was raised in Forest Hills, Queens before moving permanently to Manhattan. An alumnus of Wesleyan University and Downstate Medical Center, he had a private practice in psychiatry and was affiliated with Beth Israel Hospital until his retirement in 1989. Since that time, he pursued his life-long interests in art and antiques. He loved to cook, paint, travel and most of all laugh with his beloved wife of 22 years, Vera Vento. In addition to his wife Vera, he is survived by his daughters, Hilary Jacobs Hendel and Amanda Jacobs Wolf and four grandchildren, Samantha and Kate Kaplan and Peyton and Charlotte Wolf. He is also survived by his sister, Carole Berk of Bethesda, MD. A memorial service will be held Monday, September 26 at 3pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. at 76th St.

A report in the Off the Menu column last Wednesday about the Tippler, a new bar in Manhattan, misstated its address. It is 425 West 15th Street, not 75 Ninth Avenue. The report also misspelled the surname of an owner. He is Paul Tanguay, not Tanguy.

An article on Monday about a study that recommends changes in police lineup procedures misidentified the university affiliation of Steven Clark, a psychologist who expressed skepticism about the study's conclusions and urged further research. He is a professor at the University of California, Riverside -- not at the University of Southern California.

The composer and writer Elizabeth Swados has created a musical work, ''The La MaMa Cantata,'' comprising decades of quotations by Ellen Stewart, the founder of La MaMa Experimental Theater Club, and is set to direct the piece at that downtown theater on Nov. 7 and 8. The piece is intended as a celebration of Ms. Stewart, who helped establish the Off Off Broadway scene with La MaMa and who died in January at 91. Ms. Swados is best known for her 1978 Broadway musical ''Runaways,'' for which she received Tony Award nominations for direction, music and lyrics, book and choreography. She and Ms. Stewart also collaborated for years on productions like ''Seven Against Thebes'' and ''Mythos Oedipus.'' In an e-mail Ms. Swados described the new work as a ''carnival of Ellen Stewart's own words from her 50-year career,'' as well as stories and anecdotes involving Ms. Stewart that others shared with Ms. Swados. The two performances, part of La MaMa's 50th-anniversary season, will include a company of 25 actors, soloists and chorus members. The season will begin with a two-day celebration, featuring a block party on Oct. 16 near the theater's East Village home and a gala on Oct. 17 at which Patti Smith and Bill Irwin will perform.

In August officials of the City and County of Denver announced that they had chosen Sotheby's to sell four canvases by the Abstract Expressionist painter Clyfford Still to raise money for the endowment of the new Clyfford Still Museum, which is scheduled to open there on Nov. 18. The agreement called for Sotheby's to try to sell the four as a group to a museum by Monday; if it were unable to do so, the works -- which together are estimated to be worth more than $50 million -- would then go to auction separately. Christie's, the rival auction house that had also competed for the sale, was so miffed by Denver's selection of Sotheby's that it hired lawyers and lobbyists in an unsuccessful effort to stop the arrangement. On Tuesday Sotheby's officials said that attempts to sell the paintings to a museum failed and that the works would be included in a contemporary-art auction on Nov. 9. The four canvases, bequeathed to Denver by the artist's widow, Patricia Still, include ''1949-A No. 1,'' a canvas of jagged and thick brush strokes in fiery reds and blacks, above, that is expected to bring $25 million to $35 million. ''Key works by Abstract Expressionists are hard to come by,'' said Tobias Meyer, the worldwide head of Sotheby's contemporary art department. ''But to have four paintings in one sale is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.''

ALBANY - State officials are investigating an accusation that a state worker repeatedly used a cattle prod on a developmentally disabled resident at a group home outside Albany. The accusation was made by a co-worker and came to light in late July, according to police records. The matter was investigated by the Washington County Sheriff's Office, but the cattle prod was not recovered, and the victim is not able to speak on his own behalf. The district attorney's office in Washington County ultimately decided not to pursue a criminal case.

MOLLOD-LUCKA--Sandi. It is with indescribable sadness, grief and pain that we are announcing the passing of Sandi Mollod Lucka of NYC. Sandi died on September 18 at 12:11pm, the day after her birthday, as a result of complications from cancer. Sandi had fought a courageous and heroic battle against cancer and refused to give up or give in right up to the last second. Sandi's life gives everyone who has ever met her a model for how to be a good and kind person in every way. She gave of herself whenever anyone needed her and lived her life with compassion, grace and integrity. Sandi left behind her father and mother, Bernard and Cynthia Mollod, who guided her into and through this world; her brother and best friend Michael Mollod, who depended on her for her compassion and wisdom; her loving husband Klaus Lucka, whom she adored and loved with all her being and heart; her niece and nephew, Lucas and Daphne Mollod, who loved and adored her as their aunt and role model. She died way too young and will be missed by everyone who has ever had the privilege of knowing her. Services are on Wednesday, 12:45pm, September 21st at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC followed by interment at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont NY. We love you Sandi.

MAY--William F. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center mourn the passing of William F. May, long-time supporter and member of Lincoln Center's Board of Directors and Directors Emeriti Council. He was Founding Chairman of the Film Society of Lincoln Center serving together with its Founding President and CEO, Martin E. Segal, as well as a member of the Lincoln Center Fund, the Nominating, Audit, Education, and Community Relations committees, and an Honorary Director of the Lincoln Center Institute. Mitt Romney is stepping up his effort to consolidate the support of the Republican establishment and announced on Tuesday that he was forming a Congressional team to recruit party leaders to join his campaign. Senator Roy Blunt of Missouri is leading the movement on Capitol Hill, overseeing the effort to sign up members of the House and Senate to get behind the candidacy of Mr. Romney. Republican presidential candidates often try to distance themselves from Washington, but Mr. Romney is working to shore up support from party leaders to bolster his argument that he is the most electable candidate to challenge President Obama.

Tropical Storm Irene did not wreak the kind of havoc that was feared within New York City, but the storm was still expensive. The cost to the city from the storm was at least $55 million, based on preliminary reports by its agencies.

An article on Saturday about the bankruptcy proceedings of Solyndra, a solar manufacturer that received $528 million in federal loan guarantees, referred imprecisely to the circumstances under which commercial lenders would take precedence over the government in recouping their investments. Their claims will come ahead of the government's if Solyndra is liquidated but not if it reorganized; the government has not entirely waived the privilege of coming first. The article also referred incompletely to commercial investors that provided a loan to Solyndra in February. The loan was made by Argonaut and 18 other investors, not by Argonaut alone.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about Greece's consideration of radical budget cuts to meet international lenders' conditions for financial assistance misstated the effect of public sector layoffs on meeting deficit reduction targets. Reducing the number of civil servants would make it easier to meet such targets, not ''add to the difficulty.''

A headline in some copies on Monday with an article about Justin Rose's victory in the BMW Championship golf tournament referred imprecisely to the significance of the win. While it was Rose's first victory of the year, it was not his first ever. (He has three wins on the PGA Tour.)

A building scaffold fell onto a city bus at 125th Street and Fred- erick Douglass Boulevard on Tuesday morning, causing minor injuries to 17 people, including bus passengers and two police officers, the Fire Department said. The scaffold had been erect- ed at a five-story brick building that was being demolished, offi- cials said. A police spokesman said preliminary accounts indi- cated that bricks fell onto the scaffold, knocking it down at 9:25 a.m. A bus passenger, Sasha Chavkin, a reporter for The New York World, a journalism site housed at Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism, said: ''People were running from the back and screaming. After about a minute, the bus driver let everyone off the bus.'' Firefighters swarmed the bus and the scaffolding. Shortly before noon, a transit worker drove the bus down the block, where a tow truck dragged it away.

The Charlie Sheen roast on Comedy Central was a cake walk compared with the season premiere of ''Two and a Half Men'' on CBS on Monday. That wasn't a sitcom romp, it was more like watching Iraqis tear down statues of Saddam Hussein in the early days of the American-led invasion. Real anger seemed to seep through punch lines in a funeral service that was supposed to finesse the loss of Mr. Sheen and set the stage for his replacement, Ashton Kutcher. Perhaps to coax the audience to focus on him, and not the past, Mr. Kutcher appeared naked in a few scenes, his private parts blurred for the camera.
ROBINSON--Stanley. A loyal friend who was always there for us. He will be in our hearts forever. Peter Lindeman, Rachelle Goldman and family

When a team as old as Detroit sets a franchise record, it is usually impressive. The Lions began as the Portsmouth Spartans in 1930. Before their 48-3 victory over the Chiefs on Sunday, the Lions had never won a regular-season game by more than 44 points. It turns out they had some extra motivation.

Joe Dressner once made one of my best friends cry. Joe, an iconoclastic importer of naturally made wines, died on Saturday at the age of 60 after a three-year battle with brain cancer. Even if he did make my friend cry, I'll miss him sorely. He would regularly bring a crew of his vignerons from France to the United States, where they would meet members of the trade, offer consumer tastings and raise hell after hours. These visits were important to him. They helped sell wine, of course, but he also believed that it was crucial for the public and the trade to see for themselves that wine -- good wine -- was made by people who had a vision and philosophy as well as warts and flaws and sometimes bizarre hairstyles.

Will this be the first Broadway musical where you'll have to pass a football trivia contest before they let you take your seats? A singing, dancing version of ''Diner,''Barry Levinson's 1982 coming-of-age comedy about a group of friends growing up in Baltimore in 1959, is headed to Broadway next year, its press representatives said on Tuesday. Mr. Levinson, who directed the original film and earned an Academy Award nomination for its screenplay, will write the book of the ''Diner'' musical, and Sheryl Crow will write the music and lyrics; Kathleen Marshall, a recent Tony Award-winner for her choreography of ''Anything Goes,'' will direct and choreograph this production. Mr. Levinson, whose films include ''Good Morning, Vietnam,'' ''Rain Man'' and further Baltimore-based comedies like ''Tin Men'' and ''Avalon,'' said in a statement: '' 'Diner' was a pivotal moment in my career, and since then I have continued to live with the characters, realizing there is much more to their story. I'm excited to be embarking on this stage version, which affords me the opportunity as a storyteller to expand on my original vision and let the characters express their innermost feeling and thoughts through song.''
HALF--Maxine. A very special woman. Mother, leader, friend. Sam and Robert Gottlieb

The lambasting of Charlie Sheen's real and fictional personas proved to be a ratings gold mine for CBS and Comedy Central on Monday night. The season premiere of ''Two and a Half Men'' on CBS, which featured the funeral of Mr. Sheen's character, Charlie Harper, drew 27.8 million viewers. It was the highest-rated and most-watched season premiere of a scripted show since the second-season premiere of ''Desperate Housewives'' in September 2005. The show also lifted the rest of the CBS comedy slate, providing a big lead-in for its new comedy ''2 Broke Girls'' (19.1 million viewers) and helping ''How I Met Your Mother'' reach its highest premiere audience ever (11.3 million). Meanwhile, the roast of Mr. Sheen on Comedy Central was the second-most-watched telecast in the history of that cable channel, at 6.4 million total viewers, and the most-watched ever in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

HALF--Maxine, 87, passed suddenly on September 19. Our most loving mother and grandmother whose vibrant personality and giving heart was unsurpassed. Her generosity to all who shared in her life will always be remembered. She never missed a day without talking to her children and grandchildren. She was a fierce advocate for those in need and she was capable of handling whatever challenges life brought. As one of the few working mothers of her time, she gracefully balanced a career while raising children. In 1948 she and her late husband, Robert Half, established the firm Robert Half & Accountemps. She was a brilliant force in business and instrumental in making the company grow worldwide; yet, her true joy was her family. We feel so fortunate to have celebrated so many wonderful times with her. She was always full of energy and loved life. Her kindness, generosity, beautiful soul and selflessness will always be cherished by us. She inspired us to be our best and always told us to love ourselves. Without Grandma Mac and Mom, our hearts are broken and our tears endless, but our memories and joys are immeasurable. Nancy and Donny Peggy and Marc Stephanie, Kevin, Ryan, Adam Lauren and Stephanie

Google on Tuesday opened its invitation-only social network, Google+, to anyone who wants to join at google.com/+. Google+ emphasizes privacy -- like easily sharing with select groups of siblings or colleagues -- and features like a video chat service called Hangouts. For Google, it is a way to fend off Facebook, which has been attracting users and advertisers, and gain social data to use to improve other Google services like search.

FRIDAY'S PUZZLE - When you write about something that is created by different people every day, like, oh, I don't know, crossword puzzles, you can't play favorites. Every puzzle is a piece of art unto itself, and each one deserves to be enjoyed and evaluated (notice I didn't say judged) on its own merit. It's not easy; there are bound to be constructors whose styles I am more in sync with than others. Still, we make every effort to be fair and balanced here, don't we?

Merce Cunningham's artistic heirs plan to offer classes in his technique after his dance company ceases operations at the end of the year, company officials said on Thursday. The Merce Cunningham Trust said Robert Swinston, the company's director of choreography, would teach classes starting in April at City Center, where the trust will take up offices. Jean Freebury, a former company member, will also teach Cunningham technique at the Mark Morris Dance Center starting in December, and a course will be offered at Dance New Amsterdam. Cunningham died in 2009, several months after a plan had been put in place to phase out the company. The trust is assuming oversight of Cunningham's work and is taking over for the Merce Cunningham Dance Foundation, which will close next year. Plans for teaching Cunningham's technique had been unclear until now. The foundation's executive director, Trevor Carlson, was also appointed as the fifth trustee, the trust said.

In the spring of 1861, two men appeared before the St. Louis County clerk to sign a document. One of the men, as described in detail in the document's margins, was a "barber and boathand," 37 years old and 5 feet 7-and-a-half inches tall. Other such documents described signees as "light," "dark," "copper," "high yellow," "bright" - and even though it did not say so here, everyone knew the man who signed his name in a wide script, Moses Dickson, was a free African American.

For over a decade, the British fitness line Sweaty Betty has been sold almost exclusively on its home turf. This fall, the collection - favored by fit and fabulous stars like Victoria Beckham, Elle Macpherson, Julianne Moore and Amber Valletta - arrives stateside for the first time via quarterly catalogs and its new Web address, sweatybetty.com. The brand's co-founder, Tamara Hill-Norton, said she had always dreamed of expanding to the United States. "In the U.K., exercising is still often seen as a chore," says Hill-Norton, who started the company with her husband, Simon, in 1997. "In the U.S., people push the boundaries and look for exciting new ways to keep it fresh." So now we Yankees can sweat in style with black and white printed pants - "In the Hamptons, everyone seemed to love them" - or a killer kickboxing number (as seen here on the model Flaviana Matata).

The United States National Slavery Museum, an organization founded by the former Virginia governor Douglas L. Wilder to build a museum in Frederickburg, Va., that would discuss that chapter in American history, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The Richmond Times-Dispatch reported that the museum indicated in its bankruptcy filing that it had $3 million in unsecured debts. Among its unpaid bills is one for more than $215,000 in property taxes owed on the 38-acre parcel where the museum was to have opened several years ago. Since then, the proposed museum's director has departed, its board has stopped meeting and some people who gave artifacts to the museum have asked for their return.

Shortly after Prada acquired the label in 2001, it sort of fell off the fashion map, and hasn't been produced since 2004.

On Dec. 7, the Comedy Central pundit will play host to David Hallberg, the American dancer who announced earlier this week that he will join the Bolshoi Ballet -- the first time an American has enlisted with the Russian company. Mr. Hallberg, a principal dancer at The American Ballet Theater who hails from Rapid City, S.D., will start at the Bolshoi on Nov. 4. The Colbert Report has previously featured dance luminaries like Savion Glover and cast members from the Broadway musical "Fela." Mikhail Baryshnikov has showed up too, but not to dance, so Mr. Hallberg will be the first ballet dancer to perform on the show. A spokeswoman for the show suggested that viewers might be surprised at Mr. Colbert's dancing abilities too.

I've always had a bit of trouble with the extended version of my first name. Gregory. It just feels a little too proper, doesn't it, as if it would be silly for me not to receive a dozen Fabergé eggs upon the occasion of my birth. (When you combine it with my middle name, you get Gregory Paul. I think we can all agree that's pretty papal-sounding for a Jew.) Anyway, another bummer about my name, especially when I was young and cared about this sort of thing, was that I had very few other Gregorys to look up to. The name didn't have the famous person starting lineup of a Michael or Matthew or David. I mean, Greg Gumbel seems nice and all.

London has Selfridges, Harvey Nicks and Liberty; New York has Bergdorf Goodman, Barneys and Saks; and Paris has Le Bon Marché, Les Galeries Lafayette and Au Printemps. Milan, on the other hand, has been conspicuously lacking in luxury department stores. But that all changed earlier this month, with the opening earlier of Excelsior, a multilevel shopping destination with a fashion sense that runs the gamut from Dries Van Noten to Balmain (the renowned local boutique owner Antonia Giacinti is a consultant), a trio of restaurants from the local celebrity chef Davide Oldani and departments stocked with everything from retro-fabulous meat slicers to flower arrangements by the edgy florist Numero 9. The former cinema has been reimagined by the architect Jean Nouvel as an ode to the history of film: floors are laid out as parapet balconies, and wraparound L.E.D. screens show a continuous stream of film stills. Even the sales clerks dress the part. The women who work in the cosmetics and fragrance hall on the first floor wear stripy Breton tops, cropped black trousers and ankle-strap heels and the guys who sell men's clothes on the second floor sport tartan shirts, chinos and solid ties. Despite the inauspicious location, right next to a low-end mall, and the coy facade (Nouvel hid the entrance behind a giant louvered blind, and there are no window displays), we foresee a flurry of fashion-week pilgrimages.

On a hot summer day in Manaus, Brazil, Diana Taylor, the former banking superintendent of New York and longtime companion of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, was strolling through a slum. A city of about two million in the middle of the Amazon, Manaus is where the Boston-based microfinance group Acción International started an ambitious lending operation in February, and Taylor, who is chairwoman of the group's board, had flown down with a delegation of staff and investors to observe how the experiment was coming along on the ground. Nearly six feet tall, thin and wearing large, round sunglasses, khaki pants and leather driving moccasins that had the kind of distressed effect only years of wear can produce, Taylor did not blend in.

Line2 HD may not be the first app to turn your iPad into a phone, but it is an easy-to-use addition that puts phone calls, texts, voicemail and e-mail on a single screen-and offers a stack of other features as well. Like Line2's iPhone app the HD version lets you make or receive calls over a 3G or Wi-Fi connection. You get a new phone number (like Google Voice), which can also receive texts and has voicemail.

MIAMI -- One day before the Republican presidential candidates were to gather for a debate in Florida, Mitt Romney intensified his criticism of Gov. Rick Perry's position on Social Security on Wednesday and belittled the concept of turning the federal program over to the states or to local governments. ''People move, and they go from state to state to state,'' Mr. Romney said. ''How would you deal with people moving all over the place?''

A federal appeals court in Manhattan on Wednesday unanimously upheld the convictions of a Syrian arms dealer and two associates who had been charged in an international sting operation run by the government that defense lawyers had criticized as having unfairly ensnared people. Prosecutors said that the arms dealer, Monzer al-Kassar, who was extradited from Spain in 2008, had agreed to sell weapons to informants working for the United States Drug Enforcement Administration who were posing as representatives of a Colombian terrorist group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC.

Former POW (World War II, 106th Infantry Division, Battle of the Bulge, Stalag 11B), Director, Montefiore Medical Center Nutrition Department for 37 years, 15 year volunteer at the Bronx VA Medical Center. Survived by his wife of 62 years, Jean; his son, Norman, and his wife, Janice; his daughter, Elaine, and her husband, Steve; and his grandchildren, Rachel, Rebecca, Leah, Alyssa, Carly and Samuel. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Ex-Prisoners of War Association, National Headquarters, 3201 East Pioneer Parkway #

The Copenhagen Journal article on Sept. 14, about rising pedestrian anger over bicyclists in Copenhagen who violate traffic laws, misstated the surname of the city's deputy mayor for technology and the environment, who played down the conflict. She is Ayfer Baykal, not Bayka. The article also misspelled the name of a street leading to the Copenhagen city center that on some days is traveled by as many as 36,000 bikers. It is Norrebrogade, not Norrebrigade.

An obituary on Tuesday about the conductor Kurt Sanderling misstated the name of the town where he was born, which is now Orzysz, Poland. It was Arys, East Prussia, not Ays. The obituary also referred incorrectly to the career of Mr. Sanderling's wife, the double bassist Barbara Sanderling. She is retired from the Berlin Symphony Orchestra; she is not a member of the Berlin Philharmonic.

The latest version of Apple's Safari browser for Windows and Mac OS X includes a Reading List feature that lets you quickly save Web pages for later perusal. To save a Web page on screen, go to Safari's Bookmarks menu and choose the ''Add to Reading List'' option. You can also press Control-Shift-D in Windows or Command- Shift-D on a Mac to save the current page to the Reading List. And you can Shift-click on a link within a Web page to save that article to the Reading List without opening it. To see all your saved articles, click the small eyeglasses icon in the Safari toolbar to slide open the Reading List side panel. The Reading List feature will also be available in iOS 5, the coming system software update for Apple's iPad, iPhone and iPod Touch; the company says saved articles can be synchronized across devices through the forthcoming iCloud online service.

A long-time member of the garment industry, he is survived by his loving wife of 58 years, Phyllis. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Mrs. Kraut, Jeff and his brother Robert, daughters-in-law Ellen and Nancy, and grandchildren. Michael Dowling, President & CEO Richard Goldstein, Chairman North Shore-LIJ Health System

Why do like engineers like to graft together disparate devices? Shoes with a built in speaker and MP3 player come to mind as one of the stranger pairings, but the folks at Sony have come up with an electronic mash-up that makes surprising sense. It's a set of binoculars with a built-in video camera.
