WANG--Carol "Sandy", of Wilmington, NC and West Harwich, MA, dearly loved wife, mother, sister, grandmother, aunt, cousin and friend died peacefully on September 17, 2011 at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, MA, with her husband of forty-eight years by her side. She was sixty-eight years old. Born in New York City, a graduate of Queens College and Bank Street Graduate School of Education, Sandy served as Head of Lower School at the Tower Hill School in Wilmington, DE and, prior, was Director of Development for Moorestown Friends School in Moorestown, NJ. Sandy was known as a compassionate advocate for children, an inspirational mentor to faculty and a tireless supporter of school families, but her legacy also extends to the institutions she served. She directed fundraising and development campaigns, built lasting academic programs and successfully led multi-year school building projects, including the new Pre-School Wing and Playground at the Tower Hill School, which the Trustees and Donors named "Sandy's Place" in her honor in 2008. Treasured and admired by her family, and looked to for wisdom and guidance, Sandy was loved immeasurably. When she was diagnosed with cancer in 2010, she inspired all who knew her by living each day just as she had before her illness with strength, enthusiasm, grace and a beautiful smile. In the last year of her life she realized her dream of traveling internationally with her children and grandchildren, recommitted to the game of bridge, celebrating every Master Point, and continued to be an active participant in the Lifelong Learning Institute at UNCW. She enjoyed time with family and friends at her Cape Cod home over the past year and never missed one of her grandchildren's hockey games, school plays or dance recitals. Sandy cherished the loving relationships she shared with her friends, colleagues and family, and felt lucky for these gifts every day of her life. Daughter of the late George and Diana Glotzer, Sandy is survived by her husband, Michael Wang, children Andrew Wang and Kathy Seward, daughter-in-law and son-in-law Karen Wang and Duane Seward, brother Alan Glotzer, sister-in-law Susan Miller, grandchildren Lydia, Zachary, Sophie and Macy and her nieces, nephew and cousins. She will be missed. A memorial service will be held on Monday, September 26 at 1:0pm at The Frank H. Kenan Chapel located at 510 Arboretum Drive, Wilmington, NC 28405. In lieu of flowers, donations in Sandy's memory may be sent to Faculty Professional Development, Tower Hill School, 2813 W. 17th St., Wilmington, DE 19806 or Landfall Foundation, 1924 Pembroke Jones Drive, Wilmington, NC 28405.

Tony Bennetthas apologized on his Facebook page for remarks he made on Howard Stern's radio show suggesting that the United States had caused the Sept. 11 attacks. In an interview broadcast on Monday, Mr. Bennett, the 85-year-old pop crooner, was talking with Mr. Stern and his co-host, Robin Quivers, about war and terrorism when he said: ''But who are the terrorists? Are we the terrorists, or are they the terrorists? Two wrongs don't make a right.''

To the Editor: ''Sewing Her Way Out of Poverty'' has become a popular and successful strategy for women around the world thanks to the social effect of microfinance. Nicholas D. Kristof (column, Sept. 15) has reminded us of the enormous benefits of small, income-generating loans to primarily poor women.

DICKER--Herbert. Born in Brooklyn on May 10, 1921, passed away peacefully on September 21st, 2011. Beloved husband of Dorothy Dicker, devoted father to Sandra Dunn and Kristina Trino-Molenkamp, cherished grandfather to Kaila J. Dunn, and loving brother of Ruth Zittel and the late Leon Dicker. Lawyer and senior partner with Wilson, Elser, Moskowitz Edelman & Dicker. New York City's Tax commissioner under Mayor Lindsay, and member of the Brooklyn Law School Board of Trustees . Services: Friday, 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

For fans of the Muppets there's more than one great and powerful Oz who has shaped their cultural consciousness. There's the literary character, and then there's the very real Frank Oz, the director and Muppeteer, who will be making a special appearance at the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, in conjunction with its presentation of ''Jim Henson's Fantastic World,'' the museum said on Wednesday. Mr. Oz, who helped create and performed puppet characters like Fozzie Bear, Grover, Bert and the ''Star Wars'' Jedi master Yoda, and who went on to direct films including ''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels'' and ''What About Bob?'', will appear at the museum on Oct. 23. He will be interviewed by Craig Shemin, the president of The Jim Henson Legacy, and discuss his performing and filmmaking career, as well as his development of Miss Piggy's persona. The museum said it would screen ''The Muppets Take Manhattan,'' which Mr. Oz directed, on Oct. 22 and 23, and his film version of ''Little Shop of Horrors,'' on Oct. 29 and 30.

The Noticed column last week, about professional athletes who attended runway shows and parties during New York Fashion Week, misstated the date of the Tommy Hilfiger show, which was attended by the New York Ranger Brad Richards. It was Sept. 9, not Sept. 12.

An article on Tuesday about the flurry of recent activity in conference realignment in college sports misspelled the surname of a former president of the University of Oregon who likened the movement to a game of musical chairs. He is David Frohnmayer, not Frohenmayer.

GERSEN--Daniel, of New York, NY died on September 19, 2011 at age 94. Raised in Elizabethtown, New York, a small village in the Adirondacks, by his parents Alexander and Manya Gersen, a country doctor and a dentist, respectively. He received his LLB from Columbia Law School and was a member of the Columbia Law Review, and a graduate of Amherst College. During World War II he was stationed in India; serving in the U.S. Army Air Corp. From 2007 to 2010, Of Counsel to the firm of Wolf Haldenstein, prior to which was senior partner of his own firm Gersen, Blakeman & Ackert LLP, with a law career spanning 70 years of active involvement as counselor, lawyer and trusted advisor to his clients in the areas of commercial litigation, labor and employment law, banking and finance, corporate law and trusts and estates. An advocate for variance not-for-profit corporations and a member of numerous organizations including The School of American Ballet, Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, Council of Canadian and American Relations, Parkinson's Disease Foundation and the New York Society for the Deaf and a long-time supporter of the Adirondack Council. He will be remembered for his friendship and wise counsel. He leaves all who knew him with years of wonderful memories of his charm, wit and indomitable spirit. His love of the Adirondack Mountains, Physics and Mathematics and music continued all through his life. He is predeceased by his sisters, Ruth Reichbart and her husband Joseph and his sister Edith Yokell. He is survived by his wife, Adeline, his step-daughter Linda Borrino and her husband Pasquale, his step-son John Senise and his wife Hillary, his step-grandchildren Michael and Julia Senise, his brother-in-law Stanley Yokell, of Boulder, Colorado and his nephew Michael Yokell and his wife Debra Rakim, his niece June Yokell, his nephew Larry Yokell, his nephew Richard Reichbart and his companion Nansie Ross. A memorial service celebrating his life will be held on October 18th at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York 10028 at 2:00pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to either: Parkinson's Disease Foundation or Orpheus Chamber Orchestra.

An article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about bicycle-oriented development in Portland, Ore., omitted one of the developers of the EcoFlats apartment and retail complex, which has racks for bikes, but offers no parking for vehicles. Besides Jean-Pierre Veillet, Doug Shapiro of Hoyt Street Properties also developed the project.
What do you do after you ''retire'' at 41 from a popular and influential rock band? If you're James Murphy, frontman of the indie-dance act LCD Soundsystem, you dabble.

BLACK booties, wardrobe essentials for a streetwise fall outfit, and nude pumps, the ladylike footwear Kate Middleton wore all summer long, have crossbred. ''For fall, a two-tone bootie is the perfect hybrid,'' said Annie Ladino, a stylist who has dressed celebrities like Julia Roberts and Brooklyn Decker. ''Its chameleon effect adds a cool factor to a look while keeping you refined and polished.'' Black-and-brown booties go well with popular fall colors like burgundy and orange, and we like them with multiprints, too. And, of course, they'll always look great with a pair of jeans and a blazer.

Incumbency, it turns out, does not always have its privileges. Last month, the Republican National Committee raised significantly more money than the Democratic National Committee, according to records filed this week with the Federal Election Commission. The Republicans pulled in $8.2 million to the Democrats' $5.4 million in August, a traditionally slow month for fund-raising for both parties.

Two of the more colorful characters caught in the government's vast insider trading investigation were sentenced on Wednesday, three weeks before its central figure - Raj Rajaratnam - was set to learn his fate. Zvi Goffer, a former hedge fund trader, received a 10-year sentence from Judge Richard J. Sullivan in Federal District Court in Manhattan, among the longest insider trading sentences ever.

Lady Antebellum, the country-pop trio that swept the Grammy Awards this year, opened at No. 1 on the Billboard chart this week with its new album, ''Own the Night'' (Capitol Nashville). It sold 347,000 copies in the United States in its first week out, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Also on the album chart this week, Adele's ''21'' (XL/Columbia) holds steady at No. 2 with 119,000 sales, almost unchanged from the week before, while Lil Wayne's ''Tha Carter IV'' (Cash Money/Universal Republic), the stop seller for the last two weeks, slides to No. 3 with 117,000, a nearly 50 percent drop in sales. The country singer Brantley Gilbert is No. 4 with 51,000 sales of ''Halfway to Heaven'' (Valory), which came out on a small label more than a year ago but was re-released last week by a subsidiary of Taylor Swift's label, Big Machine.

''Yank!,'' a musical that gained a following during its 2010 Off Broadway run, in part because of its provocative love story between World War II servicemen, has lead actors in place for a four-week developmental workshop this fall that might be a prelude to a Broadway production. Bobby Steggert (''Ragtime'') will reprise his performance as the main character Stu from the York Theater Company production last year, while Santino Fontana (the recent Broadway revival of ''The Importance of Being Earnest'') will succeed Ivan Hernandez in the role of Mitch, who falls by fits and starts into a romance with Stu. A spokesman for the Old Globe Theater, which is producing the workshop, confirmed the casting lineup on Wednesday.

He was a vigorous and caring leader who helped immeasurably in creating the FSLC as a new constituent at LCPA. We send our sympathy to his devoted wife Kathleen and his entire family. Ann Tenenbaum, Chairman, Dan Stern, President, Martin E. Segal, Founder, Rose Kuo, Executive Director

(NBC) COMMUNITY A new season of NBC's Thursday night comedy block begins as the study group members reunite after summer break and wonder if they'll see Pierce (Chevy Chase), who left in anger after last spring's paintball game. Jeff (Joel McHale) has a run-in with the new biology teacher, Professor Kane (Michael K. Williams), and is kicked out of class. And Dean Pelton (Jim Rash, above) finds a new nemesis in Vice Dean Laybourne (John Goodman) of the Air-Conditioning Repair Annex. In ''Parks and Recreation,'' at 8:30, Leslie (Amy Poehler) decides to break up with Ben (Adam Scott) or follow her dream of running for office. Ann (Rashida Jones) dispenses medical advice, and Ron (Nick Offerman) prepares for the return of his first ex-wife, Tammy (Patricia Clarkson). In ''The Office,'' at 9, the new regional manager of Dunder Mifflin is revealed amid a frenzy of speculation. James Spader joins the cast as the company's mysterious new chief executive. And in the premiere of ''Whitney,'' at 9:30, Whitney (Whitney Cummings), a whiny photographer, worries that she and her exceedingly patient longtime beau, Alex (Chris D'Elia), may have to rev up their relationship if it's going to survive. 7 P.M. The ''In the Garden'' column last week, about Ken Landon's waterlily collection in San Angelo, Tex., misstated the name of the first waterlily he received as a child. It is Nymphaea Rose Arey, not Nymphaea Rosa Ray. And a picture caption misidentified one of the waterlilies in his collection. It is Nymphaea Bull's Eye, not Nymphaea Tanzanite.

An article on Saturday about the widespread push to prevent the execution of the Georgia inmate Troy Davis misidentified a death row inmate in Louisiana whose cause was taken up in the 1980s by Sister Helen Prejean and chronicled in her book ''Dead Man Walking.'' That autobiographical account was built around her work with Elmo Patrick Sonnier -- not with Matthew Poncelet, the name of the character played by Sean Penn in the 1995 movie ''Dead Man Walking.'' (The character was a composite of Mr. Sonnier and Robert Lee Willie, another inmate she counseled and wrote about in the book.)

An article on Sept. 10 about magazine covers commemorating the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks referred imprecisely to the role played by two artists, who designed the Time magazine anniversary cover, in the creation of the ''Tribute in Light'' memorial that appears every year at ground zero. While the artists, Julian LaVerdiere and Paul Myoda, created the memorial, they did so along with John Bennett, Gustavo Bonevardi, Richard Nash Gould and the light designer Paul Marantz; they were not the sole co-creators.

'BEHAVIORAL AND NEURAL CORRELATES OF DELAY OF GRATIFICATION 40 YEARS LATER' by B. J. Casey, Walter Mischel and 12 other collaborators in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. Dr. Casey is director of the Sackler Institute for Developmental Psychobiology at Weill Cornell Medical College, and Dr. Mischel, a psychologist, is Niven professor of humane letters at Columbia University. THE EXPERIMENT For nearly four decades the marshmallow test has fascinated people. In this experiment Dr. Mischel probed 4-year-olds' self-control by offering them one marshmallow now or two 15 minutes later. When Dr. Mischel caught up with the preschoolers years later, those who exhibited more self-control in the experiment turned out to be less likely to abuse drugs and more successful in relationships, work and handling stress as adults than their eat-it-now counterparts. Dr. Mischel, Dr. Casey and their collaborators wanted a closer look at what was happening in these subjects' brains. They rounded up 59 of the more than 500 participants -- now in their mid-40s -- to retake the test, and then scanned the brains of 26 of them using functional M.R.I. Dr. Mischel had proposed that a ''cool'' system rooted in the conscious control circuitry in the brain and a ''hot'' system centered in the region devoted to desire and emotions were both involved in self-control. The question was whether people who quickly grabbed for the marshmallow -- the ''low delayers'' -- would have less activity in the right prefrontal cortex (cognitive control) and more in the ventral striatum (where positive rewards are processed), compared with the ''high delayers.'' Aware that sweets might not be as much of a lure to adults, Dr. Casey used happy, neutral and fearful faces to stand in for positive and negative social cues.

FALCONE UNDER FIRE A group of Republican lawmakers has taken aim at the hedge fund manager Philip A. Falcone, below, asking for details of his contact with the White House about a telecommunications company he is backing. Representative Ralph Hall of Texas, the chairman of the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology, and six other committee members are questioning the timing of donations to Democrats and requests for meetings with the White House made by employees of LightSquared, Mr. Falcone's venture. LightSquared is hoping to start a broadband network to sell wireless service wholesale, but some studies have found that the network would interfere with GPS signals. AZAM AHMED

11:14 p.m. | Updated United Technologies has agreed to buy the Goodrich Corporation for $16.4 billion in cash, the companies said late on Wednesday, in an effort to expand in the fast-growing commercial aviation business.

NEW DELHI - Teacups in hand and butter biscuits within reach, a handful of local technology titans debated the future of some young Indian entrepreneurs on a summer Saturday. After grilling five teams over several hours, the group, the Indian Angel Network, put two promising start-ups on the short list for potential financing. ''The Angel Network is really trying to help breed innovation,'' said Padmaja Ruparel, the president of the organization. ''Our efforts are really going into driving the economic engine of India.''

Cherished grandmother of Eric and Sheryl, Ross, Gregg, Lauren, Stephanie and Phoebe, and cherished great-grandmother of Owen. Services Thursday 10am at "Riverside-Nassau North Chapels", 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

WHEN Benedetta Antonelli, an Italian stylist, first saw the workwear manufacturing company run by the family of her beau, Jonathan Joory, she wanted to wear everything she saw. As Mr. Joory recalled, ''Her first reaction was how cool all this stuff would be if it were made for women.'' A year and a half later, they have a new business, Confezioni Crosby, made on Crosby Street in SoHo, offering traditional workwear infused with Italian tailoring and some schoolgirl touches. MAY--William F. The Trustees and community of the American Museum of Natural History are saddened by the death of Bill May, Trustee of the Museum since 1977 and Honorary Trustee since 1996. He was an active and steadfast champion of the Museum's mission of scientific exploration and education about the natural world and human cultures, contributing his vast expertise and wisdom to the full range of the Museum's work during a period of great institutional growth. Our deepest sympathies go to his wife Kathleen and the entire May family. Lewis W. Bernard, Chairman Ellen V. Futter, President

O'BRIEN--John "Jack", of Blauvelt, NY passed away peacefully at home on Sunday, September 18th, 2011 at the age of 86 surrounded by his loving family. He was born to the late Thomas and Beatrice O'Brien in Fairymount, County Roscommon, Ireland. In 1956, he married his beloved wife Eileen (Smyth) of the Bronx, NY. They lived and raised their family in Staten Island, NY for many years before settling in Blauvelt, NY in 1978. Jack is survived by his devoted wife Eileen and six children and their spouses; Denis O'Brien and Laurie of Mystic, CT; Jean Alfonso and Joseph of Upper Saddle River, NJ; Loretta Kane and Michael of Tappan, NY; John O'Brien and Lisa of Bronxville, NY; Richard O'Brien and Julie of Howell, NJ; and Thomas O'Brien of Jersey City, NJ along with thirteen dear grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. He is also survived by his loving sister, Mary (Molly) Mullen and her husband Patrick. He was predeceased by his grandson baby Michael Kane in 1997. Jack worked as a Pressman for the New York Times for more than 30 years. An avid lover of Irish music and culture, Jack enjoyed nothing more than an evening of live Irish music and to take his bride for a spin on the dance floor. He was a founding member of the Rockland County Irish-American Society and a devoted father and grandfather loved by all for his easy smile and sense of humor. He will be dearly missed by all. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated Saturday, 10 am, at St. Catharine's Church, 523 Western Highway, Blauvelt, NY 10913. Interment will follow at St. Anthony's Cemetery, 36 Route 59A, Nanuet, NY 10954. The family will be receiving friends on Friday, from 2-4 and 7-9 pm at the Moritz Funeral Home, 98 Route 303 South,Tappan, NY. (www.moritzfh.net or 845-359-0890). In lieu of flowers, donations in Jack's memory to United Hospice of Rockland, 11 Stokum Ln., New City, NY 10956 (845-634-4974) would be greatly appreciated.

PHILADELPHIA -- Eagles quarterback Michael Vick, who is recovering from a concussion, participated in the team's walk-through practice Wednesday, but his availability for Philadelphia's game Sunday against the Giants remained unknown. As of Wednesday afternoon, Vick had yet to be cleared by an independent neurological consultant, and his results on the ImPACT concussion test were not close enough to his baseline performance. A magnetic resonance imaging test was negative.

Q. In my Gmail address, I have a period in there to separate my first and last names for easier reading. When I was logging in the other day, I mistyped my user name into the Gmail Web site without the period but my password still worked. How is that? A. Although the period in the first part of your e-mail address may make it easier for humans to process at glance, the Gmail service ignores it. In other words, the system sees honey.badger@gmail.com and honeybadger@gmail.com as the same address and your password works with either variation.

The fall travel issue of T explores the art of the tour, starting with the model Lara Stone, who heads home to the Netherlands for a romp through her old stomping grounds. The performer Casey Spooner, of the art-rock group Fischerspooner, takes us from stage to stream on his whirlwind trip through four countries. And Diana Taylor, the board chairwoman of the microfinance group Acción - and Mayor Bloomberg's longtime companion - leads the way to Manaus, Brazil, where the organization recently began making loans. Along the way we stop in Beirut to find the city eternally optimistic in the wake of the Arab Spring; Provence, where one of the world's most reclusive patrons has turned his vineyard into an architectural theme park; and the Tuscarora Reservation in New York State, for a look at how the tribe's heritage corn has survived the ages, and why it matters to agriculture. Elsewhere, Daphne Merkin looks for retail therapy in Jerusalem, The Selby discovers punk-rock tapas in Tokyo, and Jeremy Irons reveals his Budapest, part of an up-to-the-minute guide to "Hollywood on the Danube." See all the stories here.

An elderly family member started smoking as a young person, maybe a teenager, tucking a pack of cigarettes into his rolled-up shirtsleeve or into her purse. In addition to Prada, Jil Sander, Dolce & Gabbana, Gucci, et al, a must-see on this season's Milan fashion week calendar is "Lei e le Altre," an exhibition at the Museo della Permanente, culled from the archives of RCS Periodici, the publishing company behind titles like Max, Amica, L'Europeo and the legendary but defunct Lei. Curated by Maria Luisa Frisa and designed by Arabeschi di Latte, the dense, labyrinthine installation presents style milestones at every turn, including Jackie Kennedy on a Roman holiday, Françoise Hardy in 1970s-era Yves Saint Laurent and fashion's current patron saint, Lady Gaga. But the view is ultimately panoramic: "Fashion can be used to read and interpret society, and to tell stories about the evolution and emancipation of women," Frisa says. Here fashion acts not only as a reflection of social change, but as a driving force behind it - and not just on paper.

The ratings for "The X Factor" premiere on Wednesday may not have met expectations, but the second episode last night at least held steady. With 12.5 million viewers, the overall ratings matched the debut episode, while the 18-to-49-year-old audience dropped off by just 2 percent. It was enough to give Fox a victory in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49 demographic for the night, representing Fox's first ratings win ever for a Thursday during premiere week. CBS once again finished first in total viewers, led by two episodes of "Big Bang Theory" (averaging 14.4 million viewers) and its new drama "Person of Interest" (13.2 million), according to Nielsen data. However, "Person of Interest" fell in its second half-hour and was fourth in the 18-to-49 category for its 9 p.m. time slot, behind "X-Factor," "Grey's Anatomy" on ABC and "Whitney" on NBC.

The National Gallery of Art in Washington recently unveiled "The Invention of Glory: Afonso V and the Pastrana Tapestries," four enormous pieces created by Flemish weavers in the 1470s. Commissioned to applaud King Afonso V of Portugal, who invaded Moroccan coastal cities in the mid-15th century, the tapestries never made it to Lisbon. Instead, they languished in the Spanish town of Pastrana: moth-eaten, faded and rarely seen.

Red Bulls Coach Hans Backe on Friday suspended defender Rafael Marquez for Saturday's match against visiting Portland after the club's Mexican international was critical of his teammates after Wednesday's 3-1 loss to Real Salt Lake. The decision will probably will spare Marquez another negative reaction from the club's fans. The match is expected to be sold out in the 25,000-seat Red Bull Arena. Marquez was booed by the fans in the Arena's South Ward, home to the team's most dedicated fans.

Over the past three years, the New York-based, itinerant art organization e-flux has been cultivating a large-scale micro-economy through a project called Time/Bank. Physical branches at museums in Den Haag and Frankfurt circulated an alternative currency whose notes, designed by the artist Lawrence Weiner, are printed in denominations of hours. During these exhibitions, anyone could spend time helping others to earn bills, which are redeemable for daily items, groceries, art books and other staples. Julieta Aranda and Anton Vidokle, the artists who founded Time/Bank, call it "a platform that enables people to get things done without using money" - indeed, to this day the bank is still functioning, globally, with more than a thousand users who deposit time into the Time/Bank Web site and withdraw it in the form of skills performed by others.

For nearly three decades beginning in the 1960s, the designer Giorgio Sant'Angelo held fashion insiders in his sway. Among these was the editor Diana Vreeland, who famously urged Sant'Angelo, an architect and industrial designer by training, to make accessories and clothes. "She sent me to Arizona,'' Sant'Angelo once said, ''with Veruschka, the model, four suitcases full of fabrics, wires and tape and told me to wrap and tie everything as I wanted and then she gave me eight pages in the magazine.'' That editorial, set in the Painted Desert, photographed by Franco Rubartelli, and published in Vogue in 1968, forged Sant'Angelo's career. Now, 22 years after his death, Sant'Angelo's creative force returns to Arizona in the form of a retrospective - the designer's first - at the Phoenix Art Museum.

The dirt-bike racer Ashley Fiolek, 20, is the first woman in motocross to be signed to a major corporate team, the youngest to win the American women's motocross championship and the only woman to twice take home the gold in motocross at the X Games. And in a sport in which sound is essential, she has done all of this without the ability to hear. "I have been told that most people use sound to know when to shift," says Fiolek, who has been deaf since birth. "I feel when my motorcycle needs to shift. The engine's vibrations change and I know it's time." At 5-foot-2 and 110 pounds, Fiolek might be Honda-Red Bull's most petite team member, but her next goal is decidedly large: to be the first woman to compete in a men's race. "My fans really want to see me qualify," she says.

The four men who made up the Beatles are, to the vast majority of us, larger-than-life figures who made a tremendous and lasting impact on music, film and fashion and in numerous other arenas of popular culture. But to a select few, they are just - or are also - people: friends, siblings, parents, husbands. Among the members of that exclusive club is Olivia Harrison, who married George Harrison in 1978 and remained with him until his death in 2001. Ms. Harrison, who is the mother of Harrison's son, Dhani, does not consider herself a celebrity and does not fully embrace the spotlight, but she has become a guardian of her husband's legacy and of the mementos and artifacts he left behind at Friar Park, their sizable estate in Henley-on-Thames, England.

Packers (2-0) at Bears (1-1)Sunday, 4:15 p.m.Line: Packers 3.Jay Cutler is a 50-Tesla, super-cooled, solenoid-style electromagnet for criticism. He can attract scorn from hundreds of miles away. Everything about Cutler's career is polarizing: the gaudy statistics that contrast his 35-35 win-loss record; his penchant for turnovers; his snippy, irritable public demeanor; and his career-long association with mercurial offensive masterminds like Mike Shanahan, Josh McDaniels and Mike Martz, who only magnify his peculiar attraction-repulsion effect.Last season's N.F.C. championship game became Ferris Cutler's Day Off, with the (somewhat) injured quarterback looking less willing than able on the sideline as his backups got battered by the Packers. It was the type of nonperformance that defines a career, fairly or not, and a win Sunday could deflect a tiny bit of criticism. Unfortunately, Cutler's Bears are 1-4 against the Packers in the past two seasons, and their offensive line is still bad enough to make even the toughest quarterback consider using a sick day. Pick: Packers

11:10 p.m. | Updated The names of five Yankees regulars were missing when the lineup for Thursday night's game against Tampa Bay was posted on the clubhouse door at 5 p.m. The starters who played in a dreary 15-8 loss to the Rays did poorly and were out of the game in a hurry. Less than 24 hours after the Yankees celebrated their American League East title, Derek Jeter made two errors and Nick Swisher made another, allowing the Rays to keep pounding Bartolo Colon and move two games behind the idle Boston Red Sox in the A.L. wild-card race.

LEVINE--Gertrude, On September 20, 2011, at the age of 91. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Bernard D. Levine, she will be greatly mourned by her daughter Rona Shamoon and son-in-law Dr. Harry Shamoon, her son Dr. Mitchell Levine and daughter-in-law Sara Levine, her grandchildren Evan, Mark, Michael, Elizabeth and Miriam, her brothers Rabbi Aharon Greenberg and Rabbi Yitzchak Greenberg, her sisters-in-law Blu Greenberg and Chana Greenberg, and her many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. She was a wonderful teacher and role model to her family. Shiva will be held at her apartment in Riverdale, Friday morning September 23, and Sunday, September 25 through Tuesday, September 27. Contributions may be made in her memory to UJA/Federation, Doctors Without Borders or the American Jewish World Service.

1:25 p.m. | Updated Arnold Schwarzenegger has led a life that is made for storytelling: Austrian immigrant comes to the United States as an elite bodybuilder, gains fame and wealth as an international movie star, marries a Kennedy and, even more improbably, is elected governor of California. Now Mr. Schwarzenegger, 64, is promising to write about his experiences in a memoir, expected to land in bookstores in October 2012.

Neon signs flash and blink and blare. They outline leggy dancers; they scream out ''LIQUOR''; they direct you toward a hotdog. Yet in hyper-stimulated New York, even things designed to be noticed go unnoticed. That is why one woman set about documenting them. Since last December, Kirsten Hively has jaunted around the city photographing bursts of neon that advertise everything from churches to porn shops. Her photos, shot at night, have a minimal, lonesome look: bars plead for you to enter, phrases float in the darkness, a tooth brushes its own head.

It may be that no technological advancement in New York transportation history has been so equally desired and dreaded, but the ability to chat on a cellphone in the subway will finally be available - though in a very limited way - next week. The wired underground project will begin on Tuesday at four stations in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan, where subscribers to the AT&T and T-Mobile networks will be able to talk away on station platforms, transportation officials said.

DARLING--Jeffrey T.,55 of Toms River, NJ passed on Tuesday, September 20, 2011 at Community Medical Center, Toms River, NJ. RODBELL--Thelma Salmanson, of Palm Beach, FL, 91, beloved mother of Barbara, Alan (and Shelly), and Carol Salmanson (and Steve Leto), sister of Anne Schlusselberg, and grandmother of Leonard Daniel and Rebecca Salmanson. Born in Sambor, Poland (now Ukraine), she immigrated in 1930 to West Warwick, RI, and moved to Providence in 1947 when she married Leonard Salmanson, who died in 1975. In 1978 she married Leonard Rodbell and moved to Atlanta, where his children Sidney, Paul and Arthur, and grandchildren considered her a part of their family. She was a passionate supporter of the State of Israel since its founding, as well as many other charities. She will be sorely missed by all her friends and family. Funeral and burial will be held at Lincoln Cemetery in Warwick, RI at 3pm on Friday, September 23rd. Shiva will be observed at 980 Fifth Ave in New York City from Sunday, September 25th through Monday, September 27th, from 1-9pm. Israel (317 Madison Ave., Ste. 607, New York, NY 10017).

ALIBABA SHARES An investment group that includes Silver Lake Partners and DST Global said Thursday that it would begin a $1.6 billion tender offer for shares in the Alibaba Group, the Chinese e-commerce giant. The program will value Alibaba at more than $32 billion, according to people with knowledge of the matter. ''We believe the high-quality investors making commitments to this important program share our mission and philosophy,'' said Jack Ma, above, Alibaba's chief executive.
The bitter, boisterous 44-day strike at the Boathouse Restaurant in Central Park ended on Thursday as the two sides announced that they had agreed to a four-year union contract.

HUNTINGTON--Derek Updegraf, 64, longtime Manhattan resident and former President of ZZZ Carpentry Inc., died on September 19th at home in the West Village. Son of John Willard Huntington and Patricia Shaffer Huntington, Derek was born on 26 February 1947 and grew up in West Hartford, CT. He graduated from Phillips Academy Andover in 1965 and Yale College in 1969. At Yale he was a nationally ranked lacrosse player, and a member of Fence Club and Scroll & Key Senior Society. Music was always a vital part of Derek's life. Throughout the 1970's he was a professional singer, songwriter, music producer and sound engineer, living and performing in Los Angeles, Boston and across New England. In 1980, Derek moved to Manhattan and in 1982 he founded ZZZ Carpentry, a high-end residential construction firm, collaborating closely with a number of notable architects on both traditional and modern renovations. Derek was an avid fresh and salt water fly fisherman, an enthusiastic tennis player, and an all-around athlete. He was a summer resident of Saltaire on Fire Island. Derek had many friends whom he loved and who loved him. He is survived by his wife and partner of 21 years, Caroline Northcote Sidnam, son Samuel Dworkin Huntington, stepdaughter Emma X Sidnam Pucci, stepson Samuel Northcote Pucci, former wife Elizabeth Dworkin, sister Sara Huntington Ohly of New Haven, CT and brother John Willard Huntington of Chicago IL. The time and place of a memorial service have not yet been determined. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Natural Resources Defense Council or The Wildlife Conservation Society.

The Prattsville Journal article in some editions on Thursday, about a tavern owned by Ken Cox that lost its bar in Tropical Storm Irene but has become a gathering place for the flood-ravaged town in the Catskill Mountains, misstated the name of the agency that employs Mr. Cox in his day job. A picture caption on Thursday with an obituary about Sam DeLuca, a sports broadcaster and former professional football player, misstated his tenure with the New York Jets. As the obituary correctly noted, he was with the team from 1964 until the last game of the 1967 preseason, not from 1964 to 1966.

PARIS - For the first time since the passage of a law banning the wearing of full veils in public, a French court on Thursday fined two women for wearing the niqab, an Islamic facial covering that leaves only the eyes uncovered. The court in Meaux, a city northeast of Paris, ordered Hind Ahmas, 32, to pay 120 euros, while Najate Nait Ali, 36, was fined 80 euros, a court official said. Yann Gre, one of their lawyers, told Agence France Presse that the two women would appeal their case to France's highest court and to the European Court of Human Rights.

FILARDO--Albert Carl (January 2, 1918-September 18, 2011): loving, compassionate father, husband, grandparent of Maggie Rosen-Filardo; carpenter, educator; forged in the Great Depression, decorated WWII veteran and witness to genocide; passionate believer in the liberation and full development of all; freethinking, anti-authoritarian intellectual humanist; a feminist before his time; an empathic, intuitive, artistic spirit; a serious man of playful wit and a keen eye for the telling detail, who saw worlds of meanings in every grain of sand; he had a remarkable capacity for growth and self-reflection, and gave freely of himself to the very end. Peter & Emily Filardo

Joel Stone President Boca Rio Golf Club, Inc.

In what turned out to be a bad case of over expectations, the Fox network and its biggest star, Simon Cowell, posted disappointing ratings for the premiere of the widely-anticipated singing competition, ''The X-Factor,'' Wednesday night. The show, which had network competitors fearing that Fox could have on its hands another blockbuster the size of ''American Idol,'' performed well in an objective sense, attracting about 12.5 million viewers and scoring a much-better-than-average 4.2 rating in the 18- to 49-year-old audience that Fox primarily sells to advertisers.

IMBERMAN--Benson, age 97, passed away peacefully on September 22, 2011. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice, devoted father of Ellen (Robert) Israel, Fred (Marcie) Imberman, and Leni Rabinowitz. Adoring grandfather of Amy, Laurie, Carrie, Matthew, Daniel and Debra. Great-grandfather to Natalie, Joseph, Zoe, Lucas, Mia and Benjamin. Loving friend of Marina Sikhuashvili. A pioneer in the antique business, he founded Kentshire Galleries in 1940. He had a wonderful life and will be missed by all who knew him. Services Sunday 11:45am, September 25 at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

PERLBINDER--Julius, 97, died peacefully Thursday, September 21, 2011 at his home in Hewlett Bay Park, New York. He is survived by his beloved wife of 74 years, Jean, two sons, Stephen and daughter-in-law Sandy, and Mark and daughter-in law, Dara, three grandchildren, Andrea Stein, Astrid SabellaRosa, and Muffy Fleuret, seven great grandchildren, Caleb, Eamon, and Dashiell Stein, Julian and Mason SabellaRosa, and Gabby and Penelope Fleuret, and two sisters Lillian West and Augusta Berger. Mr. Perlbinder graduated from NYU Law School in 1936. As president of Perlbinder Realty Corporation, he was a major force in high rise residential apartment construction in New York City for over half a century. An avid golfer and long time member of the Seawane and Lido Golf Clubs, he was actively involved in the initial construction of Lido and Seawane and the reconstruction later on of Seawane. Julius Perlbinder will be remembered for the charitable causes he embraced, but he will be most remembered for the difference he made in the lives of friends and family. We love you Dad.

ROSE--Philip, 1921-2011. Come celebrate the life of the Tony Award winning Broadway producer, writer, and director. Memorial: October 17th, Noon at the Ambassador Theater, 219 West 49th Street, Manhattan. All are welcome.

RAYSMAN--Irene Davies, born November 25, 1923, died September 21, 2011. Daughter of Herbert and Lillian Davies, widow of Victor Raysman, to whom she was married for 60 years. Professor of education at Hofstra University, beloved mother of Richard Raysman (Georgia) and Dorothy Dorman (Robert), grandmother to Joshua, Sarah, Peter and Julia, and great-grandmother of Oscar, Abby, Cairon and Maya. Funeral Sunday, September 25 at 10am, at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

Bloomberg vociferously defended the measure on Thursday as crucial to the city's economic well-being. Responding to a question about the financial markets, Mr. Bloomberg said that he expected New York City to lose tax revenue as Wall Street profits fell, and that the state should allow the city to find other sources of revenue.
An article on Thursday about Troy Davis, who was executed in Georgia, misspelled, in some editions, the surname of the police officer he was convicted of killing. He was Mark MacPhail, not McPhail.

SWAIN--Herbert W. Of Barrington, RI, died on September 18 at home. A native of Plainfield, NJ, Herbert is survived by Laura, beloved and devoted wife of 68 years. One of three sons of Mr. and Mrs Walter P. Swain of Plainfield, NJ, Herbert graduated from The Wardlaw School in Plainfield and Dartmouth College with the legendary In with the hurricane, out with the war class of 1942. He earned his wings in Pensacola in 1943. He was as a Marine flight instructor in El Toro, CA where he met and married the former Laura Lupton of San Bernardino, CA. He rose to the rank of Captain, transporting materiel throughout the South Pacific during WWII. Toward the end of the War, Herbert served as personal pilot and aide to General Holland M. Smith, former Commanding General, Fleet Marine Force, Pacific. He retired in 1991 after serving as Sr. Vice President and Director of Operations for Cherry Webb Touraine Specialty Stores. His retail career began at Stern Brothers in New York, followed by Franklin Simon and the May Co. in Cleveland. An avid athlete, Herbert was Chairman of the tennis programs for The Plainfield Country Club, Orchard Lake Country Club, Bloomfield Hills, MI and co-founder of the former Valley Heights Racquet Club, Walnut Creek, CA. He was a former member of The Union League Club of New York, Founders and Patriots of America and the Agawam of East Providence. He was a member of The Rhode Island Country Club and served on the Vestry at St. Johns Episcopal Church, Barrington. His love of flying continued throughout his life, and he enjoyed flying his plane around the eastern seaboard. A father, leader, mentor, and gentleman, we will all miss his quiet strength. In addition to Laura, Herbert is survived by sons Herbert Jr. of New York City, Thomas Lupton Swain of Walnut Creek, CA, daughter Laura Swain Ladd of Hillsborough NC; his grandchildren, Jessica Lupton Heywood Esq. of Washington, DC, Samuel Swain Heywood Esq. of Miami, FL, Edward Wyatt Swain, James Wyatt Ladd, Kailen Wang Swain, Cody Wang Swain, and two great-grandchildren. He is pre-deceased by his daughter Sandra Lupton Swain. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to Home and Hospice Care of Rhode Island, 1085 North Main St, Providence RI 02904.

6:24 p.m. | Updated ALBANY - Seeking to fulfill a campaign promise, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday began publishing portions of his daily schedule on a new government Web site that he said would function as a virtual town hall. The schedules released for the governor's first eight months in office reveal a significant number of previously unknown details about his calendar. The schedules list the meetings Mr. Cuomo had with Republican lawmakers he hoped might support same-sex marriage, and a conversation he had with a top staff member about a pivotal vote by state workers on proposed wage and benefit concessions.

The number of overcrowded classes in New York is the largest in 10 years, according to a survey conducted by the teachers union and released on Thursday. As a result of attrition, budget cuts and increased enrollment in some areas of the city, nearly 7,000 classes are over their contractual limits this year, the survey, by the United Federation of Teachers, found. That figure exceeds last year's number by almost 1,000.

DICKER--Herbert. Born in Brooklyn on May 10, 1921, passed away peacefully on September 21st, 2011. Beloved husband of Dorothy Dicker, devoted father to Sandra Dunn and Kristina Trino-Molenkamp, cherished grandfather to Kaila J. Dunn, and loving brother of Ruth Zittel and the late Leon Dicker. Lawyer and senior partner with Wilson, Elser, Moskowitz Edelman & Dicker. New York City's Tax commissioner under Mayor Lindsay, and member of the Brooklyn Law School Board of Trustees . Services: Friday, 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

FELDMAN--Justin. The partners of Cooley LLP mourn the passing of our beloved retired partner Justin Feldman and celebrate the long life and career of a giant in our profession and a leader in our city. Justin was a partner in the New York office of Cooley (then Kronish, Lieb, Weiner & Hellman LLP) from 1982 until he retired. He was our mentor and dear friend. His career as a lawyer in private practice and in public service was exemplary. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Linda, his children and grandchildren.

The chief executive of a Wall Street investment bank sold a large stake in his company to pay off a personal debt on Thursday, a move that frightened its shareholders during an already scary day in the markets. Richard B. Handler, the head of the Jefferies Group - and the highest-paid chief executive of a major Wall Street bank last year - sold two million shares, or $25.2 million worth of stock, to the bank's largest shareholder, according to a securities filing.

STANLEY--Hazel Phillips, September 17, 2011 at the age of 93. Adored, and adoring wife of the late Richard L Stanley, founder and publisher of Real Estate Forum Magazine. Beloved mother of Roger Berke, Andrea B. Klein and her husband Peter, stepmother of Jill Stanley (Adam Zins) and Linda Stanley MacNeal (Kerry MacNeal). Devoted and generous friend. Hazel was an active Bioenergetic Analyst, giving many workshops nationally and internationally. She was a member of both the New York Society and International Institute for Bioenergetic Analysis. Hazel studied and worked with Drs. Kilton Stewart, Alexander Lowen, John Pierokas and Jean Houston. Hazel will be remembered for her radiant spirit, her wisdom and love. She will always be an inspiration and remain in the hearts of those who had the privilege to know her. Donations may be made to WNET, Global Fund for Women, World Wildlife Fund and Hospice & Palliative Care of Westchester.

The playwright Romulus Linney has been associated with the Signature Theater Company since its first season, in 1991, when he was its founding playwright-in-residence. Now that Off Broadway group, which presents full seasons of work by a single playwright, is planning a permanent place for the name of Mr. Linney, who died in January.

After a slightly rocky summer for French-New York relations (see: Strauss-Kahn, Dominique), Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and President Nicolas Sarkozy of France stood Thursday morning before a mist-enshrouded Statue of Liberty to praise the enduring friendship symbolized by the monument. The statue, a gift from France, will turn 125 on Oct. 28, so the event was something of an early birthday party, as well as an opportunity for Mr. Bloomberg to tout New York's cosmopolitanism. Mr. Sarkozy, in turn, seized on the symbolism of Lady Liberty to hail the freedom-seeking revolutions in the Arab world.

HARVEY--Robert Hughes, 89, of Naples, FL and formerly of New Vernon, NJ, passed away on September 19, 2011. Raised in Winona, Mississippi, he was a devoted employee of the Exxon Corporation for 35 years, with a brilliant career that began in 1948 as a process engineer at the Baton Rouge Refinery and culminated with his retirement in 1983 as Corporate Vice President, Communications and Computer Sciences. During World War II, Mr. Harvey volunteered for the Army Air Corps, where he served as an armament and chemical officer in the Medium Bomb Department and was discharged as a Captain in 1946. He graduated from LSU in 1948 magna cum laude with a degree in Chemical Engineering, and was a member of the varsity tennis team. Mr. Harvey served for ten years on the Board of Directors of the United Way of Morris County, and as its Chairman for two years; was Vice President of Morris Sussex Boy Scouts of America, for which he received the Silver Beaver and the William H. Spurgeon III awards, and served as Vice President of the Colonial Symphony of New Jersey. An avid and competitive athlete, he excelled at golf and tennis, having won the Mississippi high school doubles tennis championship in 1939, and the singles championship the following year. He went on to win many club championships in both golf and tennis. Devoted husband, father, grandfather, and great grandfather, he is survived by his wife of 63 years, Corinne Pascal, formerly of New Orleans; six children Fred, Tom, Elizabeth, Tim, Anita and Jim; 12 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He will be dearly remembered for his playful sense of humor, his wise guidance, his love for life, family and friends, and his pursuit of excellence in everything he did. Private Services will be held in New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to LSU Foundation, "Robert Hughes Harvey Endowed Professorship", 1818 W. Lakeshore Drive, Baton Rouge, LA 70808-9966 or to Avow Hospice at: www.avowhospice.org

Rain has followed the Yankees around all season, so it is hardly a surprise that more wet weather is in the forecast for the team's final three home games of the season, all against the staggering Boston Red Sox. What impact any downpours may have on the tight wild-card race remains to be seen. The Red Sox, who had a day off on Thursday, are scheduled to play the Yankees on Friday night, at 4 p.m. on Saturday and at 1 p.m. on Sunday. The AccuWeather forecast calls for showers and thunderstorms Friday and Friday night, some showers and thunderstorms on Saturday and a chance of more rain on Sunday.

FELDMAN--Justin N, 92 years of age, died peacefully at his home in New York on September 21, 2011, with his adoring wife of twenty-five years, Linda Fairstein, at his side. He is survived by three children, Jane Feldman of Denver, Colorado, Diane Feldman of Washington, DC, and Geoffrey Feldman of Lowell, Massachusetts, and by two grandsons, Matthew and Alexander Zavislan of Denver, Colorado. He is also survived by his brother and sister-in-law, Guy and Marisa Fairstein; Lisa, Marc, Suzy, Isla and Mila Fairstein, and by his devoted friend, Rabin Sooklall. Justin was born in Manhattan on May 25, 1919, graduated from Columbia College (1940) and Columbia Law School (1942), then served from 1943-1946 in the United States Army Air Force as a Trial Judge Advocate for Courts-Martial. In 1946, he was Director of Veterans Affairs for the American Veterans Committee, supervising the establishment of a national legal assistance clinic for returning WWII veterans. From 1952-1955, Justin was Administrative Assistant to Congressman Franklin D. Roosevelt, Jr., with whom he later practiced law. He was a founding member of the firm of Landis, Feldman, Reilly and Akins, which merged into Poletti, Freidin, Prashker, Feldman and Gartner. In 1982 he joined Kronish Lieb Weiner and Hellman as head of the litigation department. He remained of counsel to that firm now Cooley LLP - until his retirement from the bar at the age of 90. Justin was a leader in the movement to reform the Democratic Party in Manhattan. His article in the National Municipal Review in 1949 "How Tammany Holds Power" ignited the drive for direct election of Manhattan district leaders. He was the Fair Deal candidate for Manhattan Borough President, which forced the withdrawal of the Tammany candidate in favor of Robert Wagner. In 1960, Justin was a member of the special task-force on the reorganization of federal regulatory agencies for President John Kennedy, and was later instrumental in persuading Robert Kennedy to run for the Senate from New York. In 1970, Governor Rockefeller appointed Justin to the Board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and by appointment of Mayor Koch in 1983 he was a member of the New York City Charter Revision Commission. He was Chair of the City Bar Association's Committee on the Judiciary, on which he served for ten years. In addition to his long record of public service and his distinguished career as a litigator and corporate lawyer, Justin had indomitable spirit and courage, great good humor, profound love of family, friends, the law, life and Martha's Vineyard. He had a great run, to the very last day. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made in support of the Justin Feldman '42 Public Service Fellowship and sent to Columbia Law School, 435 W. 116th Street Box A2, New York, New York 10027. Funeral will be private and a memorial service to be announced at a later date.

A circus-like revival of the popular 1970s musical ''Pippin,'' which director Diane Paulus was aiming for Broadway in the 2012-13 season, is in limbo now that another production of the show - this one inspired by virtual reality games - will open this fall in London at the Menier Chocolate Factory, which has a track record of moving revivals to Broadway. Stephen Schwartz, the ''Pippin'' composer and lyricist, said in an interview that he had opted to pursue a revival first with the Chocolate Factory because the director there, Mitch Sebastian, had initially pitched his concept before Ms. Paulus (''The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess,'' ''Hair'') and her producer, Barry Weissler (''Chicago'').

CREELMAN--Scott Huntley, Deerfield, MA - Scott Huntley Creelman, former CEO of Spalding Sports Worldwide, died on Wednesday, September 21, 2011 after a five year battle with cancer. Visiting hours will be Friday, September 23, 2011 from 3:00pm to 6:00pm at Smith-Kelleher Funeral Home, 87 Franklin Street, Greenfield, MA 01301 (413) 773-8853. A memorial service will be held Saturday, September 24, 2011 at 1:00pm at the First Church of Deerfield, 71 Old Main St, Deerfield, MA 01342 with a reception to follow. Gifts in his memory may be made to Sara's Wish Foundation, 23 Ash Lane, Amherst, MA 01002 or The Food Bank of Western Massachusetts, PO Box 160,Hatfield, MA 01038.

SMITH--Timothy Vincent, on September 20, 2011. Beloved husband of Mary (nee Mongeau), devoted brother of John and the late Mary and Helen, loving uncle of numerous nieces and nephews. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call Friday, September 23, 3-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday, September 24 9:30am at St Monica's Church 413 East 79th Street at 1st Avenue.

An article on Wednesday about a decision by West Hollywood, Calif., to ban the sale of fur garments referred imprecisely to an ordinance that banned the sale of dogs and cats in pet stores there. While the city was one of the first to ban such sales of dogs and cats, most stores had already quit selling them by the time the ordinance passed. It is not the case that the city passed such an ordinance even ''though no pet stores in the city sold so-called companion animals.''

Merce Cunningham's artistic heirs plan to offer classes in his technique after his dance company ceases operations at the end of the year, company officials said on Thursday. The Merce Cunningham Trust said Robert Swinston, the company's director of choreography, would teach classes starting in April at City Center, where the trust will take up offices. Jean Freebury, a former company member, will also teach Cunningham technique at the Mark Morris Dance Center starting in December, and a course will be offered at Dance New Amsterdam. Cunningham died in 2009, several months after a plan had been put in place to phase out the company. The trust is assuming oversight of Cunningham's work and is taking over for the Merce Cunningham Dance Foundation, which will close next year. Plans for teaching Cunningham's technique had been unclear until now. The foundation's executive director, Trevor Carlson, was also appointed as the fifth trustee, the trust said. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof visits the world’s largest refugee camp, home to hundreds of thousands of Somalis who are fleeing famine, drought and war.

My Sunday column is about the famine in Somalia, and the overlay of violence and rape on top of it. It's hard to know the scale of the violence, but I finished my reporting convinced that this is an instance of mass rape.

American accusations of Pakistani complicity in the attack on the United States embassy in Kabul last week received a sharp rebuke from Pakistan's top military and foreign affairs officials, escalating tensions in an already frayed relationship. I've noted that Tyler Cowen and others seem, mysteriously, to believe that any uptick in Irish GDP somehow refutes Keynesian analysis; I've been seeing a lot of similar stuff about the Baltic nations, whose experience is supposed to prove that austerity works.

Never mind all the bleak stuff I've been writing lately. A solution is at hand! All we need to do is use some of those faster-than-light neutrinos to send a message to the past, warning them not to deregulate (and not to let Greece join the euro).

The Italian auteur Paolo Sorrentino's first novel, "Everybody's Right" (Europa Editions, $15), is about an aging musician, a nightclub crooner who loses his mind in Brazil after his starlight begins to dim. It has parallels with his latest film "This Must Be the Place," a similarly strange tale in which Sean Penn plays a catatonic, lipsticked rock star in the Robert Smith mold.

After Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson made it clear there would be changes to Citi Field this off-season, readers had plenty of ideas when the Bats blog asked for suggested alterations to the ballpark that could put the Mets back on the winning path. Somewhat surprisingly, a good number of readers did not want to make any changes to three-year-old Citi Field. ''Don't change the park to suit the team - change the team to suit the park!'' wrote JTA from Brookline, Mass. ''The Mets have a crop of talented young arms on their way up. Leave the dimensions alone and rebuild the rest of the team around pitching, speed and defense.''

IMBERMAN--Benson, age 97, passed away peacefully on September 22, 2011. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice, devoted father of Ellen (Robert) Israel, Fred (Marcie) Imberman, and Leni Rabinowitz. Adoring grandfather of Amy, Laurie, Carrie, Matthew, Daniel and Debra. Great-grandfather to Natalie, Joseph, Zoe, Lucas, Mia and Benjamin. Loving friend of Marina Sikhuashvili. A pioneer in the antique business, he founded Kentshire Galleries in 1940. He had a wonderful life and will be missed by all who knew him. Services Sunday 11:45am, September 25 at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

A listing of credits on Friday with a film review of ''Pearl Jam Twenty'' misidentified the distributor. The film was released by Abramorama -- not Vinyl Films, which is one of the movie's production companies.

Like many teachers, Jamie Fidler does not end her workday when her students go home, mainly because she cannot afford to, she says. At 3:30 p.m., when the last class ends, Ms. Fidler, a first-grade teacher at Public School 261 in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, heads to her second job, where she tutors children until 5:30.

The United States National Slavery Museum, an organization founded by the former Virginia governor Douglas L. Wilder to build a museum in Frederickburg, Va., that would discuss that chapter in American history, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The Richmond Times-Dispatch reported that the museum indicated in its bankruptcy filing that it had $3 million in unsecured debts. Among its unpaid bills is one for more than $215,000 in property taxes owed on the 38-acre parcel where the museum was to have opened several years ago. Since then, the proposed museum's director has departed, its board has stopped meeting and some people who gave artifacts to the museum have asked for their return. The museum's major remaining asset is its land and last summer Fredericksburg officials said they planned to sell the property. But the bankruptcy filing on Wednesday will have the effect of blocking any sale, at least temporarily, the Times-Dispatch reported.

Carl C. Icahn has cut short his effort to replace the board at Clorox, the activist investor disclosed in a securities filing on Friday, after he failed to garner enough support from other shareholders. It is a significant win for Clorox. Mr. Icahn has prodded the company to put itself up for sale, and last month he proposed a full slate of 11 director candidates, including himself; his son, Brett; a longtime lieutenant, Vincent J. Intrieri; and a former executive director of the Central Intelligence Agency.

FELDMAN--Justin. The partners of Cooley LLP mourn the passing of our beloved retired partner Justin Feldman and celebrate the long life and career of a giant in our profession and a leader in our city. Justin was a partner in the New York office of Cooley (then Kronish, Lieb, Weiner & Hellman LLP) from 1982 until he retired. He was our mentor and dear friend. His career as a lawyer in private practice and in public service was exemplary. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Linda, his children and grandchildren.

KLEINBERG--Bertha (nee Friesner). August 23, 1921 - September 22, 2011. Aishet Chayil ("Woman of Valor") Bertha Kleinberg, 90, departed this life September 22, 2011 at her home in Riverdale, NY surrounded by her loving husband and family. Born in Germany, Mrs. Kleinberg escaped Hitler in 1939 with her parents and married her beloved husband Milo in 1950. She is survived by her husband; sons Jeffrey and Michael; grandchildren Jarad, Matthew, Marissa, Alyssa, Joshua and Arielle; and daughter-in-laws Ellyn and Arlene. Funeral services will be held Sunday, September 25, at 9:45am at Riverdale Jewish Center in Riverdale, NY. Donations in Mrs. Kleinberg's memory may be made to Riverdale Jewish Center.

PERLBINDER--Julius, 97, died peacefully Thursday, September 21, 2011 at his home in Hewlett Bay Park, New York. He is survived by his beloved wife of 74 years, Jean, two sons, Stephen and daughter-in-law Sandy, and Mark and daughter-in law, Dara, three grandchildren, Andrea Stein, Astrid SabellaRosa, and Muffy Flouret, seven great grandchildren, Caleb, Eamon, and Dashiell Stein, Julian and Mason SabellaRosa, and Gaby and Penelope Flouret, and two sisters Lillian West and Augusta Berger. Mr. Perlbinder graduated from NYU Law School in 1936. As president of Perlbinder Realty Corporation, he was a major force in high rise residential apartment construction in New York City for over half a century. An avid golfer and long time member of the Seawane and Lido Golf Clubs, he was actively involved in the initial construction of Lido and Seawane and the reconstruction later on of Seawane. Julius Perlbinder will be remembered for the charitable causes he embraced, but he will be most remembered for the difference he made in the lives of friends and family. We love you Dad.

Just as Bravo has a talk show about its gossipy ''Housewives'' (and its other hit shows), AMC will soon have a talk show about its gory zombie drama, ''The Walking Dead.'' The channel said Thursday that the half-hour show, called ''Talking Dead,'' would start on Sunday, Oct. 16 at 11 p.m., the same night that the second season of the drama has its premiere. It will then move to a Friday night time slot. Joel Stillerman, an AMC executive, said in a statement that ''Talking Dead'' will complement the online chatter about each episode of the series, which drew record numbers of viewers to the channel last fall. (Its average of 3.5 viewers each week is more than double the audience AMC attracts for its critical darling ''Mad Men.'') The show, he said, will be a ''kind of live water cooler.'' It will include discussions with actors, producers and fans of the series.

Matthew Lombardo's addiction-themed drama ''High'' was one of the fastest flops on Broadway in recent years, closing just five days after opening last April in spite of the star power of its leading lady, Kathleen Turner. Having lost its entire investment of $1.8 million in New York, why is ''High'' now poised to become the relatively rare Broadway play to go on national tour? A group of producers announced this week that Ms. Turner would reprise her role as a tough-talking nun and addiction counselor, Sister Jamison Connelly, in a tour that is to begin at the Cutler Majestic Theater in Boston, where tickets for the play are on sale for Dec. 6-11. Plans are in the works to go on to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Philadelphia, Washington, Chicago, Dallas, San Francisco and perhaps elsewhere. A London production of the play, which centers on Sister Jamison's relationship with a young, hard-luck addict, is also being considered for next year.

Edward Villella, the founding and current artistic director of Miami City Ballet, will step down at the end of the 2012-2013 season, the company announced on Thursday afternoon. Mr. Villella, a former principal dancer with New York City Ballet, who founded the company with Toby Ansin in 1985, is leaving to continue other professional pursuits. In a statement Mr. Villella said: ''My ambition from the start was to give Miami and South Florida a major dance company; my strategy was to proceed carefully and steadily, evolving rather than over-extending. Today it's no longer a fledgling operation with a limited repertory (almost entirely Balanchine) and an even more limited budget. Instead, it's a 45-plus group of brilliant dancers and has a range of ballets that stretches from the classics - 'Giselle,' 'Coppelia,' 'Don Quixote,' 'Romeo and Juliet' - to the choicest works by Balanchine's greatest successors (Jerome Robbins, Paul Taylor, Twyla Tharp).''

To avoid further clogging the already sluggish home foreclosure pipeline, some lenders have been offering cash incentives to strapped homeowners at risk of foreclosure to complete short sales and move out of their homes. Chase, for instance, has been quietly offering as much as $35,000 to homeowners who are ''upside down'' on their loans - meaning, they owe more than the home is currently worth. In a short sale, the lender allows the sale of the home for less than the loan amount and often relieves the borrower of any further obligation.

RODBELL--Thelma Salmanson, of Palm Beach, FL, 91, beloved mother of Barbara, Alan (and Shelly), and Carol Salmanson (and Steve Leto), sister of Anne Schlusselberg, and grandmother of Leonard Daniel and Rebecca Salmanson. Born in Sambor, Poland (now Ukraine), she immigrated in 1930 to West Warwick, RI, and moved to Providence in 1947 when she married Leonard Salmanson, who died in 1975. In 1978 she married Leonard Rodbell and moved to Atlanta, where his children Sidney, Paul and Arthur, and grandchildren considered her a part of their family. She was a passionate supporter of the State of Israel since its founding, as well as many other charities. She will be sorely missed by all her friends and family. Funeral and burial will be held at Lincoln Cemetery in Warwick, RI at 3pm on Friday, September 23rd. Shiva will be observed at 980 Fifth Ave in New York City from Sunday, September 25th through Tuesday, September 27th, from 1-9pm. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Jewish Child Care Association (120 Wall St., New York, NY 10005), NURTUREart (910 Grand Street, Brooklyn, NY 11211), or PEF for A.V. Israel (317 Madison Ave., Ste. 607, New York, NY 10017).

The Deal Professor column on Wednesday, about missteps by the Yahoo board, referred incorrectly to the position of a Yahoo shareholder, the hedge fund Third Point Management, on the company's stakes in Alibaba and Yahoo Japan. The hedge fund has not said whether it supports a sale of those assets; it is not the case that its founder, Daniel S. Loeb, has pushed for the sale.

Groupon disclosed a major accounting change on Friday, essentially halving its once-jaw-dropping revenue after it encountered resistance from regulators with its filing to go public. Groupon, the online coupon titan, announced separately that its chief operating officer of about five months, Margo Georgiadis, had stepped down.

Red Bulls Coach Hans Backe on Friday suspended defender Rafael Marquez for Saturday's match against visiting Portland after the club's Mexican international was critical of his teammates after Wednesday's 3-1 loss to Real Salt Lake. The Major League Soccer club confirmed Backe's decision to banish Marquez, who has appeared in only 15 of the team's 29 league matches because of injuries and international duty. The decision will probably will spare Marquez another negative reaction from the club's fans. The match is expected to be sold out in the 25,000-seat Red Bull Arena. Marquez was booed by the fans in the Arena's South Ward, home to the team's most dedicated fans. Against R.S.L., the Red Bulls were coming off a 1-0 win at Dallas last Saturday (a game in which Marquez did not play) and hoping to build on a four-game streak without a loss (which came after eight games without a win) in a drive to make the 10-team playoffs in M.L.S. In that game, the Red Bulls allowed R.S.L., which has now won five straight games, to score three goals in the game's first 21 minutes. After the match, Marquez, 32, when confronted by reporters asking about the poor performance by one of the worst defenses in the league, said through a translator: ''I'm focusing on really performance at my highest level. That doesn't mean that the whole back line can perform at that same level, so that's a problem. I think this is a team game and unfortunately there isn't an equal level between my teammates and I.'' Marquez, with Thierry Henry and goalkeeper Frank Rost, is one of the team's three designated players. He is among the highest paid players in the league, earning a guaranteed $4.6 million this season, his first full year with the Red Bulls. He joined the club last summer after eight seasons with Barcelona of Spain and has several more years remaining on his contract. That, however, has been cast into doubt by the events of the past few days. Kristen Dyer, who covers the club for MLSsoccer.com, the league's official Web site, reported on his Twitter feed that Marquez declined to comment about the suspension after training on Friday at Montclair State University in Little Falls, N.J. Dyer added that the American defender Tim Ream had a face-to-face meeting with Marquez, but would not disclose the nature of the chat. In an email message Ream said, ''I'm definitely not going to comment and will be laying low.'' Marquez added on Wednesday, ''There have been some mistakes, but if you see the statistics I'm trying to steal balls, get them back for the team, make a couple of good passes.'' As Stefan Bondy pointed out in his blog on the Web site of the New York Daily News, Marquez has no goals, four assists and four yellow cards so far this season and is No. 138 in the latest Castrol Rankings that rates the performance of all league players. Those comments by Marquez may have been ill-timed, but it is clear that the defender who is a legend in his native land has grown accustomed to playing with high-level defenders surrounding him. It is a situation that has allowed him to largely eschew most of his defensive duties and float around the midfield and defense while spraying long diagonal balls to players on the wings. That situation, however, does not exist with the Red Bulls, whose central defense includes Ream, the second-year American pro, and other players who clearly are not at the same level of players at Barcelona and Mexico. And to state the obvious, Marquez has never been a favorite among American soccer fans for his play in international matches against the United States. He can be rough, chippy, even dirty on the field ... clutching, grabbing and fouling. Off the field, he can be another person. Against Dallas, Backe employed an all-American back line (Carlos Mendes, Stephen Keel, Ream and Chris Albright) that defended furiously and earned credit for helping goalkeeper Frank Rost earn his first win in M.L.S. But in audio provided by the Red Bulls on Friday to preview the match against the Timbers, Backe had a different take.

New York City decided to give twice as many elementary and middle schools D's and F's on their annual progress reports this year as last year, officials announced on Friday, stepping up efforts to isolate struggling schools and select them for closing or other types of intervention. By expanding the number of schools receiving the lowest grades, and by removing a safety net that kept schools from dropping more than two letter grades in a year, Shael Polakow-Suransky, the city's chief academic officer, said the city was offering ''a more precise and accurate representation of how the schools are actually performing.''

The ratings for ''The X Factor'' premiere on Wednesday may not have met expectations, but the second episode last night at least held steady. With 12.5 million viewers, the overall ratings matched the debut episode, while the 18-to-49-year-old audience dropped off by just 2 percent. It was enough to give Fox a victory in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49 demographic for the night, representing Fox's first ratings win ever for a Thursday during premiere week. CBS once again finished first in total viewers, led by two episodes of ''Big Bang Theory'' (averaging 14.4 million viewers) and its new drama ''Person of Interest'' (13.2 million), according to Nielsen data. However, ''Person of Interest'' fell in its second half-hour and was fourth in the 18-to-49 category for its 9 p.m. time slot, behind ''X-Factor,'' ''Grey's Anatomy'' on ABC and ''Whitney'' on NBC. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

There's only a shred of plot in ''Noah and the Tower Flower,'' but there's plenty of energy to spare. More often than not, that's enough to carry this bittersweet, 75-minute play. Noah and Natalie, both from housing projects in Dublin, meet in a bar where they have sought refuge from their troubles. Noah has just been released from prison, while Natalie is battling a craving for heroin. These self-described ''tosspots'' (''losers,'' according to the glossary in the program) soon wind up in her apartment, where doubts surface, tenderness emerges and tensions occasionally flare.

FELDMAN--Justin. We mourn the death of our beloved partner and dearest friend. He mentored us; he cared about our families; and we adored him for it all. To Linda and the family our deepest condolences. Alan Levine and Bill Schwartz

An obituary on Sept. 16 about Malcolm Wallop, a three-term senator from Wyoming and a descendant of the English aristocracy, described incorrectly the circumstances under which Senator Wallop's paternal grandfather, Oliver Henry Wallop, became the eighth earl of Portsmouth. It occurred when his older brother John died without an heir, not when the last of his siblings died without children. The obituary also misstated the title held by his sister, Jean, who survives him. She is Jean Countess of Carnavon, not Lady Jean Porchester.

An article on Thursday about cloud-based software for small businesses misstated the amount that Roper DeGarmo, the owner of a small insurance company, pays for his customer resource management service from Salesforce.com. It is $1,500 a year -- not a month.
