A chart on Thursday with an article about the stock markets' Wednesday performance misstated the trading range of the Dow Jones industrial average. The range was 11,100 to 11,500 points -- not 10,400 to 10,600 points.

8 P.M. (HBO) LITTLE FOCKERS (2010) Ben Stiller and Robert De Niro (above left, with Mr. Stiller) reprise their roles as Greg Focker, the unfortunately named nurse, and his father-in-law, Jack, a former C.I.A. operative wound to the point of snapping. In the franchise's latest installment the clan gathers for the Focker twins' birthday and Jack decides to anoint Greg the family patriarch. Barbra Streisand and Dustin Hoffman return as Greg's happy, sexy, hippie parents; Blythe Danneris the freshly blossomed mother of Greg's wife, Pam (Teri Polo). It seems clear that ''Mr. Stiller, who in the 10 years since the first 'Fockers' has become a Hollywood powerhouse, isn't interested in being the butt of anyone's joke,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this comedy from Paul Weitz. ''Mr. De Niro might not mind making mincemeat of his own legacy, as a painful bit with a grinning Harvey Keitel suggests. (Somewhere, Martin Scorsese is lighting a votive candle.) But Mr. Stiller is no longer in a laughing mood.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Lucky Severson reports on legislation in Alabama -- temporarily blocked by a federal judge -- that penalizes undocumented immigrants who work, rent property or have false papers as well as anyone who harbors, hires or transports them.

FELDMAN--Justin N, 92 years of age, died peacefully at his home in New York on September 21, 2011, with his adoring wife of twenty-five years, Linda Fairstein, at his side. He is survived by three children, Jane Feldman of Denver, Colorado, Diane Feldman of Washington, DC, and Geoffrey Feldman of Lowell, Massachusetts, and by two grandsons, Matthew and Alexander Zavislan of Denver, Colorado. He is also survived by his brother and sister-in-law, Guy and Marisa Fairstein; Lisa, Marc, Suzy, Isla and Mila Fairstein, and by his devoted friend, Rabin Sooklall. Justin was born in Manhattan on May 25, 1919, graduated from Columbia College (1940) and Columbia Law School (1942), then served from 1943-1946 in the United States Army Air Force as a Trial Judge Advocate for Courts-Martial. In 1946, he was Director of Veterans Affairs for the American Veterans Committee, supervising the establishment of a national legal assistance clinic for returning WWII veterans. From 1952-1955, Justin was Administrative Assistant to Congressman Franklin D. Roosevelt, Jr., with whom he later practiced law. He was a founding member of the firm of Landis, Feldman, Reilly and Akins, which merged into Poletti, Freidin, Prashker, Feldman and Gartner. In 1982 he joined Kronish Lieb Weiner and Hellman as head of the litigation department. He remained of counsel to that firm now Cooley LLP - until his retirement from the bar at the age of 90. Justin was a leader in the movement to reform the Democratic Party in Manhattan. His article in the National Municipal Review in 1949 "How Tammany Holds Power" ignited the drive for direct election of Manhattan district leaders. He was the Fair Deal candidate for Manhattan Borough President, which forced the withdrawal of the Tammany candidate in favor of Robert Wagner. In 1960, Justin was a member of the special task-force on the reorganization of federal regulatory agencies for President John Kennedy, and was later instrumental in persuading Robert Kennedy to run for the Senate from New York. In 1970, Governor Rockefeller appointed Justin to the Board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and by appointment of Mayor Koch in 1983 he was a member of the New York City Charter Revision Commission. He was Chair of the City Bar Association's Committee on the Judiciary, on which he served for ten years. In addition to his long record of public service and his distinguished career as a litigator and corporate lawyer, Justin had indomitable spirit and courage, great good humor, profound love of family, friends, the law, life and Martha's Vineyard. He had a great run, to the very last day. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made in support of the Justin Feldman '42 Public Service Fellowship and sent to Columbia Law School, 435 W. 116th Street Box A2, New York, New York 10027. Funeral will be private and a memorial service to be announced at a later date.

STANLEY--Hazel Phillips, September 17, 2011 at the age of 93. Adored, and adoring wife of the late Richard L Stanley, founder and publisher of Real Estate Forum Magazine. Beloved mother of Roger Berke, Andrea B. Klein and her husband Peter, stepmother of Jill Stanley (Adam Zins) and Linda Stanley MacNeal (Kerry MacNeal). Devoted and generous friend. Hazel was an active Bioenergetic Analyst, giving many workshops nationally and internationally. She was a member of both the New York Society and International Institute for Bioenergetic Analysis. Hazel studied and worked with Drs. Kilton Stewart, Alexander Lowen, John Pierokas and Jean Houston. Hazel will be remembered for her radiant spirit, her wisdom and love. She will always be an inspiration and remain in the hearts of those who had the privilege to know her. Donations may be made to WNET, Global Fund for Women, World Wildlife Fund and Hospice & Palliative Care of Westchester.

WALSH--Caroline, daughter of William D. Walsh and the late Mary Jane Walsh. Caroline passed away on Sunday, September 18th at Sonoma Developmental Center's Acute Care Unit. She was born May 4th, 1962 at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in New York. Along with her father, she is survived by three sisters, Deborah Hirsch of Montclair, NJ, Suzi Tinsley of Menlo Park, CA and Tara Jane Arnold of Los Altos, CA; and two brothers Michael Walsh of Texas and Peter Walsh of Atherton, CA. Caroline was a long time resident of Sonoma Developmental Center and received excellent and loving care. She had a loving spirit and always had a smile on her face. She will be very deeply missed by her entire family including numerous nephews and nieces. Private family services will be conducted at the Sonoma Developmental Center. In lieu of flowers, please send donations Sonoma Developmental PHA P.O. Box 122, Eldridge, CA 95431.

Even though most Americans seem to think it's easier for single people to plan for retirement, unmarried people tend to be less prepared financially for life after full-time work, according to a quarterly survey from Charles Schwab & Company. More than half of married Americans, and more than two-thirds of singles, say they believe it is easier to make major financial decisions for retirement when there is no spouse in the picture, the survey found. (The telephone survey of 2,000 adults was conducted in August by Kelton Research, using random-digit dialing of listed and unlisted numbers.)

Day Funeral Home, Red Bank, NJ 07701. In lieu of flowers, donations in Pat's memory can be made to the American Cancer Society, Jersey Shore Region, 801 Broad Street, Shrewsbury, NJ, 07702. After receiving much criticism from the financial services industry and lawmakers, the Labor Department said Monday that it would rethink a proposed new rule requiring more investment professionals to take responsibility for the advice they provide to investors in retirement plans, including 401(k)s and individual retirement accounts. ''This extra time will enable us to strengthen the protections we already proposed and to do it in a way that is more straightforward and more clear,'' said Phyllis Borzi, assistant secretary of the Employee Benefits Security Administration, who held a conference call with reporters on Monday. ''There was a lot of misinformation about what our rule did and intended to do.''

In his contribution to The Stone last week, Alex Rosenberg posed a defense of naturalism - "the philosophical theory that treats science as our most reliable source of knowledge and scientific method as the most effective route to knowledge" - at the expense of other theoretical endeavors such as, notably, literary theory. To the question of "whether disciplines like literary theory provide real understanding," Professor Rosenberg's answer is as unequivocal as it is withering: just like fiction, literary theory can be "fun," but neither one qualifies as "knowledge."

I look a fair bit at bond market "breakevens" -- the difference in interest rates between regular bonds and inflation-protected bonds of the same maturity, which give a measure of inflation expectations. It's not a perfect measure by any means, since there are issues of risk and liquidity, and anyway what bond investors expect isn't necessarily reasonable. But breakevens do give a quick read on the issue, and can be helpful in thinking about where we are.

STEADMAN--Marcia Winder, 85, beloved mother, wife, grandmother and friend, died on September 19, 2011. She was born in Meriden, CT on August 13, 1926. Besides her parents Frederick J. Winder and Elizabeth O'Neil Winder, Marcia was preceded in death by her husband of 59 years, E. Thomas Steadman, a physician at New York Hospital; sister, Jane Winder, and brother, Frank Winder. Marcia is survived by her daughter Tracy Wise, her sons Broeck, Dirk, Webb, and Coe Steadman, and by her many grandchildren. Marcia graduated from Smith College in 1948. She lived in Tenafly, NJ; Englewood, NJ; New York City and finally in Madison, CT. Marcia had a zest for life; she loved her family and the world of nature around her. She will be remembered by all who knew her for her spark, and for her keen intellect, sharp wit, strength and generosity of spirit. Please visit: www.swanfuneralhome madison.com for a memorial tribute.

I feel terrible for these parents, but their nonsense about ''doing what's right for the child'' by keeping them, not questioning their origins and pushing this under the rug is nauseating -- not to mention self-serving. Being involved in an international child-stealing ring, whether at first by sheer ignorance but then by willful ignorance, is not a morally defensible position. FELDMAN--Justin N, 92 years of age, died peacefully at his home in New York on September 21, 2011, with his adoring wife of twenty-five years, Linda Fairstein, at his side. He is survived by three children, Jane Feldman of Denver, Colorado, Diane Feldman of Washington, DC, and Geoffrey Feldman of Lowell, Massachusetts, and by two grandsons, Matthew and Alexander Zavislan of Denver, Colorado. He is also survived by his brother and sister-in-law, Guy and Marisa Fairstein; Lisa, Marc, Suzy, Isla and Mila Fairstein, and by his devoted friend, Rabin Sooklall. Justin was born in Manhattan on May 25, 1919, graduated from Columbia College (1940) and Columbia Law School (1942), then served from 1943-1946 in the United States Army Air Force as a Trial Judge Advocate for Courts-Martial. In 1946, he was Director of Veterans Affairs for the American Veterans Committee, supervising the establishment of a national legal assistance clinic for returning WWII veterans. From 1952-1955, Justin was Administrative Assistant to Congressman Franklin D. Roosevelt, Jr., with whom he later practiced law. He was a founding member of the firm of Landis, Feldman, Reilly and Akins, which merged into Poletti, Freidin, Prashker, Feldman and Gartner. In 1982 he joined Kronish Lieb Weiner and Hellman as head of the litigation department. He remained of counsel to that firm now Cooley LLP - until his retirement from the bar at the age of 90. Justin was a leader in the movement to reform the Democratic Party in Manhattan. His article in the National Municipal Review in 1949 "How Tammany Holds Power" ignited the drive for direct election of Manhattan district leaders. He was the Fair Deal candidate for Manhattan Borough President, which forced the withdrawal of the Tammany candidate in favor of Robert Wagner. In 1960, Justin was a member of the special task-force on the reorganization of federal regulatory agencies for President John Kennedy, and was later instrumental in persuading Robert Kennedy to run for the Senate from New York. In 1970, Governor Rockefeller appointed Justin to the Board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and by appointment of Mayor Koch in 1983 he was a member of the New York City Charter Revision Commission. He was Chair of the City Bar Association's Committee on the Judiciary, on which he served for ten years. In addition to his long record of public service and his distinguished career as a litigator and corporate lawyer, Justin had indomitable spirit and courage, great good humor, profound love of family, friends, the law, life and Martha's Vineyard. He had a great run, to the very last day. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made in support of the Justin Feldman '42 Public Service Fellowship and sent to Columbia Law School, 435 W. 116th Street Box A2, New York, New York 10027. Funeral will be private and a memorial service to be announced at a later date.

STERLING--Joel J.,passed away at his home in Roslyn Estates on Friday, September 23rd at the age of 85. Joel was born in New York City and served in the US Army Air Force in World War II. He studied electrical engineering at CCNY and later started an electrical manufacturing company, Sterling Transformer. In 1958 he joined the family insurance business founded, in 1932 by his father, Jonah. He ultimately became Chairman and retired in 1989. Today Sterling & Sterling is one of the largest privately owned insurance brokers in the country. An avid yachtsman, he was a long time member of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club having served as its Commodore. As celestial navigator, he won the Newport to Bermuda race in 1978, and came in 10th as Captain on his own boat in 1982. Joel is survived by the love of his life, his wife Tinette, three sons Michael, David, and Philip, a daughter-in-law (Mona), his brother Daniel, and thirteen grandchildren. The funeral will be held today at 12 noon at Guttermans Funeral Home in Woodburv, NY. Burial will be In Mount Hebron cemetery in Flushing. The family has requested that any donations in Joel's memory be made to Hospice Care Network, 99 Sunnyside Blvd, Woodbury, NY 11797.

By the standards of global hipness, New Zealand - where local food is a way of life and you're as likely to see a beard on a farmer as on a barista - has been cool for years. Which may be why the windy capital city of Wellington is getting buzz as the Portland of the Pacific. Fueled by an abundance of fishing and agriculture, the restaurant scene is brimming with experimentation. The menu at Boulcott Street Bistro (99 Boulcott Street; 011-64-4-499-4199) includes dishes like Pukekohe chicken with fennel and cabanossi. Ambeli (18 Majoribanks Street; 011-64-4-385-7577) serves inventive takes on Mediterranean cooking. Martin Bosley's (103 Oriental Parade; 011-64-4-920-8302) has a mostly seafood menu and a wine list long on rare New Zealand whites. And La Boca Loca Taqueria (19 Park Road; 011-64-4-388-2451) brings Mexico to the growing suburb around Peter Jackson's ''Wellywood'' studios. Cocktails have gotten serious, too: Matterhorn (106 Cuba Street; 011-64-4-384-3359) makes its own tinctures and liquors infused with flavors of geranium and cigar.

CHRIS FORCIER The Furman player and member of a quarterbacking family had seven touchdown passes to break the program's single-game record in a 62-21 victory over visiting Presbyterian. Forcier was 12 of 16 for 226 yards, and also rushed for a 13-yard touchdown. The previous record was five, by Hugh Swilling against Virginia Military in 1991 and Jordan Sorrells against Wofford in 2009. MOHAMED SANU The Rutgers receiver had a record-setting 16 catches for 176 yards and 2 touchdowns as host Rutgers knocked error-prone Ohio from the unbeaten ranks with a 38-26 victory. Sanu, right, who caught touchdowns of 7 and 4 yards from Chas Dodd, broke the Rutgers record of 13 receptions that he had tied in his last game. Sixteen catches is a Big East record, too.

WILLIAM STEIG, who died in 2003, is probably best known for creating the characters that led to the smash franchise ''Shrek,'' the computer-animated films that bear little resemblance to the loose and splotchy drawings that inspired them. Now a new collection of Steig's drawings, ''Cats, Dogs, Men, Women, Ninnies & Clowns'' (Abrams Image, $40), appears as a fresh and quirky way of discovering (or rediscovering) the celebrated illustrator's oeuvre. The images, all previously unpublished, are grouped thematically and tenderly introduced by Steig's widow, Jeanne. Jules Feiffer provides an afterword, and in the preface, Roz Chast explains that, while Steig's artistry may have lacked technical virtuosity, he made up for it with in ingenuous spirit, meeting a challenge issued by his favorite painter, Picasso, who once said: ''All children are artists. The problem is how to remain an artist once we grow up.'' MATT McCANN

The dirt-bike racer Ashley Fiolek, 20, is the first woman in motocross to be signed to a major corporate team, the youngest to win the American women's motocross championship and the only woman to take home the gold in motocross at the X Games three times. And in a sport in which sound is essential, she has done all of this without the ability to hear. ''I have been told that most people use sound to know when to shift,'' says Fiolek, who has been deaf since birth. ''I feel when my motorcycle needs to shift. The engine's vibrations change and I know it's time.'' At 5-foot-2 and 110 pounds, Fiolek might be Honda-Red Bull's most petite team member, but her next goal is decidedly large: to be the first woman to compete in a men's race. ''My fans really want to see me qualify,'' she says. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Only the second restaurant in Budapest to earn a Michelin star, Onyx (above; Vorosmarty ter 7-8; 011-36-30-508-0622; onyxrestaurant.hu) is leading the city's revival of traditional Hungarian cuisine. Though the menu dabbles in molecular gastronomy, the overriding passion of its young executive chef, Szabina Szullo, is in re-envisioning the classics. Her seven-course tasting menu features lamb soup with tarragon foam, tenderloin with celeriac purée and a 21st-century makeover of the traditional dessert somloi galuska. It's easier to get a table at Cafe Gerloczy (Gerloczy utca 1; 011-36-1-501-4000; gerloczy.hu), where a casual lunch crowd packs the shaded terrace for pâtés, spreads and homemade bread. The menu gets serious in the evening, with dishes like guinea fowl in pastry with feta cheese. Up in the Castle District, 21 Magyar Vendéglö (Fortuna utca 21; 011-36-1-202-2113; 21restaurant.hu) resurrects the tastes of pre-communist Hungary with delicacies like Hortobagy pancakes with minced chicken and sirloin steak with duck liver. And at Rosenstein (Mosonyi utca 3; 011-36-1-333-3492; rosenstein.hu), which has been turning out the classics since 1996, the highlights include smoked tenderloin with sweet volcanic Tokay sauce, roast duck with braised cabbage and prunes and, on Fridays, a splendid solet, the traditional Jewish dish of baked beans topped with boiled eggs and fried goose breast.

LEVINE--Gertrude, On September 20, 2011, at the age of 91. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Bernard D. Levine, she will be greatly mourned by her daughter Rona Shamoon and son-in-law Dr. Harry Shamoon, her son Dr. Mitchell Levine and daughter-in-law Sara Levine, her grandchildren Evan, Mark, Michael, Elizabeth and Miriam, her brothers Rabbi Aharon Greenberg and Rabbi Yitzchak Greenberg, her sisters-in-law Blu Greenberg and Chana Greenberg, and her many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. She was a wonderful teacher and role model to her family. Shiva will be held at her apartment in Riverdale, Friday morning September 23, and Sunday, September 25 through Tuesday, September 27. Contributions may be made in her memory to UJA/Federation, Doctors Without Borders or the American Jewish World Service.

There are cities you love for what they offer in terms of superficial diversion - the joy of hunting down a perfect piece of passementerie in Paris or of locating a wonderfully sinuous leather journal in Milan - and there are cities you love for their significant history and scope, despite their lack of good shopping. Athens is one of those cities, offering up the Parthenon and not much else, as is (so I'm told) St. Petersburg. Jerusalem is one of my favorite cities on the planet; its yellow stone and golden light draw me back time and again, but when I was there this past July as a judge for the Jerusalem Film Festival I was reminded of the serious absence of retail therapy. I wasn't expecting to stumble upon a Barneys or Sephora, Lord knows; even a well-stocked stationery store would have done. But aside from numerous shops carrying Judaica, faux relics and silver kiddush cups - and breathless malls carrying T-shirts and running shoes - I couldn't find anything I could sink my acquisitive teeth into, until, gasping for breath, I stumbled upon a cutting-edge boutique hidden away on a little street. But more on that later.

The What I Wore column last Sunday, about clothes worn by the television correspondent Olivia Munn during New York Fashion Week, misstated her role in Esquire magazine's ''Sexiest Woman Alive'' readers' poll in 2010. She was a nominee, not the winner. (Minka Kelly won.)

''Sometimes on a shoot, people will want me to wear something that just isn't me, and I can't do it,'' said Daphne Guinness, whose extraordinary wardrobe is the subject of a new exhibition at the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology through Jan. 7, 2012. ''I can't be anything but myself.'' The truth is that this pint-size brewery heiress's passion for clothes is as sincere as it is extreme. Her funds might run as deep as her walk-in closets (the exhibition is well stocked with looks by Alexander McQueen, Chanel, Gareth Pugh and Azzedine Alaïa), but unlike countless other couture clotheshorses, Ms. Guinness doesn't fetishize fashion as a status symbol. Instead, she has developed, over the years, a sartorial persona that is one part Victorian damsel, one part sci-fi geisha and 100 percent her own. SAMEER REDDY

An article on Sept. 16 on ''Hunter's Point,'' a new play in San Francisco that deals with homelessness, misidentified the academic institution where Christine Young, director and co-producer of Hunter's Point, teaches. She is at the University of San Francisco, not San Francisco State University.

MOLLOD-LUCKA--Sandi. It is with indescribable sadness, grief and pain that we are announcing the passing of Sandi Mollod Lucka of NYC. Sandi died on September 18 at 12:11pm, the day after her birthday, as a result of complications from cancer. Sandi had fought a courageous and heroic battle against cancer and refused to give up or give in right up to the last second. Sandi's life gives everyone who has ever met her a model for how to be a good and kind person in every way. She gave of herself whenever anyone needed her and lived her life with compassion, grace and integrity. Sandi left behind her father and mother, Bernard and Cynthia Mollod, who guided her into and through this world; her brother and best friend Michael Mollod, who depended on her for her compassion and wisdom; her loving husband Klaus Lucka, whom she adored and loved with all her being and heart; her niece and nephew, Lucas and Daphne Mollod, who loved and adored her as their aunt and role model. She died way too young and will be missed by everyone who has ever had the privilege of knowing her. We love you Sandi.

CRAMER--Carol Ann. Died September 7, 2011, of a cerebral aneurysm at her home in Manhattan, nine days before her 62nd birthday. Carol was an inveterate city person, who devoured the arts and ideas of the 20th/21st century and was an early supporter of native Cuban artists. Most recently associated with CATM Gallery in Chelsea, she previously owned a gallery in Great Barrington, MA. Carol attended The Fieldston School, NYU, and UC Berkeley and held an MFA from Columbia University Film School. Predeceased by her parents Dr. Joseph B. Cramer and Hope Woronock Cramer and sister Mai (Marcia) Cramer Ward, she is survived by her brother-in-law Peter, aunt E. Jane Woronock Szathmary, uncle Martin G. Cramer, many cousins and friends, and especially her childhood friend Beth Copeland Williams. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Arthritis Foundation or Amnesty International. A memorial service celebrating her life will be held at the Cuban Art Space, 231 W. 29th St., #

''DECEPCIÓN,'' the title of Luis Gispert's show at the uptown Mary Boone Gallery in Manhattan, translates from the Spanish not to its English cognate, but more literally to disillusionment or disappointment. The word applies to the effect of the show's huge photographs, which depict fantasy landscapes seen through the windshields of luxury vehicles. The photos pair interiors of BMWs and Cadillacs strewn with designer logos with images of scenery, the dreamscapes to which plush S.U.V.'s promise to carry their charges.

FILARDO--Albert Carl (January 2, 1918-September 18, 2011): loving, compassionate father, husband, grandparent of Maggie Rosen-Filardo; carpenter, educator; forged in the Great Depression, decorated WWII veteran and witness to genocide; passionate believer in the liberation and full development of all; freethinking, anti-authoritarian intellectual humanist; a feminist before his time; an empathic, intuitive, artistic spirit; a serious man of playful wit and a keen eye for the telling detail, who saw worlds of meanings in every grain of sand; he had a remarkable capacity for growth and self-reflection, and gave freely of himself to the very end. A rich film tradition and low production costs have long brought stars to Budapest, among them Jeremy Irons, 63, pictured here on the shores of the Danube River. Irons made ''Nijinski,'' his first movie in the capital, in 1980, and returned to make ''M. Butterfly,'' ''Being Julia'' and Showtime's ''The Borgias.'' When not on set, Irons explores the city's ''wonderful crumbling faded beauty'' on his motorcycle. ''It's very hard to find the soul of a city,'' he says, but he suggests starting at the Dohany Street Synagogue (011-36-1-413-5500), the Hungarian State Opera (right; opera.hu) and the Western Railway Station (Terez korut at Nyugati ter), designed by the Eiffel Company of Paris. Irons also recommends Cafe Kor (011-36-1-311-0053; cafekor.com), Pomo D'Oro (011-36-1-302-6473; pomodorobudapest.com) and Nobu (noburestaurants.com/budapest), inside the Kempinski Hotel (011-36-1-429-3777; kempinski.com), where he usually stays. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Mohammed Ghani Hikmat, the Iraqi sculptor who created many of Baghdad's most famous landmarks and who led the effort to recover works of art looted from the National Museum of Iraq after the fall of Saddam Hussein, died on Sept. 12 in Amman, Jordan, where he had gone for medical treatment. He was 82. The cause was kidney failure, his son, Yasir Mohammed, said.

An article last Sunday about the American economist Adam S. Posen, who serves on the Bank of England's policy committee, misspelled part of the name of the town in the dateline and referred incorrectly to its location. Mr. Posen recently spoke in Wotton-Under-Edge in southwest England -- not Wooten-Under-Edge in the southeast of the country.

''Design is not about objects anymore; it's more pervasive,'' says Vasif Kortun, a director of Istanbul's new arts center Salt (Istiklal Caddesi 136; saltonline.org). ''Turkey is picking it up belatedly.'' And quickly. Since the opening of Adnan Kazmaoglu's austerely geometric Yesil Vadi Mosque in Istanbul last year, a design and architecture movement is sweeping through the city. Salt's Beyoglu building, a columned space by the local architect Han Tumertekin on the boulevard Istiklal, features the work of a different Turkish designer in each room - there's a cinema by Hakan Demirel, a bookstore by Omer Unal and a cafe by Ali Selcuk and the chef Murat Bozok. Regular symposiums cover everything from urban planning to electronic music, and later this fall a second outpost will open nearby in Galata. There are plenty of fresh faces at the retail level, too: two local powerhouses, Autoban (autoban212.com) and Derin (derindesign.com), recently opened showrooms in Akaretler, and at Haaz (haaz.info), in Nisantasi, homegrown designs mingle with pieces by international names like Tom Dixon and Edra.

FRUGAL TRAVELER Rio de Janeiro has become very expensive, but Seth Kugel eats three very Brazilian, very generously portioned and surprisingly healthy meals at the city's corner juice bars -- all for about $27.

HALF--Maxine, 87, passed suddenly on September 19. Our most loving mother and grandmother whose vibrant personality and giving heart was unsurpassed. Her generosity to all who shared in her life will always be remembered. She never missed a day without talking to her children and grandchildren. She was a fierce advocate for those in need and she was capable of handling whatever challenges life brought. As one of the few working mothers of her time, she gracefully balanced a career while raising children. In 1948 she and her late husband, Robert Half, established the firm Robert Half & Accountemps. She was a brilliant force in business and instrumental in making the company grow worldwide; yet, her true joy was her family. We feel so fortunate to have celebrated so many wonderful times with her. She was always full of energy and loved life. Her kindness, generosity, beautiful soul and selflessness will always be cherished by us. She inspired us to be our best and always told us to love ourselves. Without Grandma Mac and Mom, our hearts are broken and our tears endless, but our memories and joys are immeasurable. Nancy and Donny Peggy and Marc Stephanie, Kevin, Ryan, Adam Lauren and Stephanie

HARRIS--Stella, born in Brooklyn on April 21, 1931, beloved wife of Herbert, devoted mother of Marc and Yvette, Jay and Cheryl, Lilli and Irwin, Sharyn and Sam, loving sister of Mildred, adored grandmother of Ilan and Ariel, Andi, Dovid and Sorah, Keith, Rebecca, David, Mathew, Lane, Samantha, Joshua and great-grandmother of Simcha Zissel. Graduate of Washington Irving High School and Brooklyn College, an elegant woman of great style, physically active all her life, a woman of many accomplishments, extremely charitable and very generous. We will miss her dearly.

Traditionally the heartland of Jewish life in Budapest, the Seventh District in recent decades has fallen into decay and neglect. But designers and club owners have begun moving into its empty buildings and courtyards, giving the neighborhood a newfound vitality. The photographer Claudia Martins and the graphic artist Zita Majoros opened Printa --1 (Rumbach Sebestyen utca 10; printa.hu), which houses an art gallery --2 , a showroom for young designers and a cafe serving direct-trade espresso. The owners also run courses in silk-screen printing. At night the district really comes to life, with partygoers funneling through narrow streets to an ever-growing roster of ''ruin pubs'' like Szimplakert --3 (Kazinczky utca 14; szimpla.hu) -- which is decorated with heaps of trashy furniture, moody lighting and Trabant body parts -- and the courtyard bar Fogashaz (Akacfa utca 51; fogashaz.hu), where a sign reading ''False Teeth'' gives away its previous life as a dental clinic. On Sunday mornings, the party continues at the restored fin de siècle Gozsdu Udvar (between Kiraly utca 13 and Dob utca 16), six interlinked courtyards of restaurants and bars that transform into an outdoor market.

The Check In/Check Out column on Aug. 28, about Soho House in Berlin, misspelled the name of the district filled with cafes and bars that it is near. And a correction in this space on Sept. 11 gave another incorrect spelling for the district. It is Prenzlauer Berg -- not Prenzelauer Berg or Prenzlauerberg.

Although ostrich flesh is promoted as a leaner, more healthful alternative to beef, pork and chicken, the bird itself can be a health hazard to ostrich farmers. An ostrich can stand as tall as nine feet and weigh as much as 350 pounds -- and run as fast as 40 miles per hour. ''Your only hope to control them is to use intimidation,'' says Douglas Osborne, the owner of O.K. Corral Ostrich Farms in Oro Grande, Calif., the nation's largest such farm, ''because if you turn your back, they're going to do a Navajo rain dance on you.'' They're worth the danger. Osborne sells newborn chicks for $300 each; a bird's price will rise by $100 per month thereafter. Mature females with exceptional bloodlines will occasionally sell for more than $10,000. As for the actual ostrich meat, the price is comparable with prime beef's. Says Osborne, whose herd numbers over 3,000, ''I sell out of everything I produce.'' Life expectancy of an ostrich: 50 to 75 years
CROWN HEIGHTS TWO-FAMILY $925,000

THE PATIENT'S STORY A 46-year-old man came to the Metropolitan Hospital on Manhattan's Upper East Side early one afternoon. He had a case of the hiccups that wouldn't go away. The problem started two days earlier. In the midst of what seemed a perfectly ordinary day, he started to hiccup and wasn't able to stop. He tried all the usual treatments. He held his breath. He drank glass after glass of cold water. He thought scary thoughts. But no matter what he did, every 20 to 30 seconds, his chest would jump, and then his throat would close, cutting short the involuntary intake of air. After two days of nonstop hiccupping, he went to the hospital. 1. THE PHYSICIAN ASSISTANT It was evening by the time Steve Ferrante, a physician assistant, saw the patient. The patient told him he didn't have any medical problems; didn't smoke or drink and took no medications. He had had two hernia operations -- one three years ago and one earlier that week. And he'd been hiccupping constantly for the past two days. Ferrante asked whether there were there any other symptoms: chest pain, shortness of breath, fever, chills or cough? Nothing. Other than the hiccups, the patient felt fine. The physical exam was unremarkable.

Before Christina Vantzou, a Kansas City, Mo.-born art student, fell in love with an American expat during a layover in Brussels seven years ago, she had never given the city a second thought. She assumed it was as bland as everyone said, and when she packed her bags and moved there soon after, she found plenty of Europeans who agreed. ''The people I was hanging out with at the time referred to it as the Mexico of Europe,'' she says. ''Everyone wanted to go to Paris or London or Amsterdam, and Brussels was just this weird place in the middle.'' At first, Vantzou stayed mostly for her relationship and for the hefty artist's stipend she received from the Belgian government, having secured E.U. citizenship by way of her Greek father. But then a funny thing happened. Not only was she discovering that there was more to the cultural scene than she'd imagined, she was also watching as other artists - Parisians, even - began settling in the city. Long ignored or even mocked by its neighbors, Brussels seemed to be entering a kind of creative renaissance. ''Where it used to be like 'Brussels? Why the heck would you move there?' these days it's like, 'Oh, yeah, I've been hearing about all the stuff happening there,' '' Vantzou says. ''Brussels used to be this forgotten place, and suddenly people are talking about it like they were talking about Berlin 10 years ago.''

Ralph J. Lomma, who at midcentury helped set the static pastime of miniature golf in motion, letting players tilt at windmills, shoot across rising drawbridges and, at game's end, watch the ball vanish forever into the maw of a voracious clown, died on Sept. 12 in Scranton, Pa. He was 87. The cause was complications of a fall he had several months ago, his son, Jonathan, said.

Munnar, India, May 14, 2011 I was in Kochi, in the Indian state of Kerala, on business. One weekend, a couple of my colleagues and I went on a weekend trip to Munnar, about three hours east of Kochi. The scenery was incredible -- vibrant green tea plants covered the hillside for miles and miles. I found the colors in this photograph striking: the houses on the hill, the tea plants, the girl's vibrant clothes. For me, the scene really captured the humble, mystic beauty of Munnar and Kerala. MOIRA CECONI, New York City

GOBER--Joyce, beloved mother, grandmother, teacher, friend and Westchester Philharmonic board member. Service on October 10, at 10am B'Nai Yisrael, Armonk.

FINK--Rebecca, passed away at age 95 on September 22, 2011 at her home in Boca Raton, Florida peacefully, surrounded by her family and dedicated nurses. The daughter of Pearl Margolis and Cantor Jacob Margolis, sister of the late Yona, Dora, Geula, Bela, and Jon. She proudly graduated from Freeport High School, Pratt College, and went to work in the fledgling Manhattan fashion industry as a dress designer. A beauty with unmatched intellect, with a strong religious background ventured out into the secular world. She married her polar opposite, Dr. Benjamin Fink, in 1939, and soon was left stateside to raise as a single Jewish woman in a backward South, two children, Gerald and Robert, while her husband served in the South Pacific, punctuated by conjugal visits to Rebecca from 1939-1946. Following WWII, they settled in Freeport, NY, where Ben was the ultra-dedicated GP whose office was adjacent to their home. Rebecca and Ben raised four children, of whom she was proud: Dr. Gerald Fink (Dr. Rosalie), Dr. Robert Fink (Geri), Dr. Alan Fink (Phyllis), Dr. Janet Kowal (Dr. Robert). She is also survived by her loving grandchildren: Julia Feldman (Uri), Dr. Jennifer Fink (Sarah Sohn), Peninah Salad (Rabbi Jay), Deena Taggert (Nissim), Anna Kaminetsky (Shimon), and Sara Wachtel (Jonathan), Dr. Gregg Fink (Jennifer), Matthew Fink, Dr. Rachel Kowal (Matt Feldman), Brian Kowal (Lorin), as well as 33 great-grandchildren. She raised her family and her husband with love, discipline and loyalty that never changed to the day she died. An extremely private woman, she mastered every challenge she came in contact with: fashion design, painting, cooking, fishing, and remaining a loyal sorority sister for over 50 years. Moving to Florida in the 1970s with Ben and many of their childhood and college friends, she enjoyed the sunshine, easy friendships, the sporadic visits of her working children, and the attention of many of her grandchildren. Her loyalty to her family, her intellectual rigor, her amazing fish dishes, and her proud independence will never be forgotten by those who knew her. A remarkable woman, she was helped immensely to reach 95 by the love of her grandson, Brian Kowal, granddaughter Peninah Salad, and aid/friend Rythnade Sylvain. Contributions can be made in her honor to Ruth Rales Jewish Family Service of South Palm Beach County, 7901 W. Atlantic Ave., Delray Beach, FL 33446.
HALF--Maxine. A very special woman. Mother, leader, friend. Sam and Robert Gottlieb

The designer Blake Simpson started coming out from Los Angeles to Joshua Tree in the late 1990s, after buying a house in the desert that he's still tinkering with. At the time, he was making furniture for Marc Jacobs and for the renovation of the Sunset Tower Hotel. Then, in 2002, he spotted the 1950s motel that would become his new five-room hideaway, Mojave Sands (mojavesands.com; doubles from $200). ''It was just sitting there, more or less abandoned,'' he says. ''But I could see that it had really good bones.'' True to the D.I.Y. culture of the high desert, Simpson did a lot of the nine-year renovation himself, stripping and sanding the concrete floors and putting up honey-colored cedar planks for walls. He made the beds from black walnut and paired them with new and vintage modern furniture. And he used perforated metal tread plates to create a private patio for each room. Simpson did have a little help from his friends, like the ''California hippie in his mid-60s'' who Simpson says turned up at just the right time to lay the dry-stacked slate for the facade. His stylist pal Laurel Rose made the curtains from linen inset with scraps from vintage saris. And his neighbor, the actress Ann Magnuson, helped him trawl the local flea markets for decor - ''objets d'art that Blake finds like stray kittens,'' as she puts it - including midcentury Scandinavian pottery, manual typewriters and vintage record players. (Every room has one; there's wi-fi but no TV.)

THE Brazilian jeweler H. Stern named its latest capsule of sphere-inspired gold pieces the Copernicus collection after the 16th-century German astronomer whose Heliocentric model of the universe put the sun at the center of the solar system. It was a revolutionary notion at the time (planets circling the sun!) and one that struck an artistic chord for H. Stern's president and creative director, Roberto Stern. ''We've always been inspired by nature,'' he said. ''This time I had orbits on my mind.'' Comprising 24 18-karat gold pieces, many of which bear a signature diamond bead, the collection is characterized by loopy, never-ending lines on earrings, necklaces and rings. Here, a bracelet made of hollow, faceted baubles to circle your pretty wrist until infinity. Copernicus bracelet with diamonds, $34,000. Go to hstern.net. EDWARD BARSAMIAN
WEISS--Ida (Berson). Our beloved sister-in-law and aunt. Our sincere sympathies to the entire family. Bernard, Wendy and Cathy

DAVE GROHL (LEFT): There were 30,000, maybe 35,000 people at Reading. I'm not sure, but it was a lot bigger than any show I had ever played. I think this picture was taken before the gig, and the reason I can tell the difference between pre- and postgig is that Kurt [Cobain] was seriously injured by jumping into my drum set. That bottle he's holding out toward the camera was some kind of incredibly potent cough syrup, and he was carrying that thing around like a flask. So this is preshow, and he was drinking that cough syrup, which led him to dive into my drum set, which put him in a sling for the rest of the night. That gig was definitely a triumph. KRIST NOVOSELIC (RIGHT): You're in a rock band, and you're surviving, you've got food, plenty of beer. We were constantly doing photo sessions at the time, so you're looking for a prop. It's Covonia Bronchial Balsam. That was before Nirvana hit big. We recorded ''Nevermind'' in April of 1991, and then we were on tour with Sonic Youth. So this is the last of the unknown Nirvana.

McCARTAN--Edward F.,died September 25, 2010, surrounded by love, music and poetry. To the Sports Editor: Regardless of whether one favors the establishment of an Olympic soccer team representing a united England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, the chosen name, Team G.B., is likely to displease both Irelands, Northern and the Republic. Great Britain is the larger island that is home to the first three of the aforementioned countries, but Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland share the smaller island called Ireland.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the aftermath of a plane crash that killed 11 at an air show in Reno, Nev., on Sept. 16 described incorrectly a plane that crashed the next day during another air show in Martinsburg, W.Va.. The voting for the Most Valuable Player awards will be fascinating this year. Strong contenders come from also-ran teams. Playoff-bound contenders have teammates who could spoil their chances. A pitcher is a strong contender for the first time in 20 years. The tricky part for voters is defining the word value. ''I just think they should get rid of the name,'' said Davey Lopes, the first-base coach for the Los Angeles Dodgers. ''As players - and I know how it was - when we talk about most valuable player, we all didn't say, 'Who's the most valuable player to the team?' It was, 'Who's the best player in the National League?' That's the most valuable player. That's how I see it. Writers, for the most part, don't see it that way.''
A film column last Sunday about character actors misidentified the actress who played the maid Amelia in the 2006 movie ''Babel.'' It was Adriana Barraza, not Lupe Ontiveros.

Packers (2-0) at Bears (1-1) Sunday, 4:15 p.m. Line: Packers 3 . Jay Cutler is a 50-Tesla, super-cooled, solenoid-style electromagnet for criticism. He can attract scorn from hundreds of miles away. Everything about Cutler's career is polarizing: the gaudy statistics that contrast his 35-35 win-loss record; his penchant for turnovers; his snippy, irritable public demeanor; and his career-long association with mercurial offensive masterminds like Mike Shanahan, Josh McDaniels and Mike Martz, who only magnify his peculiar attraction-repulsion effect. Last season's N.F.C. championship game became Ferris Cutler's Day Off, with the (somewhat) injured quarterback looking less willing than able on the sideline as his backups got battered by the Packers. It was the type of nonperformance that defines a career, fairly or not, and a win Sunday could deflect a tiny bit of criticism. Unfortunately, Cutler's Bears are 1-4 against the Packers in the past two seasons, and their offensive line is still bad enough to make even the toughest quarterback consider using a sick day. Pick: Packers Texans (2-0) at Saints (1-1) Sunday, 1 p.m. Line: Saints by 4. Had the Texans faced the Saints last year, Drew Brees would have thrown for 600 yards. Houston's defense has improved drastically since then. The coordinator Wade Phillips has apparently grown smarter since leaving the Cowboys (it's a common phenomenon), and newcomers like cornerback Johnathan Joseph and the rookie defensive lineman J.J. Watt have helped the star pass rusher Mario Williams make an early impact. The Texans rank first in the N.F.L. in pass defense, though the Dolphins' defeatist attack and the Colts' ''Men of a Certain Age'' offense did not offer the kind of test the Texans face this week. The Saints offense is just like it was in previous years, only moreso: the arrivals of running backs Darren Sproles and Mark Ingram have more than offset the loss of the injured receiver Marques Colston. The offense no longer gets much attention because a) we are used to it and b) offensive production around the league is so high that Brees can complete 67.4 percent of his passes and throw for six touchdowns in two weeks without attracting notice. The first team to score 30 points will win this game, but at least the Texans defense is now good enough to keep that from happening before halftime. Pick: Saints

The National Gallery of Art in Washington recently unveiled ''The Invention of Glory: Alfonso V and the Pastrana Tapestries,'' four enormous pieces created by Flemish weavers in the 1470s. Commissioned to applaud King Afonso V of Portugal, who invaded Moroccan coastal cities in the mid-15th century, the tapestries never made it to Lisbon. Instead, they languished in the Spanish town of Pastrana: moth-eaten, faded and rarely seen. With the help of the Fundacion Carlos de Amberes and the meticulous restoration work of the Belgian Royal Manufactures De Wit, the sieges of Tangiers and Asilah crackle once more: with their clashing knights carrying enormous spears, the scenes look like outtakes from ''Game of Thrones.''

BOTTLE STOPS For a crash-course in Hungarian wine without the trip to Tokaj, stop at the Budapest Wine Society's flagship shop, the Bortarsasag Parlament (Vecsey utca 5; 011-36-1-269-3286; bortarsasag.hu). Founded in the early 1990s by two enthusiasts, Attila Talos and Tom Howells, the group gives visitors a tasting tour of the local terroir, from dessert whites to full-bodied reds. The society also runs a restaurant, Klassz Bisztro (Andrassy utca 41; klasszbisztro.hu), whose 50 carefully selected bottles are a roll call of the country's best independent producers. Many of those vineyards also turn up on the menus at wine-centered restaurants like Bock Bisztro (Erzsebet korut 43-49; 011-36-1-321-0340; bockbisztro.hu) and Borkonyha (left; Sas utca 3; 011-36-1-266-0835; borkonyha.hu), and at wine bars like Borbirosag (Csarnok ter 5; 011-36-1-219-0912; borbirosag.com), which offers hundreds of vintages by the glass.

ORLANDO, Fla. -- Herman Cain, the former chief executive of Godfather's Pizza, won the Florida straw poll Saturday, handing a thorough defeat to Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who came in second after working the crowd of activists with a breakfast speech. Mr. Cain won nearly 40 percent of the 2,657 votes cast, more than doubling Mr. Perry's total and that of Mitt Romney, who came in a close third.

The ''In the Region'' article in some copies last Sunday, about the construction of rental apartments in Elmwood Park, N.J., gave an outdated business affiliation for Joseph P. Langan, a developer there. He is the owner of the River Drive Construction Company; he is no longer with Langan Engineering and Environmental Services, which his father founded in 1970.

SIX months ago, Keli Goff, a blogger, political commentator and self-appointed fashion industry watchdog, chided designers for their near-exclusion of black models on the runways. Most shows, she wrote on her Web site, Loop21.com, ''were about as diverse as a Tea Party rally.'' Of 144 shows last spring, she reported, 25 featured no black models at all, while others included only one or two. Just days ago, in the wake of New York Fashion Week, Ms. Goff softened her stance, having noticed an encouraging, if modest, uptick in black models on the catwalks. According to her tabulations, more than 90 percent of the 200-plus designers had at least one black model, a jump of 7 percentage points over last fall.

IT was unusual in the post-housing-crash world that Michael L. Breaux fell for an apartment at PS90, a once-decrepit public school in central Harlem converted to a mixed-income condominium in 2009, before seeing a finished unit. Buyers who a few years ago might have snapped up apartments in new developments after merely viewing floor plans have been reluctant to do so, and new projects, including many in Harlem, have suffered mightily along with the economy.

The $34.6 million sale of a co-op at 927 Fifth Avenue by William Lie Zeckendorf, a developer of 15 Central Park West, was the biggest of the week, according to brokers who handled the deal. Mr. Zeckendorf, who paid $29.1 million for the five-bedroom five-and-a-half-bathroom apartment, had sold his penthouse at 15 Central Park West in December, making a $30 million profit. He then bought the 927 Fifth Avenue property from the estate of Bruce Wasserstein, the chairman and chief executive of Lazard who died in 2009. A few months later he decided to sell, saying the space was too large, and listed it for $31.5 million.

New York is a changeling, a different city to everyone who passes through. The premiere of the fall TV season will reflect that: Just last month, a record 23 prime-time shows filmed here, thanks in part to recent tax breaks. In sound stages from the Chelsea Piers to the Brooklyn Navy Yard, designers rebuilt the landscape to fit plot lines, making the city seem brighter and sadder, wealthier and grittier, older and newer.

On a balmy night this April, when young people in Egypt, Syria, Yemen and Bahrain swarmed the streets to protest repressive regimes, Beirut's 20-somethings were partying on the rooftop of a new American-style restaurant. It was opening night for this latest branch of the country's popular Crepaway restaurants, and because it sits right on the city's former Green Line - the no man's land that separated the Christian East from the Muslim West during Lebanon's 15-year civil war, which ended in 1990 - there were slickly designed posters depicting army tanks with the words the art of peace on every wall. Everyone ate sliders, drank vodka cocktails from an open bar and shifted fluidly between English, French and Arabic. The crowd looked more Marais than Middle East: boys wore mustaches and skinny jeans, the girls floaty minidresses and gladiator heels. If people weren't dancing to the pounding nu-disco, they were screaming over one another while they texted and tweeted.

AMATO--Robert A. Robert A. Amato, died on September 19, 2011. He was born on June 17, 1931 in Corona, New York and grew up in Bayside, New York. He lived for many of his years in Garden City, New York and New York City. He was a long term resident of East Hampton, New York and Palm Beach, Florida. He passed away as a result of an unknown ischemic event, and fell into a coma from which he never recovered. In many ways he lived the American dream. He graduated from Bayside High and worked in the family garage door business in Maspeth, New York. He served his countryduring the Korean War in the U.S. Air Force. Seeking greener pastures, the arc of his life changed dramatically when he chose a white-collar career. He began his transformation with General Binding Corp., the Yellow pages and eventually landed at Jobson Publishing Corporation. At the retirement of the founder Frank Jobson, with little capital, but much spirit and spunk, he spearheaded a leveraged buy-out of Jobson Publishing. Under his astute and streetwise leadership, he grew Jobson Publishing from a small 10-person liquor industry publisher, into a 400+ employee market leader in the international healthcare marketplace. He became a respected industry visionary in the worldwide eyecare and eyewear market. One of the founders of The Vision Industry Council of America, now The VisionCouncil, he was instrumental in developing the International Vision Expo shows, now among the most well attended and important in the industry. He was honored for his leadership with The Ben Robinson Award by the United Jewish Appeal (UJA). He retired in May 2005 and Jobson's continued market leadership is a symbol of his business legacy. He traveled the world, but found his greatest joy in the company of his family. His true love and constant companion was his wife of 23 years, Nancy Amato, who survives him. He is also survived by his children, Janet Moffitt (Rick Ringhausen), Robert S. Amato (Anne), Ronald J. Amato (Jeanne), Roger C. Amato (Debra) and Jill Wilkins (Chris). Additionally he leaves behind his 13 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He will be deeply missed by all who loved him. Apassionate believer in the transformative nature of education, Bob created the Robert & Nancy Amato Education Foundation, to support the college education of disadvantaged children. A memorial service will be held Friday September 30, 2011 at the Frank Campbell Funeral home, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st and Madison), NYC at 11:30 am. In Lieu of flowers the family requests donations be made to The Wounded Warriors (www.wounded warriorproject.org) or SmileTrain (www.smiletrain.org).

HUNTINGTON--Derek Updegraf, 64, longtime Manhattan resident and former President of ZZZ Carpentry Inc., died on September 19th at home in the West Village. Son of John Willard Huntington and Patricia Shaffer Huntington, Derek was born on 26 February 1947 and grew up in West Hartford, CT. He graduated from Phillips Academy Andover in 1965 and Yale College in 1969. At Yale he was a nationally ranked lacrosse player, and a member of Fence Club and Scroll & Key Senior Society. Music was always a vital part of Derek's life. Throughout the 1970's he was a professional singer, songwriter, music producer and sound engineer, living and performing in Los Angeles, Boston and across New England. In 1980, Derek moved to Manhattan and in 1982 he founded ZZZ Carpentry, a high-end residential construction firm, collaborating closely with a number of notable architects on both traditional and modern renovations. Derek was an avid fresh and salt water fly fisherman, an enthusiastic tennis player, and an all-around athlete. He was a summer resident of Saltaire on Fire Island. Derek had many friends whom he loved and who loved him. He is survived by his wife and partner of 21 years, Caroline Northcote Sidnam, son Samuel Dworkin Huntington, stepdaughter Emma X Sidnam Pucci, stepson Samuel Northcote Pucci, former wife Elizabeth Dworkin, sister Sara Huntington Ohly of New Haven, CT and brother John Willard Huntington of Chicago IL. The time and place of a memorial service have not yet been determined. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Natural Resources Defense Council or The Wildlife Conservation Society.

After closing its doors in 2005 for a rafters-to-orchestra-pit renovation, Moscow's Bolshoi Theater still kicked up controversy - embezzlement, corruption, sex scandal. Now, three years past due and way over budget, the hall, which dates to 1825, will reopen next month with a gala performance of the ballet and opera companies' greatest hits. In attendance will be President Dmitri Medvedev and other heads of state, who will finally see what $760 million restores. It took more than 3,500 workers to restore the Apollo and the Muses ceiling piece, replicate the missing Villeroy & Boch tiles and hang 617 pounds of crystal from the main chandelier. Much of the work was supervised by the president's office itself, which stepped in when construction faltered in 2009, after a contractor was paid three times for the same work. Now the acoustics are fixed, subterranean hydraulic stages are built, and, for the finishing touch, the Romanov coat of arms has been reinstated above the lintels, in place of the hammer and sickle. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A NEW set of terms and conditions for the OnStar service, the General Motors-supported safety and connectivity system, is generating privacy concerns among some subscribers, many of whom have long raised questions about the potential for abuse. Last week, OnStar sent e-mails notifying customers of changes in the company's policies. Two changes in those terms raised concerns from the standpoint of privacy. The first regards what happens when a customer cancels the service. Until now, when OnStar service stopped, so did the vehicle's two-way communications system.

The notoriously wild frontman for Jane's Addiction and Porno for Pyros may have settled down, but he's still a rolling stone, thanks to a demanding tour schedule that includes Lollapalooza, the seminal music festival he founded in Chicago in 1991, and its offshoots in Chile and -- starting next year -- Brazil. Farrell and his wife, Etty, a dancer who often performs with him, are virtually inseparable. She auditioned for Jane's Addiction in 1997, and ''I fell in love with her at first sight,'' he says. ''We've been traveling together in one capacity or another ever since.'' Their happy place? The cliff-top pineapple field in Maui where they tied the knot.

Post-Fidel anticipation has tourists flocking to Cuba to bask in the sunset of the revolution: the patched-together Studebakers, the stuck-in-time streetscapes. But visitors often leave without a real sense of the island's rich, pre-Communist past, much less its inscrutable present - both the subjects of new photo books. Michael Dweck's ''Habana Libre'' (above left, Damiani, $65) is a sun-baked ''Who's Who'' of Cuba's cultural elite. Michael Connors's ''Splendor of Cuba'' (above right, Rizzoli, $85) catalogs the country's 450-year architectural history, casting a rosy eye on exquisitely preserved examples of Spanish-Creole colonial style. Additional images from each book are available in our slide show.

STOWENS--Doris H.,died September 17th of lung cancer at the age of 92. She had a distinguished career as Registrar of the American Craft Museum where her generosity and expertise was appreciated by both the artists and staff. The one-piece dress is back. Zipped on in 30 seconds, it eliminates the time-consuming thought that goes into dressing in multiple separates. Fall's novelty is a carwash-flap design from Alexander Wang (just don't ride a bicycle in it). Also seen is Dior's successful revival of 1950s luncheon dresses with draped necklines. It's too bad they were kept hidden in the showroom while exaggerated designs were sent down the runway to entertain the media; luckily, store buyers concentrate on the offstage collection of wearable clothes. A more contemporary look is the bell-shape dress. The new hemlines have nothing to do with the ups and downs of the stock market.
Art Holland Cotter

On a hot summer day in Manaus, Brazil, Diana Taylor, the former banking superintendent of New York and longtime companion of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, was strolling through a slum. A city of about two million in the middle of the Amazon, Manaus is where the Boston-based microfinance group Accion International started an ambitious lending operation in February, and Taylor, who is chairwoman of the group's board, had flown down with a delegation of staff and investors to observe how the experiment was coming along on the ground. Nearly six feet tall, thin and wearing large, round sunglasses, khaki pants and leather driving moccasins that had the kind of distressed effect only years of wear can produce, Taylor did not blend in. But as pedestrians paused to stare, she neither reveled in the attention nor was fazed by it, instead noting details of the storefronts she passed: whether they had adequate signage, say, or were advantageously located in front of a bus stop. After two blocks, having passed four businesses bearing stickers with Accion's logo - indications that the owners had taken out loans - Taylor stopped in front of a cellphone supply kiosk. ''These are really smart,'' she said, pointing to a sticker in the shop's window. ''We should have them everywhere!''

By late summer, most of the corn in America is head high and bristling. The stalks stand shoulder to shoulder like an army without rank, their sharp-edged, swordlike leaves forming a nearly impenetrable wall. A modern cornfield would have rebuffed Cary Grant in ''North by Northwest'' because there are no rows to speak of, only a dense lattice of intersecting spears. This corn - grown by the tens of millions of acres - has been genetically engineered, altered by having stacks of apparently desirable traits wedged into its genetic code. Saving the kernels of engineered corn in the fall to plant in the spring is both illegal, because of company patents, and largely irrelevant, since the plants they yield, which contain a packet of foreign genes, won't necessarily resemble the parent crop. Nearly all the corn you see anywhere in our nation of corn is this year's model, new and, so they say, improved. Genetically modified corn is the path industrial agriculture has chosen - a profoundly controversial one. But a growing movement of gardeners and small farmers is keeping alive the genetic diversity that modern agriculture has rejected.

''I don't need a swing in my room, I need a bloody minibar,'' says the model Lara Stone, distending her world-famous lower lip and disparaging with a withering shrug the desperately cool flourishes of the designed-to-death hotel - a converted house of detention - where she is staying in Amsterdam. We are in a car speeding back to the city from Stone's childhood home in Mierlo, a sylvan burg about 80 miles south that could be described (in a good way!) as the Massapequa of the Netherlands. We've been hanging out with Stone's parents, Michael and Toos, eating pancakes at a supremely odd ecclesiastically themed pancake house where a looming Virgin Mary stares down at flapjacks as big as personal pan pizzas.
BROAD--Stanley. So greatly missed, always in our thoughts, forever in our hearts. Love, Your Family

Viewed from the country road that winds into Le Puy-Sainte-Réparade, an agricultural village about 10 miles north of Aix-en-Provence, the rounded aluminum winery of Château La Coste glints silver in a field of sun-baked vines, like a spaceship touched down in Cézanne country. What just might trump a U.F.O. sighting for spectacle is the fact that the building is by Jean Nouvel and it is joined on this woodsy 600-acre setting by a Frank Gehry-designed music pavilion, three buildings by Tadao Ando and sculptures by the likes of Richard Serra and Louise Bourgeois -- most of the work commissioned by a single patron. Still to come are structures by Gehry, Oscar Niemeyer, Norman Foster and Renzo Piano. Begun in 2003 and opened to the public this summer, La Coste is both a cultural theme park and a personal canvas for its owner, Patrick McKillen, the Belfast-born property magnate and intensely private champion of art and architecture. (He declined to be interviewed for this article.) ''Paddy is our quietest client,'' says the architect Richard Rogers of McKillen, who is a major shareholder in the group that owns Claridge's and other London hotels. In addition to Rogers's plans for a pavilion to display drawings, there are more than 20 projects under way: two 1940s wood pavilions by Jean Prouvé that are being turned into an art library; organic gardens by the French landscape designer Louis Benech; 29 villa accommodations; and a James Turrell light tunnel, among other works.

GUNCKEL--Dr. James E.,a pioneering botanist in both meristem culture and radiation biology at Rutgers University, died September 19 in Jamesburg, NJ. He was 97. In addition to teaching a generation of plant scientists the art and science of plant tissue cloning, Dr. Gunckel became a leading expert on the effects of radiation on a variety of plant species. He served as an expert witness on the probable impact of radiation leakage on the ecosystem surrounding Three Mile Island. Dr. Gunckel was particularly proud of the career achievements of his many graduate students at Rutgers. "They always wanted to thank him for his commitment to preparing them to assume leading research positions in academia," recalls Dr. Rod Sharp, one of those graduate students who later rose to the position of Director of Research at the New Jersey Agricultural Experiment Station. "Professor Gunckel would say, 'Don't thank me. Just pass it on to the next generation.'"

An article last Sunday about Kerrville, a small city of roughly 22,000 residents near San Antonio, incorrectly stated the number of visitors who attend the Texas Furniture Makers' Show each year. It is roughly 5,000, not 500,000. Also, because of an editing error, the article incorrectly stated the size of the campus of the James Avery Craftsman headquarters in some editions. It is 40 acres, not 25.

Survived by his wife of 62 years, Jean; his son, Norman, and his wife, Janice; his daughter, Elaine, and her husband, Steve; and his grandchildren, Rachel, Rebecca, Leah, Alyssa, Carly and Samuel. When she traveled, Pavia Rosati used to scour ''90 Web sites for hours, then narrow down the information into a 40-page mega-Word document.'' To save the rest of us the trouble, Rosati started Fathom (fathomaway.com): guides, postcards and resources by journalists, tuned-in travelers and readers eager to share. ''It's crowd sourcing with an editorial filter,'' says Rosati (above right, in Capri with Fathom's editorial director, Jeralyn Gerba, left). ''Everyone loves the voice of the people, but can you trust them?'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

''EXCUSE me,'' the Russian soprano Anna Netrebko declared at a recent dress rehearsal of Donizetti's ''Anna Bolena,'' the operatic melodrama about Henry VIII's unlucky second wife, which will open the Metropolitan Opera's 128th season on Monday evening. She walked to the edge of the stage and peered into the dark, near-empty auditorium. ''This gorgeously beautiful light,'' she went on. ''Can we do anything about that? I am blinded. I can't see anything.''

The police made scores of arrests on Saturday as hundreds of people, many of whom had been encamped in the financial district as part of a lengthy protest, marched north to Union Square. As darkness fell, large numbers of officers were deployed on streets near the encampment in Zuccotti Park, at Broadway and Liberty Street, where hundreds more people had gathered. Paul J. Browne, the Police Department's chief spokesman, said in a statement, ''There were approximately 80 arrests, mainly for disorderly conduct by individuals who blocked vehicular and pedestrian traffic, but also for resisting arrest, obstructing governmental administration and, in one instance, for assault on a police officer.''

Nicole Lara Cohen, a daughter of Joanne Bernstein-Cohen and Dr. David I. Cohen of Manhattan, is to be married Sunday afternoon to Alexander Lawrence Cumming, a son of Roger A. Cumming, also of Manhattan and the late Megan Lawrence Cumming. Judge Margarita López Torres of Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn is to officiate at the Harold Pratt House, an event space in Manhattan. The bride, 34, is a senior applications analyst at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in Manhattan, where she helps implement computer systems. She graduated from the University of Pennsylvania magna cum laude.

Christiaan The in-demand hairstylist Christiaan practically grew up in his father's barbershop, in a tiny Dutch town called Bovenkarspel. The oldest of 12 children, he had to pitch in ''as soon as I was able to sweep the floor.'' Now he's known for creating looks for the likes of Lady Gaga and Grace Jones. (Yes, that flat top was his.) For ''Little Dutch Girl'' (Page 94), Christiaan joined an old friend, Lara Stone, whose golden locks he pinched into messy pigtails on their home turf in the Netherlands. Aside from his work for countless ad campaigns and magazines, Christiaan hopes one day to publish his photo diary, for which he has taken 10 to 20 pictures each day for the past 15 years.

PAUL--James Caverly Newlin, died peacefully at his home in Trappe Maryland on September 13, 2011. He was 85. Jim Paul was born April 30, 1926 in the Chestnut Hill area of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, to the late William and Adelaide Paul, also of Chestnut Hill and, later, Easton, MD. He moved his family to Addis Ababa, Ethiopia in 1963, where he served for six years as the founding dean and moving force behind the establishment of Ethiopia's first law school, and later served as Dean of Rutgers law school. He enjoyed retirement on Maryland's Eastern Shore, in particular sailing and bird watching, and spending time with his grandchildren. Jim is survived by his wife of 63 years, Peggy Paul of Trappe, Maryland; a sister, Margaret P. Kingsland, of Catonsville, MD and a brother, Peter C. Paul, of Cambridge, MD; two daughters, Martha M. Paul of Concord, MA and Adelaide S. Paul of Philadelphia, PA; a son, Nicholas N. Paul of San Diego, CA; seven grandchildren; and two great-granddaughters. Jim's life will be celebrated, and remembered, at a service to take place at Third Haven Friends Meeting, 405 S. Washington St., Easton, Maryland, on October 8, 2011, at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the Talbot Hospice Foundation, 586 Cynwood Drive, Easton, MD 21601. Services are being handled by Fellows, Helfenbein and Newnam Funeral Home, PA, 200 S. Harrison St., Easton, MD 21601. For online tributes, please visit www.fhnfuneralhome.com.

9 P.M. (HBO) BOARDWALK EMPIRE Nucky Thompson (Steve Buscemi, above center), whose fortunes have soared in the wake of Prohibition legislation, finds himself investigated for voter fraud after rigging a mayoral election and faces not only jail time but also the insurrection of his closest allies in this second-season premiere. (The series just earned an Emmy for Martin Scorsese, who won for outstanding directing of the pilot episode of a drama series.) Meanwhile, Chalky (Michael Kenneth Williams) is threatened by a Ku Klux Klan attack; Margaret (Kelly Macdonald) struggles with the disciplinary problems of her son (portrayed by two actors, Rory and Declan McTigue); and Angela (Aleksa Palladino) and Gillian (Gretchen Mol) compete for the affections of Jimmy (Michael Pitt). A preshow program begins at 8:30. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Chris Wallace interviews David Plouffe, a senior adviser to President Obama, about Mr. Obama's jobs act and deficit-reduction plan. (Mr. Plouffe will also appear on ''State of the Union With Candy Crowley,'' at 9 on CNN, and on ''This Week With Christiane Amanpour,'' at 10 on ABC.)

The Italian auteur Paolo Sorrentino's first novel, ''Everybody's Right'' (Europa Editions, $15), is about an aging musician, a nightclub crooner who loses his mind in Brazil after his starlight begins to dim. It has parallels with his latest film ''This Must Be the Place,'' a similarly strange tale in which Sean Penn plays a catatonic, lipsticked rock star in the Robert Smith mold. Susan Hochbaum's coffee-table confection, ''Pastry Paris'' (The Little Bookroom, $20), juxtaposes patisserie staples with Paris landmarks: the Palais Garnier as mille-feuille and the interior dome of the Pantheon as a banana-topped tart by Christian Constant.

An article on Sept. 11 about the German film director Tom Tykwer erroneously included one actress among those cast in ''Cloud Atlas,'' Mr. Tykwer's next project. Natalie Portman will not be in the movie.

A listing in the Westchester Calendar in some editions last Sunday misstated the admission price to the 50th Anniversary Armonk Outdoor Art Show that runs from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. today. The prices for adults are $8 and $10 -- not $7 and $9. (Admission is free for those under 18.)

FOUNDED 250 years ago, Pittsfield, Mass., is a model of old Americana: a mixture of handsome 19th-century buildings and stately early-20th-century homes, with the Berkshire Mountains just a stone's throw away. By the middle of the last century, it was a bustling urban town center with a steady stream of work provided by General Electric. But by the 1970s, the city had fallen on hard times, after G.E. moved operations south and left PCBs in the Housatonic River. It seemed that Pittsfield had been passed over by the golden touch that had brought wealth and tourists to surrounding Berkshire towns. But in the last few years Pittsfield has begun to reawaken. The bones of those old buildings are still as beautiful as they were midcentury. And there are now galleries, boutiques and restaurants opening up where ''For Rent'' signs long dominated.SARAH WILDMAN

This morning at 5:04, autumn arrived. In New York City as elsewhere, the natural year is winding down, and in just a few weeks, it will be winter. The changing of the seasons is an intricate process involving much more than the turning and falling of the leaves and the growing chill. But often in this city, we do not slow down to notice. We could see it all if we could just stand still.

The Field Notes column on Sept. 11, about the closing of the Priscilla of Boston bridal salons, described incorrectly the wedding of Julie Nixon Eisenhower, whose gown was by Priscilla. She was married in New York in December 1968, a month before her father, Richard M. Nixon, became president; therefore, she was not a White House bride. (As the column correctly noted, her sister, Tricia, married at the White House, in 1971.)

La Rotonde, the neo-Classical monument overlooking the Bassin de la Villette in the 19th Arrondissement in Paris, is finally seeing new life after sitting empty for years. Inside the building, a luminous atrium is surrounded on three floors by a series of connected rooms to be used for art installations, private receptions, classes and workshops, cocktail hours and more. Outside, pink cafe chairs spill onto the Place de Stalingrad, facing the water.

FELDMAN--Justin. The partners of Cooley LLP mourn the passing of our beloved retired partner Justin Feldman and celebrate the long life and career of a giant in our profession and a leader in our city. Justin was a partner in the New York office of Cooley (then Kronish, Lieb, Weiner & Hellman LLP) from 1982 until he retired. He was our mentor and dear friend. His career as a lawyer in private practice and in public service was exemplary. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Linda, his children and grandchildren.

LORBER--Bette. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Health System are greatly saddened by the death of Bette Lorber, wife of Life Trustee Jerome Z. Lorber, a long-time benefactor of LIJ Medical Center. Thanks to Bette and Jerry's generosity, the Bette and Jerome Lorber Center for the Advancement of Medical Education was established, making a variety of resources, special programs and activities available to all LIJ medical residents. A former teacher, Bette contributed her invaluable expertise to and enthusiasm for this and other innovative initiatives, particularly those utilizing technology in medical education. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Jerry and his family. Michael Dowling, President & CEO Richard Goldstein, Chair North Shore-LIJ Health System

There's a reason Robert Capa never married. Her name is Gerda Taro. In 2007, three flimsy cardboard boxes of negatives arrived at the International Center of Photography in New York. This was the so-called ''Mexican Suitcase,'' the lost cache of Spanish Civil War photos by Robert Capa, Gerda Taro and David Seymour. A historic discovery, the images were breathlessly trotted out by the world press, which is how the Spanish writer Susana Fortes first encountered a picture of Taro, gamine extraordinaire, asleep in Capa's pajamas. ''Artistically speaking it isn't a great shot, but a homemade one, extremely tender, the kind of photo a man in love takes of his girlfriend while she's sleeping,'' Fortes recalled.

Yoshiyuki Okada was the manager of a theme-park-like izakaya, or Japanese-style tapas bar, when, in 2001, he decided he wanted more freedom -- like the freedom to dye his hair platinum and play punk music at full volume. Okada ventured to Tokyo's modish Daikanyama neighborhood to open his own, much smaller izakaya, Tatemichiya, where customers dine on yakitori and deep-fried octopus balls to the blaring guitars of the Ramones, the Sex Pistols and Japanese punk bands like the Stalin and Cobra. Though many of Tokyo's izakayas have switched to gas or electric cooking, Okada insists on grilling with live coals. HARUMI FURUTA 1.Dry tofu for five to six hours.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Colleges Run to (Pay)daylight,'' Sept. 20'' Universities rushing to join conferences that will pay the most money underscores that Division I football and basketball are in reality professional minor leagues. Everyone cashes in but the so-called student-athletes, who are considered amateurs. They should be classified as athlete-students and receive some financial reward the way the other organizations profiting from their efforts do. Gary Lefkowitz
