Some hotels seem to have gone to the dogs -- literally. Canines are now on staff at hotels across the country, from urban addresses to rural retreats, as perks you can pet. Red Mountain Resort and Spa (redmountainresort.com) near southern St. George, Utah, offers hounds to hikers. A golden retriever named Blondie and her trainer will guide guests in four-hour treks over the sandstone trails ($59). And for those testing out pet ownership, the resort provides puppies from a local shelter free for walks, after which adoption is optional, if compelling.

PERIOD PIECES As retro mania sweeps through Budapest, the remnants of socialism are taking on an ironic sense of style. THE GOODS: Nosztalgia Bazar (Dohany utca 7; nosztalgiaetterem.hu) offers accessories, including the trademark ''T'' sneakers from Tisza Cipo, communist Hungary's answer to Adidas. The brand, which also has a flagship store (Karoly korut 1; 011-36-1-266-3055; tiszacipo.hu), was recently revived by the entrepreneur Laszlo Vidak.

The On the Street column last Sunday, about people whose clothes reflect their personalities, misidentified the man shown in several pictures wearing variations on a dark jacket. He is Marius Carluci, not Andrew Mukamal.

IN addition to Prada, Jil Sander, Dolce & Gabbana, Gucci et al, a must-see on this season's Milan Fashion Week calendar is ''Lei e le altra,'' an exhibition at the Museo della Permanente, culled from the archives of RCS Periodici, the publishing company behind titles like Max, Amica, L'Europea and the legendary but now defunct Lei. Curated by Maria Luisa Frisa and designed by Arabeschi di Latte, the dense, labyrinthlike installation presents milestones of style at every turn, from Jackie Kennedy on a Roman holiday to Françoise Hardy in '70s Yves Saint Laurent to fashion's current patron saint, Lady Gaga. But ultimately the view is panoramic, with fashion being not only a reflection of social change, but also a driving force behind it. HELENA NILSSON STRÄNGBERG

Born in New York in 1922, he was a man of many feats and passions: WWII Merchant Marine Veteran, corporate executive, ACLU activist, columnist, devoted husband and father. Survivors include wife Naomi Barnett; children Amy and Marshall Gittler and families; stepdaughter Amy Goldfarb and family; stepson Herbert; and an extended family from Ethiopia, France and the United States. (Please visit www.harveygittler.com) Donations to: Harvey Gittler Memorial Fund, Oberlin College Development Office, 50 West Lorain St., Oberlin, OH 44074. The fund will promote civil liberties.

Wen we finished editing this issue of T, which is devoted to travel, we realized that it was more about the art of the tour than the activity of tourism. Sandra Ballentine, for example, caught up with Perry Farrell and his family in Chicago (Page 36), where Lollapalooza now alights every August. The Kills -- right back on the road after Jamie Hince and Kate Moss's wedding and honeymoon -- checked in from New York with their off-gig tips (Page 17). And Casey Spooner (Page 110) provided a gorgeous and hilarious account of his band Fischerspooner's summer romp through Patagonia, Bogotá, Moscow and Berlin. (His description of the Liquidrom spa in Germany will make the stressed out among you hop on a plane right now.) But these are only a few of the tours contained in these pages. This summer Abby Aguirre traveled to Manaus, Brazil, with Diana Taylor (Page 72) and a group of her colleagues and investors in Acción International, a microfinance organization that operates in 23 countries. The formidable and beautiful Taylor was on a tour of the businesses and communities that have received financing from Acción. Aguirre's story is at once a compelling portrait of a woman of disarming intelligence and commitment, and a nuanced road map to the issues raised by microlending, both the pros and cons.

WITH the Yankees' almost-annual trip to the postseason officially booked, and the rival Red Sox fading fast, Yankees fans did their best to explode Twitter last week in a fit of joy and schadenfreude. The good cheer began on Monday, when Mariano Rivera, the team's closer, set a record for saves, recording his 602nd in a 6-4 victory over the Minnesota Twins. One fan surmised that the ballplayer had reached the pinnacle of baseball respect, posting: ''Plenty of baseball fans hate the Yankees, but I don't think any hate Mariano Rivera.''

On the day last month when the earthquake touched us so timidly, I came home late, near midnight, and parked by the cluster of tidy housing projects near my apartment in Brooklyn. In addition to public housing, South Williamsburg is home to shabby artists' lofts like mine, apartments of Hasidic Jews and one very high-priced condo. There isn't much crossover between subdivisions, but I've lived here nine years, and I know many of my neighbors. We recognize each other's faces; we stop to pet each other's dogs.

The tiny Mediterranean island of Caprera, near Sardinia, was not the sort of place to find an American diplomat in the late summer of 1861, but that's precisely where Henry Shelton Sanford landed late in the afternoon of Sept. 8. It had been a long, involved trip: he came from Brussels to Genoa by train, secretly chartered a ship to avoid public notice and, on the night of Sept. 7, sailed through the Ligurian Sea to Sardinia. Landing late the next day, he hired a small boat to take him to Caprera, then walked more than a mile on a narrow path across the rocky, windswept island.

From Oct. 7 to July 2012, the Centre Pompidou-Metz will present "Bivouac," a retrospective dedicated to the work of the designers Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec. "It's like a big family dinner where everybody shows up," says Erwan (above, seated). The family, in this case, is the brothers' radically original work, from "Lit Clos" of 2000, a raised, semi-enclosed bed like a bird cage, to "Ploum," a new sofa for Ligne Roset, which they compare to a very ripe fruit. This is the Bouroullecs' first major show in their native France, organized by ambience and demarcated by supersize versions of their room-divider designs, including the plastic seaweed-inspired "Algues" and their textile "Clouds"; one long wall will hold nearly 300 drawings. To coincide with the show, Phaidon is releasing a new monograph of their work. "We're still young, so a celebration of our career is nice but a little anxiety-inducing," said Ronan, the older of the two, who recently turned 40. "Each time we do an exhibition it feels like: that's done, let's move on to something else." That something else will be a permanent lighting installation for the Gabriel staircase in the Château de Versailles.

Catherine Rampell comments skeptically on Peter Orszag's call for delegating more policy to panels of nonpolitical experts. I'd add that this is an odd time to make such a proposal. Yes, the political world is deeply dysfunctional -- but what's equally remarkable is just how terrible the judgment of the supposed experts has been. It's not just the complete failure to foresee this crisis. Fancy international organizations have been persistently offering disastrous advice, counseling austerity and interest rate hikes just as the recovery, such as it is, stumbles. Politicians say dumb things about monetary policy -- but so does the ECB.

The new Broadway revival of the Stephen Sondheim-James Goldman musical "Follies" grossed more than $1.12 million last week, breaking into the the theatrical box office million-dollar club for the first time and edging the long-running musical "Jersey Boys" out of the Top 5 shows in ticket sales. The "Follies" windfall represents the highest one-week gross for a Broadway production with music and lyrics by Mr. Sondheim. The previous one-week high for a show by Mr. Sondheim, who has been writing Broadway shows for 55 years, was $1.03 million for the revival of "A Little Night Music" during New Year's week in 2009-10.

Postwar California provided the perfect environment for modernism to flourish. Newly available materials like machine-molded plywood combined with mass production to revolutionize furniture design; industrial steel transformed residential construction; and the region's comfortable climate invited indoor-outdoor living. This month, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art presents "California Design, 1930-1965: Living in a Modern Way," a survey of California's homegrown style including the iconic 1945-49 Eames House (a room from which will be installed as part of the exhibition), Barbie's circa 1962 Dream House (complete with cardboard hi-fi/television console) and a 1952 desk (top left) by Greta Magnusson Grossman. In New York, the Museum of Arts and Design offers a counterpoint with "Crafting Modernism" (Oct. 12 to Jan. 15, 2012), a look at the American Studio Craft Movement, which embraced traditional techniques like woodworking, weaving and silversmithing to produce radical results, like Vladimir Kagan's trippy mosaic tile table or Jan de Swart's 1965 blanket chest (top right).

Another article you have probably seen and likely talked about today appears in the Sunday Review section. In the article "Delay Kindergarten at Your Child's Peril," two neuroscientists, Sam Wang and Sandra Aamodt, take on a practice that has become increasingly popular: holding kindergarten-age children back for a year in what the authors describe as "an attempt to give them a leg up on peers." It is called redshirting (a term taken from the loophole college athletes use to prolong their eligibility), and it happens to 1 in 11 children in the kindergarten age group. Many parents have chosen to do it thinking they were helping their children. They aren't, the authors argue.

SOUTH HAVEN, Mich. -- Three thousand miles into my trans-America bicycle journey -- my odometer clicked over on Saturday -- I've finally been stymied by the weather. I had an exceedingly pleasant passage across Lake Michigan on the high-speed ferry from Milwaukee to Muskegon, during which I made occasional forays on deck to stand up to a cold wind that seemed capable of slinging me overboard. But I'm now pinned by that same wind (or so it seems) to the eastern shore of the lake, heading south. It has also been raining, so my days in the saddle have been relatively short and very damp. (Thank goodness for hot showers and motel guest laundries.) Now, though I need to turn east lest I end up back in Chicago, the rain is persisting and the wind has grown only stronger. I'm frustrated and eager to put some miles behind me, but to ride in intermittent, sometimes forceful downpours (thunderstorms are forecast) into a 15- to 20-mile-per-hour blow strikes me as foolish, or worse -- no fun.

For the L.A. artist Sarah Cain, space is more than just physical - it's also psychic and emotional. "I try to morph the three," says Cain, whose site-specific work dips into a playfully vivid palette that defies her contemplative nature. Cain used abandoned buildings to develop her style, and some of her earliest efforts, along the dirt roads of her native upstate New York, went entirely unseen. A 2004 installation in a squat in San Francisco's North Beach, however, brought her the attention of the art world. She is now represented by Honor Fraser in L.A. and Anthony Meier Fine Arts in San Francisco and was recently commissioned by LAND (Los Angeles Nomadic Division) to do an installation in a former Masonic lodge in Marfa, Tex. On view through Dec. 4 as part of a suite of public projects, "Forget Me Not" takes its name from the flower pin once worn by the Masons and later adopted by the Nazis. "Supreme Being" (above), a three-dimensional canvas bordered in gold leaf, is the only component Cain created off-site for the piece; its diagonal stripes were traced from the floorboards in her studio.

Before he earned worldwide acclaim as the creator of Sherlock Holmes, a struggling physician named Arthur Conan Doyle tried his hand at a different kind of fiction writing: a novel from the perspective of a 50-year-old man who is confined to his room when he has an attack of gout. The original manuscript of that novel, titled "The Narrative of John Smith," was lost in the mail en route to Conan Doyle's publishers, and though he later rewrote it from memory, the book was never published in his lifetime. Conan Doyle was later to remark: "My shock at its disappearance would be as nothing to my horror if it were suddenly to appear again - in print."

In fact, they're all bound for a new demonstration garden in Kameon's office and showroom.

Moises Saman returned to Libya on assignment for The New York Times shortly after the fall of Tripoli at the end of August. Since then, Mr. Saman, a nominee for membership in Magnum Photos, has had the rare opportunity to photograph more freely. That was in stark contrast to the first leg of his Libyan assignment spent in a press pool covering the forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi - at times even confined to his hotel room. Lately he has been able to roam through a different, less familiar, side of the country that has captivated him.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich. - Mitt Romney, returning to his home state this weekend, won the Michigan straw poll, picking up more than half of the 681 votes cast by Republican activists. Mr. Romney won 51 percent of the vote in the National Journal Hotline/National Association of Home Builders straw poll, whose results were released early Sunday, far surpassing Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who finished second with 17 percent. Herman Cain, the former chief executive of Godfather's Pizza, who finished first in Florida's straw poll this weekend, was third with 9 percent of the vote.

OKUN--Lola B. On September 24. Wife of the late Irwin, mother of Beth and Todd, grandmother of Elissa, Brooke, Joshua and Sarah, great-grandmother of Jillian, Mallory, Hazel, Owen and Lucas. Interment at New Montefiore Cemetery in Pinelawn.

Jaws dropped in Hollywood on Sunday: For the second weekend in a row, a 17-year-old movie, ''The Lion King,'' was No. 1 at the North American box office. That animated film, re-released by Walt Disney Studios in 3-D, took in an estimated $22 million for a two-week total of $61.7 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. ''Moneyball,'' which stars Brad Pitt in the true story of a baseball underdog, was a strong second with an estimated $20.6 million in ticket sales. Sony Pictures Entertainment spent about $50 million to make ''Moneyball,'' which avoided the dreaded sports-movie pigeonhole with rave reviews and a well-oiled marketing campaign.

CRAMER--Carol Ann. Died September 7, 2011, of a cerebral aneurysm at her home in Manhattan, nine days before her 62nd birthday. Carol was an inveterate city person, who devoured the arts and ideas of the 20th/21st century and was an early supporter of native Cuban artists. Most recently associated with CATM Gallery in Chelsea, she previously owned a gallery in Great Barrington, MA. Carol attended The Fieldston School, NYU, and UC Berkeley and held an MFA from Columbia University Film School. Predeceased by her parents Dr. Joseph B. Cramer and Hope Woronock Cramer and sister Mai (Marcia) Cramer Ward, she is survived by her brother-in-law Peter, aunt E. Jane Woronock Szathmary, uncle Martin G. Cramer, many cousins and friends, and especially her childhood friend Beth Copeland Williams. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Arthritis Foundation or Amnesty International. A memorial service celebrating her life will be held at the Cuban Art Space, 231 W. 29th St., #

FINK--Rebecca, passed away at age 95 on September 22, 2011 at her home in Boca Raton, Florida peacefully, surrounded by her family and dedicated nurses. The daughter of Pearl Margolis and Cantor Jacob Margolis, sister of the late Yona, Dora, Geula, Bela, and Jon. She proudly graduated from Freeport High School, Pratt College, and went to work in the fledgling Manhattan fashion industry as a dress designer. A beauty with unmatched intellect, with a strong religious background ventured out into the secular world. She married her polar opposite, Dr. Benjamin Fink, in 1939, and soon was left stateside to raise as a single Jewish woman in a backward South, two children, Gerald and Robert, while her husband served in the South Pacific, punctuated by conjugal visits to Rebecca from 1939-1946. Following WWII, they settled in Freeport, NY, where Ben was the ultra-dedicated GP whose office was adjacent to their home. Rebecca and Ben raised four children, of whom she was proud: Dr. Gerald Fink (Dr. Rosalie), Dr. Robert Fink (Geri), Dr. Alan Fink (Phyllis), Dr. Janet Kowal (Dr. Robert). She is also survived by her loving grandchildren: Julia Feldman (Uri), Dr. Jennifer Fink (Sarah Sohn), Peninah Salad (Rabbi Jay), Deena Taggert (Nissim), Anna Kaminetsky (Shimon), and Sara Wachtel (Jonathan), Dr. Gregg Fink (Jennifer), Matthew Fink, Dr. Rachel Kowal (Matt Feldman), Brian Kowal (Lorin), as well as 33 great-grandchildren. She raised her family and her husband with love, discipline and loyalty that never changed to the day she died. An extremely private woman, she mastered every challenge she came in contact with: fashion design, painting, cooking, fishing, and remaining a loyal sorority sister for over 50 years. Moving to Florida in the 1970s with Ben and many of their childhood and college friends, she enjoyed the sunshine, easy friendships, the sporadic visits of her working children, and the attention of many of her grandchildren. Her loyalty to her family, her intellectual rigor, her amazing fish dishes, and her proud independence will never be forgotten by those who knew her. A remarkable woman, she was helped immensely to reach 95 by the love of her grandson, Brian Kowal, granddaughter Peninah Salad, and aid/friend Rythnade Sylvain. Contributions can be made in her honor to Ruth Rales Jewish Family Service of South Palm Beach County, 7901 W. Atlantic Ave., Delray Beach, FL 33446.

One of the most telling moments of Mark Zuckerberg's presentation Thursday morning in San Francisco was a reference to a technology company he said he deeply admired. It wasn't Apple, though his turn on stage seemed to lift several pages from the Steve Jobs playbook. It wasn't Google, from which he has plucked some of his key lieutenants. Rather, it was Intel, the world's biggest microprocessor maker. Its co-founder, Gordon E. Moore, is credited with the observation that computer processing power doubles every 18 months. We now know that it doubles even faster. We know too that the logic he so astutely articulated fueled inexorable changes in technology, commerce and life as we know it.

Warby Parker has surprised skeptics by building a business that sells stylish prescription eyeglasses online. Now it has raised $12 million in venture capital, bringing its total to $13.5 million, to help it expand and manage the demand for the glasses. The money came from Tiger Global, the Menlo Talent Fund and existing investors including Lerer Ventures, Thrive Capital and First Round Capital.

CANTOR--Myron D. (Mike), died peacefully at home September 24, 2011 at 97 years of age. Grew up in New Jersey. Earned a BA (1935), LLD (1937) Cornell University Member New Jersey Bar, later Macy's executive training program. WWII, Ensign U.S. Naval Reserves. Ran Wonder Store and later founded clothing company Mity Togs. Taught business New School, wrote How to Own and Operate Your Own Small Store (1979). Original player vocals and Guitar Jazz at Noon founded 1962, group played in Manhattan. Married Delia Heming Cantor (1959). Survived by wife Delia Scarsdale NY; six children Jane Kauffman New York, NY, Frank Cantor Boulder, CO, Daniel Cantor Watertown, MA, Peter Naumburg Albuquerque, NM, Eric Naumburg,M.D. Columbia, MD, Elizabeth Naumburg, M.D. Rochester, NY; 19 grandchildren, 11 great-grandchildren.

Mr. Pitt has had 11 films that have earned more than $125 million, including ''The Curious Case of Benjamin Button,'' which opened Christmas Day in 2008 -- a Thursday -- took in $28.3 million its first weekend, and eventually $134 million, and ''Seven,'' which had an opening weekend total of $20.7 million in September 1995 and went on to attract $149 million. The reignited effort by Republican activists and donors to persuade Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey to run for president may say more about the jittery state of the party's major financial backers than it does about any possibility Mr. Christie will change his mind and announce a campaign. The Christie-focused lobbying effort took on new life on Friday. It was based this time on poor reviews of Gov. Rick Perry's performance in the Fox News/Google debate on Thursday night, which sent a wave of anxiety through the ranks of activists and donors who were looking to Mr. Perry, of Texas, as an alternative to the other leading candidate, former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts.

COHN--Ernest A, on September 22, 2011. Beloved husband of the late Hedva. Dear brother of the late Herta Chesny, Edith Schlesinger and Hans Collins. Devoted uncle of Miriam Chesny, Ilana Favero and the late Harry Chesny. Services were held.

AMATO--Robert A. Robert A. Amato, died on September 19, 2011. He was born on June 17, 1931 in Corona, New York and grew up in Bayside, New York. He lived for many of his years in Garden City, New York and New York City. He was a long term resident of East Hampton, New York and Palm Beach, Florida. He passed away as a result of an unknown ischemic event, and fell into a coma from which he never recovered. In many ways he lived the American dream. He graduated from Bayside High and worked in the family garage door business in Maspeth, New York. He served his countryduring the Korean War in the U.S. Air Force. Seeking greener pastures, the arc of his life changed dramatically when he chose a white-collar career. He began his transformation with General Binding Corp., the Yellow pages and eventually landed at Jobson Publishing Corporation. At the retirement of the founder Frank Jobson, with little capital, but much spirit and spunk, he spearheaded a leveraged buy-out of Jobson Publishing. Under his astute and streetwise leadership, he grew Jobson Publishing from a small 10-person liquor industry publisher, into a 400+ employee market leader in the international healthcare marketplace. He became a respected industry visionary in the worldwide eyecare and eyewear market. One of the founders of The Vision Industry Council of America, now The VisionCouncil, he was instrumental in developing the International Vision Expo shows, now among the most well attended and important in the industry. He was honored for his leadership with The Ben Robinson Award by the United Jewish Appeal (UJA). He retired in May 2005 and Jobson's continued market leadership is a symbol of his business legacy. He traveled the world, but found his greatest joy in the company of his family. His true love and constant companion was his wife of 23 years, Nancy Amato, who survives him. He is also survived by his children, Janet Moffitt (Rick Ringhausen), Robert S. Amato (Anne), Ronald J. Amato (Jeanne), Roger C. Amato (Debra) and Jill Wilkins (Chris). Additionally he leaves behind his 13 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He will be deeply missed by all who loved him. Apassionate believer in the transformative nature of education, Bob created the Robert & Nancy Amato Education Foundation, to support the college education of disadvantaged children. A memorial service will be held Friday September 30, 2011 at the Frank Campbell Funeral home, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st and Madison), NYC at 11:30 am. In Lieu of flowers the family requests donations be made to The Wounded Warriors (www.wounded warriorproject.org) or SmileTrain (www.smiletrain.org).

CHRISTENFELD--Florence Ruderman, 94, of Woodbridge, CT, and formerly of New York, New York, and Budd Lake, NJ, passed away on September 23, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Leonard Christenfeld and mother to Sharon (Gilbert) Wise of New York, NY, Loren (Debra) Christenfeld of Tucson, AZ, Tina (Gerald) Weiner of Woodbridge, CT, Keri (Ted) Hurwitz of Gaithersburg, MD, and the late Devry Christenfeld; cherished grandmother to Avery Wise of Charlotte, NC, Aubrey Wise of New York, NY, Evan (Dawn) Weiner of New York, NY, Leigh (Eliot) Marchant of New York, NY, and Marin Weiner of Portland, ME; loving great-grandmother to Morgan and Jake Weiner, and Quinn and Eliza Marchant; beloved aunt to Glenn, Joanne, Alex, and Zachary Bayer of Westport, CT, and Neil, Cathy, Gillian, Carolyn, and Daniel Bayer of Miami, FL. Devoted daughter of the late Jacob and Molly Ruderman, she was predeceased by her sister Gloria (Robert) Bayer and her brother Warren (Carol) Ruderman. She was a graduate of Tilden High School (Brooklyn), and City College of New York, NY. An avid reader, skilled knitter, and lover of opera, her vivacious personality and love of life will be missed by her family and friends. A private ceremony will be held at Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Griffin Hospital Development Fund, 130 Division Street, Derby, CT 06418 in Florence's memory.

KEY PLAY Giants linebacker Michael Boley stuffed Eagles running back LeSean McCoy in the backfield on a critical fourth-and-1 in the fourth quarter. Eagles Coach Andy Reid's controversial decision not to punt with just over 11 minutes remaining led to the go-ahead touchdown. Boley said he read McCoy's cut before leveling him for a 3-yard loss. ''He tried to get out the back door, but I was right there,'' Boley said. NOTABLE NUMBER The Eagles had possession for 36 minutes 51 seconds, an overwhelming amount of time for the Giants' defense to be on the field. But the Eagles could not take advantage, running 21 more offensive plays than the Giants but converting on only one of five trips into the red zone.

Stephen Mueller, a New York painter who expanded and refined the vocabulary of 1960s Color Field painting into deliriously buoyant mystical-comic works, died on Sept. 16 in Manhattan. He was 63. The cause was cancer, his sister, Debra Pendleton, said.

NOTABLE NUMBER The Jets seemed surprised that the Raiders shifted their coverage, favoring zone instead of man-to-man. Many of their receivers were shut down through three quarters. Plaxico Burress grabbed the first pass Mark Sanchez threw, then nothing again until midway through the fourth quarter, when he snared two, including a 16-yard touchdown that drew the Jets to 31-24. Santonio Holmes was targeted only twice. KEY PERFORMANCE The Jets at least had an encouraging day by Colin Baxter, who replaced the injured Nick Mangold at center. Baxter didn't make any glaring mistakes -- no fumbled exchanges with Mark Sanchez or penalties. The offensive line as a whole helped the Jets run the ball better than they have all season, at least at certain points. If Mangold cannot play next week, the Jets could do worse than having Baxter play again.

Just how attuned are television producers these days to chatter about their shows on Twitter? So much so that they watched in awe, half a world away, as two Twitter users saved a team on ''The Amazing Race'' from being kicked off the CBS show. The 19th season of the race-around-the-world reality show had just started taping in June in Southern California when one of the contestants, Kaylani Paliotta, unknowingly left her passport at a gas station. The camera crew with Ms. Paliotta and her teammate, Lisa Tilley, noticed what had been left behind, but could not tell them. Instead, they sent word to producers at the next stop, Los Angeles International Airport, to expect a premature end to the team's race.

WASHINGTON - Insiders could spot the constraints on Lamar Alexander in the Senate at least six years ago, as the two parties fought over judicial nominations. After a series of Democratic filibusters against the nominees of President George W. Bush, Senator Alexander helped start the bipartisan ''Gang of 14'' that worked to forestall the Republicans' ''nuclear option,'' which would have eliminated the use of filibusters to block judicial appointments. But he could not publicly join the group.

It's usually busy behind the deli counter at the Milano Market, on Broadway near 113th Street in Morningside Heights. So some of the workers who leave their cars at metered parking spaces out front have always relied on Steve Hann, a sidewalk book vendor, to replenish the meters throughout the day. ''They'd give me a handful of quarters every morning and I'd feed the meter for them, no big deal'' said Mr. Hann, who has been selling books at the location for more than 20 years. In return, the deli workers would keep Mr. Hann well-caffeinated with free coffee, making him something of a professional meter feeder, depositing coins every hour - most recently, it was four quarters for an hour.

Redskins (2-0) at Cowboys (1-1), 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPN Line: Cowboys by 5 The Redskins have been waiting a long time to deliver a hearty ''I told you so,'' so they can be forgiven for a little premature self-congratulation over their perfect start. Rex Grossman called Santana Moss, Jabar Gaffney and Anthony Armstrong ''the best wide receiving corps in the league,'' which must mean he has not had a look at the Patriots, the Jets, the Eagles, the Packers, the Saints or about 20 other N.F.L. teams.

Europe won the Solheim Cup for the first time since 2003, finishing powerfully to beat the United States, 15- 13, at Killeen Castle in Dunsany, Ireland. Suzann Pettersen of Norway turned the momentum Europe's way when she recovered from 1 down with birdies on the last three holes to beat Michelle Wie by one hole. Her win left Europe needing just 1 point from the last two singles to win the trophy. The sides were tied, 8-8, entering Sunday's 12 singles matches, but Europe received a boost when Cristie Kerr of the United States had to forfeit her match with Karen Stupples of England because of a wrist injury. TUNKHANNOCK, Pa. -- Standing in the living room of their house, now full of mud, slime and debris, Helen and Peter Kelly cannot believe that Congress is bickering over disaster aid to people like them. The roaring waters of the Susquehanna River burst into their home more than two weeks ago. ''Water -- you work with it every day, and then it destroys your whole life,'' Mrs. Kelly said.

Mrs. Gray was born and raised in New Rochelle, NY. She lived in Manhasset, NY for forty-three years, moving to Montclair, NJ in 2002. New England has scored at least 30 points in 11 straight games, three shy of the record held by the 1999-2000 Rams.

"Quirky but serious" is how the architect George L. Legendre describes "Pasta by Design" (Thames & Hudson, $30), his taxonomy of 92 noodles, from the itty-bitty acini de pepe to ziti. Legendre shares his South London office with a fellow architect and inveterate pasta preparer, Marco Guarnieri, who gave him the idea to catalog with mathematical exactitude the difference between, say, fusilli and fusilli Capri. (The latter is longer, but both go great with a ragù.) Home cooks might blanch at the CAD-style schematics and trigonometric equations, but they can nonetheless appreciate that each pasta profile comes with cooking times and serving suggestions.

Suge Knight, the founder of Death Row Records who played a leading role during a turbulent and violent period of hip-hop history, will the be subject of a feature-length documentary on Showtime, the network announced Tuesday. The filmmakers said Mr. Knight had agreed to give extensive interviews about his life and the rapid rise and slow fall of his record label; he is also producing a soundtrack for the film. The film will be directed by Antoine Fuqua, who directed "Training Day" and "Brooklyn's Finest," and will be produced by Bradley J. Fischer, who produced "Black Swan" and "Shutter Island." No release date has been announced.

Small-business owners are often described in monolithic terms. But as I rediscovered during a conversation with three women who run companies, their goals and motivations tend to vary. When I met recently with Jessica Johnson, Susan Parker and Carissa Reiniger of our newly formed business group, we talked about their long-term goals. (Alexandra Mayzler, the fourth member of the group, couldn't make the meeting.) I was particularly curious about their thoughts and attitudes about eventually exiting the companies that they or their families - in the cases of Ms. Johnson and Ms. Parker - built.

"I've always made stuff and wanted to know how things worked," says Bethan Laura Wood, a 28-year-old British product designer who studied under Martino Gamper and Jurgen Bey, and whose work was featured with that of her mentors at the cutting-edge Milan gallery Nilufar in April. Wood takes nuts-and-bolts materials to fantastic places; her Moon Rock tables are inlaid with laser-cut plastic laminate, as is her Particle jewelry (shown here), inspired by lowly particle board. Wood's own look, a confection of glitter, pattern and wrapping, has evolved since her teen years from a defense against bullying classmates ("I thought I'd give them a reason") into a form of play. Look for Wood at the Pavilion of Art & Design London show this month.

Shakira, the pop diva from Colombia, will be honored as the person of the year at the Latin Grammys in November. The president of the Latin Recording Academy, Gabriel Abaroa Jr., said the singer was being honored for her philanthropic work as well as her successful recording career. At 34, Shakira is the youngest person to receive the tribute from the 12-year-old group, which was formed to present a Latin version of the Grammy awards. Past recipients have included Carlos Santana, Julio Iglesias, Gloria Estefan and Ricky Martin. One of the most successful Latin artists to cross over into English-speaking radio, Shakira has won two Grammys and three Latin Grammys. She enjoyed a world-wide smash hit in 2006 with "Hips Don't Lie." She has done charity work since she was 18 years old, when she started the Pies Descalzos Foundation, an organization that provides schools to poor children in Colombia.

The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington said it would replace the long-maligned organ in its concert hall with a new 5,000-pipe instrument built by Casavant Frères of St-Hyacinthe, Quebec. The existing organ, which was built by Aeolian-Skinner and installed in 1972, has been criticized by performers and reviewers for its poor functioning and musical inadequacy. A 1997 renovation of the hall made the problems worse. "It was getting to the point where it was ruining performances," said Jeff Weiler, an organ consultant hired by the Kennedy Center. The new organ will be installed starting next summer, with a 61-pipe stop incorporated from its predecessor.  The instrument will cost more than $2 million, the Kennedy Center said. David M. Rubenstein, the Kennedy Center's chairman and the managing director of the Carlyle Group, a private equity firm, is paying for the new organ and its installation.

For the second year in a row, an iconic modernist chair has been transformed by a star-studded roster of designers to benefit the Breast Cancer Research Foundation. Following the success of its Pink Wishbone Project, in which designers put their own spin on Hans Wegner's classic Wishbone chair, SUITE New York, the Manhattan design showroom that is the project's mastermind, organized the Pink Swan Project for 2011. It lets 18 A-listers in design, fashion and architecture loose on Arne Jacobsen's Swan chair, which is manufactured by the Danish company Fritz Hansen. The one-of-a-kind chairs will be up for auction from Oct. 1 to Oct. 31 on CharityBuzz.

7:23 p.m. | Updated Robert Socolow of Princeton University has written "Wedges Reaffirmed," an essay published today by The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists and Climate Central. The piece examines lessons he's learned since he and a colleague, Stephen Pacala, co-authored "Stabilization Wedges: Solving the Climate Problem for the Next 50 Years with Current Technologies" in 2004. The influential paper, published in Science, divided the challenge of keeping emissions of greenhouse gases through mid-century at levels prevailing in the 2000s into seven "wedges" of carbon dioxide reductions -- through switching to renewable and nuclear power, ramping up energy efficiency, ending deforestation and taking action in other areas. (The new essay adds two wedges because the scope of the challenge has grown in the last seven years.)

The artist Karen Kilimnik tends to work in small, intimate canvases and props, tackling subjects like Kate Moss or the battles of Napoleon with seeming fairy tale romance. For "Psyché," a new production choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky for the Paris Opera Ballet, Kilimnik started from a selection of pre-existing paintings to create five massive, dreamlike backdrops, including an enchanting, moonlit forest and a garden resplendent with clouds, flowers and perfume bottles. She then augmented these with rhinestones, glitter and, for good measure, a host of two-dimensional objects like the five-foot snail that enters and exits the stage at various points during the performance. Being able to work on this scale was a dream in itself. "It was wonderful," she said.

Paul Barbera shoots slick interiors for clients like Elle Decoration and Vogue Living. But before he ventured into the studios of the 32 designers in his new book "Where They Create" (Frame Publishers, $45), he begged them not to clean up. "It's not like messy wall, messy table, pencil on floor and rubbish near door equals great artist," Barbera insists, but those intimate details make for rich material. Matali Crasset's personal library, Maarten Baas's prototypes and even the crudely fashioned cardboard strip that keeps Confetti System's air-conditioner from jostling its hand-cut garlands reveal what it's really like inside a designer's world.

The Common Sense column on Saturday, about a series of ethical and legal lapses at the global bank UBS, misstated the legal status of Jérôme Kerviel, the former Société Générale trader convicted in a trading scandal at that bank. He was sentenced to three years for unauthorized trading but remains free pending appeal; he is not in prison.

The new Broadway revival of the Stephen Sondheim-James Goldman musical ''Follies'' grossed more than $1.12 million last week, breaking into the the theatrical box office million-dollar club for the first time and edging the long-running musical ''Jersey Boys'' out of the Top 5 shows in ticket sales. The ''Follies'' windfall represents the highest one-week gross for a Broadway production with music and lyrics by Mr. Sondheim. The previous one-week high for a show by Mr. Sondheim, who has been writing Broadway shows for 55 years, was $1.03 million for the revival of ''A Little Night Music'' during New Year's week in 2009-10. Like ''Follies,'' which opened on Sept. 12 to strong reviews, most Broadway musicals and plays made gains at the box office last week after the traditional post-Labor Day slide, according to data compiled and released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade association for theater owners and producers. The 22 shows now running grossed a total of $18.5 million, up from $16 million the previous week and $14.6 million for the comparable week last season.

REICHERT--Helen Faith Keane, peacefully at home on September 25, 2011 at the age of 109. A native New Yorker, born November 11, 1901, and known as "Happy," she was a proud member of the first Girl Scouts Troop who sold WWI war bonds outside the NY Public Library. Graduate of Cornell University BA '25, and Columbia University MA '31, Happy began her career as a copywriter and educator. In 1949, she founded as a voice for women, The Round Table of Fashion Executives, and in 1951, hosted TV talk show, "FYI: The Helen Faith Keane Show," on Channel 5, winning McCall's Magazine Golden Microphone Award for outstanding broadcasting service to women. She joined The Graduate School of Retailing at NYU in 1947 to teach, "Costume History," a course she created. Former students, calling her Professor Keane, became lifelong friends. Women, whose business lives she impacted, continually called for her creative input. Happy was predeceased by her husband, Philip Reichert M.D., founding member in 1949 of The American College of Cardiology, and her sister, Lee. She is survived by brothers, Irving and Peter, sister-in-law Beth, many nieces and nephews, and devoted caregiver, Olive Villaluna. In lieu of flowers, Happy, as an advocate of education, can be honored by donations to Cornell Medical College. An avid piano player, world traveler, theatergoer, scholar of history, and fan of Central Park since her childhood, Happy lived a remarkable multi-talented life. Happy are we to have called her our friend, and to have shared her laughter and her love.

REICHERT--Helen "Happy." Shareholders, Directors and Officers of 480 Park Avenue Corporation announce with sorrow the passing of our oldest shareholder Helen Reichert at the age of 109. She will be deeply missed by all.

An article on Saturday about the United States' pressuring Europe to act more firmly on its debt crisis misspelled the surname of the French finance minister, who referred to continuing policy deliberations. He is François Baroin, not Baron.

An article on Sept. 13 about a visit to France by President Paul Kagame of Rwanda erroneously attributed a distinction to the visit. While it was the first time since the 1994 Rwanda genocide that Mr. Kagame had met with President Nicolas Sarkozy in an official bilateral visit to France, it was not Mr. Kagame's ''first visit to France since the genocide.'' (He visited during the 40-nation Afrique Summit meeting held in Nice in June 2010 and met with Mr. Sarkozy then as well.)

Goldman Sachs, bracing for what could be one of its worst quarters since it went public 12 years ago, is preparing to expand its cost-cutting initiative by hundreds of millions of dollars, a move that could lead to additional job losses at the Wall Street bank. This summer, Goldman said that it would wring out $1.2 billion in costs from its operations by mid-2012 and cut roughly 1,000 jobs, about 3 percent of its work force. But as the market turmoil has weighed on trading and other businesses in recent weeks, senior executives have been debating even deeper reductions, according to people briefed on the matter who were not authorized to speak publicly.

On Sept. 15, just in time for the opening of the United Nations General Assembly, City Room asked a question: What nation that you probably wouldn't hear about would you like to hear about? Or, more precisely, what nation's diplomats would you like to find out about? One nation that came to mind was Malawi, one of the world's poorest countries. It was last in the news in July when antigovernment protests left at least 19 people dead. The president, Bingu wa Mutharika, a former World Bank economist who had been credited with reducing hunger in his country of 16 million, tired of dissent and demonstrations and warned that he did not want protesters returning to the streets. ''I'll go after you,'' he was quoted as saying. ''Even if you hide in holes, I'll smoke you out.''

The protracted conflict betweenCharlie Sheen and Warner Brothers Television ended quietly on Monday when the two sides agreed to settle a lawsuit the actor filed after the studio fired him from the hit CBS sitcom, ''Two and a Half Men.'' Warner Brothers issued a statement saying that the settlement had been agreed ''to the parties' mutual satisfaction.'' Mr. Sheen had also sued the comedy's executive producer, Chuck Lorre, and that action was also settled by the agreement. No terms were disclosed and the statement said all the parties had ''agreed to maintain confidentiality over the terms.''

NEW BOARD MEMBER Chelsea Clinton, below, has joined the board of IAC/InterActiveCorp, the Internet media company controlled by Barry Diller. A securities filing issued on Monday disclosed that Ms. Clinton, 31, is now a director of the company, whose portfolio of Web sites includes the Daily Beast, CollegeHumor and Match.com. It also publishes Newsweek magazine. Mr. Diller, the chief executive of IAC, was a supporter of Ms. Clinton's father, Bill Clinton, in the 1992 presidential election. He also supported Hillary Rodham Clinton's presidential campaign. PETER LATTMAN

An opera about Sun Yat-sen, China's first president and Nationalist leader, has been canceled shortly before its scheduled opening at the National Center for the Performing Arts in Beijing because of official objections to the music, according to the composer's representatives. The work, ''Dr. Sun Yat-sen'' by Huang Ruo and a production of Opera Hong Kong, was to have opened on Friday, roughly coinciding celebrations of the 100th anniversary of the Chinese revolution. Mr. Ruo's management, Karsten Witt Music Management in Berlin, said a government official had gone to rehearsals and decided that the music was inappropriate. ''I guess because maybe it's not romantic enough, something like that,'' said an agency representative, who spoke on condition of anonymity because she was not Mr. Ruo's individual agent. The representative said the objection was not over the content. The government long knew of the subject matter and had the libretto, she said. ''I suppose they wanted something to glorify'' the subject more, the representative said. ''In fact, it's not at all too avant-garde.''

Although final audience numbers were not yet available on Monday, the ''Sunday Night Football'' game (the Pittsburgh Steelers defeated the Indianapolis Colts 23-20) once again carried NBC to a ratings victory. Among scripted entertainment shows, the series premiere of ''Pan Am'' on ABC took off with 10.9 million total viewers, a higher total audience than its lead in, ''Desperate Housewives'' (9.8 million viewers). A new timeslot and an Emmy win for Julianna Margulies (not to mention a dynamite new haircut, with bangs) did not translate to a ratings increase for ''The Good Wife'' on CBS. That legal drama attracted 10.5 million viewers, down from 12.9 million for last season's premiere episode. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Before he earned worldwide acclaim as the creator of Sherlock Holmes, a struggling physician named Arthur Conan Doyle tried his hand at a different kind of fiction writing: a novel from the perspective of a 50-year-old man who is confined to his room when he has an attack of gout. The original manuscript of that novel, titled ''The Narrative of John Smith,'' was lost in the mail en route to Conan Doyle's publishers, and though he later rewrote it from memory, the book was never published in his lifetime. Conan Doyle was later to remark: ''My shock at its disappearance would be as nothing to my horror if it were suddenly to appear again - in print.'' So Conan Doyle might want to brace himself, wherever he is. On Monday the British Library is releasing ''The Narrative of John Smith,'' representing the first time the novel will be available to a wide audience; the library will also display the manuscript at its Sir John Ritblat Treasures Gallery in London. A news release from the British Library said that the novel was written between 1883 and 1884 and described it as ''semi-autobiographical in nature,'' comprising the title character's ''reflections and conversations with his doctor, friends and other visitors concerning a range of contemporary debates on literature, science, religion, war and politics.'' When Conan Doyle wrote ''A Study in Scarlet'' a few years later, he retained some elements from ''John Smith,'' including the character's talkative landlady, Mrs. Rundle, who seems to be a precursor to Sherlock Holmes's Baker Street housekeeper, Mrs. Hudson.

8 P.M. (ESPN) CATCHING HELL (2011) On Oct. 14, 2003, elated Chicago Cubs fans believed they would host a World Series for the first time since 1945, as the team led the Florida Marlins, 3-0, in the eighth inning of Game 6 of the National League Championship Series at Wrigley Field. And then Steve Bartman, reaching for a foul pop fly from his seat in the stands, above, deflected the ball away from the Cubs' left fielder Moises Alou and set the stage for an eight-run rally by the Marlins -- and in the process became the focus of rage from fellow Cubs fans. Telling the story is the director Alex Gibney, whose ''Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room'' was nominated in 2005 for an Oscar for best documentary feature, which he went on to win with ''Taxi to the Dark Side'' in 2007. 8 P.M. (Fox) GLEE Shelby Corcoran (Idina Menzel) returns to McKinley High and performs ''Somewhere'' from ''West Side Story'' with Rachel (Lea Michele, near left, with Ms. Menzel), her biological daughter. In ''New Girl,'' at 9, the guys help Jess (Zooey Deschanel) retrieve her stuff from her ex's apartment, just as their old roommate, Winston (Lamorne Morris), moves back into the loft after a stint playing basketball abroad. And in ''Raising Hope,'' at 9:30, Sabrina (Shannon Woodward) is forced to introduce the Chance family to her father (Stephen Root).

Jim Himes, a second-term congressman from Connecticut, is a surviving member of one of Washington's most endangered species: a Democrat with Wall Street ties. A former Goldman Sachs banker whose district includes the hedge fund capitals of Greenwich and Stamford, Conn., Mr. Himes understands the world of high finance better than most of his Congressional peers. And lately, as a series of contentious regulatory and tax proposals has brought the moneyed class under fire, he has been playing the part of a Wall Street whisperer, trying to bring well-heeled Democrats in the financial industry back to the party that has made villains of them.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art, which has been trying to rebrand itself over the last year as a visitor-friendly art behemoth, unveiled a redesigned Web site on Monday, the first time the site has been thoroughly updated in more than a decade. It includes several new features that are beginning to become standard for large museums, like a zoomable, clickable floor plan similar to one the Art Institute of Chicago created two years ago. The Met's version allows prospective visitors to look closely at almost 400 galleries to see what to expect, and visitors already at the museum to use smartphones on parts of the site to find their way to favorite artworks.

With the love of her family and support of her husband, Dr. Gianpaolo (Paul) Maestrone, who served as APDA's director of scientific and medical affairs for 20 years, she helped expand it into the country's largest grassroots organization serving Americans with Parkinson's disease, their families and caregivers. Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has signed its first multiyear agreement with City Center, according to officials of the two companies who were scheduled to announce that arrangement on Tuesday. Ailey, which is now approaching its 40th season at City Center on West 55th Street, cemented the relationship by agreeing to a 10-year, nonexclusive contract that names the company as the hall's principal dance company. The center will also provide major support toward commissioning a new Ailey work each year.

Sometime this year -- if it hasn't already happened -- the world population will reach seven billion. Many of those people lack the sophisticated medical care taken for granted in the industrial world, and they are still getting sick and dying from diseases that have been all but eradicated in countries like the United States. One way to address the problem is to make drugs and vaccines available to everyone, but in many countries that remains an expensive dream. So what to do? This special issue is devoted to low-cost innovations that are making a big difference.

In response to the question posed in my previous essay in The Stone — “What is naturalism?”  — Alex Rosenberg defines it as “the philosophical theory that treats science as our most reliable source of knowledge and scientific method as the most effective route to knowledge.” His post, “Why I Am a Naturalist,” nicely exemplifies one of my main complaints, by leaving it unclear what he means by “science” or “scientific method,” even though it is crucial for what he is committing himself to as a “naturalist.” Still, there are clues. He describes “the test of knowledge that scientific findings attain” as “experimental/observational methods,” which suggests that theorems of mathematics would not count as scientific findings. The impression is confirmed by Professor Rosenberg’s phrase “mathematicians and scientists,” as though he doesn’t see mathematicians as scientists. That’s bad news for his naturalism, for mathematical proof is just as effective a route to knowledge as experimental/observational methods. Of course, since the natural sciences depend on mathematics, Rosenberg desires to find a place for it — but admits that he doesn’t know how.

Beijing Design Week, which runs from Sept. 26 to Oct. 3, will showcase more than 2,000 works from some 30 countries - and, perhaps more significant, it will highlight China's resolve to become a cultural superpower. Installations span the city, from the 751 industrial district and the sleek Sanlitun neighborhood to the China Millennium Monument, where the British designer Paul Cocksedge's massive piece - 30 sheets of rolled steel engraved with classical Chinese and English poetry - anchors this year's "Guest City" and embodies the week's spirit of aesthetic exchange. The week also marks the opening of the First Beijing International Design Triennial, organized around the theme of "Ren: Good Design" and held at the National Museum of China. Ren, which loosely translates as "caring for others," locates curatorial efforts in a communal context that jibes, at least ideologically, with the country's political principles and sets a positive agenda for the hothouse environment of contemporary China.

With its shimmering vision of a fairy-tale realm where grace and good manners prevail, Oliver Messel's production of "The Sleeping Beauty" for Sadler's Wells (later the Royal) Ballet, in 1946, raised the curtain on London's postwar recovery and held a mirror to England's sense of pride. When the ballet was performed at the Metropolitan Opera House in New York three years later, applause greeted the scenery - a magnificent palace extending into the wings and beyond, set in a stately park among ancient trees. "The Sleeping Beauty" was such a success that Messel never lived it down. For decades, it has been the basis of his reputation, and so irresistible and magical is its spell that, had he done nothing else, it would have been enough.

American Ballet Theater is taking its traditions into a center of the dance world. The company said on Wednesday that it would present a weeklong course on its training techniques in St. Petersburg, Russia, home of the Mariinsky Theater - the former Kirov - and a venerable part of ballet history. Ballet Theater will hold the five-day session starting on Oct. 31 to present its national training curriculum, which the company said had certified 550 teachers across the United States since 2008, when it began. The curriculum combines "artistic training with the basics of dancer health and child development," Ballet Theater said. The news follows a recent announcement that one of the company's stars, David Hallberg, would take on a principal dancer position with the Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow, the first American in such a role.

Getting a read on the city of Los Angeles has never been easy. Twenty years ago, when my husband was offered a job in L.A., we left New York. I figured that as a writer, my work was portable, and as an urbanite, I would easily adjust. But Los Angeles, with its shifting perspectives and unwieldy size, was perplexing. When we first arrived, I spoke with an architectural historian on the verge of relocating. He offered me one salient tip before making his exit: "The two most interesting things about Los Angeles," he said, "are the domestic architecture and the ephemeral population." He was right: the stream of characters is constant, and the number of exceptional houses is astonishing. And as the critic Reyner Banham had so famously done before me, I got my driver's license, began reading Esther McCoy and learned to love Los Angeles.

"Working in Africa opens doors of my subconscious more widely, my dreams are very vivid when I'm there," says Viviane Sassen, whose photographs are on view as part of the New Photography series at MoMA. Sassen, who is Dutch, grew up in Kenya; lately she has used her medium as a form of self-analysis, creating graphic, color-saturated compositions that mine her childhood memories but also underscore her status as an outsider in a part of the world she will always consider home. In "Alpha," two young men cross paths in the street, but one, completely darkened to a silhouette, could be viewed as the wayward shadow of the other. In "Parasomnia," which is also the title of the series, a man who may or may not be asleep has tipped over in his chair, but Sassen has rotated the image so that he almost appears to be in free fall. "I try to make images that confuse me," she says. "And I hope they confuse others, too."

There are so many iPod, iPhone and iPad docks out there it makes you wonder if manufacturers have given up supporting other phones and portable media players. Live hyperlinks are great for whisking you to the Web in a hurry, but addresses formatted as regular text still require cutting and pasting into the browser to get you to the page. If you use Mozilla Firefox or Google's Chrome browser, you can save a step. After copying the Web address from text, right click on the browser's address bar and choose the "Paste and Go" option to automatically zip over to that page.

BERRY--Nancy Davison, daughter of Annette and Daniel Davison, devoted mother and loving wife, passed away last Thursday morning at her home in New York City. Her vibrant spirit and generous nature will be missed and celebrated by all who knew her. She is survived by her husband of 43 years, John Berry; children Annette and Sean; his fiance Erin Carney; son-in-law Daniel Miller and granddaughter Piper Bee Miller. The memorial is Wednesday, September 28th at 2:00pm at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue. Donations may be made to the ASPCA or the Humane Society, two causes she passionately supported.

Six of the presumptive favorites to win the Super Bowl had flaws on full display on Sunday. For now, Green Bay looks to be the class of the league, and fans of unbeaten Buffalo and Detroit are surely proud of their teams. But four others teams -- the two franchises with the best records in 2010, the only team to make the conference championship game in each of the past two seasons, and the so-called dream team -- experienced varying degrees of distress. The defenses of Rex Ryan and Bill Belichick were punctured like never before.

Coming soon to a playing field near you is a trick play so clever it is likely to be imitated on punt returns throughout the land. Green Bay quarterback Aaron Rodgers, speaking for the team that was duped, called it ''the most incredible play I've ever seen,'' a convincing pantomime that left people ''wondering what the heck just happened.'' His teammate Greg Jennings thought it was ''the best play I've ever seen.'' With a little more than a minute left in the Packers' 27-17 victory over the Bears on Sunday, Green Bay punter Tim Masthay got off a towering kick meant to pin Chicago deep in its territory. The ball was heading left, but return man Devin Hester pretended it was going right, staring into the sky at a pretend pigskin and moving into place behind a wall of play-acting teammates. Ten Packers, looking at Hester rather than the ball, ran toward him.

Fewer tap-dancing lambs? Less cannibalism? The creators of ''Silence! The Musical,'' a theatrical parody of the 1991 film ''The Silence of the Lambs,'' have sliced 10 to 15 minutes from the production that had a popular run Off Broadway this summer in preparation for a new, open-ended engagement starting Oct. 25 at a slightly larger theater downtown, the producers of the show announced on Tuesday. Among other things, the show will drop the intermission used during the run at Theater 80, which ended last week. The tightened production, with a planned 90-minute run time, is slated to open at the 9th Space Theater at P.S. 122.

SHELINSKY--Pamela. Carter Ledyard & Milburn LLP mourns the passing of Pamela. She was a talented lawyer and valued colleague and will be missed by all. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her father Mark, her brother Jason and to her entire family.

TRUPPIN--Ada, MD, died peacefully at home, at age 86, on September 27, surrounded by her loving children, grandchildren and caregivers. Born in Cape Town in 1925, she graduated first in her class at University of Cape Town Medical School in 1952. She married Michael Truppin, MD, and they moved to New York in 1953, and trained at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Dr. Truppin practiced pediatrics for many years, then became a psychiatrist, practicing until 2003. A true intellectual and lover of the arts, she was passionate about ideas and deeply interested in people. She leaves behind her daughters, Nicola and Andrea, her grandchildren, Miriam, Benjamin and Milo, her son-in-law, Jeffrey, and her longtime housekeeper, Gilda. Funeral: Sunday October 2, 11am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel 630 Amsterdam at 91St. Burial: Sharon Gardens, 273 Lakeview Ave. Valhalla, NY. Shiva at her residence, Sunday 4-9pm; Monday and Tuesday 12-3pm and 6-9pm. Donations in Dr. Truppin's memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Assn, www.alz.org.

An article last Wednesday about the chef Michael Solomonov and his Israeli restaurant in Philadelphia, Zahav, misspelled the given name of the chef whose cookbook, ''Spice: Flavors of the Eastern Mediterranean,'' is a source of ideas for Mr. Solomonov. She is Ana Sortun, not Anna. The article also misstated the subtitle of another book that Mr. Solomonov uses, ''Artichoke to Za'atar,'' by Greg Malouf and Lucy Malouf. It is ''Modern Middle Eastern Food,'' not ''A Mediterranean Journey.''

The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington said it would replace the long-maligned organ in its concert hall with a new 5,000-pipe instrument built by Casavant Freres of St-Hyacinthe, Quebec. The existing organ, which was built by Aeolian-Skinner and installed in 1972, has been criticized by performers and reviewers for its poor functioning and musical inadequacy. A 1997 renovation of the hall made the problems worse. ''It was getting to the point where it was ruining performances,'' said Jeff Weiler, an organ consultant hired by the Kennedy Center. The new organ will be installed starting next summer, with a 61-pipe stop incorporated from its predecessor. The instrument will cost more than $2 million, the Kennedy Center said. David M. Rubenstein, the Kennedy Center's chairman and the managing director of the Carlyle Group, a private equity firm, is paying for the new organ and its installation. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

ALBANY - I.B.M. and four other technology companies agreed Tuesday to pour $4 billion into computer-chip research in New York, promising to hire thousands of workers and giving a major boost to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo as he campaigns for companies to invest in the state and create jobs. Mr. Cuomo, sounding downright giddy as he kicked off an economic development conference here, heralded the investment as a ''really, really big deal'' that proved that New York, especially upstate, could lure new investment from major corporations flush with potential suitors.

BECKER--Jack. The former shareholders, staff and alumni of Snow Becker Krauss P.C. are deeply saddened by the untimely loss of our beloved friend and colleague, Jack Becker. As a founding member, and as managing attorney for almost 30 years, Jack was the constant driving force behind Snow Becker and its success. We will always remember him warmly for his generosity and concern for all those who worked at the firm. We will never forget his unique blend of energy, intelligence, depth and breadth of knowledge, as well as his quick and decisive manner. As illness beset him in later years, he conducted a dignified and valiant battle, tenacious to the end in keeping with his character. On behalf of our colleagues, we extend heartfelt condolences to his wife, Deborah, their daughters, Marjorie and Barbara, sons-in-law, Peter and Chad, seven grandchildren, and the entire Becker family.

BECKER--Jack. The Partners and employees of McLaughlin & Stern, LLP mourn the passing of our esteemed partner, Jack Becker.

Bank of America's potential liability for bad mortgages - in the tens of billions of dollars - is well known. But Bank of America is haunted by other demons from the financial crisis, the most significant one being a lawsuit arising from its troubled Merrill Lynch acquisition. This lawsuit, brought by Bank of America shareholders, claims that Bank of America and its executives, including its former chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, failed to disclose what would be a $15.31 billion loss at Merrill in the days before and after the acquisition. The plaintiffs contend that this staggering loss was hidden to ensure that Bank of America shareholders did not vote against the transaction.

Bruce, Columbia Law School graduate, former Commissioner of Rent Control, loyal Brooklyn Dodger fan and Religious Democrat, died September 24th after a two year illness, leaving his much loved partner Tom Brown, brother Mike, sister-in-law Lucille, nephews Mathew and Mark and his wife Kathleen and grand nephews Benjamin and Grant. His many friends loved him and sought his counsel, notwithstanding his admiration for a tall glass of bourbon and too many cigarettes. Funeral service on Wednesday 1:00pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. (at E. 81st).

10 P.M. (BBC America) LUTHER Idris Elba (''The Wire'') returns as John Luther, a brilliant detective tormented by his own dark side, never mind those of the psychopaths he tracks down in the bowels of London. Last season he let a killer of children fall from a beam nearly to his death; became uncomfortably close to Alice Morgan (Ruth Wilson), a physicist who had killed her parents; and was framed for the murder of his wife by his colleague and best friend, Ian Reed (Steven Mackintosh). This four-part sequel finds a devastated Luther returning to work at the newly created Serious and Serial Unit, headed by the former complaints officer Martin Schenk (Dermot Crowley). Luther's first order of business is to keep his old partner Justin Ripley (Warren Brown) out of uniform. His second is to solve a series of ritualistic murders in historic locations while rescuing Jenny (Aimee Ffion Edwards, above with Mr. Elba), the daughter of an acquaintance, from the underbelly of prostitution. ''Law & Order: UK,'' in which a cop killer demands to be tried as a victim and not a murderer, leads in at 9. 8 P.M. (ABC) THE MIDDLE Axl (Charlie McDermott) gets Sue (Eden Sher) into trouble in high school. Mike (Neil Flynn) meets with the fourth grade teacher (Chord Overstreet), who is letting Brick (Atticus Shaffer) skip gym class. And Frankie (Patricia Heaton) tries to show everyone who's boss. In ''Modern Family,'' at 9, Phil (Ty Burrell) takes up tightrope walking; Claire (Julie Bowen) tries to teach the girls a life lesson; and Cameron (Eric Stonestreet) chooses the wrong time to go on a juice fast. In the Season 2 premiere of ''Happy Endings,'' at 9:30, Penny (Casey Wilson) buys a condo with a wine refrigerator and Italian marble countertops, and Jane (Eliza Coupe) persuades Alex (Elisha Cuthbert) and David (Zachary Knighton) to be honest with each other on the first anniversary of their almost marriage.

They came from fraying binders, from forgotten boxes in storage units, from cobwebbed closets. They had been in Mississippi and South Carolina and Georgia, and included a wallet-size photograph of a familiar preacher with a dream. Their destination was a drab office space in the back of a library in Queens. Now, a half-century removed from the moments they capture, these artifacts have come to represent the growing, perhaps surprising reputation of Queens College as something of a nexus of civil rights history.

REICHERT--Helen F. K. "Happy." We mourn the loss of our dear friend Happy Reichert. Mrs. Reichert, who until her death at the age of 109 was Cornell University's oldest living graduate, and her late husband, Dr. Philip Reichert, a renowned cardiologist and Weill Cornell faculty member, were much beloved members of our Medical College community. Generous in spirit and action, Mrs. Reichert is memorialized through the Helen F. Reichert Scholarship for promising medical students, and through the gift of her husband's collection of rare medical equipment, which remains on display in the Uris Faculty Room. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Reichert family. Antonio M. Gotto Jr., M.D., Dean Weill Cornell Medical College
WINSLOW--John Grenville. A funeral service will be held on Saturday, October 15, 2011 at 11am at Trinity Church, Queen Anne's Square, Newport, RI.
The De Gustibus column on Sept. 14, about using scales to weigh recipe ingredients, misstated the weight of a cup of sugar. It is about 200 grams, not 225 grams.

Is the nation's longest dance marathon finally losing steam, and are dinosaurs threatening to go extinct again? Both questions could be raised from the ratings for the second Monday night of the new television season as ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' posted its worst rating for a Monday performance show. And Fox's hugely promoted new time-travel prehistoric drama, ''Terra Nova,'' failed to stir overwhelming excitement for its two-hour premiere. For ''Dancing,'' ABC's most important show, the trend is looking serious, if not ominous: after being down 24 percent from last year in its premiere, it slid another 18 percent in Week 2, dropping to a 3.3 rating in the 18-to-49-year-old audience that is favored by many advertisers. That was down from a 4.0 last week and was the worst performance for the dance show's Monday edition. It also drew just over 16 million viewers, down from over 19 million last week. Fox is calling the performance of ''Terra Nova'' solid, and objectively it was, finishing with a 3 rating in that 18-to-49 audience, an improvement for Fox over its Monday average last season.

STOWENS--Doris H.,died September 17th of lung cancer at the age of 92. She had a distinguished career as Registrar of the American Craft Museum where her generosity and expertise was appreciated by both the artists and staff. Her extraordinary energy and unconventional sense of humor enriched the lives of everyone who knew her. Even as she suffered from macular degeneration and glaucoma she selflessly volunteered her time to help develop a program of museum tours for the sight disabled. Always ready with a quick-witted reply she handled whatever challenges life brought with honesty and candor. Her passing has left a deep hole in our hearts but her vibrant legacy will always be cherished. Contributions in her memory may be made to: The Jewish Guild for the Blind, 15 East 65th St., NYC 10023, Lighthouse for the Blind, 111 East 59th St, NYC 10022, or the MJHS Foundation, 440 Ninth Avenue, NYC 10001. A Memorial Service will be held Sunday, October 23rd at 2pm at the Abigail Adams Smith Auditorium, 417 East 61st St., NYC (1st and York Avenue.)

HOLLANDER--Lilly (nee Benedict), born July 31, 1928 in Vienna, Austria, died September 24, 2011 in West Cornwall, CT. Graduate of The Cooper Union, conservator of antique artworks, beloved mother of Susanne Gilbert of Montclair, NJ, and Diana Hollander of West Cornwall, CT; sister of Eva Freiberger and sister-in-law of Robert Freiberger of Pompton Plains, NJ; and mother-in-law of Avery Gilbert and grandmother of Alice and Lydia Gilbert of Montclair, NJ. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made at www.cooper.edu.

An article on Sept. 8 about a bar in Queens that set off a conflict in its immigrant community when it raffled off a free same-sex wedding reception referred imprecisely to a statistic taken from The National Herald, which posed the question ''Do you approve of gay marriage?'' to its Greek-American readers. While 86 percent said they did not approve, that figure was based on about 1,000 readers who chose to answer the question when it was posted on the paper's Web site; the figure was not arrived at through a scientific ''poll'' in which The National Herald contacted readers. The article also misidentified the location of a nearby hardware store, whose owner said he resented such a public promotion of same-sex marriage. The hardware store, owned by Larry Yang, is a few doors away from the bar on the same side of the street, not ''next door.''

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Saturday about a bankruptcy filing by the United States National Slavery Museum misstated the name of the organization's founder, who is also a former governor of Virginia. He is L. Douglas Wilder, not Douglas L. Wilder.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption last Wednesday with an article about high-end food concessions opening at Madison Square Garden misspelled the given name of one of the chefs. As the article correctly noted, he is Jean-Georges Vongerichten, not John-George.

CUMMINGS--Laura Gail. Beloved wife, daughter, sister and aunt. Died suddenly, much too soon, September 25, 2011 at her home in Greenwich, CT, three weeks shy of her 56th birthday. She is survived by her husband Andrew, her parents Eveline and Ralph Felsten, her sister Nancy, brother-in-law David Fishman, nephews Jack, Matt and Ben and her beloved in-laws Nick and Dot, sister-in-law Janet, niece Amy and nephew Kent. Caring, independent and adorable. There are no words to express our sorrow. The funeral will be held at John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont NY, Wednesday, September 28th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to UNICEF where she was a devoted volunteer.

The freewheeling artistic style of Bob Dylan, who has drawn on a variety of sources in creating his music and has previously raised questions of attribution in his work, is once again stirring debate - this time over an exhibition of his paintings at the Gagosian Gallery on the Upper East Side. When the gallery announced the exhibition, called ''The Asia Series,'' this month, it said the collection of paintings and other artwork would provide ''a visual journal'' of Mr. Dylan's travels ''in Japan, China, Vietnam and Korea,'' with ''firsthand depictions of people, street scenes, architecture and landscape.''

GALLAGHER--James M.,age 65, passed away on Friday, September 23rd, 2011 at St. Clare's Hospital in Denville, NJ. James was born and raised in New York City and lived in the Bronx before moving to Pine Brook, NJ in 1985. He is survived by his wife Carolyn D. (nee-Demarest); his son, Sean and his wife Amy of Butler, NJ; his mother, Rose of New York City, NY; and his brother, Patrick and his wife Cheryl of Virginia. Relatives and friends are invited to attend his Funeral Service on Friday, September 30, 2011 at 9:30am at the Par-Troy Funeral Home, 95 Parsippany Road, Parsippany, NJ. (973)887-3235 or visit www.partroyfuneralhome. com. Visiting hours are on Thursday from 6:00-9:00pm only at the funeral home. Please omit flowers.

After two decades of negotiations, the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston has returned the broken-off bust of a famous statue of Herakles to Turkey, where it will be reunited with its lower half, the museum announced. Turkey has long maintained that the top of this second-century A.D. statue, known as ''Weary Herakles,'' was stolen from an archaeological site in the Mediterranean and smuggled into the United States. The legs and lower body of the work are on display at the Antalya Museum in southwestern Turkey.
