The consortium is said to include Dan H. Jester, a former Goldman Sachs official who worked at the Treasury Department, and Joseph Brandon, above, who worked as General Re's chief executive until 2008. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

An article on Saturday about the film ''American Teacher,'' by Dave Eggers and Ninive Caligare, omitted one of the authors of the book ''Teachers Have It Easy'' on which the film is based. Besides Mr. Eggers and Ms. Caligare, Daniel Moulthrop also wrote the book.

Former Mayor Edward I. Koch, who recently used the forum of a special Congressional election to broadcast his criticism of President Obama's Israel policy, announced in an e-mail on Tuesday that Mr. Obama's United Nations speech opposing the Palestinians' bid for statehood had satisfied all his concerns, and that he was now prepared to support Mr. Obama's re-election. ''Whatever rift existed before - and there was - that's gone,'' Mr. Koch said in a telephone interview. He said that he was now ready to go out and make the case to Jewish voters that the president deserved their support.

BRUSSELS -- The European Commission is expected to unveil a detailed plan on Wednesday to create a financial transaction tax, despite the opposition of several member countries and a formal acknowledgement that it could have a significant negative effect on the European Union's gross domestic product. The plan, which has the strong support of France and Germany, will be discussed in a speech before the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, by José Manuel Barroso, the president of the commission, the executive arm of the European Union.

LEVIN--Leona M.,(nee Wexler), 86, died in New York City on September 26, 2011. Loving wife of the late Samuel David Levin, Leona was a graduate of the University of Chicago and former Director of Nursing Home Services for Cook County. A lifelong resident of Chicago, she moved to New York in 2008 to be closer to family. She is survived by her sister, Sheldra Horwitz of Naples, Florida, her loving daughters Alisa F. (Charles M. Nathan) Levin of Brooklyn, New York and Rhea B. Levin of Malibu, California, and two adoring grandchildren, Samuel David Nathan and Lillien Esther Nathan. She also took pride in her son-in-law's children and grandchildren, Lisa Nathan and Russell and Susan Frei Nathan and their children, Emilia and Ben. Graveside services will be held Wednesday, September 28 at 11:30am at Waldheim Jewish Cemetery Gate 215, in Chicago. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Congregation Beth Elohim, 274 Garfield Place, Brooklyn, NY 11215. www.congregationbethelohim.org or to UJA Federation of NY, 130 E. 59th street, NY, NY 10022. www.ujafedny.org.

ANDERSON-GOLD--Sharon, passed away on September 26th after a long illness. She is survived, by her devoted husband Howard, sons Jason Harris Gold and Jordan Benjamin Gold, and daughter-in-law Hyunchu Kim Gold, RN. Sharon graduated from East Hartford Catholic High School and earned a bachelor of science degree from Central Connecticut State University, New Britain, CT; and master's degrees in political science and philosophy as well as a doctoral degree in philosophy from The New School for Social Research, New York, NY. She was professor and chair of the Science and Technology Studies Department at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, NY. As a scholar, Sharon specialized in applied ethics and social and political philosophy. Several of her published works focused on international justice and human rights, including her book Cosmopolitanism and Human Rights. Service Saturday, October 1st, 3pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Interment private. The family will receive friends at their home in New York City, Saturday 6-9:30pm.

A report in some copies of the World Briefings column on Sept. 15 about Turkey's decision on where to locate a radar system that is part of a new NATO shield against a missile attack in Europe described the location of the base incorrectly. It is west of Turkey's border with Iran, not east.

An article on Sept. 19 about the Palestinian Authority's decision to seek full membership at the United Nations misstated the relationship between Rashid Khalidi, a Columbia University professor, and the Palestinians who have negotiated with Israel. Professor Khalidi advised the Palestinian delegation to peace talks in Madrid and in Washington between 1991 and 1993. He is neither a current nor former political adviser to the Palestinian Authority.

Radiohead, the influential British progressive rock band, gave an unusually long televised performance Monday night, playing songs from its new album, ''King of Limbs,'' and others on an hourlong special of The Colbert Report, the comedian Stephen Colbert's political satire show. The band's leader, Thom Yorke, is not renowned for his sense of humor, but he and the other members of Radiohead allowed themselves to be lampooned by Mr. Colbert, who plays a dimwitted right-wing talk show host on this show that satirizes real right-wing talk show hosts with his absurd statements.

Guns N' Roses, the hard rock band whose glory days were in the 1980s, and Eric B. & Rakim, one of the most influential rap groups of that era, were among the 15 artists nominated for induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame next year, the hall announced this morning. Both were nominated in their first year of eligibility. The other artists who are receiving their first nominations include Freddie King, the Cure, Heart, the Spinners and Joan Jett and the Blackhearts. The list also contains several acts that have been nominated before, among them the Beastie Boys, Donovan, the Red Hot Chili Peppers and War.

FRIDAY'S PUZZLE - Recently, I have been the lucky recipient of mail from people who tell me that they do not always understand when I am joking. This is totally understandable, of course; humor is subjective, much like curly hair or freckles. I'm sorry, that's genetic. I always get those two confused. Anyway, I felt bad that some readers were missing out on the fun, so as a public service to those who tend to miss my humor, I've decided today to highlight all of the jokes in this post from hereon in both clearly and definitively through the use of a highly technical punctuation symbol, the asterisk. This is especially important in the next paragraph, as it will hopefully keep me from being sued by people who don't realize that I am operating strictly from the Soupy Sales School of Humor Writing.

Irene Neuwirth prefers to keep things low key. The Los Angeles-based fine jewelry designer has never been one for pop-up shops or Fashion's Night Out extravaganzas. But when BOFFO, the art and culture nonprofit, approached her about participating in its annual designer series, Neuwirth just couldn't resist. "When I was a CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund finalist, I became really friendly with Richard Chai," says Neuwirth, by way of explaining her excitement about working with BOFFO, the group that initiated Chai's memorable ice age pop-up last year. "After visiting Richard's shop, I thought, What a cool project. This is something I would like to be a part of." Neuwirth's shop (57 Walker Street), which features a starry metal installation by the architect Marc Fornes of "The Very Many" and a living wall of lush green plants, is open until Oct. 12 and stocks Neuwirth's one-of-a-kind rainbow moonstone pendant necklaces and pieces from her new diamond collection. "I love the contrast between my very modern and feminine gems and Marc's really modern and conceptual work," Neuwirth says.

I have written before about the folly of Major League Baseball's plans to expand its postseason by two teams, creating a sudden-death wild card playoff in both leagues. This foolishness is probably a done deal: Rumor has it the new playoff system could into effect as early as next season, or 2013 at the latest. But if I were the owners and players, I would interpret last night's extraordinary finish to the regular season as a sign from the baseball gods, warning them to reconsider their playoff-expanding madness before it's too late.

In 2009, an alternative fashion week event, Content, was held at the Ace Hotel in Portland, Ore., to expose the work of that city's remarkable but somewhat isolated crop of independent designers. Each designer was given a room in the hotel, with free rein to transform it into a kind of fashion installation and only one rule: Nothing was for sale. Clothes hung from the shower curtains above the Ace's claw-foot bathtubs; one designer carted in a half-dozen birch tree trunks to drive home a sylvan theme; another concocted a gruesome murder scene with three bloodied (yet impeccably dressed) victims strewn about the floor.

It’s not spring for Guillaume Henry’s girl — it’s summer. She’s warm, flushed from wandering through the woods, and as night falls she decides to pull back her wind-whipped hair. “Texture without intention,” is how Romina Manenti explained the feeling intended for the low ponytails backstage at Carven. She used Bumble and Bumble Thickening Spray and then Shine Brilliantine to coat the hair, which she then separated into two parts twisted inward, secured with an elastic. “As if she’s been outside all day,” is how Nina Haverkamp described the makeup: a messy eyebrow, shiny taupe eyelid and slightly tinted lip. The mouth was prepped with Homeoplasmine from the pharmacy, which Haverkamp then wiped away to apply a dab of foundation. As for the specifics of the shadow, it was a combination of Mattese NYC shades that are no longer available: C51, the taupe and C80 (a shiny pink), if you wish to try and track them down.

MONTPELIER, Ohio — Feeling a little pruney here. For several days now — pretty much since I wrote about how lucky I’ve been with the weather — the skies have been broodingly gray, the air has been heavy, the wind has been contrary and chill, and for a few hours each day I’ve been rained on. A couple of the days I could have stayed put, I guess, but at this point my legs start pedaling in the morning whether I’m on the bike or not, and rain is hardly catastrophic. Anyway, now that the Yankees are in the playoffs, I want to be home for the World Series. (Am I confident they’ll make it? Not really. As everyone knows, they don’t have the starting pitching.)

Larry Mishel has a very good piece systematically debunking the zombie claim that fears of regulation are holding back job creation. There is, literally, not a shred of evidence for this claim — not in the numbers, not in what businesses say. Yet it has been eagerly adopted not just by Republican politicians but by Chicago economists, Federal Reserve presidents, and more. I think the willingness of so many people to completely abandon any intellectual principles here, so that they can play for Team Republican — or maybe we should call that Team Oligarch — is part of what has me down these days.

Game predictions are back for 2011. As always, the probability model is based on passing, running, turnovers and penalty efficiency. SR is the percentage of runs in which the a team’s point expectancy (based on down, distance and yard line) has improved.

In centuries past, Africa was known as the “Dark Continent,” which originated less as a slur than as a testament to the deficiency of mapmakers: clueless about the continent’s interior, they would often just blot it out, as if the place didn’t fully exist. Opacity still marks the popular conception of Africa, especially when it comes to its cities, which take a back seat to safari-ready grasslands and oceans of desert. To change this, the celebrated London architect David Adjaye began a decade-long quest to photograph Africa’s urban spaces — practically all of them, save the war-torn Somali capital, Mogadishu. “The project is really fueled by the widespread misconception of Africa as an impoverished or unpeopled expanse,” said Adjaye, who was born to Ghanaian parents in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. “I was born in a metropolitan city; I was born in a cosmopolitan condition among different groups of Africans, Indians and Chinese.”

DOUGLAS--Paul. With profound sorrow, ICD-International Center for the Disabled mourns the loss of Paul W. Douglas, distinguished trustee and great friend. As a longtime Board member, he brought extraordinary intelligence and generosity to his support of ICD's mission. He will be sincerely missed by all who knew him. We extend deepest condolences to his family. Justin Wender, Chair Les Halpert, Ph.D., President and CEO

SAO PAULO, Brazil -- In this city, where conspicuous consumption is common, Andre Esteves is virtually anonymous among the suits of the financial district. Yet possibly no one embodies the financial ascent of Brazil better than Mr. Esteves. At 43, he has built BTG Pactual into Brazil's largest independent investment bank and has amassed a fortune estimated at $3 billion by Forbes magazine. Still, he has driven the same Mercedes pickup for four years and takes only two weeks of vacation a year.

FINANCIAL INTEGRATION In case UBS employees still doubted the Swiss bank's plans to keep its investment banking operations, the firm's new interim chief executive reiterated that the division was not going anywhere. Sergio P. Ermotti, UBS's chief for now, wrote in an internal memorandum on Wednesday that the firm would maintain an ''integrated bank model'' -- an investment bank, wealth management and asset management -- despite the welter of problems that the bank has had to deal with over the last few years. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

The Yankees finally learned that the Detroit Tigers will be their opponent in the American League division series starting Friday night, setting up a premiere pitching duel in Game 1 between C. C. Sabathia and Justin Verlander. The Tigers got a ticket to New York when the Texas Rangers defeated the Los Angeles Angels on Wednesday. The series will be a rematch of the 2006 division series. That was not a good memory for the Yankees, who were crushed, three games to one.

In 1902, the International Banking Corporation, a predecessor of Citigroup, went in search of the next big gold rush. But it did not go west. It opened up small outposts in Shanghai, Calcutta and Manila. In 1914, another Citigroup ancestor opened a branch in Buenos Aires, becoming the first big American player in the city. The story of Wall Street in the emerging markets has been a long one, filled with twists and turns. Most recently, deal makers and big banks have been contending with the global market volatility, which is rocking such risky locales.

Sensing - or at least fervently hoping - that it has a hit on its hands, Starz Entertainment, the premium cable service, announced Tuesday that it would renew the drama series, ''Boss,'' starring Kelsey Grammer, for a second season even before the show has its premiere on Oct. 21. The show features Mr. Grammer as the fictional mayor of Chicago, suffering from a degenerative brain disorder that is causing his world to slowly collapse. The series's preemptive renewal one-ups HBO, one of Starz's cable competitors, which last year ordered a second season for the Atlantic City prohibition-era gangster drama ''Boardwalk Empire'' only two days after the series's first episode aired.

When Lebnan Nader introduced his iPhone app in late August, the game was an instant hit. Within four days Birdy Nam Nam - think Angry Birds meets Arab Spring - had been downloaded more than 400,000 times. His next challenge is to find outside money to make the business grow. Mr. Nader, who developed the program on a shoestring budget of $1,000 with help from his brother and a friend, wants to use the money to add features like online sharing and sound effects. But despite his success, Mr. Nader, 26, stumbled across a potential venture capital investor only by accident.
To the Editor: Re ''Wangari Maathai, Peace Prize Laureate, Dies at 71'' (obituary, Sept. 27):

Al Qaeda has a message for President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran: enough with the conspiracy theories about Sept. 11. The latest issue of the terror group's English-language magazine, Inspire, lashed out at the Iranian president for indulging in the claim that the American government -- and not Al Qaeda -- was responsible for the attack. It was a claim Mr. Ahmadinejad repeated during his address to the United Nations General Assembly last week, when he suggested that the killing of Osama bin Laden was part of a dark conspiracy to conceal the real perpetrators of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

A chart on Saturday with the continuation of an article about Palestinian efforts to receive full membership in the United Nations misstated the General Assembly's voting procedure for approving admission. A two-thirds majority of members who are present and voting is required -- not a two-thirds majority of all 193 members. The error also appeared on Sept. 17 in a front-page article about the Palestinian president's official announcement that he would seek full membership.

ANDERSON-GOLD--Sharon, passed away on September 26th after a long illness. She is survived, by her devoted husband Howard, sons Jason Harris Gold and Jordan Benjamin Gold, and daughter-in-law Hyunchu Kim Gold, RN. Sharon graduated from East Hartford Catholic High School and earned a bachelor of science degree from Central Connecticut State University, New Britain, CT; and master's degrees in political science and philosophy as well as a doctoral degree in philosophy from The New School for Social Research, New York, NY. She was professor and chair of the Science and Technology Studies Department at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, NY. As a scholar, Sharon specialized in applied ethics and social and political philosophy. Several of her published works focused on international justice and human rights, including her book Cosmopolitanism and Human Rights. Service Saturday, October 1st, 3pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Interment private. The family will receive friends at their home in New York City, Saturday 6-9:30pm.

Iran announced the mass production of a new cruise missile on Wednesday, the latest in a series of belligerent-sounding proclamations from that country in the face of its increased isolation by a Western-led group of nations worried about Iran's nuclear program and avowed hostility toward Israel. Brig. Gen. Ahmad Vahidi, Iran's defense minister, said the new missile, first unveiled a month ago and known as the Qader, which means Able in Farsi, had been mass-produced ''as quickly as possible,'' the country's state-run media reported. The missile, designed to destroy warships and coastal targets, has a range of about 125 miles, the media said.
BECKER--Jack. The Partners and employees of McLaughlin & Stern, LLP mourn the passing of our esteemed partner, Jack Becker.

As a draft of the Volcker Rule has made the rounds in the last several weeks, it has alternatively caused fits of despair and cries of exultation. And that's just among the proponents of the regulation. Then came news that the Swiss bank UBS had lost $2.3 billion thanks to a rogue trader. Of course, it's terrible for the bank, and the last thing we need right now is another fragile financial institution. But for Volckerites, the timing couldn't be better. It comes just when the rule's champions are trying to preserve the draft's strongest measures and buttress the weaker clauses.

ROSENBLUM--Marvin A.,80 of Chester, NJ died Tuesday September 27, 2011 at the Morristown Memorial Hospital. He was born in Perth Amboy and lived most of his life in Fords and Edison before moving to Chester, N.J. 10 years ago. Marvin was a 1950 graduate of Rutgers University, and a self employed entrepreneur merchant, having formerly owned Fords Hardware in Fords, N.J. and was the former CEO and President of Precision Polymers, a publicly traded company, in Mountainside. He was the founding member and second president of Temple Emanu-el in Edison, the former president of the International Federation for Secular and Humanistic Judaism, and a long standing member of YPO /WPO. Marvin is survived by his wife Esti Rosenblum to whom he was married for 58 years, his children Jan E. Dragotta and her husband Frank of Marlboro, Jody B. Ostroff and her husband Michael of Summit, Joshua D. Rosenblum and his wife Kim of N.Y.C., six grandchildren Francis, Kyle, Max, Tess, Samuel, and Spencer, and his sister Marcia Stillman and her husband Jack of Princeton. Funeral services will be held Sunday October 2, 2011 at 10am at Temple Emanu-el 100 James St. Edison, N.J. Interment will follow in Beth Israel Cemetery. Services are entrusted to the Flynn and Son Funeral Home 23 Ford Ave., Fords, N.J. (732) 826-0358. For directions, or to send condolence messages, visit our Web site at www.flynnfuneral.com

Live hyperlinks are great for whisking you to the Web in a hurry, but addresses formatted as regular text still require cutting and pasting into the browser to get you to the page. If you use Mozilla Firefox or Google's Chrome browser, you can save a step. After copying the Web address from text, right click on the browser's address bar and choose the ''Paste and Go'' option to automatically zip over to that page. The current versions of Firefox and Chrome also support entering keywords in the address bar as a shortcut to a Web search. If you have copied a word or phrase to the computer's clipboard, right click on the browser's address bar and choose the ''Paste and Search'' option to start the search engine.

A light bulb went off for Christy Prunier while giving her 8-year-old daughter, Willa, a bath. The girl complained that she didn't like ''babyish'' soaps anymore. Ms. Prunier got to work, and after three years of research, introduced a line of skin care products aimed at preteenage girls. The name? Willa, of course.

The dream of concealing a tiny video camera inside a pair of glasses dates back to the days of Dick Tracy, but these days a child can have the real thing, with the Spy Net Stealth Recording Video Glasses, in toy stores this month from Jakks Pacific. And they really work. While they probably won't win any fashion contests (one observer thought I'd had a cataract operation), the dark glasses deliver some impressive technology for $40. The low-res camera peeks out of a small hole in the bridge and the tiny lithium-polymer battery, 128 megabytes of RAM and USB port are just behind the fat hinges.

South Africa's failure to issue a visa to the Dalai Lama, or even respond to his repeated requests for one, was sharply criticized on Wednesday by the Dalai Lama and by Desmond Tutu, the former Archbishop of Capetown. The two men called the failure disrespectful. The Dalai Lama wants to travel to South Africa to attend an 80th birthday party on Oct. 7 for Archbishop Tutu, a fellow Nobel laureate and anti-apartheid champion.

Last survivor of her siblings David, Barry, Helen and Morris. Forever in our hearts.

The article also referred incompletely to advisers for the Empowerhouse entry. A number of faculty members at the schools helped, not just Profs. Laura Briggs and David Lewis at Parsons.

BAER-SCHENKEIN--Eva, RN, CRNA, LNC, former director Beekman-Downtown Hospital of Nursing, and Bronx Lebanon Hospital Center, author, stand-up comic and poet, died 79. She will be missed. Contributions to American Cancer Society.

The unrelenting clamor about the possibility of new candidates joining the Republican presidential race may be overlooking one important number: 100. That is the number of days remaining until the first votes are likely to be cast in the party's nominating contest. And that is the number of days left for campaigns to build their teams in Iowa, New Hampshire, South Carolina - and, if they are successful, to points beyond.

Burdened by slowing consumer spending at home, Wal-Mart Stores sought another jolt to its sales. The world's biggest retailer turned its eyes to a continent where it has little presence: Africa. Wal-Mart announced last fall that it would seek to buy Massmart, its closest counterpart in sub-Saharan Africa, and this year it won approval to buy half of the retailer for $2.4 billion.

Globalization has been kind to Wall Street. The opening of European capital markets to American investment banks quickly led to United States financial domination of the Continent and of a large part of the rest of the world. American private equity firms have been equally successful at capturing the global market. But as they say on Wall Street, past performance is no indication of future results.

Who remembers that the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Yankees, 6-5, at Yankee Stadium on April 15, 1983? The real contest that night was between the Yankees' manager, Billy Martin, and Vic Voltaggio, the home-plate umpire. After warmly discussing the merits of one of Voltaggio's calls, Martin found himself ejected from the game. ''He cursed me, and I dumped him,'' Voltaggio explained.

WE couldn't help but notice how many of the fashion flock are carrying little clutches this fall. This new Anve clutch, made in the shape of a paper bag from one piece of leather, was created by Annett Bourquin and Kerstin Greve, who live in Lisbon. ''We grew up with little satchel bags hanging around our necks with an apple and a sandwich inside,'' Ms. Borquin said of their inspiration. The bags, in red, blue, black or gray, can be rolled up, flapped and clutched under the arm. And there's room enough inside for a P.B. and J. Anve leather clutches, $228 at Assembly New York, 170 Ludlow Street, (212) 253-5393;assemblynewyork.com.

Signature Theater Company will produce Off Broadway world premieres next year of plays by the Pulitzer Prize winner Edward Albee, Katori Hall (''The Mountaintop'') and Kenneth Lonergan (''The Starry Messenger''), as well a new work by Will Eno (''Middletown'') and three dramas by the South African playwright Athol Fugard. James Houghton, artistic director of Signature, also announced on Wednesday that all tickets for the regular runs of productions would be sold for $25 during the next decade, an extension of this nonprofit theater company's landmark program to make shows more affordable to audiences. To finance those discounts - Signature tickets are normally $75 - the theater is seeking new underwriters for its Signature Ticket Initiative, which began in 2005 with $15 tickets and Time Warner as the lead sponsor. Mr. Houghton said in an interview that Signature needed $20 million over the decade to cover the discounts and that it was seeking a new lead sponsor to make a multimillion-dollar commitment. Time Warner, he said, is among the companies and individuals helping with initial contributions to support the new discounts, but it is no longer the lead sponsor. Mr. Houghton declined to identify the companies or individuals he was talking to about succeeding Time Warner as the top sponsor. Asked what would happen to the $25 tickets if a lead sponsor were not recruited, Mr. Houghton expressed confidence about finding the support. Signature is moving from its single theater space on West 42nd Street this winter into a new home nearby, a three-theater complex named Signature Center, and the expanded facilities are leading to an increase in the number of annual productions there.

Gov. Rick Perry of Texas said Wednesday that it was ''inappropriate'' of him to have branded as heartless those who oppose tuition breaks for the children of illegal immigrants. In an interview with Newsmaxx.com, Mr. Perry said that his remarks during last week's debate were ''inappropriate'' and that he had been ''overpassionate'' in his answer to the question.

Heidi Klum is a Victoria's Secret model and the host of the hit reality-TV show ''Project Runway.'' But her admirers should beware: Searching online for her name with terms like ''hot pictures'' and ''free downloads'' can bring a cold shower. Ms. Klum is this year's most dangerous celebrity to search for on the Web, according to the security software company McAfee, a unit of Intel. Clicking on links promising sexy pictures or videos of her comes with a nearly one-in-10 chance of contracting a bad case of spyware, adware, phishing scams or other malware. The study uses data from McAfee's free SiteAdvisor product, a tool for the Internet Explorer and Firefox browsers that protects users from malicious Web sites.

Aided by lax oversight and a personal connection, the owners of a technology firm stole at least $6.5 million from the city's Education Department by vastly overstating how much they paid their workers and submitting false documents to city agencies, the special investigator for the New York City school system charged in a report issued on Wednesday. Investigators also accused the official, who was then executive director of the Education Department's Division of Financial Operations, of helping to enable the fraud by giving the firm, Future Technology Associates, access to confidential information. She also had a ''close personal relationship'' with one of the owners, the investigators found.

Wall Street loves to crow about its overseas conquests. Vikram S. Pandit, the head of Citigroup, boldly promised in 2009 that ''we will be the single largest emerging markets financial services company.'' Goldman Sachs's chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, said at a conference last year that one of his firm's big goals was ''to be Goldman Sachs in more places.''

MINIMAL and modern, Diana Broussard's eye-catching link necklaces, inspired by the graphic gold chains of the late 1970s and made in Italy in lightweight plexiglass, make a statement without making a fuss. Available in bold royal blue, yellow and bordeaux, as well as more neutral hues, they add instant, arty chic when paired with a shift dress or your casual weekend wear. Chain-link necklaces, $250 at Diana Broussard, 22 Christopher Street, (646) 336-6365; dianabroussard.com.

American Ballet Theater is taking its traditions into a center of the dance world. The company said on Wednesday that it would present a weeklong course on its training techniques in St. Petersburg, Russia, home of the Mariinsky Theater - the former Kirov - and a venerable part of ballet history. Ballet Theater will hold the five-day session starting on Oct. 31 to present its national training curriculum, which the company said had certified 550 teachers across the United States since 2008, when it began. The curriculum combines ''artistic training with the basics of dancer health and child development,'' Ballet Theater said. The news follows a recent announcement that one of the company's stars, David Hallberg, would take on a principal dancer position with the Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow, the first American in such a role. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

There are so many iPod, iPhone and iPad docks out there it makes you wonder if manufacturers have given up supporting other phones and portable media players. In a way they have: they generally make more money selling iPod docks than making devices compatible with every single phone under the sun. However, there is hope. Here are a few devices that help you break free of Apple's gravitational pull:

RIO DE JANEIRO -- ''I'm a missionary of God.'' Amid the death growls and mock-opera shrieks resonating from the stage in the so-called City of Rock on the western edge of Rio's sprawl, those weren't exactly the first words I expected to hear from a jovial man in an orange uniform at Rock in Rio, the huge music festival that kicked off here last weekend.

Responding to what it sees as a cultural need in Lower Manhattan as plans for a proposed performing arts center at the World Trade Center site remain up in the air, Pace University announced this week that it will begin a new annual series of performing and visual-arts programs at its 650-seat Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts on Spruce Street near City Hall. The inaugural season of the series, called ''Pace Presents,'' will include the bandleader and trumpeter Terence Blanchard's quintet; cabaret with sisters Ann Hampton Callaway and Liz Callaway; and music from the New York Choral Society and the Senegalese master Baaba Maal, said Martin I. Kagan, the center's new director of cultural affairs. The season is scheduled to open Oct. 12 with multimedia presentations on great painters by Janetta Rebold Benton, the art historian known for her popular lectures at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

BECKER--Jack. It is with indescribable sadness that we are announcing the death of Jack Becker of Chappaqua and New York City. Jack died on September 27, 2011, 11 days shy of his 76th birthday, as a result of a long battle with cancer. Jack fought a courageous and heroic battle against his disease. He refused to give up or give in, right up to the very end. Jack will be remembered for his optimism, his kindness and generosity, his deep commitment to Judaism, his humor and his integrity. Jack was a founding partner of Snow Becker Krauss P.C., and he enthusiastically practiced law up until the very end. Jack left behind his wife of 52 years, Deborah Schoen, whom he loved deeply; his daughters, Barbara and Marjorie, of whom he was so proud and who revered him; his sons-in-law, Chad and Peter, who will miss him dearly; and all of his grandchildren, Emily, Sami, Georgia, Spencer, Jesse, Matty and Q, who absolutely adored him. Jack was predeceased by his older brother, Allan, whom he loved and admired. He died before we were ready and he will be missed by all who had the honor and privilege to know him. We love you.

FOR nearly three decades beginning in the 1960s, the designer Giorgio di Sant'Angelo held fashion insiders in his sway. Among these was the editor Diana Vreeland, who urged Sant'Angelo, an architect and industrial designer by training, to make accessories and clothes. ''She sent me to Arizona,'' Sant'Angelo once said, ''with Veruschka, the model; four suitcases full of fabrics; wires; and tape and told me to wrap and tie everything as I wanted and then she gave me eight pages in the magazine.'' That editorial, set in the Painted Desert, photographed by Franco Rubartelli and published in Vogue in 1968, forged his career.

MUMBAI, India -- WHEN the Ssangyong Motor company, a South Korean sport utility vehicle maker, came up for sale twice in the last seven years, the Indian auto company Mahindra & Mahindra passed both times. Last year, Mahindra was finally ready to pull the trigger, acquiring a 70 percent stake in Ssangyong for $460 million. The deal, which closed in March, was another indication that Indian companies were growing more confident in making cross-border acquisitions.

An article on Monday about the leftist victory in France's upper-house election, a setback for President Nicolas Sarkozy, mistranslated part of a quotation by a spokesman for Mr. Sarkozy's party in reaction to the results. The spokesman, Jean-François Copé, said they were ''disappointing, but not a surprise'' -- not ''deceptive, but not a surprise.''

Of all the broadcast networks, Fox is the most inclusive of gay and lesbian characters on its prime time shows, and CBS is the least inclusive, according to a study released on Wednesday by the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, or GLAAD. That advocacy group said its annual study had found a decline in the total number of gay and lesbian characters on network television this season versus the 2010-2011 television season, but a relatively steady number of such characters on cable. HBO, with the vampire series ''True Blood,'' among other shows, and Showtime, with shows like ''Shameless'' and others, stood out among the cable channels for the number of gay and lesbian characters, GLAAD said.

A STYLE.COM review of the fall Ferragamo runway show suggested that the collection ''might be the sleeper hit of Milan Fashion Week.'' Certainly the fresh use of houndstooth -- in sexy tailoring, in accessories -- by Massimiliano Giornetti, Ferragamo's creative director, has caught on. In Milan last week, Anna Dello Russo turned up in his wrap-front houndstooth dress. In New York, the model Jessica Hart wore the same style on Fashion's Night Out (left) and, later in the week, a Ferragamo blazer with denim shorts at a runway show (right). And he is scarcely the only designer to rediscover the classic check. Gwyneth Paltrow wore a Stella McCartney coat in London (far right), and Mia Wasikowska chose a Gucci houndstooth dress for the Toronto Film Festival. There are houndstooth pants at J. Crew for $138. Robert Rodriguez did a sensibly priced houndstooth cape ($695 at Bergdorf Goodman). And then there are the accessories: Ralph Lauren sunglasses (above), $250; Wolford tights, $65. Stripes and polka dots -- give it a rest.

The Scene City column last Thursday, about a stage reading of ''8,'' a play based on the trial that invalidated a gay-marriage ban in California, transposed the given names of the playwright who adapted it from the trial transcript. He is Dustin Lance Black, not Lance Dustin Black.

IS fashion stagnant? Not really, though to gaze at the latest round of runway shows, you might think so. In New York, and in Milan this week, designers embraced the primly corseted silhouettes of the American midcentury with an extravagant fervor. Their outpouring of springtime sheaths, cocktail frocks, camp shirts and circle skirts, all emblems of late 1950s bourgeois chic, seemed worthy at times of Suzy Parker, their collections like outtakes from a Slim Aarons shoot. Fashion's rekindled infatuation with Modernism, expressed by talents like Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez of Proenza Schouler and Consuelo Castiglioni of Marni, seems familiar in more ways than one. This is not, after all, the first time designers have revisited the prosperous postwar era to conjure a feeling of stability, one expected to resonate with anxious consumers. Reviving a period enriched by material comforts as substantial as a Steuben crystal bowl also represents a long-overdue return to old-fashioned concepts of quality.

MYITSONE, Myanmar -- The massive dam under construction in this remote corner of Myanmar is prompting a litany of concerns that are common to such projects: about the risks of tampering with nature, about damage to wildlife, about the displacement of villagers. But for many people in Myanmar, also known as Burma, the fears surrounding the Myitsone dam go much deeper. It will be the first dam across the Irrawaddy River, the iconic, even mythic waterway that has given life to centuries of Burmese civilization.
To those who call us snitches, I say, 'Why don't you obey the law?' BANG JAE-WON, who ferrets out lawbreakers in South Korea for a reward. [A11]

In the continuing hot dog wars in front of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the military men have returned to the sidewalk. The two men, Armando Crescenzi and Harold Dalton, are former soldiers who now hold a position on the museum's plaza, brandishing veteran vending permits that they say give them the right to sell hot dogs to the throngs of hungry tourists and visitors in front of the entrance to the museum.

(HBO) THE LATINO LIST Timothy Greenfield-Sanders, the photographer and the director of three editions of ''The Black List'' on HBO, presents video portraits of Latinos who have contributed to contemporary society in music, science, journalism, theater, literature, business and government. Maria Hinojosa of NPR interviews the subjects, including the singer-songwriter Gloria Estefan and her husband, the producer Emilio Estefan; the actors America Ferrera, John Leguizamo and Eva Longoria; the writer Sandra Cisneros; José Moreno Hernández, a former NASA astronaut; Consuelo Castillo Kickbusch, who became the highest-ranking Hispanic woman in the combat support field of the United States Army; Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey; and the Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor, above. Greg Kinnear is Frank Herlihy, a two-timing yuppie who was hit by a bus while trying to avoid a falling air-conditioner. And Téa Leoni is Frank's widow, Gwen, whom he wants Bertram to befriend and prevent from remarrying. She hates Bertram at first, and then she doesn't.

Wall Street's headlong rush into emerging markets could collide with the government's push to fight corruption overseas. The Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission have been increasing their enforcement of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act in an effort to police bribery by American companies in other countries. Since 2008, the government has brought more than 150 cases under the law, dwarfing the total number filed in the previous 30 years the law was in place.

When it comes to deal-making, a global perspective matters. As economic engines stall in the United States and Western Europe, private equity firms, corporate suitors and investment bankers are increasingly venturing overseas, touching down in far-flung locales like Uganda, Malaysia and Chile.

OPENINGS As Milan Fashion Week ends and Italian design is the talk of the fashion world, what better time for the ROBERTO CAVALLI shop to reopen at 711 Madison Avenue, (212) 755-7722; robertocavalli.com. The renovated store is done up in the designer's signature animal prints, with python-print leather chairs and pony-hair rugs. It will sell men's wear and accessories on the ground floor and women's clothing and shoes, including crocodile skin ankle boots, $1,350, upstairs. ... As of Friday, residents of the Flatiron district can add French flair to their wardrobes as COMPTOIR DES COTONNIERS moves to the neighborhood. It's the brand's fifth store in New York, and one of its largest in the world, and will be stocked with the fall collection, including pieces like a jacket with leather sleeves, $275. It will also carry the College collection, a new line for girls in their early teens, including a checkered dress, $120, and a knit cardigan, $135. At 137 Fifth Avenue, (212) 460-5289; comptoirdescotonniers.com. ... As fall weather sets it, thoughts may not turn to beach season, yet VILEBREQUIN has opened a flagship at 1007 Madison Avenue, (212) 650-0353; www.vilebrequin.com. It will stock colorful swimsuits inspired by the art of Andy Warhol. And for kids who want to sport the same suit as Dad, select prints are available in both ''father and son'' sizing. ... WITH & WESSEL, a label introduced this fall by the husband and wife team of Stian Tolnaes and Cathrine Wessel, has opened its first store, at 247 Elizabeth Street, (917) 261-5607; withandwessel.com. Inspired by their Norwegian roots, the couple's collections are made of 100 percent merino wool of different weights, including T-shirts and leggings; a wrap cardigan, $250; and a men's henley, $120.

THE new Intermix outpost in the meatpacking district sits right at the southern entrance to the High Line, which is fast becoming a lustrous magnet for fashion-seeking tourists and stylish neighborhood regulars. Taking their cues from the reclaimed railway, the Intermix designers retained the building's original overhead steel tracks. (The space once housed the Manhattan Refrigerating Company, and the trains ran right through it, off-loading inside.) Now, at the glass-enclosed boutique, shoppers can build a chic look from the two floors of designer wares, with exclusive pieces from brands like Rag & Bone, Helmut Lang and Derek Lam. There are fur vests from Adrienne Landau and Yves Salomon, shearling moto jackets courtesy of Preen Line and Rag & Bone, and a selection of sexy high-heel booties from Giuseppe Zanotti and Brian Atwood. Intermix, 812 Washington Street, (646) 480-5762; intermixonline.com.

The 67th floor of Two International Finance Center, a soaring silver tower in Hong Kong, has a new resident. DST Global, the Russian multibillion-dollar investment firm, quietly opened its China headquarters here in August. The office, with four investment professionals, is DST's largest single team - a telling sign of its founder Yuri Milner's growing ambitions for the region.

WALLACE--George A. P.,A professional engineer who dedicated much of his professional career to promoting the adoption of energy-saving technologies in home and industrial heating and cooling, died on September 25, 2011 in Lakeville, CT at age 85. He was a long-time resident of New York City and Northwest Corner, CT. Mr. Wallace came from a long line of Scottish explorers, soldiers, industrialists, and engineers. Born in Chester, PA in 1926, Mr. Wallace chose to pursue his education as a chemical engineer, graduating from Cornell University with a Bachelor's degree in Chemical Engineering and a Masters of Engineering certificate in 1947. With his strong engineering background, Mr. Wallace became a licensed Professional Engineer with the State of New York, a life member of the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating, and Air-conditioning Engineers and member of the New York Academy of Sciences. After a brief career in the chemical industry, Mr. Wallace, Samuel Eannace, and a group of associates formed Wallace Eannace Associates, Inc., a new type of sales engineering firm in the New York-New Jersey region. Specializing in pumping and heat transfer equipment, the company combines technical service and education with product distribution. His goals were to promote awareness of the need and feasibility of improving the efficiency of HVAC systems, a goal that was significantly stimulated during the 1970's when the US was suffering under the Arab oil embargo and was being forced to recognize the urgency of reducing its dependence on Mideast oil. Under this pressure and supported by government, HVAC engineers began to develop and install energy-conserving systems to replace older fuel-wasting types. One of Mr. Wallace's major disappointments was witnessing support for these innovations fade as cheap foreign oil once again became available. However, in Europe, a partnership of governments and industry was pushing greater efficiency in all energy use. Mr. Wallace studied these systems and helped to stimulate some adoption in the US. Coincidentally, nuclear energy was being promoted as the solution to fossil fuel dependency. Mr. Wallace was a member and backer of the Union of Concerned Scientists virtually from its inception and strongly supported their efforts to monitor the hazards of the expansion of the nuclear industry and its adaptation to military usage. Mr. Wallace long felt that commercial interests too often trump sound science in setting directions for bringing technological developments into use by society. He remained actively engaged in these issues and in his business interests virtually to the end of his life. In addition to his commitment to the Union of Concerned Scientists, Mr. Wallace was a dedicated supporter of many national and local environmental organizations, including Salisbury Land Trust, Sharon Audubon, Appalachian Mountain Club, American Bird Conservancy, and Sierra Club. Mr. Wallace served in the United States Navy as an Aviation Radio Technician during World War II and received an honorable discharge in 1946. He is fondly remembered by his family and friends as a sensitive man with a keen sense of the importance of personal relationships in private and professional life. Mr. Wallace was an extremely thoughtful and intellectual man who placed a high premium on dialogue, the objective exchange of ideas, and on scientific education and understanding in society. He was an avid reader and life-long student of world history. Mr. Wallace is survived by his wife of 54 years, Joan, a son, George E. Wallace of Warrenton, VA, two daughters, E. Ainslie Wallace of Salisbury, CT and Elaine Connolly of Scarborough, ME, and eight grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a donation to the Union of Concerned Scientists either via their website at www.ucsusa.org or by mail to Union of Concerned Scientists, Attn: John Mace, 2 Brattle Square, Cambridge, MA 02138.

MORRIS--Malamud B. on September 27, 2011. Beloved husband of the late Myrtle, father of Gary and Deborah, grandfather of Rebecca and Joshua. Graveside service Sunday, October 2, 3pm, New Montefiore Cemetery.

''BECOMING YOURSELF: THE AFTERLIFE OF RECEPTION'' by Ed Finn, a University Innovation Fellow at Arizona State University. This essay is the third in a series of pamphlets published online by the Stanford Literary Lab. THE ARGUMENT The literary elite has traditionally served as judge and jury when it comes to measuring a contemporary writer's influence. Mr. Finn, who recently completed his doctorate in English at Stanford University, argues that there is a better way: ''We need to look beyond the symbolic markets of prestige to the real market, the site of mass literary consumption, where authors succeed or fail based on their ability to speak to that most diverse and complicated of readerships: the general public.''

Mo Rothman, a film executive and entrepreneur who was instrumental in reviving interest in Charlie Chaplin's movies in the 1970s, and who orchestrated the aging star's triumphant return to the United States in 1972 after a bitter, self-imposed exile of 20 years, died on Sept. 15 in Los Angeles. He was 92. His death was confirmed by his wife, Lyn. Mr. Rothman, an experienced distributor of American films to overseas audiences and an instinctive publicist, had become an independent operator in 1971 when he and the 82-year-old Chaplin met at the star's 38-acre Swiss estate and signed a $7 million deal for distribution rights to some of Chaplin's most famous work, including ''City Lights,''''Modern Times,''''The Gold Rush,''''Limelight,'' and ''The Great Dictator.''

A bill that would have required New York City mayors to disclose when they make long-distance trips will not get a hearing in the City Council, the bill's sponsor, Peter F. ''I was told that the Council was focusing on other issues,'' he said.

The fourth annual Food and Drink issue is like one of those dinner parties where you decide to make something you've never tried before. An experiment in real time, with inescapable consequences for your trusting guests. In place of the long-form narrative journalism that is our stock in trade, we concocted a completely bite-size issue made up of concise answers to a wide-ranging series of questions. Everything from "How can you tell if food is genetically engineered?" to "How many kinds of Pringles are there?" (Anyone for Hong Kong Fish Balls? Yes, that's a flavor.) The longest answer is about 600 words, or less than one-tenth the size of a typical cover story, and there are more than 50 of them. We did this because it enabled us to cover a lot of ground, and because we thought it would be fun just to change up the menu.

No politician was more determined than Senator Charles Sumner of Massachusetts to ensure that secession and war resulted in emancipation. He interpreted every event through the lens of freedom. A quick end to the conflict, he feared, would leave slavery intact. Although he did not wish for it, he saw the benefit of the humiliating Union defeat at Bull Run in July 1861. He informed the abolitionist Wendell Phillips, "The battle & defeat have done much for the slave. I told the Predt that our defeat was the worst event & the best event in our history; the worst, as it was the greatest present calamity & shame, - the best, as it made the extinction of Slavery inevitable."

Several years ago, in the late '80s, I met my friend Tim Blanks over lunch at the Fiera in Milan. In those days, most of the designers, with the notable exception of Giorgio Armani, showed in the Fiera, including Gianni Versace, and it was convenient to stay for lunch; the food was good, too. Afterward, Tim and I walked to the Romeo Gigli store, then in a Renault garage that in time became Corso Como 10. Everyone seemed to make that pilgrimage, so popular were Mr. Gigli's trousers, coats and sari-colored shirts that they became a fashion uniform.

No product was used by Stephane Lancien backstage at Isabel Marant to create mussed hair meant to look as if a girl had just been for a spin in a convertible. "Sexy - but by mistake," said Lancien of the messy, haphazard style. The face was more low key. "It's my makeup in real life," said the model Snejana Onopka of Karim Rahman's work. A longtime collaborator with Marant, Rahman managed to make sense of the designer's taste for duality. "She likes color; she doesn't like color. She likes lipstick; she doesn't like lipstick," he said. "It's a fine balance." This effect was created using foundation mixed with moisturizer and a flush of L'Oréal Glam Bronze in Golden and Universal Sun all over the face and close to the nose "like sun marks." There was no mascara, but brown kohl was penciled between upper and lower lashes and blended with the finger. Lips were a bright salmon - L'Oréal Colour Riche Pink Passion - apparently the anti-color, anti-lipstick of lipsticks.

The Boston Red Sox announced Friday that they would not pick up their option on Terry Francona's contract, parting ways with the manager who led them to the World Series championships in 2004 and 2007 after decades of failure. Gambling on contemporary art is a risky business. Yet for the collectors he advises, Allan Schwartzman's knack for choosing works that only gain value makes him seem psychic. On the home front, Schwartzman, 54, has been similarly clairvoyant, amassing exactly the right pieces he would need for his New York apartment years before it ever existed. "I've always loved furniture," he says, "and before I started buying art I thought I'd collect it. I knew someday I would move, and just hoped it fit whatever place I moved to."

At around 12:30 backstage at Dior, a model let out a shriek just as Pat McGrath was discussing products necessary for fatigued or bug-bitten skin (as was the case in mosquito-ridden Milan). The timing was uncanny, as the provocateur was a large grasshopper that managed to make his rounds all the way over to where Orlando Pita was working on hair. Mosquitoes in Milan and grasshoppers, er sauterelles - not the garden variety - at the Musee de Rodin: oh my! The look, according to Pita was "very fresh and modern, turning a page from the past," at least for this season. This meant a twist of a bun with a side part and slight wave in the front created by using Pita's Plump for volume, control hairspray and dry shampoo. The trick was that there was no ponytail beneath to hold the hair; it was deceptively simple. For makeup, McGrath went with a contoured eye and "classic, beautiful red lip." One of the 28 members of McGrath's team brought a face by for her approval. "Don't forget, kids: not a hard lip with pencil, I prefer the finger, it's softer." This is what made the lady modern. Three of Dior's reds were used, chosen based on the clothes: red orange, blue orange and pinky red. Nails were also a mix of five shades: Incognito, a nude; Riviera, an orange; Waterlily, a green; Forget me not, a lavender; and Lucky, a red.

I've been making this pasta for a very long time, probably since the 1980s, since it's derived from a Marcella Hazan recipe. It's dead simple - one of the things that I love about it - and you can precook the cauliflower a day ahead or so if you'd like. I usually do the whole thing at once: cook the cauliflower in water, scoop it out and then, later, cook the pasta in the same water. It's already boiling, and you want the taste of the cauliflower anyway, so why not?

Waiting for the Maison Martin Margiela show this afternoon, I was horrified, and slightly entertained, to hear the tale of Drew Elliott's amazing adventure ride into Paris from the airport that morning. First, Mr. Elliott, of Paper Magazine, was on a delayed flight that arrived six hours late. Then his cab driver, halfway into the city, received a cellphone call alerting him that his wife had gone into labor. The driver pulled over and deposited Mr. Elliott and his luggage on the side of the road.

When Caroline Burnett decided to open Heroes, in Berlin's Neukölln district, her initial emphasis was not on food. "The cafe was a pretext for the art," says Burnett, an American editor who curates art shows in a dynamic exhibition space in the back. Today she and her partner, Damien Poinsard, a French-born cook who helps run a theater group on the side, are drawing regulars as much with their down-home fare as with their roster of up-and-coming artists. Crepes and quiches are standards; specials depend on who's cooking. If Poinsard is in the kitchen, the menu might include pot au feu or stewed chicken; when Burnett is in, she says, the special is likely to be meatloaf, reflecting her nostalgia for home. So you wanted to clean grease off a bit of machinery. The year was 1956 or 1971 or even 1993. Your cleaner of choice was probably the industrial degreaser trichloroethylene, a petroleum-based clear liquid that was as common in mid-20th-century America as Ipana toothpaste, Crackerjack and asbestos. It was used in dry-cleaning, in machine shops and on military bases.

Jean and Steven Goldman have always done things their way - which has usually meant swimming against the current. In the mid-1960s, when the newly married couple lived in Cambridge, Mass., where Steven attended Harvard Law School and Jean worked as a curator at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston, they could have bought Warhols and Lichtensteins (which were going for a song then). Instead, they set their sights on what Jean has called "postage-stamp Renaissance scribbles," gradually amassing a large and important collection of Italian drawings from the 15th to the 17th centuries.

Cabo Polonio, a remote beach village in southeastern Uruguay, sits on a green peninsula between the Atlantic and a desert landscape of shifting sand dunes. Strewn across the grassy promontory are a single lighthouse and a few hundred whimsical dwellings. Rasta-colored flags serve as wind vanes, tinted glass bottles are embedded in walls, and exteriors are painted with pictures of suns, cow spots, rainbows and a Klimt-like rendering of a woman. One stands out as particularly fanciful. It's more sculpture than cabin, constructed from panes of glass, wood, plastic, bamboo blinds and green plexiglass, with tall, lush plants growing out of the floor.

Each April, during the Milan Furniture Fair, the German lighting designer Ingo Maurer presents an exhibition of new work. These shows, which highlight Maurer's innovative, provocative and poetic pieces (and those of designers whose ideas he finds interesting), never fail to impress. But this year, Maurer - who designs everything from table lights to subway stations, and who was recently awarded the prestigious Compasso d'Oro for career achievement - outdid himself with a design that was, in a word, enchanting. A 12-foot-high hanging mass of emerald-green sponges seemed to glow from within (thanks to hidden L.E.D.'s), and teemed with life in the form of about 100 exquisite, hand-painted models of butterflies, dragonflies, lizards and other creatures. This wasn't, strictly speaking, a light fixture - not that it mattered to besotted observers. But what exactly was it?

There's a reigning joke that commands everyone to "set their clocks to Pacific Standard Time" this weekend, as the decade-in-the-making horde of exhibitions and events in and around Los Angeles chronicling the area's postwar art scenes finally kicks off. Perhaps the most countercultural and sunshiny of the opening parties will be the Tresspass Parade barnstorming Downtown L.A.'s historic Broadway district on Sunday morning. The event - helmed by the genre-bending artists Arto Lindsay and Rirkrit Tiravanija, and organized by former the Milan gallerist Emi Fontana's Pasadena project space West of Rome - is a celebration of Southern California's time-honored tradition of festive dissidence. Floats, costumes and other parade paraphernalia should be done up in subversive style. And there will be T-shirts! - onto which 2-D luminaries like John Baldessari and Barbara Kruger will emblazon call-to-action slogans.

Jets (2-1) at Ravens (2-1)Sunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Ravens by 3.5.Any team coached by a member of the Ryan family does not so much play a 16-game schedule as careen from bitter rivalry to bitter rivalry, each game becoming the kind of over-boiled grudge match usually settled with suplexes and folding chairs at ringside. It happened to Buddy Ryan's Eagles, and it has happened to Rex Ryan's Jets.Jets-Cowboys becomes Rex Ryan against Rob Ryan. Jets-Patriots becomes Rex Ryan against Bill Belichick. Jets-Ravens devolves into Rex Ryan against the team that declined to promote him to head coach when he was its defensive coordinator. Next time the Jets face the Raiders, it will be Rex Ryan against the team that broke his quarterback's nose. Even Rex Ryan could not muster a feud with the Jaguars, but Joe Namath got into the act this week, so if you play the current Jets against the 1968 version in a video game, that is now a grudge match, too.Granted, the presence of the ex-Ravens Bart Scott, Jim Leonhard and Derrick Mason on the Jets roster does give the game a familiarity-breeds-contempt angle. "This is a family game, but it's also a heated rivalry," said Ravens defensive end Terrell Suggs, perhaps not realizing that Jets charity softball tournaments are also heated rivalries. "You've got to go beat up on the ones you love." In other words, this time it's personal. Just like all the other times. Pick: Jets.

A LOOK at the postseason, which didn't really take shape until Wednesday night's wild finish. From left, JOSH HAMILTON of Texas isback after leading his team to the 2010 World Series; JUSTIN VERLANDER of Detroit is a most valuable player candidate in the Ameri- can League; ROY HALLADAY pitched a no-hitter last October for Philadelphia, and no one would be shocked if he did it again; ALBERT PUJOLS of St. Louis is probably the most feared hitter in the postseason; Milwaukee's PRINCE FIELDER is almost as fearsome as Pujols; JUSTIN UPTON is the biggest name on a fairly anonymous Arizona club; EVAN LONGORIA hit the homer that put Tampa Bay in the playoffs; and the Yankees' DEREK JETER finished the season at .297, proving he isn't anywhere near done.

CUNNEEN--John Michael. Manhattan lawyer, died on September 27, 2011 at the age of 92. Beloved son of the late John James Cunneen and Mary Margaret Cunneen (nee Beha). Loving father of five and adored grandfather of Olivia and Jasper Cunneen. Dear brother of Joseph Cunneen and the late Mary Elizabeth Riely. He attended Xavier High School, Holy Cross College and Columbia Law School. After joining the U.S. Attorney's Office in Manhattan he went into private practice. He served in the Navy during World War II in the Pacific and later as naval attache in Rangoon, Burma. A long standing member of The Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, he is remembered for his fierce loyalty to his family, his stubbornness and dry wit, his Roman Catholic faith, his incomprehensible devotion to the Red Sox and Celtics, and his kindness to strangers. All in all a "top notch" guy. Mass of Christian burial to be held today 12:30pm at The Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY. A memorial service will be held in Manhattan at a later date. Please call Andrett Funeral Home 212-475-2024 for more information.

In the 1970s, when photography became a serious hobby for Leland Bobbé, he was the drummer in a band called City Lights that played the downtown scene, where he eventually photographed the Ramones, Mink DeVille, Patti Smith, Television and others. Mr. Bobbé's band issued an album on Sire Records in 1975, but he supported himself by driving a cab, and he spent many hours observing the streets. He also spent considerable time riding his bike up and down the Bowery.

The Detroit Tigers opened the season on March 31 at Yankee Stadium. On the last day of September, they will start the postseason in the same place. In between, they reversed a discouraging trend that had kept them from the playoffs the last four seasons. After reaching the World Series in 2006, the Tigers made a habit of wilting down the stretch. They finished a combined 28 games below .500 after the All-Star break from 2007 through 2010, and started this year's second half with two losses, dropping a game behind Cleveland on July 16.

Jon M. Huntsman Jr. is moving his presidential campaign headquarters to New Hampshire from Florida, aides said Thursday, a decision that underscores that his path to the nomination is wholly dependent on trying to score an upset in the nation's first primary. The Huntsman campaign has been focusing intensively on New Hampshire for weeks, all but abandoning the three-state strategy that once included South Carolina and Florida. But the decision to close the Orlando office and relocate the staff to Manchester signals a new sense of urgency and is part of what one adviser characterized as a ''course correction.''

9 P.M. (13) HUGH LAURIE: LET THEM TALK -- A CELEBRATION OF NEW ORLEANS BLUES Mr. Laurie (''House''), right, who was first introduced to the blues as a teenager when he heard Professor Longhair's ''Tipitina,'' tours New Orleans and sings along with some of its legends, like Allen Toussaint and Irma Thomas, while accompanying himself on the piano and guitar. He also gets a little vocal backup from his fellow Briton Tom Jones. Concert sequences in this ''Great Performances'' presentation were filmed at Latrobe's on Royal in the French Quarter; the songlist, comprised of standards and neglected gems, includes ''Swanee River,'' ''You Don't Know My Mind,'' ''Copperhead Road,'' ''John Henry,'' ''St. James Infirmary,'' ''Buddy Bolden's Blues'' and ''Baby Please Make a Change.'' Mr. Laurie appears on ''The Tonight Show With Jay Leno,'' at 11:35 on NBC. 10 A.M. (Fox Business Network) VARNEY & CO. Liz Claman interviews Warren Buffett, the chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, right, about President Obama's proposed Buffett Rule, which stipulates that people who make more than $1 million a year should pay at least the same percentage of their earnings in taxes as middle-class Americans; his recent stock repurchase; and a possible European bailout. At 11 p.m., Mr. Buffett appears on ''Charlie Rose'' on Channel 13.

STRANSKY--Otto E.,88, died September 28, 2011. Beloved husband of 58 years to Toni. Father of Mark and Barry. Loving grandfather of four and friend to many. Funeral: Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY, Sunday, October 2, 11am. Forever in our hearts.

As they rumbled through the American League playoffs last fall, the Texas Rangers knew they could count on Cliff Lee. He worked 24 innings, allowing two earned runs and earning three of the seven victories the Rangers needed to reach their first World Series. When Lee lost twice against the San Francisco Giants, he took the Rangers down with him. After losing Lee to the Philadelphia Phillies, the Rangers did not replace him with another established ace. They allocated Lee's dollars to third baseman Adrian Beltre and others, trusting that their existing stable of starters could carry them back to October.

REICHERT--Helen Faith Keane, peacefully at home on September 25, 2011 at the age of 109. A native New Yorker, born November 11, 1901, and known as "Happy," she was a proud member of the first Girl Scouts Troop who sold WWI war bonds outside the NY Public Library. Graduate of Cornell University BA '25, and Columbia University MA '31, Happy began her career as a copywriter and educator. In 1949, she founded as a voice for women, The Round Table of Fashion Executives, and in 1951, hosted TV talk show, "FYI: The Helen Faith Keane Show," on Channel 5, winning McCall's Magazine Golden Microphone Award for outstanding broadcasting service to women. She joined The Graduate School of Retailing at NYU in 1947 to teach, "Costume History," a course she created. Former students, calling her Professor Keane, became lifelong friends. Women, whose business lives she impacted, continually called for her creative input. Happy was predeceased by her husband, Philip Reichert M.D., founding member in 1949 of The American College of Cardiology, and her sister, Lee. She is survived by brothers, Irving and Peter, sister-in-law Beth, many nieces and nephews, and devoted caregiver, Olive Villaluna. In lieu of flowers, Happy, as an advocate of education, can be honored by donations to Cornell Medical College. An avid piano player, world traveler, theatergoer, scholar of history, and fan of Central Park since her childhood, Happy lived a remarkable multi-talented life. Happy are we to have called her our friend, and to have shared her laughter and her love.

Two of the best-known stock market gauges in the world - the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500 - may share the same home under a deal being discussed. McGraw-Hill, the owner of Standard & Poor's, is in advanced talks with the CME Group Inc., which owns Dow Jones Indexes, about forming a joint venture, according to people briefed on the matter who were not authorized to speak publicly.

David Zelag Goodman, a prolific screenwriter who, with Sam Peckinpah, wrote ''Straw Dogs'' and was nominated for an Academy Award for his work on the romantic comedy ''Lovers and Other Strangers,'' died on Monday in Oakland, Calif. He was 81. The cause was progressive supranuclear palsy, a neurological disorder, his wife, Marjorie Goodman, said.

MALAMUD--Morris B. on September 27, 2011. Beloved husband of the late Myrtle, father of Gary and Deborah, grandfather of Rebecca and Joshua. Graveside service Sunday, October 2, 3pm, New Montefiore Cemetery.

A blockbuster film is headed to the Museum of Modern Art, and it didn't even have to make a dent at the box office. The museum announced that it would buy ''The Clock,'' a 24-hour video installation by Christian Marclay that uses a montage of timepieces from movies to count down a day in real time. The film earned Mr. Marclay the Golden Lion as best artist at the Venice Biennale this year, and the work was a surprise hit with the public, drawing overflow gallery crowds at all hours when it was shown in London, Los Angeles and New York in the last year.

An article on Thursday about Costco's efforts to get cantaloupe farmers to adopt measures to prevent bacterial contamination of the fruit misidentified the city in Washington State where the company has its headquarters. It is in Issaquah, not Seattle.

The rapper T.I. was released from a halfway house in Atlanta early Thursday morning after spending 10 months in federal prison on a probation violation, federal prison officials told The Associated Press. In contrast to his flamboyant release from federal prison on Aug. 31, T.I. left the halfway house with no fanfare. He got into a chauffeur-driven car and pulled out. The rapper, whose real name is Clifford J. Harris Jr., was punished with an extra two-week stint in prison after his manager, his wife and a television producer picked him up from an Arkansas prison in a luxury bus and transported him to Atlanta.

Julie Taymor will square off next week against the theater producers who fired her in March as director of the Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' as the two sides begin arbitration proceedings over more than $500,000 in royalties that Ms. Taymor says she is owed. Ms. Taymor's union, the Stage Directors and Choreographers Society, filed an arbitration claim against the ''Spider-Man'' producers in June, shortly before the $75 million musical - the most expensive in Broadway history - opened to mixed reviews from theater critics. The union said that the producers had not paid Ms. Taymor any royalties covering the run of the show, which began preview performances in late November 2010, and that she received only a $125,000 fee five years ago. She was let go in March after artistic clashes with the producers, who had wanted her to make substantial changes after critics savaged the musical in an early round of reviews last winter.

LONDON -- The fallout of Manchester City's defeat in Munich is only just beginning. The story so far is that Carlos Tévez, the captain last season for City and its leading goal scorer, refused to play when called from the bench as the team was losing, 2-0, in Bayern Munich's Allianz Arena on Tuesday.

KROLL--Arnold (Arn) H.,passed away on Tuesday, September 27, 2011 at age 76 in Orleans, MA. He graduated from Dartmouth College and Harvard Law School, and served as an officer in the U.S. Army (Artillery). After his military service, he worked as a senior investment banker involved in many domestic and foreign mergers and financings at Lehman Brothers, L.F. Rothschild Unterberg, Towbin, Wertheim Schroder and Burnham & Company. He also served on numerous public and private corporate boards of directors including being a founding board member of America West Airlines, now U.S. Airways, subsequent to its acquisition of the latter airline. Mr. Kroll lived and worked in New York City and served as a trustee of the Lexington School for the Deaf and the Hewitt School, as well as on the board of the Child Care Action Campaign. Since retirement, Mr. Kroll lived on Amelia Island, Florida and spent the summers on Cape Cod. During his time in Florida, he served on the board of the Nassau County (Florida) Volunteer Center, as a mentor for Take Stock in Children, and on the Steering Committee of Cummelia. He leaves behind his beloved wife of 46 years, Lois, as well as his daughters, Alison Hessert, Luisa Pelosi and Heather Bailey, and his granddaughters, Montana, Gabriella, Lela and Cassandra. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the MDS Foundation, www.mds-foundation.org. A memorial service will be held at the University Club in New York City on December 16.

In the final days before the close of the third quarter fund-raising period, the presidential candidates are bringing out the big guns: their spouses. ''Almost there'' was the subject line of an e-mail solicitation sent Thursday afternoon by Anita Perry, wife of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas.

A report in the Weekend Miser column last Friday about an event in the ''stillspotting nyc'' exhibition, ''To a Great City,'' a series of soundscapes created by the composer Arvo Pärt and the architecture firm Snohetta, misstated the firm's role in the National September 11 Memorial and Museum. It is designing the entry pavilion, not the memorial and museum. (Aedas Architects is designing the memorial and museum.)

An article on Thursday about a federal judge's ruling that upheld most of Alabama's far-reaching immigration law misstated the role of the American Civil Liberties Union in one of the lawsuits challenging the law. The A.C.L.U. represents plaintiffs in the suit; it is not itself a plaintiff.

An article on Thursday about a ruling in a case filed by the trustee for victims of Bernard L. Madoff's Ponzi scheme against the owners of the New York Mets misstated, because of miscalculations by the trustee, Irving H. Picard, the amount of money that might be unavailable as a result of the ruling to pay all victim claims. The recovery amount could be reduced by $6.2 billion, not $11 billion. An article updating the case is on Page B3.

The Boston Red Sox odds of reaching the playoffs peaked on Sept. 3. Following a 12-7 win against the Texas Rangers, they held a 9-game lead over the Tampa Bay Rays with 24 games to play, giving them a 99.6 percent chance of making the post-season. The Red Sox, of course, once had a reputation for elevating improbable collapses into the routine, dealing their opponents one inside straight after another.

FRASCINO--Robert James, MD Robert James Frascino, MD, who fought HIV professionally for 30 years and personally for 20 years, died suddenly on September 17 in Mtn. View, CA. He was 59. The cause of death was bacterial sepsis. His husband, Steven Natterstad, MD, and his sister, Linda Godfrey, were with Bob when he died. His dog, Presto, was also close by. Bob was a physician, an educator, a tireless advocate for the HIV/AIDS community, a trustee of Oberlin College and a concert pianist. His love of life, keen intellect, sense of humor and ever-present smile will be missed by all who knew him. His boundless generosity with his time, his energy and his advocacy encompassed his family, his friends and his community alike. Dr. Frascino crossed the line from physician to patient when an occupational exposure resulted in his testing HIV positive. In 1996, when his health began to fail, he gave up his HIV/AIDS medical practice and turned his efforts to HIV education and fundraising. In his words, "I could now speak with the knowledge and authority of a physician, but with the eyes and heart and soul of a patient." He and Steve, both concert pianists, founded the Concerted Effort benefit concert series, raising funds for crucial HIV/AIDS services worldwide. Concerted Effort 2011, the 17th in the series, was to take place on September 18, the day following Bob's death. Dr. Frascino served as a physician expert at The Body, an HIV/AIDS website. Known as "Dr. Bob" to his global online community, he touched the lives of millions of people through his forums and blog. In addition to his husband and sister, Bob is survived by his parents, Jennie and Angelo Frascino of Saratoga, CA, and by many friends, colleagues and "eyeballs" around the world. A ceremony will be held November 11 at Villa Montalvo, Saratoga, CA. A reception will follow. Donations may be made to The Robert James Frascino AIDS Foundation, 1000 Fremont Avenue, Suite 145, Los Altos, CA 94024. www.concertedeffort.org

LONG--Cindy, of Clarksville, TN, on September 19. Beloved life companion of Becky Garland, sister of Harriet Karns and David (Sharon) Long. Also survived by her nephews Gordon and Scott Karns. Updated, 12:30 a.m. Friday | Service on the Long Island Rail Road was largely suspended out of Penn Station and Atlantic Terminal in Brooklyn Thursday evening after a lightning strike near the Jamaica hub of the railroad knocked out signal systems. Officials were warning customers that the continuing trouble with the signals would most likely affect service Friday morning. The doors to Penn Station were closed for a while because of overcrowding. After 11:30 p.m., commuters could again get into the station, and the railroad resumed hourly service to Babylon, Huntington, Long Beach and Ronkonkoma.
