A report in the World Briefings column on Sept. 15 about a Vatican offer of reconciliation to the Society of St. Pius X, a breakaway group, misidentified the cleric who was excommunicated for ordaining four of its bishops without permission in 1988. He was Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre -- not Bishop Bernard Fellay, who was one of the four bishops ordained, and subsequently excommunicated. The report also misstated a detail behind the international anger over Pope Benedict XVI's lifting of the excommunications of the four bishops in 2009. The anger arose because one of the four bishops, Richard Williamson, was already known to have denied the scope of the Holocaust. That information had not just emerged.

The United States Capitol Police on Thursday said they were investigating The Onion, a satiric media organization, for making false reports on Twitter claiming that there was a hostage situation inside the Capitol building. Starting at 10:33 a.m., The Onion's Twitter account began spewing the fake messages that began with this post: ''BREAKING: Witnesses reporting screams and gunfire heard inside Capitol building.''

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the Federal Trade Commission's decision that Reebok International had not substantiated body-toning claims for its EasyTone sneakers described incorrectly the listing status of Adidas, Reebok's parent. Its shares trade on the Frankfurt exchange; it does not have American depository receipts.

Billboard's headline says it all: ''Tony Bennett Becomes Oldest Living Artist to Top Billboard 200.'' Last week Mr. Bennett, 85, released ''Duets II'' (Columbia), which features his collaborations with Lady Gaga, Amy Winehouse, Carrie Underwood and others many decades his junior, and sang a belated birthday concert at the Metropolitan Opera that was attended by Bill and Hillary Clinton.

A tell-all memoir from Courtney Love will be released by William Morrow next fall, the publisher said on Thursday. Ms. Love, the musician and actress, will give an account of her life from childhood to the present, including tales from her own band, Hole, her stints in Hollywood, her marriage to Kurt Cobain and her relationships with Billy Corgan and Edward Norton. Ms. Love will work with a co-writer, Anthony Bozza. ''Courtney is one of the most fascinating and provocative artists of our time, one of those rare performers who continues to reinvent herself time and again throughout the arc of her career,'' Lynn Grady, the deputy publisher of Morrow, said in a statement. ''It's time for the public to hear her tell her story, as she lived it.''

The German Parliament's move to expand the euro-zone bailout fund on Thursday is welcome, but the European debt crisis is no closer to resolution than it was two months ago. Even with Germany's roughly $287 billion increased contribution, the fund is still too small to provide more than a few days of calm to jittery markets. The big picture, in fact, has gotten much worse. Greece's indebtedness is growing, European bank balance sheets are shakier and investors are increasingly skeptical that Europe has the will to stabilize shaky credit and stock markets. Also conspicuously lacking is any clear plan for generating the economic growth needed to begin paying down those growing debts.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- All Tomorrow's Parties, the festival that pays lovingly microscopic attention to olden tastes in underground pop from around the world, started its three-day run last night. It has relocated its New York-area edition to Asbury Park from the Catskills, and this was a life-affirming move. The old place, Kutshers Country Club, is a down-at-heels resort -- the enclosed and remote feeling there made the event feel like a quarantined zone for those afflicted with obscure interests.

Karlie Kloss closed the Dior show on Friday in a gown with a black lace top and a transparent pink skirt that revealed most of her rear end, a finale that some online commentators read as a pointed statement by its temporary designer. Bill Gaytten has been directing the studio while the label seeks a successor to John Galliano, who was fired in the spring, but Mr. Gaytten has not been seen as a likely candidate for the job since his couture collection, shown in July, was widely panned.

On a recent evening at Colicchio & Sons, in the Meatpacking District, the wine writer Mark Oldman attended an engagement dinner during which several bottles of 1970 Chateau Palmer were drunk. "I still remember the plums-and-truffle perfume and enduringly silky, savory finish," Oldman said. He was so enamored, in fact, that before leaving, he snuck out an empty bottle with him as a souvenir. (Oenophiles, Oldman noted, refer to empties as "dead soldiers.")

The proliferation of steady rains from August onwards has yielded a stunning crop of mushrooms this fall, both edible and otherwise. Recently, I found a lovely maitake mushroom cluster that weighed over two pounds growing at the base of a giant pin oak near where I was staying just outside New Paltz. The maitake had grown over and around a fallen branch, and there were a few acorns attached to the bottom. I took the whole thing home.

The synth-pop duo known as Bubbles recently performed at the Agnès B. flagship store in Soho. A crowd of forty or so looked on as Alain Levitt banged on his machines, and Jason P. Grisell flailed around the small stage area. Endearingly low-maintenance, the group wins hearts with their unpretentious slacks, sneakers, and baseball hats. Bubbles has played most of the better underground venues in New York, and is steadily gaining steam. And yet, while Levitt's music was danceable and solidly interesting, Grisell's vocals left the audience pondering whether or not we are in for a revival of that No-Wave school of "Can't sing? Start a hit band!'"

In "The Scrapbook of Frankie Pratt" (Ecco, $26), Caroline Preston, a former archivist, pastes vintage postcards, Jazz Age ephemera and typewritten snippets into a sweetly beguiling novel about a New England girl who trades Vassar College for Greenwich Village on the advice of Edna St. Vincent Millay.

There's bad news from the workplace: as The New York Times reported on Tuesday, the cost of health insurance rose sharply in 2011 after several years of relatively slow growth. According to the Kaiser Family Foundation's annual survey on employer health benefits, the average premium to insure a family of four grew 9 percent, to just over $15,073. For single coverage, premiums rose 8 percent, to $5,429.

UPDATE 5 p.m.: Florida has decided to hold its Republican primary on Jan. 31 next year, ignoring party rules that require later voting and likely pushing a string of other states to move their contests up. Florida's decision is certain to mean that Iowa, Nevada, New Hampshire and South Carolina will all move to hold their nominating contests earlier in January.

8:51 p.m. | Updated The insider trading investigation of Mark Cuban, the billionaire owner of the Dallas Mavericks basketball team, began more than two years after the trading took place, when a lawyer for the Securities and Exchange Commission discovered a post in an Internet chat room suggesting that the trading was illegal, according to an S.E.C. report released Friday.

The St. Louis Cardinals spent so long chasing the Atlanta Braves, Tony La Russa said, that their goal was simply to force a one-game playoff on Thursday. It was not until the pregame hours Wednesday that La Russa even looked ahead to the division series schedule. When he did, he saw an encouraging sign: the series would not start until Saturday. This meant that Chris Carpenter, the Cardinals' No. 1 starter, could potentially start twice in a five-game series. The plan crystallized when Carpenter shut out Houston, 8-0, on Wednesday, giving the Cardinals the wild card when the Braves lost to the Phillies.

The old savings advice about skipping your daily cup of coffee and banking the cash instead has never really resonated with me. For one thing, I really, really like my morning Joe. Plus, would I actually put the money in an account? Or would I spend it on, say, Altoids instead? So I'm happy to ignore the financial benefit of delaying that particular bit of gratification.

3rd Ward, the five-year-old Brooklyn arts and design collective, is expanding to Philadelphia, the organization announced on its blog. A lease has been signed on a 27,000-square foot space -- a historic church and two adjoining warehouses -- in the Northern Liberties/Old Kensington neighborhood in north Philadelphia, where 3rd Ward will offer classes in woodworking, jewelry-making, screen-printing, graphic design and other disciplines, as it does in Brooklyn. The collective hopes to attract the same kind of freelancers, artisans and dabblers to its new space, which will be renovated.

BACH--Julian. Born on August 31, 1914 in Deal, New Jersey, and died September 30, 2011 at his home in New York City at the age of 97. He was graduated from The Choate School and from Harvard College, Magna cum Laude, Phi Beta Kappa. While at Harvard, he was published in "The New Republic" and had covered the coal mines of Pennsylvania and West Virginia, textile mill towns in the South and the drought in the dust bowls of the Midwest. He then became a junior foreign correspondent in London and the Balkans for Raymond Moley's Today magazine. After a stint at the London School of Economics, he became an editor of Life Magazine, when it was just a year old. His eleven years at Life were interrupted by four years in the Army. He volunteered for the infantry the day after the United States entered the war and served in Iceland, England, France, the Battle of the Bulge and Germany rising to the rank of captain. On his voyage home he wrote "America's Germany", which had been commissioned by Random House. Returning to Life Magazine for a few years, he left to become executive editor of True, then the world's largest men's magazine, and subsequently editor-in-chief of its sister magazine, Today's Woman. In the early sixties he formed The Julian Bach Literacy Agency with the help of Christopher Shaw, eventually representing some 500 primarily American and English authors. He loved music and was a devotee of concerts and the Metropolitan Opera. An enthusiastic traveler, he particularly liked hiking in the Swiss Alps. He attended virtually every Harvard varsity and freshman football game, both home and away until his mid eighties. His brief marriage to Kathryn Rains ended in divorce. In 1947, he married Halle Cowen (Schlesinger) who died in 1972. He is survived by his wife of 34 years, Hope Liberman (Harris), his daughter, Prudence Mortimer (Jay), his sister Doris Gordon, his stepson, Arthur (Tony) Cowen III (Edna), his stepdaughters, Alice Eberhardt (Ron), Audrey Matson (Marcus). He was predeceased by another stepdaughter, Halle (Jill) Cowen. He is also survived by seven grandchildren: Harriman Bach Mortimer, Jeffrey Cowen, Jane Cowen Hamilton, Eliza Cowen, Katherine Nintzel, Abigail Nintzel, Claire Matson and two great-grandchildren. Services at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel) Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Tuesday, October 4th at 11am. Burial private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The New York Service for the Handicapped, 1140 Broadway, NY, NY 10001.

NO. 8 NEBRASKA AT NO. 7 WISCONSIN 8 p.m. Eastern, ABC Nebraska's first Big Ten game is one of the most anticipated matchups of the season. This is the first meeting of top-10 teams in Madison since 1962. So far, Wisconsin, behind quarterback Russell Wilson, has overwhelmed opponents. Nebraska has also scored a lot of points, but its defense has been suspect, giving up 29 points to Fresno State and 38 against Washington. The Cornhuskers will need to be better defensively, but much also hinges on the play of quarterback Taylor Martinez. While Wilson looks to throw before scrambling, Martinez is second in the Big Ten with 421 yards rushing and has run for seven touchdowns. Nebraska is 10-0 when he rushes for more than 50 yards.

PINEDA--Andre, was a Democratic pollster with more than 20 years of experience in national, state and local politics. Among his many accomplishments, Andre conducted public opinion research for former New Mexico Governor Bill Richardson during the Democratic presidential primary in 2008, and later ran Latino voter research for Barack Obama's general election campaign. In addition to his work in this country, Andre conducted research in France, Germany and the Netherlands in order to help his technology clients better understand their new customer base. He worked on behalf of political and corporate clients from the Americas, Europe and Asia. Pineda also won competitive selection by the European Union to a program designed to give young leaders from around the world a first-hand appreciation of the EU's goals, policies and peoples. He was an example to young politicos everywhere, particularly at the University of Southern California, where he served as a lecturer, mentor and role model to USC students through his work at the Jesse M. Unruh Institute of Politics. Andre was a tremendous pollster, political professional, peer and friend. He will be missed.

10 P.M. (Cinemax) BLACK SWAN (2010) Natalie Portman, above, in the role that earned her an Academy Award, stars as Nina, a ballerina teetering on the brink of insanity as she tries to break out of the corps and into the dual lead of ''Swan Lake'': the Swan Queen and her villainous black swan twin. Mila Kunis is Lily, the sultry newcomer who is everything the increasingly tormented Nina is not, as their company's artistic director, Thomas (Vincent Cassel), insists on pointing out. And Barbara Hershey is Nina's mother, a former dancer who desperately wants her daughter to achieve everything she never could. The result is ''a witchy brew of madness and cunning,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this film from Darren Aronofsky (''The Wrestler''), which also earned Oscar nominations for best director and picture. ''One of the pleasures of 'Black Swan' is its lack of reverence toward the rarefied world of ballet, which to outsiders can look as lively as a crypt,'' Ms. Dargis said. ''Mr. Aronofsky makes this world (or his version of it) exciting partly by pulling back the velvet curtains and showing you the sacrifices and crushingly hard work that go into creating beautiful dances.'' She added, ''Much like the new version of 'Swan Lake' that Thomas creates, 'Black Swan' is visceral and real even while it's one delirious, phantasmagoric freakout.'' NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND Robert Darnton, the director of the Harvard University Library, discusses his crusade for the creation of an international digital public library based on Thomas Jefferson's belief that ''the field of knowledge is the common property of mankind.''

He may have lost his crown as the person who has most often hosted ''Saturday Night Live,'' but Steve Martin has since claimed another prize that we don't see Alec Baldwin taking away from him any time soon. On Thursday night Mr. Martin and his bluegrass band, the Steep Canyon Rangers, were named entertainer of the year at the International Bluegrass Music Association Awards in Nashville, The Associated Press reported. At a ceremony at the Ryman Auditorium, Mr. Martin and the Steep Canyon Rangers unseated Dailey & Vincent, who had won the award, the association's top prize, for three consecutive years. In an acceptance speech Mr. Martin said, ''I want to thank all the other nominees -- for losing.'' He was more conciliatory in remarks he made afterward, telling The A.P.: ''It really means a lot, sort of like winning two Oscars. It's something we work very hard at and I kind of started from scratch. I mean I've been playing banjo for 50 years, but performing in a band I've never done.'' He added, ''You know, the hardest part was talking and tuning.''

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is scheduled to take the witness stand Monday morning to testify against a Republican political consultant accused of stealing more than $1 million from him, according to two people familiar with the trial schedule. The much-anticipated testimony is expected to be among the most intriguing pieces of courtroom theater in the city's recent history, with a sitting mayor becoming a state's witness. Mr. Bloomberg is known for being thin skinned when he is called to account publicly for his or his administration's actions.

12:46 p.m. | Updated Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, still reeling from a debate performance that upset many of the bedrock conservatives he considers his base, came out swinging Friday against his rival Mitt Romney, accusing the former Massachusetts governor of backing policies indistinguishable from those of President Obama and having ''paved the way for Obamacare.'' While Mr. Perry has already been sharply critical of Mr. Romney and his health care record, the Texan's speech before the Georgia Public Policy Foundation was a more intensive critique and seemed to reflect a strategy to undercut Mr. Romney's attempts to draw away Perry supporters and other Republican voters.

'' The X Factor'' once again carried Fox to a Thursday-night victory in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49-year-old demographic, despite dropping 12 percent from last week's premiere. The talent show averaged just under 12 million total viewers over a two-hour period. CBS was the most-watched network over all, with ''Big Bang Theory'' beating all competition in the 18-to-49 set and reaching 14.5 million viewers. ''Charlie's Angels'' on ABC had the largest second-week drop among Thursday programming in the 18-to-49 category, falling 29 percent and averaging 7.2 million total viewers.

An art review on Friday about '' 'Wonder of the Age': Master Painters of India, 1100-1900,'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, misstated the number of moonlit trees in a work attributed to the artist Golu of Nurpur. As an image of the work that accompanied the review showed, there are five, not six.

An article on Tuesday about a decision by the United States Postal Service to issue stamps featuring people still alive described incorrectly the measure of popularity of a 1993 stamp picturing Elvis Presley and a 1995 stamp picturing Marilyn Monroe. The Elvis stamp is considered the most popular ever because people saved 124 million of the stamps. About 44 million of the Marilyn Monroe stamps were saved. It is not the case that those totals represent the number of stamps sold. (The Postal Service rates the popularity of stamps according to how many are saved, not sold. A spokesman said there are no reliable figures on actual sales before 2008.)

The legal fusillades have continued in the battle over AT&T's proposed $39 billion acquisition of T-Mobile USA, as the telecommunications giant sought on Friday to take shots at competitors seeking to stop the takeover. AT&T moved to dismiss antitrust lawsuits by Sprint Nextel and Cellular South, arguing that both companies are looking to block the deal for self-interested reasons, not because the combination of AT&T and T-Mobile would be bad for competition. (Here's AT&T's Sprint response, and here's its Cell South response.)

Two closely watched musicals under development - stage adaptations of the film ''Little Miss Sunshine'' and of the novel-turned-movie ''American Psycho'' - have been moving forward recently, theater executives familiar with both projects said on Tuesday. La Jolla Playhouse, which produced the world premiere of ''Little Miss Sunshine'' last spring, held a private reading this month of a revised script for the musical, which had drawn mixed reviews in California, according to one of the executives, who is not involved with the show. Tony Award nominees Raul Esparza (''Speed-the-Plow,'' ''Company'') and Sherie Rene Scott (''Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown'') were among the actors who joined in the reading, which was overseen by James Lapine (who wrote the book and also directed the production at La Jolla). William Finn (''Falsettos'') wrote the music and lyrics.

MULLEN--George J.,Jr. The Board of Directors and employees of Fiduciary Trust Company International mourn the loss of our friend and colleague George J. Mullen, Jr. George's career at Fiduciary Trust began in 1976 and spanned three and a half decades. His every action inspired generations of Fiduciary Trust employees to listen carefully, speak softly, and act honorably. George operated with an unfailing moral compass. He was a true gentleman of great character and wisdom, and a lover of birds and the environments that nurtured them. We will never forget his extraordinary gift for choosing the perfect bow tie, or his love of simple pleasures like spaghetti and meatballs, a glass of chardonnay, and a good walk. A proud graduate of Harvard and Harvard Business School, George dedicated his life to his family and the service of his community. An avid birder, he served on the board of St. Philip's Academy, was the former president of the New Jersey Audubon, a long time advisor to the New York City Audubon, a founding member of the Bird-Safe Glass Foundation and a Life Trustee of the Manomet Center for Conservation. George had a deep appreciation of the culture of our firm and made sure that the principles of integrity and honesty were instilled in our thoughts and actions. It was an honor to work with him. Our thoughts and prayers are with his wife, Rachel, his daughters, Brooks Mullen and Amy Mullen Luster, and his son, George F. Mullen.

New York theater owners have approached Disney Theatrical Productions about mounting the company's ''Newsies the Musical'' on Broadway this season after the new show received strongly positive reviews this week at the Paper Mill Playhouse in New Jersey, according to people familiar with the discussions. ''Newsies,'' based on a 1992 Disney film that was inspired by the 1899 New York City newsboys' strike, would be an unexpected major entry to a Broadway season that has relatively few original musicals set to open.

An uncompromising Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, facing a union that has refused to agree to wage and benefits concessions and a Legislature that is insisting on redrawing the state's political map, said Friday that he would follow through on threats to lay off several thousand state workers and to veto the lawmakers' redistricting plan. Mr. Cuomo, speaking in an interview on the public-radio program ''The Capitol Pressroom,'' said he had no intention of backing down on either issue, despite the importance of organized labor to his political fortunes and lawmakers to his legislative agenda.

We usually think of the Civil War as a uniquely American event, a war unlike any other fought in the Western world during the 19th century. And of course that's true, strictly speaking: no other country saw itself split in two over slavery. But that's not the only way to think of the war. Put a different way, the Civil War was just one of several wars for national unification - including fighting in Italy and Germany - on both sides of the Atlantic during the mid-19th century.

Is there anything made in America that's less innovative than the single-family home? While we obsess over the new in terms of what we keep in our houses - the ever-increasing speed and functionality of our Smartphones, entertainment options built into refrigerators, sophisticated devices that monitor, analyze and report on our sleep cycles, even the superior technology of the running shoes we put on before heading out the flimsy fiberboard door - we're incredibly undemanding of the houses themselves. These continue to be built the same way they have for over a century, and usually not as well. Walls and windows are thin, materials cheap, design (and I use the term loosely) not well-considered. The building process is a protracted affair, taking far too long and creating embarrassing amounts of building waste (over 50 percent of all waste produced in the United States, in fact).

Rick Perry's recent vocal dismissals of evolution, and his confident assertion that "God is how we got here" reflect an obvious divide in our culture. In one sense, that divide is just over the facts: Some of us believe God created human beings just as they are now, others of us don't. But underneath this divide is a deeper one. Really divisive disagreements are typically not just over the facts. They are also about the best way to support our views of the facts. Call this a disagreement in epistemic principle. Our epistemic principles tell us what is rational to believe, what sources of information to trust. Thus while a few people may agree with Perry because they really think that the scientific evidence supports creationism, I suspect that for most people, scientific evidence (or its lack) has nothing to do with it. Their belief in creationism is instead a reflection of a deeply held epistemic principle: that, at least on some topics, scripture is a more reliable source of information than science.  For others, including myself, this is never the case.

The new show begins with a husband and wife (Dylan McDermott of "The Practice" and Connie Britton of "Friday Night Lights") and their teenage daughter (Taissa Farmiga) moving to Los Angeles to start their lives fresh. But their new Gothic fixer-up was a steal for a reason: it's haunted by a history of murder and visited by creepy neighbors, housekeepers and unwelcome guests (including Jessica Lange, Frances Conroy and Denis O'Hare) as well as a mysterious figure in a full-body S&M costume, whom the "American Horror Story" producers have affectionately dubbed "Rubber Man."

Pete Gent was able to express in words what many players feel about pro football, both good and bad. While his writing left its mark on the game, it's equally clear that the game left its mark on him. Gent died Friday from a pulmonary illness at his home in Bangor, Mich. He was 69. A few thoughts:In the early 1970s, as pro football was becoming the nation's most popular spectator sport, a group of ex-players exposed, through both their words and their actions, the game's seamy underside. A novel by Pete Gent, "North Dallas Forty," based on his five years with the Cowboys, graphically depicted the pain and anguish the public couldn't feel or see on their television screens. Yet, despite the broken bones and sleepless nights, most of the players wished it could go on forever. Many, like Gent himself, remembered their football days as some of the best times of their lives.

''Quirky but serious'' is how the architect George L. Legendre describes ''Pasta by Design'' (Thames & Hudson, $30), his taxonomy of 92 noodles, from the itty-bitty acini de pepe to ziti. Legendre shares his South London office with a fellow architect and inveterate pasta preparer, Marco Guarnieri, who gave him the idea to catalog with mathematical exactitude the difference between, say, fusilli and fusilli Capri. (The latter is longer, but both go great with a ragu.) Home cooks might blanch at the CAD-style schematics and trigonometric equations, but they can nonetheless appreciate that each pasta profile comes with cooking times and serving suggestions. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

MITROVICA, Kosovo -- After years of impasse between the national government of Kosovo and ethnic Serbs demanding autonomy within their northern enclave in the new country, international pressure has intensified on the Serbs. And while the immediate result has been minor clashes, there is new hope for some movement toward a resolution for the last geopolitically unsettled chunk of the former Yugoslavia. Frustrated by European-backed attempts to impose Kosovar police and customs officials in northern Kosovo last month, Serbian protesters set up road blocks -- a common tactic here over the years. When troops from KFOR, the NATO-led international force in Kosovo, moved on Tuesday to tear down the barricades, they said they were met by Serbian protesters who fired on them with small arms and threw rocks and pipe bombs. Sixteen protesters were reported injured, as were nine soldiers.

For decades, coaches and nutritionists advised athletes not to eat carbohydrates an hour before exercising in order to avoid the risk of ''rebound'' low-blood sugar, with its attendant wobbles and fatigue. This concern grew out of 30-year-old studies showing that blood- sugar levels declined if athletes swallowed sugary foods or drinks just before exercising.

ROBY--Vic, 93, formerly of Scarsdale, passed away on September 22, 2011 following a brief illness. Roby was a radio and television announcer for 40 years prior to his retirement in 1983. In 1950 he began his 33-year tenure as a staff announcer at WNBC radio and WNBC-TV. He was the moderator of WNBC-TV's long-running weekly news program, "Direct Line," which pioneered the viewer call-in format. He also hosted several local radio public affairs programs. Vic is survived by his loving wife of 63 years, Josephine (Emerson) Roby, their daughter, Deborah Boyce, and her husband, Joshua A. Boyce, of Sherborn, MA, two grandchildren, Erica Boyce and Joshua R. Boyce, and several nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his brother, Charlton S. Roby, of Jackson, MS. For complete obituary and online guestbook please visit www.everettfuneral.com

Probably not. As NASA discovered in the 1960s, it's impossible to stuff the equivalent of a full meal into a capsule. So Pillsbury technicians working on behalf of the space agency came up with the next best thing: a vitamin-rich, wand-shaped goo that could fit through the mouth hole in the astronauts' helmets. The Space Food Stick, a kind of proto-energy-bar, went up with a Skylab mission and became one of the culinary phenoms of the 1970s. But such innovations proved more popular with 6-year-olds than with astronauts. ''In the Mercury mission, NASA supplied the astronauts with the meal-in-a-cube,'' says Maya Cooper, a senior research scientist with Lockheed Martin and a contractor with NASA. The problem was that ''when the crews returned from space, so did the cubes. They refused to eat them. You can't ignore the psychological aspects of eating.''

In the woods outside Livade (pronounced lee-VAH-deh), a village in the north-central hills of the Istrian Peninsula in Croatia, the fall means truffle hunting. Dogs charge through autumnal leaves and oak branches along barely perceptible paths blazed by generations that came before, leading their owners to prized white delicacies. Such trophies, which some consider better and stronger in both taste and aroma than their more famous cousins from the Piedmont region of Italy, often end up at the markets and restaurants in and around Livade, the country's truffle hub. If one were to compare white truffles, which can cost thousands of dollars per pound, to diamonds, one could call Livade Croatia's Antwerp. Even with a minuscule population of 190 set around a lone roundabout with three restaurants, it's the site of two truffle fairs during the fall. One, Zigante Tartufi Days (sajamtartufa.com), begins in October, during white truffle season. Over six weekends, the festival provides demonstrations on how to hunt for, purchase and cook with the area's fungal tubers.
Television Neil Genzlinger
REIDMAN--Bea, wife of Harold, died peacefully September 17. Interment was at El Camino Memorial Park San Diego, CA. The Powers, Weinstein and Shenker families will miss her. Rest in peace, Mom.

WOMEN love Charles Askegard. Or at the very least, the women of New York City Ballet do. Since joining that company in 1997 he has performed with almost every ballerina in the company's esteemed ranks. But after next Sunday those dancers are going to have to do without their tall, elegant partner, when Mr. Askegard retires from City Ballet at the last matinee of the season, in a program that features some of his favorite roles. He is not, however, leaving dancing. Mr. Askegard, 42, is forming a company, Ballet Next, with Michele Wiles, a former American Ballet Theater ballerina who left that troupe with surprising abruptness in June.

ROSENBERG--Bella Miriam, 93, died September 29th on Rosh Hashana in New York City. Beloved sister of Martha Glaser, the adored mother of Susan, cherished wife of the deceased Dr. Emanuel Rosenberg. Hers was an incredible creative and giving life. Editor, film and theatrical producer, labor organizer, and activist for justice and human rights. She was an extraordinary friend, loyal and passionate, encouraged the search for Truth and Beauty wherever possible. Till the end of her Time she was connected to the betterment of humanity. Services will be held on October 2, at 2:30pm at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. (91st St), New York City.

IT'S a pleasure to see Alessandra Facchinetti back on the runway. You may remember her from her brief moment at Gucci, in 2004, when she succeeded Tom Ford. Then, following Valentino's retirement, she took over the creative direction at that house. It was, let us say, an impossible job, and her first ready-to-wear collections were tentative. At the time I thought: too many hands in this kitchen. But then she delivered a gorgeous haute couture collection for Valentino that I still vividly remember, the kind of witty femininity that could let in some much-needed air. Ms. Facchinetti is now designing for Uniqueness, an online project conceived by Pietro Negra, the chief executive of Pinko, a contemporary fashion label in Italy. Over a Diet Coke at the Bristol hotel in Paris the other day, she explained that Mr. Negra approached her about six months ago. ''I thought it was an interesting challenge to do something that was seasonless and on the Web,'' she said. ''Because it's how most of us live today.''

When you make your own sandwich, you anticipate its taste as you're working on it. And when you think of a particular food for a while, you become less hungry for it later. Researchers at Carnegie Mellon University, for example, found that imagining eating M&Ms makes you eat fewer of them. It's a kind of specific satiation, just as most people find room for dessert when they couldn't have another bite of their steak. The sandwich that another person prepares is not ''preconsumed'' in the same way.

''What is the paradox of Ukraine?'' asked Natalia Zabolotna, the director general of Mystetskyi Arsenal, a national art and culture museum that opened Sept. 9 in Kiev. ''Ukraine gave the world very many geniuses, but they're not listed as Ukrainian due to Ukraine's geopolitical situation. Not many people know that Kazimir Malevich was born in Kiev.'' The Mystetskyi Arsenal, housed in a former weapons arsenal built at Catherine the Great's orders, will go some way toward remedying that situation. When completed - by 2014, at a cost of $250 million - it will have nearly one million square feet of floor space. (A Malevich retrospective is in the works for the 2014 grand opening.) For now it's a work in progress, with temporary exhibitions. The ART-Kyiv contemporary art fair will run there Nov. 2 to 13., and the first international biennale of contemporary art in Ukraine, ARSENALE, is to open on May 17 and runs through July 30. As a tourist attraction the museum is meant to lure visitors to Kiev, Ukraine's capital, in tandem with the Kiev Monastery of the Caves next door, founded in the 11th century.

Brand any fish ''sustainable,'' and you risk making it so popular that it is fished to the point of depletion. A truly sustainable fish has to be not only abundant but also carefully managed to prevent overfishing. That's partly why the lean, delicious, ruby-fleshed sockeye salmon of Bristol Bay, Alaska, is the fish you can eat with the least amount of guilt. It's one of the largest remaining wild salmon populations left, and it's so strictly tended that more salmon often swim upriver

A new California law, the first of its kind in the nation, is requiring new- and used-car dealers to check their used vehicles against a federal government database and mark them with a red warning sticker if they find a serious problem. Governor Jerry Brown signed the bill into law on Monday, at the urging of consumer advocates, law enforcement officials and used-car dealers themselves.

From Oct. 7 to July 2012, the Centre Pompidou-Metz will present ''Bivouac,'' a retrospective dedicated to the work of the designers Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec. ''It's like a big family dinner where everybody shows up,'' says Erwan (above, seated). The family, in this case, is the brothers' radically original work, from ''Lit Clos'' of 2000, a raised, semi-enclosed bed like a bird cage, to ''Ploum,'' a new sofa for Ligne Roset, which they compare to a very ripe fruit. This is the Bouroullecs' first major show in their native France, organized by ambience and demarcated by supersize versions of their room-divider designs, including the plastic seaweed-inspired ''Algues'' and their textile ''Clouds''; one long wall will hold nearly 300 drawings. To coincide with the show, Phaidon is releasing a new monograph of their work. ''We're still young, so a celebration of our career is nice but a little anxiety-inducing,'' said Ronan, the older of the two, who recently turned 40. ''Each time we do an exhibition it feels like: that's done, let's move on to something else.'' That something else will be a permanent lighting installation for the Gabriel staircase in the Chateau de Versailles. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Since Georges Méliès took audiences on a trip to the Moon in 1902, filmmakers have been putting their visions of the future on the big screen. While some have focused on extremely distant time frames, many have tackled eras not too far from their own. The latest to look at the near-future is ''Real Steel'' (opening Friday), which sets its sights on 2020. By then, according to the film, the new sport of robot boxing will have emerged, with machines replacing people in the ring. The director, Shawn Levy, said he was more interested in telling a humanistic story (featuring Hugh Jackman, right, and the young Dakota Goyo) than creating a heavily sci-fi feel. ''We adopted a mantra that Tom Meyer, my production designer, coined, called 'retro forward,' '' Mr. Levy said. ''The movie has a real pastiche of iconic Americana with futuristic technological touches.'' Scenes of rodeos, motels and the open road converge with high-tech machines that can be operated remotely via bodily movement, much like playing an Xbox with Kinect. It's a lighter, less cynical view of what's to come than has been typically portrayed. Here is a survey of some other films set in very different near-futures.

When Caroline Burnett decided to open Heroes, in Berlin's Neukölln district, her initial emphasis was not on food. ''The cafe was a pretext for the art,'' says Burnett, an American editor who curates art shows in a dynamic exhibition space in the back. Today she and her partner, Damien Poinsard, a French-born cook who helps run a theater group on the side, are drawing regulars as much with their down-home fare as with their roster of up-and-coming artists. Crepes and quiches are standards; specials depend on who's cooking. If Poinsard is in the kitchen, the menu might include pot au feu or stewed chicken; when Burnett is in, she says, the special is likely to be meatloaf, reflecting her nostalgia for home.

In centuries past, Africa was known as the ''Dark Continent,'' which originated less as a slur than as a testament to the deficiency of mapmakers: clueless about the continent's interior, they would often just blot it out, as if the place didn't fully exist. Opacity still marks the popular conception of Africa, especially when it comes to its cities, which take a back seat to safari-ready grasslands and oceans of desert. To change this, the celebrated London architect David Adjaye began a decade-long quest to photograph Africa's urban spaces - practically all of them, save the war-torn Somali capital, Mogadishu. ''The project is really fueled by the widespread misconception of Africa as an impoverished or unpeopled expanse,'' said Adjaye, who was born to Ghanaian parents in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. ''I was born in a metropolitan city; I was born in a cosmopolitan condition among different groups of Africans, Indians and Chinese.'' The seven slender volumes that make up ''African Metropolitan Architecture'' (Rizzoli, $100) were winnowed from about 35,000 photos, which are bluntly documentary in style. Adjaye calls them ''anti-iconic.'' ''I didn't want to fall into the trap of making beautiful urban pictures,'' said Adjaye, who is now at work on the Smithsonian's National Museum of African American History and Culture, scheduled to open in 2015. ''I wanted to say, 'You know what, if you stick your camera out the window, this is what you're going to get.' '' The buildings surprise in terms of their sophistication, their beauty and also their weirdness, as in the case of a spiny shelled dome in Khartoum, Sudan, that looks as if it's about to sprout legs.

Singing color and patterns left their mark on the recent New York fashion collections and on the city. They were vividly reflected on many of the guests who attended the shows (some are pictured here). At the Union Square Greenmarket, the colors of autumn were in abundance, including in exotic mushrooms that resemble coral, left. At Ralph Lauren's show, right, a 15-foot-high arrangement of pastel flowers echoed the colors of the clothes. At Union Square there were lilies mixed on the same palette, while on Seventh Avenue deliverers carted the colors. A group of models were gathered on the sidewalk in the same peppermint colors, top center. Colors ranged from the most subtle to vivid fluorescents and striking florals.

Slavic food has its charms. Who can resist a bowl of soothing borscht on a winter night? But when Moscow menus get monotonous, head to the Dorogomilovsky Market. Many vendors are from former Soviet republics like Uzbekistan, Azerbaijan and Georgia, all of which have sunnier climates -- and zestier fare.

Ever since Paleolithic Picassos painted bison and aurochs on cave walls at Chauvet and Lascaux, artists have fetishized food. It is, in a sense, art's original obsession, ultimately inspiring Chardin's rabbits, Cotan's melons, Cézanne's apples -- a nearly endless menu of Western landmarks, all symbol-laden and sublime, food being a ready-made metaphor for life and death; for abundance, sexual and caloric; and for sheer, ecstatic virtuosity. Are there any more virtuosic pictures than Goya's fish or Manet's asparagus? The pleasure that Goya, Manet and their ilk clearly took in the ability to conjure a freshly killed hare or the insides of a bursting pomegranate or the oily flesh of dead sardines with a few delicious dollops of juicy pigment is as palpable and as sensual as a ripe peach. Wayne Thiebaud, a master technician and zenlike observer, exalts in the same seductive skill. His Boston cream pies, chocolate layer cakes, hot dogs and gum-ball machines are icons of midcentury Americana, dry-witted like Thiebaud but serious, too. They convey the melancholy joy of bygone loves. Rimmed in blue halos, their crisp shadows cast in the glow of an improbably sharp, California sort of light, they strike a disarming note. They're stolid, silent objects, more polished than edible, registering in our minds somewhere between the tart lemon meringues and the strawberry rhubarbs we dreamed about eating and those dried-out cakes and cloying pies we actually ate. After an initial surge of pleasure, this gap between desire and reality occasions the aforementioned sadness. But the pictures also produce other associations, the longer we stare at them. Those laconic pies are lined up like headstones in Death Valley or like gunslingers at the O.K. Corral, grave and expectant and almost mythic. And like the greatest movie westerns, they end up being more than just pleasurable or nostalgic -- or merely American.
HERBST--Stewart. Our "Full House" will miss you. Our hearts are heavy. The Thursday Poker Gang

SCHWARTZ--Sy, 88, died at home on September 30, surrounded by family. Born in 1923, he was a World War II veteran, visionary real estate developer, environmental champion, and, later, founder of the Common Sense Fund (www.commonsensefund.org). Married for 48 years to his sweetheart Sybil Davidson; then the loving companion for 15 years to the remarkable Judith Greene. He leaves three devoted children and their spouses, and nine grandchildren. Sy had an independent and creative mind; he could make you rethink your position on settled questions. He was a lover of Bach, a walker, and an advocate for the common man. He understood that he was a fortunate man. A memorial service will be held on October 9 at a location to be determined. Contact joyce@pilotregroup.com for information. Donations in Sy's memory can be made to thehighline.org

There's not nearly as much reason to fear sugar substitutes as there is to fear actual sugar and high-fructose corn syrup. The assumption that these noncaloric or low-cal sweeteners are likely tobe cancer-causing agents, and that sugar and high- fructose corn syrup are not, is as much a sugar- industry invention as anything else.The two oldest and most undeservedly infamous sugar substitutes -- saccharin and cyclamate -- were first used widely in the United States in the early 1960s, when diet soft drinks came into vogue. The sugar industry responded by financing research into potential health risks of the two sweeteners -- spending half a million dollars on cyclamate alone, which was a lot of money at the time. ''If anyone can undersell you 9 cents out of 10,'' one sugar-industry executive explained to The Times in 1969, ''you'd better find some brickbat you can throw at him.'' The brickbat was the notion that cyclamate could cause bladder cancer in rats. Or at least it could when they were consuming the equivalent of several hundred soda cans each day. Regardless, the Food and Drug Administration promptly banned its use. In the early 1970s, when a few studies suggested that saccharin could do the same -- if consumed at the rate of 800 soda cans daily -- the F.D.A. moved to ban that as well before settling for a warning label that would stay on packets of Sweet'N Low for the next quarter century. (Congress passed a bill to remove it in 2000.) To further confuse matters, the Canadians banned saccharin but left cyclamate unregulated,so Sweet'N Low in the United States is made from saccharin and in Canada from cyclamate.

TEICH--Loretta. Daughter of Ida and Julius Kleinberg, passed away in Aventura, FL, after a very brief illness on August 12, 2011, at the age of 94, surrounded by her three children whom she adored: Malvin, Marlene, and Robert. She is also survived by two grandchildren, Jason and Nick. Her beloved husband Sidney passed away in 2000. Born in Manhattan, Loretta formed an employment agency in the early 1970's, and discovered that her applicants lacked crucial skills for job placement. This led her to focus her company on training and, in 1980, she became CEO of the Allen School in New York. This institution currently has more than 60,000 graduates and students throughout the country. The Sidney and Loretta Teich Foundation, formed in 2005, has awarded scholarships to more than 200 needy nursing students. Loretta served as a volunteer in numerous venues. She also revisited, in her late 80's and 90's, her early interests of tap dancing and theater. Indeed, in the last few years, she danced and acted in a number of plays with a local group, including "Plaza Suite" and "Same Time Next Year." Loretta Teich was admired for her kindness and wisdom by all who had the good fortune to come in contact with her. She touched and transformed many lives. She will be dearly missed.

MULLEN--George J.,Jr. The Board of Directors and employees of Fiduciary Trust Company International mourn the loss of our friend and colleague George J. Mullen, Jr. George's career at Fiduciary Trust began in 1976 and spanned three and a half decades. His every action inspired generations of Fiduciary Trust employees to listen carefully, speak softly, and act honorably. George operated with an unfailing moral compass. He was a true gentleman of great character and wisdom, and a lover of birds and the environments that nurtured them. We will never forget his extraordinary gift for choosing the perfect bow tie, or his love of simple pleasures like spaghetti and meatballs, a glass of chardonnay, and a good walk. A proud graduate of Harvard and Harvard Business School, George dedicated his life to his family and the service of his community. An avid birder, he served on the board of St. Philip's Academy, was the former president of the New Jersey Audubon, a long time advisor to the New York City Audubon, a founding member of the Bird-Safe Glass Foundation and a Life Trustee of the Manomet Center for Conservation. George had a deep appreciation of the culture of our firm and made sure that the principles of integrity and honesty were instilled in our thoughts and actions. It was an honor to work with him. Our thoughts and prayers are with his wife, Rachel, his daughters, Brooks Mullen and Amy Mullen Luster, and his son, George F. Mullen.

Says,'' Sept. 25: Some coaches worry ''that officiating is too uneven to guarantee that the rules are enforced properly and equitably.'' For hundreds of years, saffron, the world's most expensive spice, was cultivated in the south of France, alongside lavender and grapevines. But in the 19th century, a combination of bad frosts and war led to the crop's disappearance. In 2003, François Pillet, now 61, and his wife, Marie, 55 -- he's an architect, she's a decorator -- moved from Paris to the Vaucluse region of Provence, where they opened L'Aube Safran, a five-room saffron-themed bed-and-breakfast near the tiny town of Le Barroux.

THE artist Karen Kilimnik tends to work on small, intimate canvases taking on subjects like Kate Moss or the battles of Napoleon with fairy tale innocence. For ''Psyché,'' a new production choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky for the Paris Opera Ballet, Ms. Kilimnik started from a selection of existing paintings to create five large dreamlike backdrops, including an enchanting moonlit forest and a garden resplendent with clouds, flowers and perfume bottles. She then augmented these with rhinestones, glitter and, for good measure, a host of objects like the five-foot snail that enters and exits the stage at various points during the performance. Being able to work on this scale was a dream in itself. ''It was wonderful,'' she said. ALIX BROWNE

ELLER--Alan V.,passed away August 31, 2011, Hendersonville, in the North Carolina mountains he so loved. The family he adored - his wife, Caryl, granddaughter, Emily Rivas and sister-in-law, Sue Ellen Smyle, overwhelmed by sadness, cherish the memories. Alan and Caryl lost their beloved daughter, Erika Kaufman, in 1982. Alan was an extraordinary man, too well loved to ever be forgotten. It was a joy to have shared our lives with him for so many years. However, it now feels nowhere near long enough. Alan's wonderful friends and extended family in Florida, New York, North Carolina, California, Australia, England and St. Thomas will gather together to honor his life in a memorial service, mid-December, Boca Raton, FL.

It is the central tax office of the Pireaus district in Athens -- not the central tax office of Athens.

With its shimmering vision of a fairy-tale realm where grace and good manners prevail, Oliver Messel's production of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' for Sadler's Wells (later the Royal) Ballet, in 1946, raised the curtain on London's postwar recovery and held a mirror to England's sense of pride. When the ballet was performed at the Metropolitan Opera House in New York three years later, applause greeted the scenery - a magnificent palace extending into the wings and beyond, set in a stately park among ancient trees. ''The Sleeping Beauty'' was such a success that Messel never lived it down. For decades, it has been the basis of his reputation, and so irresistible and magical is its spell that, had he done nothing else, it would have been enough. But he did much more. ''Oliver Messel: In the Theatre of Design'' (Rizzoli, $75), edited by Thomas Messel, his nephew, rounds out his reputation with an accounting of his works for the stage (Mozart operas at Glyndebourne, ''House of Flowers'' on Broadway) and film (''The Thief of Baghdad,'' ''Suddenly, Last Summer''), his architecture (houses on Barbados and Mustique) and interiors (a suite and private dining rooms at the Dorchester Hotel).

TRUPPIN--Ada, MD, died peacefully at home, at age 86, on September 27, surrounded by her loving children, grandchildren and caregivers. Born in Cape Town in 1925, she graduated first in her class at University of Cape Town Medical School in 1952. She married Michael Truppin, MD, and they moved to New York in 1953, and trained at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Dr. Truppin practiced pediatrics for many years, then became a psychiatrist, practicing until 2003. A true intellectual and lover of the arts, she was passionate about ideas and deeply interested in people. She leaves behind her daughters, Nicola and Andrea, her grandchildren, Miriam, Benjamin and Milo, her son-in-law, Jeffrey, and her longtime housekeeper, Gilda. Funeral: Sunday October 2, 11am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel 630 Amsterdam at 91St. Burial: Sharon Gardens, 273 Lakeview Ave. Valhalla, NY. Shiva at her residence, Sunday 4-9pm; Monday and Tuesday 12-3pm and 6-9pm. Donations in Dr. Truppin's memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Assn, www.alz.org.

In ''The Scrapbook of Frankie Pratt'' (Ecco, $26), Caroline Preston, a former archivist, pastes vintage postcards, Jazz Age ephemera and typewritten snippets into a sweetly beguiling novel about a New England girl who trades Vassar College for Greenwich Village on the advice of Edna St. Vincent Millay. David Rothenberg argues in ''Survival of the Beautiful'' (Bloomsbury Press, $30) that art has its origins millions of years before the cave paintings at Lascaux. He opens with an anecdote about the male satin bowerbird, which builds unique stick artworks and decorates them in blue -- blue flowers, blue shells, sometimes blue pigment ground up from fruit pulp -- to attract females. ''Beauty Is in the Street'' (Four Corners Books, $40) is a visual history of the 1968 Paris uprisings, which yielded not just fundamental changes in French society but a surprisingly consistent protest iconography of stenciled placards and hand-painted affiches.

Is there anything more intrinsic to a place than its food? Yes, we can order up slices of Italian prosciutto in Chicago and buy French butter in Brooklyn, but in Parma or Paris those foods take on a special significance. For travelers, food conveys the essence of a place. With that in mind, we asked correspondents with decades of culinary experience across Europe among them to share a few of the foods that are worth traveling for.

Sunday at 8:20 p.m. Eastern, NBC MATCHUP TO WATCH: Antonio Cromartie-- vs. Torrey Smith Going by his season trends, Cromartie is due for a good game Sunday, and he will need one to counter Smith, a speedy rookie whose first three N.F.L. catches went for touchdowns last week against St. Louis. With Darrelle Revis most likely to be assigned to Anquan Boldin, Ravens quarterback Joe Flacco is bound to test Cromartie, who is recovering from bruised ribs, lungs and pride. MEHLMAN--Justine Selma, died of breast cancer September 17, 2011 at home in Washington, D.C., at age 85. At her bedside were husband of 59 years, Sam, and her daughters Felice, Louise and Melissa. She was born in Brooklyn, NY to Irving and Anna Pearlstein. She spent her summers at Camp Boiberik where she excelled at sports and dance and made many lifelong friends. Justine received a BA from NYU. She was especially talented in modern dance and classical piano She performed with Benjamin Zemach and with the Martha Graham Dance Company but turned to the piano, studying with Angela Weschler in New York City and Edith Vogel in London. She taught piano in her Jericho studio in the '50s and '60s and some of her pupils made successful music careers. In September 1967, the family moved to London and in 1977 to Brussels, where she had her first bout with cancer (ovarian). Sam's three years became fourteen and the family returned to the U.S. in 1980. Justine opened her own shop - Justine Mehlman Antiques - in Georgetown, selling 18th to 20th century period jewelry and decorative art. The business flourished with the beauty, quality, condition, and genuineness of the items for sale. She was invited to speak at the Smithsonian, directed at the antique collector. Poor health lead to Justine's reluctant retirement in early 2009. She will be remembered, loved and missed. A later memorial will follow.
The good, the bad and the memorable achievements of the 2011 regular season. ELENA GUSTINES

In September and October, the produce stalls in Mercat de Santa Caterina, a thriving marketplace in Barcelona's La Ribera district, display heaps of rovellons, local autumnal mushrooms. Called saffron milk cap or pine mushroom in English, they are a rare seasonal delicacy synonymous with the arrival of fall and collected in the nearby forests of Catalonia. Depending on the soil in which they grew, their flavor can be subtly bitter, sour or even sweet.

Each April, during the Milan Furniture Fair, the German lighting designer Ingo Maurer presents an exhibition of new work. These shows, which highlight Maurer's innovative, provocative and poetic pieces (and those of designers whose ideas he finds interesting), never fail to impress. But this year, Maurer - who designs everything from table lights to subway stations, and who was recently awarded the prestigious Compasso d'Oro for career achievement - outdid himself with a design that was, in a word, enchanting. A 12-foot-high hanging mass of emerald-green sponges seemed to glow from within (thanks to hidden L.E.D.'s), and teemed with life in the form of about 100 exquisite, hand-painted models of butterflies, dragonflies, lizards and other creatures. This wasn't, strictly speaking, a light fixture - not that it mattered to besotted observers. But what exactly was it? As Maurer explained, it's a hybrid lighting and acoustical device that was commissioned by a couple in Munich, where Maurer lives and works. Their apartment, in a 19th-century building, includes an octagonal room that was created as a private chapel and is now a dining room. (The French decorator Jacques Grange designed the interiors in collaboration with Maurer.) Maurer wanted something that would both illuminate and soften the sound in the small but tall domed space (16 feet wide, 25 feet high) - and the finished product, the Biotope, is shown here.

REICHERT--Helen Faith Keane, peacefully at home on September 25, 2011 at the age of 109. A native New Yorker, born November 11, 1901, and known as "Happy," she was a proud member of the first Girl Scouts Troop who sold WWI war bonds outside the NY Public Library. Graduate of Cornell University BA '25, and Columbia University MA '31, Happy began her career as a copywriter and educator. In 1949, she founded as a voice for women, The Round Table of Fashion Executives, and in 1951, hosted TV talk show, "FYI: The Helen Faith Keane Show," on Channel 5, winning McCall's Magazine Golden Microphone Award for outstanding broadcasting service to women. She joined The Graduate School of Retailing at NYU in 1947 to teach, "Costume History," a course she created. Former students, calling her Professor Keane, became lifelong friends. Women, whose business lives she impacted, continually called for her creative input. Happy was predeceased by her husband, Philip Reichert M.D., founding member in 1949 of The American College of Cardiology, and her sister, Lee. She is survived by brothers, Irving and Peter, sister-in-law Beth, many nieces and nephews, and devoted caregiver, Olive Villaluna. In lieu of flowers, Happy, as an advocate of education, can be honored by donations to Cornell Medical College. An avid piano player, world traveler, theatergoer, scholar of history, and fan of Central Park since her childhood, Happy lived a remarkable multi-talented life. Happy are we to have called her our friend, and to have shared her laughter and her love.

Addictive as a drug? We crave certain foods so much that they seem addictive. Just thinking about cinnamon buns or pizza stimulates the release of the neural chemical dopamine, which can cause the brain to override the biological brakes that try to prevent overeating. According to ''Why Humans Like Junk Food,'' by a former Nestlé scientist named Steven A. Witherly, the brain especially loves mixtures of salt, sugar and fat and the emulsive textures of butter, mayonnaise and chocolate. Witherly has developed what he calls the food-pleasure equation, in which Pleasure = Sensation + Calories. When we eat a combination of sugar, fat and salt, he says, we get a huge synergistic bang, first in the parts of the brain that register pleasure and then in the gut, which detects and responds more favorably to the high calories in sugar and fat. It's caveman stuff, going back to when we learned to eat big-calorie foods to survive.

FILER--Herbert, Jr.,(Buddy), age 83, died September 23, 2011 in Boynton Beach, FL. He was from Great Neck, NY originally; a Korean veteran, son of Sarah and Herbert Filer. He worked on Wall Street as a partner at Filer, Schmidt & Co.; he worked as a volunteer at Bethesda Memorial Hospital for 26 years. He was an avid gardener. He was the brother of Carol Bergman and Janet Silberstein-Uncle to Jessica Sivin; Barbara Bergman; and Nancy Smith' Judy Rosemarin and Jo Ellen Silbertstein and Mark Silberstein. He leaves his wife, Eileen Filer and two children; Debbie and Kenny.

WALLACE--George A. P.,A professional engineer who dedicated much of his professional career to promoting the adoption of energy-saving technologies in home and industrial heating and cooling, died on September 25, 2011 in Lakeville, CT at age 85. He was a long-time resident of New York City and Northwest Corner, CT. Mr. Wallace came from a long line of Scottish explorers, soldiers, industrialists, and engineers. Born in Chester, PA in 1926, Mr. Wallace chose to pursue his education as a chemical engineer, graduating from Cornell University with a Bachelor's degree in Chemical Engineering and a Masters of Engineering certificate in 1947. With his strong engineering background, Mr. Wallace became a licensed Professional Engineer with the State of New York, a life member of the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating, and Air-conditioning Engineers and member of the New York Academy of Sciences. After a brief career in the chemical industry, Mr. Wallace, Samuel Eannace, and a group of associates formed Wallace Eannace Associates, Inc., a new type of sales engineering firm in the New York-New Jersey region. Specializing in pumping and heat transfer equipment, the company combines technical service and education with product distribution. His goals were to promote awareness of the need and feasibility of improving the efficiency of HVAC systems, a goal that was significantly stimulated during the 1970's when the US was suffering under the Arab oil embargo and was being forced to recognize the urgency of reducing its dependence on Mideast oil. Under this pressure and supported by government, HVAC engineers began to develop and install energy-conserving systems to replace older fuel-wasting types. One of Mr. Wallace's major disappointments was witnessing support for these innovations fade as cheap foreign oil once again became available. However, in Europe, a partnership of governments and industry was pushing greater efficiency in all energy use. Mr. Wallace studied these systems and helped to stimulate some adoption in the US. Coincidentally, nuclear energy was being promoted as the solution to fossil fuel dependency. Mr. Wallace was a member and backer of the Union of Concerned Scientists virtually from its inception and strongly supported their efforts to monitor the hazards of the expansion of the nuclear industry and its adaptation to military usage. Mr. Wallace long felt that commercial interests too often trump sound science in setting directions for bringing technological developments into use by society. He remained actively engaged in these issues and in his business interests virtually to the end of his life. In addition to his commitment to the Union of Concerned Scientists, Mr. Wallace was a dedicated supporter of many national and local environmental organizations, including Salisbury Land Trust, Sharon Audubon, Appalachian Mountain Club, American Bird Conservancy, and Sierra Club. Mr. Wallace served in the United States Navy as an Aviation Radio Technician during World War II and received an honorable discharge in 1946. He is fondly remembered by his family and friends as a sensitive man with a keen sense of the importance of personal relationships in private and professional life. Mr. Wallace was an extremely thoughtful and intellectual man who placed a high premium on dialogue, the objective exchange of ideas, and on scientific education and understanding in society. He was an avid reader and life-long student of world history. Mr. Wallace is survived by his wife of 54 years, Joan, a son, George E. Wallace of Warrenton, VA, two daughters, E. Ainslie Wallace of Salisbury, CT and Elaine Connolly of Scarborough, ME, and eight grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a donation to the Union of Concerned Scientists either via their website at www.ucsusa.org or by mail to Union of Concerned Scientists, Attn: John Mace, 2 Brattle Square, Cambridge, MA 02138.

I am wondering if there are any reputable tour operators that organize small tours for active people who want to experience the real people and culture of Europe at moderate prices.

A condominium at 988 Fifth Avenue that closed for $20 million was the highest sale of the week, according to Streeteasy.com. Deborah Kern, a broker with the Corcoran Group who handled the deal for the sellers, confirmed the sale price, which has not yet been recorded in city property records. A three-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath apartment, it had been listed a year ago for $22 million. It was taken off the market in December and relisted for $20 million in May, going into contract in August, according to Streeteasy. Ms. Kern would not identify the sellers or the buyers.

But how a wine affects you may also be a matter of stamina, body type and habit.If you want to be certain that you will be in fine form after lunch, or if you want more than a single glass, and assumingyou won't be operating heavy machinery, try theriesling from the Mosel Valley in Germany. To be more precise, the Mosel rieslings classifiedas kabinett or spätlese.

DAVIS--Ruth (nee Pauker). Ruth Pauker Davis died peacefully on October 1, 2011 in Santa Fe, NM, where she resided for the past year. A New Yorker through and through, Ruth was born and raised in Manhattan and educated at Ethical Culture, Fieldston and NYU. Long-time resident of Kingston, NY. She will be missed by those who survive her: daughters Nancy Snell (New York), Jane Davis (Santa Fe, NM) and Karen Davis (Los Angeles), mother-in-law to Stephen Snell and Nick Athanassiadis, loving grandmother to Elizabeth Snell and Michael Athanassiadis. Funeral service on Monday at Riverside Memorial Chapel. May she find eternal peace.

If the overnight flight from New York to Paris is rarely relaxing -- too short for a full night's sleep, too long for just a meal and a movie -- I take some comfort knowing that soon after we land I will have bread and butter. And not just any bread and butter. I first stop at Du Pain et des Idées (dupainetdesidees.com), a bakery in the now fashionable 10th Arrondissement, and pick up a hunk of pain des amis, a crusty, peasant-style bread with a slightly sour tang. It's left to rise overnight and baked in wide, billowing loaves the thickness of a winter-weight duvet. Then I head to Breizh Café (breizhcafe.com), a crêperie in the Third Arrondissement, and buy a 125-gram block of demi-sel butter from Bordier, a crèmerie in Brittany that makes Michelin-starred chefs swoon.

BEHRENDT--Rees A.,85, of Fort Lauderdale, FL passed away on September 26, 2011. He was a graduate of Colorado University at the age of 19, moved to San Francisco and appeared with a Theater Group. He then moved to New York and began writing Radio Segments, one being for those of an age: "Grand Central Station". His most rewarding career experience was writing for Esquire Magazine. Rees retired as a Vice President from N.W. Ayer. Later in life, with the birth of the Internet, he found great pleasure in designing Greeting Cards. Friends found great joy in his humor. He is survived by his beloved partner of 48 years, Charles "Chuck" Woodhull. He is also survived by his sister, June (Earl) Padgett, niece Susan (Mike) Sadler, nephew Sherman (Mia) Padgett, and six grand nieces and nephews. Kraeer-Fairchild Funeral Home and Cremation Center, Ft. Lauderdale. www.kraeerfairchild.com.

GLASER--Stanley Morton, of New York, passed away on Tuesday, September 27 at the age of 85. Beloved husband of 60 years to Mildred. Wonderful father of Ilene (Paul) and Alyse (Harvey). Super proud grandfather of Brett (Allison), Chad, Matthew and Joshua. Devoted brother of Lois. You will be deeply missed and in our hearts forever. Your loving family

Drut's blue-chip gallery, on East 10th Street in Manhattan, features Art Deco, midcentury and contemporary furnishings in a former 1970s-era beauty parlor that is strikingly industrial and surprisingly intimate. Go to maisongerard.com. 1. The partners have a penchant for contemporary ceramic and porcelain pieces. This monumental urn by the Danish ceramicist Per Weiss was inspired by Greek amphorae, ''with a little Keith Haring thrown in,'' says Widdershoven (above right). It's $22,000.

No stranger to brand building (he was a co-founder of Wallpaper magazine and Winkreative), the London-based entrepreneur crystallized the concept for his fledgling furniture company, Another Country, while searching for some simple bedside tables and stools for his country house. ''I realized there was a dearth of well-made, well-priced design with a modern craft heritage,'' he says. His solution? An affordable line of pared-down pieces that are handmade in England from sustainable woods. ''We're going for timeless over trendy.'' Go to anothercountry.com.

HOBBS--Gwendolyn Heller, 92, on September 3, 2011, Orleans, MA. Spent growing-up years in Bayside; graduated Manhasset High School, '37, inductee of Silver "M" Society there; then Stoneleigh College. Lover of life, the arts, and ever glamorous, she treasured a life lived close to the sea. Wife of the late Malcolm Hobbs. Denmark's national spirit is a wily shape-shifter. It travels under a number of aliases -- snaps to many, aquavit (''water of life'') to the poetic, braendevin (''burning wine'') to the not-yet-convinced -- and comes in many guises. Made from distilled potatoes or grain, the potent stuff (around 40 percent alcohol, generally) can be infused with herbs, seeds and berries, either solo or in myriad combinations, resulting in nearly endless flavors. Aniseed, dill and caraway are classics. Chile amber and saffron are not unheard of. Producers range from huge venerable brands like Aalborg Akvavit (aalborgakvavit.dk) to young boutique operations like Braunstein (braunstein.dk). The best place to sample the stuff is at one of the traditional bars and restaurants that make their own blends.

You have to trick them. Or, put another way, you have to engage them in the idea that fruit is not just something that takes upa quarter of the food plate (formerly known as the food pyramid), right there next to the vegetables. And the way to do that is by dressing fruit up in dessert's clothing.

Mealtimes matter, especially for weight control. In a recent study, researchers at Northwestern University allowed two groups of mice to eat as much high- fat food as they wanted. One group ate during its active hours, the other only during its normal sleeping period, but both groups consumed about the same number of calories. The study found that the mice who ate during their inactive time ballooned, adding 48 percent to their body weight. The animals that ate during active hours added only 20 percent, even on the high-fat diet. Eating breakfast is crucial: skipping the meal affects hormones related to appetite. Those who don't eat soon after rising typically consume more calories over the course of the day and run a higher risk of Type 2 diabetes and obesity. It's also important to stay on the three-meal- a-day schedule. Recent research conducted by Purdue University refutes well-publicized studies suggesting that eating numerous snacklike meals throughout the day might induce weight loss. In one Purdue study, overweight men ate either three meals of 750 calories or six meals of about 375 calories for 12 weeks. The latter group complained of feeling less satisfied after the smaller repasts. Purdue researchers concluded that eating ''beyond the typical three- meals-a-day pattern does not lead to better appetite control in overweightand obese individuals.''

How Can You Tell if Food Is Genetically Engineered? You can't, unless you're willing to move to Europe or Japan, where the government requires that it be labeled. Ours doesn't, so there's no way to tell. This is despite the fact that 80 to 90 percent of Americans tell pollsters they want it labeled, and Barack Obama, as a candidate, once promised to make it happen. But the industry is afraid you won't buy genetically modified foods if they're labeled -- and they're probably right. Why would you? So far at least, genetically modified food offers the consumer no tangible benefit. In America, the only way to be certain you're not buying genetically engineered food is to buy organic; the U.S.D.A. rules for organic prohibit it.

A review on Sept. 25 about ''Irma Voth,'' a novel by Miriam Toews, misstated part of the title of one of her earlier novels. It is ''A Complicated Kindness,'' not ''An Uncommon Kindness.''

I thought I knew Black Forest ham. Then I tasted the real thing at Metzgerei & Wursterei Peter Dirr (metzgerei-dirr.de), a tiny family butchery business in the heart of the German region that dates to 1897. The tender, subtly smoked ham made everything else I had tried taste like bubble gum in comparison. Apparently, what I was tasting was history. ''We still make it like they did 100 years ago,'' said Markus Dirr, son of Peter, an internationally trained chef who returned home to make his mark on the family business about 15 years ago.

In a tense showdown above the East River, the police arrested more than 700 demonstrators from the Occupy Wall Street protests who took to the roadway as they tried to cross the Brooklyn Bridge on Saturday afternoon. The police said it was the marchers' choice that led to the enforcement action.

A historical photograph on Sept. 25, with an opinion essay about the absence of a vibrant left-wing movement in the United States, was published in mirror image. The picture, of a Communist rally in Union Square in Manhattan on May 1, 1934, was taken by The Associated Press. The park pavilion should have been on the right, and the row of buildings should have been on the left. In the distance is the former Tammany Hall building, on East 17th Street near the northeast corner of Union Square Park. The photograph also appeared in mirror image in The Times on May 2, 1934. After a writer for The Times pointed out the recent error, editors retrieved the photograph, which was distributed by The A.P., from The Times's archives; it also was printed in mirror image. An editor at The A.P. checked its copy of the original photograph and found that it too was printed in mirror image. It is not known why the original prints were made in mirror image. But one possibility is that editors at The A.P. did so in order to make several signs, carried by members of the crowd in the foreground, legible to readers. (The letters evidently bled through the signs, which appear to have been made of cloth, and would have appeared backward if the image had been printed without alteration.) At the time, retouching and altering images for clarity's sake were not uncommon practices; The A.P. and The Times no longer permit such changes to photographic images.
